629 <path d="M0 0h24v24H0z" fill="none"/>

630

631 <path d="M19 8H5c-1.66 0-3 1.34-3 3v6h4v4h12v-4h4v-6c0-1.66-1.34-3-3-3zm-3 11H8v-5h8v5zm3-7c-.55 0-1-.45-1-1s.45-1 1-1 1 .45 1 1-.45 1-1 1zm-1-9H6v4h12V3z"/>

641 <a class="usa-button usa-button--unstyled" href="mailto:?subject=Information from the National Cancer Institute Web Site &body=I found this information on www.cancer.gov and I'd like to share it with you: https://www.cancer.gov/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq %0D%0A%0D%0A NCI's Web site, www.cancer.gov, provides accurate, up-to-date, comprehensive cancer information from the U.S. government's principal agency for cancer research. If you have questions or need additional information, we invite you to contact NCI's LiveHelp instant messaging service at https://livehelp.cancer.gov, or call the NCI's Contact Center 1-800-4-CANCER (1-800-422-6237) (toll-free from the United States).">

642

821 <h1>

822Breast Cancer Treatment (PDQ®)–Health Professional Version</h1>

823

824 <div id="cgvBody">

825

826 <div class="summary-sections">

827

828 <nav class="on-this-page" role="navigation">

829

830 <h6>

831On This Page</h6>

832

833 <ul>

834

837General Information About Breast Cancer</a>

838</li>

853</li>

894 <section id="_1">

895

896 <h2>

897General Information About Breast Cancer</h2>

898

899 <div id="_section_1" class="pdq-sections">

900<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

901<h6>

902In This Section</h6>

903<ul>

904<li>

905<a href="#_551_toc">

906Incidence and Mortality</a>

907</li>

908<li>

909<a href="#_952_toc">

910Anatomy</a>

911</li>

912<li>

913<a href="#_627_toc">

914Risk Factors</a>

915</li>

916<li>

917<a href="#_1749_toc">

918Protective Factors</a>

919</li>

920<li>

921<a href="#_631_toc">

922Screening</a>

923</li>

924<li>

925<a href="#_6_toc">

926Diagnosis<ul>

927<li>

928<a href="#_935_toc">

929Patient evaluation</a>

930</li>

931<li>

932<a href="#_1071_toc">

933Contralateral disease</a>

934</li>

935</ul>

936</a>

937</li>

938<li>

939<a href="#_1678_toc">

940Prognostic and Predictive Factors</a>

941</li>

942<li>

943<a href="#_1069_toc">

944Posttherapy Considerations<ul>

945<li>

946<a href="#_10_toc">

947Hormone replacement therapy</a>

948</li>

949</ul>

950</a>

951</li>

952</ul>

953</nav>

954<div class="pdq-hp-patient-toggle">

955<a href="/types/breast/patient/breast-treatment-pdq">

956Go to Patient Version</a>

957</div>

958<section id="_551">

959<h3 id="_551_toc">

960Incidence and Mortality</h3>

961<p id="_353" tabindex="-1">

962Estimated new cases and deaths from breast cancer (women only) in the United States in 2023:[<a href="#cit/section_1.1">

9631</a>

964]</p>

965<div class="pdq-content-list">

966<ul id="_354">

967<li>

968New cases: 297,790.</li>

969<li>

970Deaths: 43,170.</li>

971</ul>

972</div>

973<p id="_978" tabindex="-1">

974Breast cancer is the most common noncutaneous cancer in U.S. women, with an estimated 55,720 cases of female breast ductal carcinoma <em>

975in situ</em>

976 (DCIS) and 297,790 cases of invasive disease in 2023.[<a href="#cit/section_1.1">

9771</a>

978] About 43,170 women diagnosed with breast cancer&#8212;fewer than one in six&#8212;will die of the disease. By comparison, about 59,910 American women will die of lung cancer in 2023.[<a href="#cit/section_1.1">

9791</a>

980] Men account for 1% of breast cancer cases and breast cancer deaths. For more information, see the <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-screening-pdq#_123">

981Special Populations</a>

982 section in Breast Cancer Screening.</p>

983<p id="_1089" tabindex="-1">

984Widespread adoption of screening increases breast cancer incidence in a given population and changes the characteristics of cancers detected, with increased incidence of lower-risk cancers, premalignant lesions, and DCIS. For more information, see the <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-screening-pdq#_66">

985Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS)</a>

986 section in Breast Cancer Screening. Population studies from the United States [<a href="#cit/section_1.2">

9872</a>

988] and the United Kingdom [<a href="#cit/section_1.3">

9893</a>

990] demonstrate an increase in DCIS and invasive breast cancer incidence since the 1970s, attributable to the widespread adoption of both postmenopausal hormone therapy and screening mammography. In the last decade, women have refrained from using postmenopausal hormones, and breast cancer incidence has declined, but not to the levels seen before the widespread use of screening mammography.[<a href="#cit/section_1.4">

9914</a>

992]</p>

993</section>

994<section id="_952">

995<h3 id="_952_toc">

996Anatomy</h3>

997<p id="_1113" tabindex="-1">

998<figure id="figure_968" class="image-center-medium">

999<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/415520.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

1000Enlarge</a>

1001<img id="_968" alt="Drawing of female breast anatomy showing the lymph nodes, nipple, areola, chest wall, ribs, muscle, fatty tissue, lobe, ducts, and lobules." title="Drawing of female breast anatomy showing the lymph nodes, nipple, areola, chest wall, ribs, muscle, fatty tissue, lobe, ducts, and lobules." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/415520-750.jpg">

1002<figcaption class="caption-container">

1003Anatomy of the female breast. The nipple and areola are shown on the outside of the breast. The lymph nodes, lobes, lobules, ducts, and other parts of the inside of the breast are also shown.</figcaption>

1004</figure>

1005</p>

1006</section>

1007<section id="_627">

1008<h3 id="_627_toc">

1009Risk Factors</h3>

1010<section id="_sm_CDR0000751850_1">

1011<p id="_sm_CDR0000751850_7" tabindex="-1">

1012Increasing age is the most important risk factor for most cancers. Other risk factors for breast cancer include the following:</p>

1013<div class="pdq-content-list">

1014<ul id="_sm_CDR0000751850_2">

1015<li>

1016Family health history.[<a href="#cit/section_1.5">

10175</a>

1018]</li>

1019<li>

1020Major inheritance susceptibility.[<a href="#cit/section_1.6">

10216</a>

1022,<a href="#cit/section_1.7">

10237</a>

1024]<div class="pdq-content-list">

1025<ul id="_sm_CDR0000751850_10" class="list-dash">

1026<li>

1027Germline mutation of the <em class="gene-name">

1028BRCA1</em>

1029 and <em class="gene-name">

1030BRCA2</em>

1031 genes and other breast cancer susceptibility genes.[<a href="#cit/section_1.8">

10328</a>

1033,<a href="#cit/section_1.9">

10349</a>

1035]</li>

1036</ul>

1037</div>

1038</li>

1039<li>

1040Alcohol intake.</li>

1041<li>

1042Breast tissue density (mammographic).[<a href="#cit/section_1.10">

104310</a>

1044]</li>

1045<li>

1046Estrogen (endogenous).[<a href="#cit/section_1.11">

104711</a>

1048-<a href="#cit/section_1.13">

104913</a>

1050]<div class="pdq-content-list">

1051<ul id="_sm_CDR0000751850_3" class="list-dash">

1052<li>

1053Menstrual history (early menarche/late menopause).[<a href="#cit/section_1.14">

105414</a>

1055,<a href="#cit/section_1.15">

105615</a>

1057]</li>

1058<li>

1059 Nulliparity.</li>

1060<li>

1061Older age at first birth.</li>

1062</ul>

1063</div>

1064 </li>

1065<li>

1066Hormone therapy history.<div class="pdq-content-list">

1067<ul id="_sm_CDR0000751850_4" class="list-dash">

1068<li>

1069 Combination estrogen plus progestin hormone replacement therapy.</li>

1070</ul>

1071</div>

1072</li>

1073<li>

1074Obesity (postmenopausal).[<a href="#cit/section_1.16">

107516</a>

1076]</li>

1077<li>

1078Personal history of breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_1.17">

107917</a>

1080]</li>

1081<li>

1082Personal history of benign breast disease (BBD) (proliferative forms of BBD).[<a href="#cit/section_1.18">

108318</a>

1084-<a href="#cit/section_1.20">

108520</a>

1086]</li>

1087<li>

1088Radiation exposure to breast/chest.[<a href="#cit/section_1.21">

108921</a>

1090]</li>

1091</ul>

1092</div>

1093</section>

1094<p id="_629" tabindex="-1">

1095Age-specific risk estimates are available to help design

1096screening strategies for women with and without a family history of breast cancer. The most commonly used tools include the <a href="https://bcrisktool.cancer.gov/" title="https://bcrisktool.cancer.gov/">

1097Gail model</a>

1098 and the <a href="https://ems-trials.org/riskevaluator/" title="https://ems-trials.org/riskevaluator/">

1099IBIS/Tyrer-Cuzick model, version 8</a>

1100 (which incorporates family history to a greater extent than the Gail model, as well as breast density).[<a href="#cit/section_1.22">

110122</a>

1102] </p>

1103<p id="_931" tabindex="-1">

1104Of all women with breast cancer, 5% to 10% may have a germline

1105mutation of the genes <em class="gene-name">

1106BRCA1</em>

1107 and <em class="gene-name">

1108BRCA2</em>

1109.[<a href="#cit/section_1.23">

111023</a>

1111] Specific mutations of <em class="gene-name">

1112BRCA1</em>

1113 and

1114<em class="gene-name">

1115BRCA2</em>

1116 are more common in women of Jewish ancestry.[<a href="#cit/section_1.24">

111724</a>

1118] The estimated lifetime

1119risk of developing breast cancer for women with <em class="gene-name">

1120BRCA1</em>

1121 and <em class="gene-name">

1122BRCA2</em>

1123 mutations is

112440% to 85%. Carriers with a history of breast cancer have an increased risk of

1125contralateral disease that may be as high as 5% per year.[<a href="#cit/section_1.25">

112625</a>

1127] Male <em class="gene-name">

1128BRCA1</em>

1129 and <em class="gene-name">

1130BRCA2</em>

1131 mutation carriers also have an increased risk of breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_1.26">

113226</a>

1133] </p>

1134<p id="_980" tabindex="-1">

1135Mutations in

1136either the <em class="gene-name">

1137BRCA1</em>

1138 or the <em class="gene-name">

1139BRCA2</em>

1140 gene also confer an increased risk of ovarian cancer [<a href="#cit/section_1.26">

114126</a>

1142,<a href="#cit/section_1.27">

114327</a>

1144] or other primary

1145cancers.[<a href="#cit/section_1.26">

114626</a>

1147,<a href="#cit/section_1.27">

114827</a>

1149] Once a <em class="gene-name">

1150BRCA1</em>

1151 or <em class="gene-name">

1152BRCA2</em>

1153 mutation has been identified, other family members can be referred for genetic counseling and testing.[<a href="#cit/section_1.28">

115428</a>

1155-<a href="#cit/section_1.31">

115631</a>

1157]</p>

1158<p id="_1088" tabindex="-1">

1159For more information, see <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq">

1160Genetics of Breast and Gynecologic Cancers</a>

1161, <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-prevention-pdq">

1162 Breast Cancer Prevention</a>

1163, and <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-screening-pdq">

1164Breast Cancer Screening</a>

1165.</p>

1166</section>

1167<section id="_1749">

1168<h3 id="_1749_toc">

1169Protective Factors</h3>

1170<p id="_932" tabindex="-1">

1171Protective factors and interventions to reduce the risk of female breast cancer include the following:</p>

1172<div class="pdq-content-list">

1173<ul id="_933">

1174<li>

1175Estrogen use (after hysterectomy).[<a href="#cit/section_1.32">

117632</a>

1177-<a href="#cit/section_1.34">

117834</a>

1179]</li>

1180<li>

1181Exercise.[<a href="#cit/section_1.35">

118235</a>

1183-<a href="#cit/section_1.37">

118437</a>

1185]</li>

1186<li>

1187Early pregnancy.[<a href="#cit/section_1.38">

118838</a>

1189-<a href="#cit/section_1.40">

119040</a>

1191]</li>

1192<li>

1193Breast feeding.[<a href="#cit/section_1.41">

119441</a>

1195]</li>

1196<li>

1197Selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs).[<a href="#cit/section_1.42">

119842</a>

1199]</li>

1200<li>

1201Aromatase inhibitors or inactivators.[<a href="#cit/section_1.43">

120243</a>

1203,<a href="#cit/section_1.44">

120444</a>

1205]</li>

1206<li>

1207Risk-reducing mastectomy.[<a href="#cit/section_1.45">

120845</a>

1209]</li>

1210<li>

1211Risk-reducing oophorectomy or ovarian ablation.[<a href="#cit/section_1.46">

121246</a>

1213-<a href="#cit/section_1.49">

121449</a>

1215]</li>

1216</ul>

1217</div>

1218<p id="_1750" tabindex="-1">

1219For more information about factors that decrease the risk of breast cancer, see <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-prevention-pdq">

1220Breast Cancer Prevention</a>

1221.</p>

1222</section>

1223<section id="_631">

1224<h3 id="_631_toc">

1225Screening</h3>

1226<p id="_632" tabindex="-1">

1227Clinical trials have established that screening asymptomatic women using mammography, with or

1228without clinical breast examination, decreases breast cancer mortality.

1229For more information, see <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-screening-pdq">

1230Breast Cancer Screening</a>

1231.</p>

1232</section>

1233<section id="_6">

1234<h3 id="_6_toc">

1235Diagnosis</h3>

1236<section id="_935">

1237<h4 id="_935_toc">

1238Patient evaluation</h4>

1239<p id="_936" tabindex="-1">

1240When breast cancer is suspected, patient management generally

1241includes the following:

1242</p>

1243<div class="pdq-content-list">

1244<ul id="_937">

1245<li>

1246Confirmation of the diagnosis.</li>

1247<li>

1248Evaluation of the stage of disease.</li>

1249<li>

1250Selection of therapy.</li>

1251</ul>

1252</div>

1253<p id="_984" tabindex="-1">

1254The following tests and procedures are used to diagnose breast cancer:</p>

1255<div class="pdq-content-list">

1256<ul id="_985">

1257<li>

1258Mammography.</li>

1259<li>

1260Ultrasonography.</li>

1261<li>

1262Breast magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), if clinically indicated.</li>

1263<li>

1264Biopsy.</li>

1265</ul>

1266</div>

1267</section>

1268<section id="_1071">

1269<h4 id="_1071_toc">

1270Contralateral disease</h4>

1271<p id="_940" tabindex="-1">

1272Pathologically, breast cancer can be a multicentric and bilateral disease.

1273Bilateral disease is somewhat more common in patients with infiltrating lobular

1274carcinoma. At 10 years after diagnosis, the risk of a primary breast cancer in the contralateral breast ranges from 3% to 5%, although endocrine therapy decreases that risk.[<a href="#cit/section_1.50">

127550</a>

1276-<a href="#cit/section_1.53">

127753</a>

1278] The development of a contralateral breast cancer is associated with

1279an increased risk of distant recurrence.[<a href="#cit/section_1.54">

128054</a>

1281] When <em class="gene-name">

1282BRCA1</em>

1283/<em class="gene-name">

1284BRCA2</em>

1285 mutation carriers were diagnosed before age 40 years, the risk of a contralateral breast cancer reached nearly 50% in the ensuing 25 years.[<a href="#cit/section_1.55">

128655</a>

1287,<a href="#cit/section_1.56">

128856</a>

1289]</p>

1290<p id="_1072" tabindex="-1">

1291Patients who have breast cancer will undergo bilateral

1292mammography at the time of diagnosis to rule out synchronous disease. To

1293detect either recurrence in the ipsilateral breast in patients treated

1294with breast-conserving surgery or a second primary cancer in the contralateral

1295breast, patients

1296will continue to have regular breast physical examinations and mammograms. </p>

1297<p id="_942" tabindex="-1">

1298The role of MRI in screening the contralateral breast and monitoring women treated with breast-conserving therapy continues to evolve. Because an increased detection rate of mammographically occult disease has been demonstrated, the selective use of MRI for additional screening is occurring more frequently despite the absence of randomized controlled data. Because only 25% of MRI-positive findings represent malignancy, pathological confirmation before treatment is recommended. Whether this increased detection rate will translate into improved treatment outcomes is unknown.[<a href="#cit/section_1.57">

129957</a>

1300-<a href="#cit/section_1.59">

130159</a>

1302]

1303</p>

1304</section>

1305</section>

1306<section id="_1678">

1307<h3 id="_1678_toc">

1308Prognostic and Predictive Factors</h3>

1309<p id="_1679" tabindex="-1">

1310Breast cancer is commonly treated by various combinations of surgery, radiation

1311therapy, chemotherapy, and hormone therapy. Prognosis and selection of therapy

1312may be influenced by the following clinical and pathological features (based on conventional histology and immunohistochemistry):[<a href="#cit/section_1.60">

131360</a>

1314]</p>

1315<div class="pdq-content-list">

1316<ul id="_1680">

1317<li>

1318 Menopausal status of the patient.</li>

1319<li>

1320Stage of the

1321disease.</li>

1322<li>

1323Grade of the primary tumor.</li>

1324<li>

1325Estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) status of the tumor.</li>

1326<li>

1327Human epidermal growth factor type 2 receptor (HER2/neu) overexpression and/or amplification.</li>

1328<li>

1329Histological type. Breast

1330cancer is classified into a variety of histological types, some of which have

1331prognostic importance. Favorable histological types include

1332mucinous, medullary, and tubular carcinomas.[<a href="#cit/section_1.61">

133361</a>

1334-<a href="#cit/section_1.63">

133563</a>

1336]</li>

1337</ul>

1338</div>

1339<p id="_1681" tabindex="-1">

1340The use of molecular profiling in breast cancer includes the following:[<a href="#cit/section_1.64">

134164</a>

1342]</p>

1343<div class="pdq-content-list">

1344<ul id="_1682">

1345<li>

1346ER and PR status testing.</li>

1347<li>

1348HER2/neu receptor status testing.</li>

1349<li>

1350Gene profile testing by microarray assay or reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (e.g., MammaPrint, Oncotype DX).</li>

1351</ul>

1352</div>

1353<p id="_1683" tabindex="-1">

1354On the basis of ER, PR, and HER2/neu results, breast cancer is classified as one of the following types:</p>

1355<div class="pdq-content-list">

1356<ul id="_1684">

1357<li>

1358Hormone receptor positive.</li>

1359<li>

1360HER2/neu positive.</li>

1361<li>

1362Triple negative (ER, PR, and HER2/neu negative).</li>

1363</ul>

1364</div>

1365<p id="_1685" tabindex="-1">

1366ER, PR, and HER2 status are important in determining prognosis and in predicting response to endocrine and HER2-directed therapy. The American Society of Clinical Oncology/College of American Pathologists consensus panel has published guidelines to help standardize the performance, interpretation, and reporting of assays used to assess the ER-PR status by immunohistochemistry and HER2 status by immunohistochemistry and <em>

1367in situ</em>

1368 hybridization.[<a href="#cit/section_1.65">

136965</a>

1370,<a href="#cit/section_1.66">

137166</a>

1372]</p>

1373<p id="_1686" tabindex="-1">

1374Gene profile tests include the following:</p>

1375<div class="pdq-content-list">

1376<ul id="_1687">

1377<li>

1378<strong>

1379MammaPrint:</strong>

1380 The first gene profile test to be approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration was the MammaPrint gene signature. The 70-gene signature classifies tumors into high- and low-risk prognostic categories. [<a href="#cit/section_1.67">

138167</a>

1382-<a href="#cit/section_1.71">

138371</a>

1384] The aim of the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00433589">

1385MINDACT</a>

1386 trial (NCT00433589) (see below) was to determine the clinical usefulness and patient benefit of adjuvant chemotherapy.</li>

1387<li>

1388<strong>

1389Oncotype DX:</strong>

1390 The Oncotype DX 21 gene assay is the gene profile test with the most extensive clinical validation thus far and applies to hormone receptor&#8211;positive HER2-negative breast cancer. A 21-gene recurrence score is generated based on the level of expression of each of the 21 genes. This recurrence score informs prognosis and treatment decision-making.<p id="_2590" tabindex="-1">

1391In the node-negative population, the designated risk groups are as follows:</p>

1392<div class="pdq-content-list">

1393<ul id="_1688" class="list-dash">

1394<li>

1395Recurrence score &#8804;11: low risk. Chemotherapy is not indicated for this group.</li>

1396<li>

1397Recurrence score &gt;11 and &#8804;25: intermediate risk. Chemotherapy decision-making is complex and personalized for this group. Patient age ( &#8804;50 vs. &gt;50 years), clinicopathological features, patient preference, and more are incorporated into this decision.</li>

1398<li>

1399Recurrence score &gt;25: high risk. Chemotherapy is indicated for this group.</li>

1400</ul>

1401</div>

1402<p id="_2573" tabindex="-1">

1403In the postmenopausal node-positive population, the designated risk groups are as follows:</p>

1404<div class="pdq-content-list">

1405<ul id="_2574" class="list-dash">

1406<li>

1407Recurrence score &#8804;25: low risk. Chemotherapy is not indicated for this group.</li>

1408<li>

1409

1410 Recurrence score &gt;25: high risk. Chemotherapy is indicated for this group.

1411</li>

1412</ul>

1413</div>

1414 </li>

1415</ul>

1416</div>

1417<p id="_1689" tabindex="-1">

1418The following trials describe the prognostic and predictive value of multigene assays in early breast cancer:</p>

1419<div class="pdq-content-list">

1420<ol id="_1690">

1421<li>

1422The prognostic ability of the Oncotype DX 21-gene assay was assessed in two randomized trials.<div class="pdq-content-list">

1423<ul id="_1691">

1424<li>

1425The National Surgical Adjuvant Breast and Bowel Project (<a href="http://www.nsabp.pitt.edu/B-14.asp" title="http://www.nsabp.pitt.edu/B-14.asp">

1426NSABP B-14</a>

1427) trial randomly assigned patients to receive tamoxifen or placebo; the results favoring tamoxifen changed clinical practice in the late 1980s.[<a href="#cit/section_1.72">

142872</a>

1429] Formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded tissue was available for 668 patients. The 10-year distant recurrence risk for patients treated with tamoxifen was 7% for those with a low recurrence score (defined in this trial as &lt;18), 14% for those with an intermediate recurrence score (defined in this trial as 18&#8211;30), and 31% for those with a high recurrence score (defined in this trial as &#8805;31) (<em>

1430P</em>

1431 &lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_1.73">

143273</a>

1433]</li>

1434<li>

1435A community-based, case-control study examined the prognostic ability of the recurrence score to predict breast cancer deaths after 10 years in a group of tamoxifen-treated patients and observed a similar prognostic pattern to that seen in patients from NSABP B-14.[<a href="#cit/section_1.74">

143674</a>

1437]</li>

1438</ul>

1439</div>

1440</li>

1441<li>

1442The use of Oncotype Dx to predict benefit from chemotherapy in patients with node-negative, ER-positive breast cancer was initially assessed in a prospective-retrospective way using the tamoxifen alone (n = 227) and the combination arms (n = 424) of the <a href="http://www.nsabp.pitt.edu/B-20.asp" title="http://www.nsabp.pitt.edu/B-20.asp">

1443NSABP B-20</a>

1444 trial.[<a href="#cit/section_1.72">

144572</a>

1446] Patients in the NSABP B-20 trial were randomly assigned to receive tamoxifen alone or tamoxifen concurrently with methotrexate and fluorouracil (MF) or cyclophosphamide with MF (CMF).[<a href="#cit/section_1.75">

144775</a>

1448]<div class="pdq-content-list">

1449<ul id="_1692">

1450<li>

1451The 10-year distant disease-free survival (DFS) improved from 60% to 88% by adding chemotherapy to tamoxifen in the high-risk group (defined in this trial as &#8805;31), while no benefit was observed in the low recurrence score group.[<a href="#cit/section_1.76">

145276</a>

1453]</li>

1454</ul>

1455</div>

1456</li>

1457<li>

1458Similar findings were reported in the prospective-retrospective evaluation of the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00929591">

1459SWOG-8814</a>

1460 trial (NCT00929591) in hormone receptor&#8211;positive, lymph node-positive, postmenopausal patients treated with tamoxifen with or without cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, and fluorouracil.[<a href="#cit/section_1.77">

146177</a>

1462] However, the sample size in this analysis was small, follow-up was only 5 years, and the prognostic impact of having positive nodes needs to be taken into consideration.<div class="pdq-content-list">

1463<ul id="_1693">

1464<li>

1465Of note, both analyses (NSABP B-20 and S8814) were underpowered for any conclusive predictive analysis among patients identified as having an intermediate recurrence score.</li>

1466</ul>

1467</div>

1468</li>

1469<li>

1470Results from the prospective, randomized <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00310180">

1471TAILORx</a>

1472 trial (NCT00310180) indicate that chemotherapy is unlikely to provide substantial benefit to patients older than 50 years with ER-PR&#8211;positive and node-negative disease and a recurrence score of 11 to 25.[<a href="#cit/section_1.78">

147378</a>

1474] In this study, a low-risk score was defined as less than 11, an intermediate score was 11 to 25, and a high-risk score was greater than 25. These cut points differ from those described above.<p id="_1694" tabindex="-1">

1475Patients in this study with a low-risk score were found to have very low rates of recurrence at 5 years with endocrine therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_1.79">

147679</a>

1477] </p>

1478<div class="pdq-content-list">

1479<ul id="_1695">

1480<li>

1481Rate of invasive DFS was 93.8% at 5 years and 84.0% at 9 years.</li>

1482<li>

1483Rate of freedom from recurrence of breast cancer at a distant site was 99.3% at 5 years and 96.8% at 9 years.</li>

1484<li>

1485Rate of freedom from recurrence of breast cancer at a distant or local-regional site was 98.7% at 5 years and 95.0% at 9 years.</li>

1486<li>

1487Rate of overall survival (OS) was 98.0% at 5 years and 93.7% at 9 years.</li>

1488</ul>

1489</div>

1490<p id="_1824" tabindex="-1">

1491In the middle-risk group in the TAILORx study (recurrence score, 11&#8211;25), 6,907 women were randomly assigned to endocrine therapy alone or endocrine therapy plus chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_1.78">

149278</a>

1493] Of these, 3,399 women on the endocrine therapy-alone arm and 3,312 women on the endocrine therapy-plus-chemotherapy arm were available for an analysis according to the randomized treatment assignments. After a median follow-up of 90 months, the difference in invasive DFS, the main study end point, met the prespecified noninferiority criterion (<em>

1494P</em>

1495 &gt; .10 for a test of no difference after 835 events had occurred) suggesting the noninferiority of endocrine therapy compared with endocrine therapy plus chemotherapy. </p>

1496<div class="pdq-content-list">

1497<ul id="_1825">

1498<li>

1499 In this population, the 9-year invasive DFS rate was 83.3% for endocrine therapy alone and 84.3% for endocrine therapy plus chemotherapy (hazard ratio [HR], 1.08; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.94&#8211;1.24; <em>

1500P</em>

1501 = .26).[<a href="#cit/section_1.78">

150278</a>

1503][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

1504Level of evidence B1</a>

1505] </li>

1506<li>

1507One hundred eighty-five patients in the endocrine-only arm received chemotherapy, and 608 patients in the endocrine therapy-plus-chemotherapy arm did not receive their assigned chemotherapy. In an analysis based on the actual treatment received, the HR for invasive DFS was 1.14 (95% CI, 0.99&#8211;1.31; <em>

1508P</em>

1509 = .06). </li>

1510<li>

1511 Outcomes for the other end points examined (freedom of distant breast cancer recurrence, freedom from local and distant recurrence, and OS) were similar between the two treatment arms and none were significant at <em>

1512P</em>

1513 &lt; 0.10. </li>

1514<li>

1515There was a significant interaction between treatment assignment and age (<em>

1516P</em>

1517 = .03) with respect to invasive DFS, suggesting that chemotherapy might be beneficial in women younger than 50 years with recurrence scores ranging from 11 to 25.

1518</li>

1519<li>

1520A secondary analysis of TAILORx demonstrated that integration of clinical risk (assessed by tumor size and grade) adds prognostic information to the recurrence score in women with a recurrence score of at least 11; however, clinical risk was not predictive of a chemotherapy benefit.[<a href="#cit/section_1.80">

152180</a>

1522] The interaction between age and chemotherapy benefit was further explored in this secondary analysis. Among women aged 50 years or younger, rates of distant recurrence were lower with chemotherapy in the setting of recurrence scores of 16 to 20 and high clinical risk; and in the setting of recurrence scores of 21 to 25, regardless of clinical risk. </li>

1523<li>

1524Most women received tamoxifen as their endocrine therapy. It is not certain if any of the observed benefits of chemotherapy are attributable to ovarian function suppression and if they could be achieved through endocrine therapy.</li>

1525</ul>

1526</div>

1527</li>

1528<li>

1529The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00433589">

1530MINDACT</a>

1531 trial (NCT00433589) tested whether adding MammaPrint genomic risk to a clinical-risk classification (modified from Adjuvant! Online) might guide more appropriate choices of chemotherapy in women with node negative- or 1-to-3 node-positive disease.[<a href="#cit/section_1.81">

153281</a>

1533][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

1534Level of evidence C2</a>

1535] Unlike the TAILORx study, which only had hormone receptor&#8211;positive patients, this trial included hormone receptor&#8211;negative patients. In this prospective study, women with both genomic and clinical high-risk classification received chemotherapy, while those with both genomic and clinical low-risk classification did not receive chemotherapy. Participants with discordant results (clinical high-risk- with genomic low-risk classification, or clinical low-risk- with genomic high-risk classification) were randomly assigned to receive or not receive chemotherapy. A total of 1,550 women with high clinical risk and low genomic risk, and 592 women with low clinical risk and high genomic risk, were randomly assigned to receive or not receive chemotherapy. The primary goal of the study was to determine whether patients with high clinical risk, but low genomic risk, who did not receive chemotherapy had a 5-year survival rate without distant metastases (primary study end point) of 92% or lower (a noninferiority design). <div class="pdq-content-list">

1536<ul id="_1827">

1537<li>

1538This end point was met because the observed rate in the group was 94.7% (95% CI, 92.5%&#8211;96.2%). However, among patients with high clinical risk but low genomic risk, the rate of 5-year survival without distant metastases was 1.5% higher in the arm that did receive chemotherapy than in the arm that did not receive chemotherapy, although the study was not powered to detect a difference between these arms (HR chemotherapy vs. no chemotherapy, 0.78; 95% CI, 0.50&#8211;1.21; <em>

1539P</em>

1540 = .27)</li>

1541<li>

1542 Patients in the low clinical risk group with high genomic risk did well, and there was little evidence of benefit from chemotherapy in this group (5-year survival without distant metastases, 95.8% with chemotherapy vs. 95.0% without; HR, 1.17; 95% CI, 0.59&#8211;2.28; <em>

1543P</em>

1544 = .66). </li>

1545</ul>

1546</div>

1547</li>

1548<li>

1549The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01272037">

1550RxPONDER</a>

1551 trial (NCT01272037) included 3,350 postmenopausal and 1,665 premenopausal women with hormone receptor&#8211;positive and HER2-negative breast cancer who had a recurrence score of 25 or less. Patients were randomly assigned to receive either endocrine therapy alone or endocrine therapy plus chemotherapy. Results have been reported in abstract form; the primary study end point was invasive disease-free survival (IDFS). Because a prespecified test for interaction between treatment assignment and menopausal status was significant (<em>

1552P</em>

1553 = .004), the premenopausal and postmenopausal groups were analyzed separately.[<a href="#cit/section_1.82">

155482</a>

1555]<div class="pdq-content-list">

1556<ul id="_2342">

1557<li>

1558 In postmenopausal patients, there was no evidence of a benefit with the addition of chemotherapy (HR for endocrine therapy plus chemotherapy vs. endocrine therapy, 0.97; 95% CI, 0.78&#8211;1.22; 5-year IDFS rate, 91.6% vs. 91.9%; <em>

1559P</em>

1560 = .82).[<a href="#cit/section_1.82">

156182</a>

1562][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

1563Level of evidence B1</a>

1564]</li>

1565<li>

1566In premenopausal patients, however, there was evidence of a benefit from the addition of chemotherapy to endocrine therapy (HR, 0.54; 95% CI, 0.38&#8211;0.76; 5-year IDFS rate, 94.2% vs. 89.0%; <em>

1567P</em>

1568 = .0004). OS was also significantly improved in patients who received endocrine therapy plus chemotherapy (HR, 0.47; 95% CI, 0.24&#8211;0.94; <em>

1569P</em>

1570 = .032).[<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

1571Level of evidence A1</a>

1572]</li>

1573</ul>

1574</div>

1575</li>

1576<li>

1577The West German Study Group <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01049425">

1578Plan B</a>

1579 trial (NCT01049425) compared two chemotherapy regimens in patients with node-positive (pN1) or high-risk node-negative disease. Chemotherapy was not offered to patients with recurrence scores below 12, but they were followed. For a full description of the chemotherapy regimens, see <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_1027">

1580Postoperative Systemic Therapy</a>

1581.<div class="pdq-content-list">

1582<ul id="_2373">

1583<li>

1584The 5-year DFS rates were very high in the 348 patients who did not receive chemotherapy and did not differ between node-negative patients (94.5%) and pN1 patients (94.9%).[<a href="#cit/section_1.83">

158583</a>

1586][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

1587Level of evidence C1</a>

1588]</li>

1589</ul>

1590</div>

1591</li>

1592</ol>

1593</div>

1594<p id="_1697" tabindex="-1">

1595Many other gene-based assays may guide treatment decisions in patients with early breast cancer (e.g., Predictor Analysis of Microarray 50 [PAM50] Risk of Recurrence [ROR] score, EndoPredict, Breast Cancer Index).</p>

1596<p id="_1698" tabindex="-1">

1597Although certain rare inherited mutations,

1598such as those of <em class="gene-name">

1599BRCA1</em>

1600 and <em class="gene-name">

1601BRCA2</em>

1602, predispose women to develop breast cancer, prognostic

1603data on <em class="gene-name">

1604BRCA1</em>

1605/<em class="gene-name">

1606BRCA2</em>

1607 mutation carriers who have developed breast cancer are conflicting. These women are at greater risk of developing contralateral breast cancer.

1608For more information, see the <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/brca-genes-hp-pdq#_3469">

1609Female Breast Cancer Risks</a>

1610 section in <em class="gene-name">

1611BRCA1</em>

1612 and <em class="gene-name">

1613BRCA2</em>

1614: Cancer Risks and Management.</p>

1615</section>

1616<section id="_1069">

1617<h3 id="_1069_toc">

1618Posttherapy Considerations</h3>

1619<section id="_10">

1620<h4 id="_10_toc">

1621Hormone replacement therapy</h4>

1622<p id="_988" tabindex="-1">

1623After careful consideration, certain patients with severe symptoms may be treated with hormone replacement therapy. For more information, see the <a href="/about-cancer/treatment/side-effects/hot-flashes-hp-pdq#_210">

1624Hormone Replacement Therapy</a>

1625 section in Hot Flashes and Night Sweats and <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-prevention-pdq">

1626Breast Cancer Prevention</a>

1627.</p>

1628</section>

1629</section>

N Engl J Med 380 (25): 2395-2405, 2019.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=31157962&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=31157962&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1951[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1952</li>

1953<li id="section_1.81">

1954Cardoso F, van't Veer LJ, Bogaerts J, et al.: 70-Gene Signature as an Aid to Treatment Decisions in Early-Stage Breast Cancer. N Engl J Med 375 (8): 717-29, 2016.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=27557300&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=27557300&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1955[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1956</li>

1957<li id="section_1.82">

1958Kalinsky K, Barlow WE, Meric-Bernstam F, et al.: Abstract GS3-00: first results from a phase III randomized clinical trial of standard adjuvant endocrine therapy (ET) +/- chemotherapy (CT) in patients (pts) with 1-3 positive nodes, hormone receptor-positive (HR+) and HER2-negative (HER2-) breast cancer (BC) with recurrence score (RS) &lt; 25: SWOG S1007 (RxPonder). [Abstract] Cancer Res 81 (4): A-GS3-00, 2021. <a href="https://cancerres.aacrjournals.org/content/81/4_Supplement/GS3-00" title="https://cancerres.aacrjournals.org/content/81/4_Supplement/GS3-00">

1959Also available online</a>

1960. Last accessed July 28, 2023.</li>

1961<li id="section_1.83">

1962Nitz U, Gluz O, Clemens M, et al.: West German Study PlanB Trial: Adjuvant Four Cycles of Epirubicin and Cyclophosphamide Plus Docetaxel Versus Six Cycles of Docetaxel and Cyclophosphamide in HER2-Negative Early Breast Cancer. J Clin Oncol 37 (10): 799-808, 2019.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=30785826&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=30785826&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1963[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1964</li>

1965</ol>

1966</div>

1967

1968 </section>

1969

1970

1971

1972 <section id="_18">

1973

1974 <h2>

1975Histopathological Classification of Breast Cancer</h2>

1976

1977 <div id="_section_18" class="pdq-sections">

1978<p id="_19" tabindex="-1">

1979<a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_977">

1980Table 1</a>

1981 describes the histological classification of breast cancer based on tumor location.[<a href="#cit/section_2.1">

19821</a>

1983]

1984Infiltrating or invasive ductal cancer is the most common breast cancer

1985histological type and comprises 70% to 80% of all cases.

1986</p>

1987<table id="_977" class="table-default expandable-container">

1988<caption>

1989Table 1. Tumor Location and Related Histological Subtype</caption>

2005NOS = not otherwise specified.</td>

2008<tbody>

2009<tr>

2010<td>

2011Carcinoma, NOS</td>

2012<td>

2013&#160;</td>

2020in situ</em>

20842</a>

2085]

2086</td>

2101</td>

2108</tr>

2110<td>

2111Metaplastic</td>

2112</tr>

2113</tbody>

2114</table>

2115<p id="_25" tabindex="-1">

2116The following tumor subtypes occur in the breast but are not

2117considered typical breast cancers:

2118</p>

2119<div class="pdq-content-list">

2120<ul id="_26">

2121<li>

2122Phyllodes tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.3">

21233</a>

2124,<a href="#cit/section_2.4">

21254</a>

2126]

2127</li>

2128<li>

2129Angiosarcoma.

2130</li>

2131<li>

2132Primary lymphoma.

2133</li>

2134</ul>

2135</div>

2136<h6 do-not-show="toc">

2143[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2154</div>

2155

2156 </section>

2157

2158

2159

2160 <section id="_27">

2161

2162 <h2>

2163Stage Information for Breast Cancer</h2>

2164

2165 <div id="_section_27" class="pdq-sections">

2166<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

2167<h6>

2168In This Section</h6>

2169<ul>

2170<li>

2171<a href="#_1994_toc">

2172TNM Definitions</a>

2173</li>

2174<li>

2175<a href="#_1996_toc">

2176AJCC Anatomic and Prognostic Stage Groups</a>

2177</li>

2178<li>

2179<a href="#_1981_toc">

2180AJCC Pathological Prognostic Stage Groups</a>

2181</li>

2182</ul>

2183</nav>

2184<p id="_28" tabindex="-1">

2185The American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) staging system provides a

2186strategy for grouping patients with respect to prognosis. Therapeutic

2187decisions are formulated in part according to staging categories but also other clinical factors such as the following, some of which are included in the determination of stage:

2188</p>

2189<div class="pdq-content-list">

2190<ul id="_954">

2191<li>

2192Tumor size.</li>

2193<li>

2194Lymph node status.</li>

2195<li>

2196Estrogen-receptor and progesterone-receptor

2197levels in the tumor tissue.</li>

2198<li>

2199Human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2/neu) status in the tumor.</li>

2200<li>

2201 Tumor grade.</li>

2202<li>

2203Menopausal status.</li>

2204<li>

2205General health of the

2206patient.</li>

2207</ul>

2208</div>

2209<p id="_1984" tabindex="-1">

2210The standards used to define biomarker status are described as follows:</p>

2211<div class="pdq-content-list">

2212<ul id="_1985">

2213<li>

2214<strong>

2215Estrogen receptor (ER) expression:</strong>

2216 ER expression is measured primarily by immunohistochemistry (IHC). Any staining of 1% of cells or more is considered positive for ER.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

22171</a>

2218]</li>

2219<li>

2220<strong>

2221Progesterone receptor (PR) expression:</strong>

2222 PR expression is measured primarily by IHC. Any staining of 1% of cells or more is considered positive for PR.</li>

2223<li>

2224<strong>

2225HER2 expression:</strong>

2226 HER2 is measured primarily by either IHC to assess expression of the HER2 protein or by <em>

2227in situ</em>

2228 hybridization (ISH) to assess gene copy number. The American Society of Clinical Oncology/College of American Pathologists consensus panel has published guidelines for cases when either IHC or ISH testing is equivocal.[<a href="#cit/section_3.2">

22292</a>

2230]<p id="_2002" tabindex="-1">

2231IHC:</p>

2232<div class="pdq-content-list">

2233<ul id="_1969">

2234<li>

2235Negative: 0 or 1+ staining</li>

2236<li>

2237Equivocal: 2+ staining</li>

2238<li>

2239Positive: 3+ staining</li>

2240</ul>

2241</div>

2242<p id="_1998" tabindex="-1">

2243ISH (dual probe):</p>

2244<div class="pdq-content-list">

2245<ul id="_1971">

2246<li>

2247Possible negative results:<div class="pdq-content-list">

2248<ul id="_1972" class="list-dash">

2249<li>

2250HER2/chromosome enumeration probe (CEP17) ratio &lt;2.0 <strong>

2251AND</strong>

2252 <em class="gene-name">

2253HER2</em>

2254 copy number &lt;4</li>

2255</ul>

2256</div>

2257</li>

2258<li>

2259Possible equivocal results: (requires performing alternative ISH test to confirm equivocal or IHC if not previously performed)<div class="pdq-content-list">

2260<ul id="_1973" class="list-dash">

2261<li>

2262HER2/CEP17 ratio &lt;2.0 <strong>

2263AND</strong>

2264 <em class="gene-name">

2265HER2</em>

2266 copy number &#8805;4 but &lt;6</li>

2267</ul>

2268</div>

2269</li>

2270<li>

2271Possible positive results:<div class="pdq-content-list">

2272<ul id="_1974" class="list-dash">

2273<li>

2274HER2/CEP17 ratio &#8805;2.0 by ISH</li>

2275<li>

2276<em class="gene-name">

2277HER2</em>

2278 copy number &#8805;6 regardless of ratio by ISH</li>

2279</ul>

2280</div>

2281</li>

2282</ul>

2283</div>

2284<p id="_1999" tabindex="-1">

2285ISH (single probe):</p>

2286<div class="pdq-content-list">

2287<ul id="_1976">

2288<li>

2289Negative: &lt;4 <em class="gene-name">

2290HER2</em>

2291 copies</li>

2292<li>

2293Equivocal: &#8805;4 <em class="gene-name">

2294HER2</em>

2295 copies but &lt;6 HER2 copies</li>

2296<li>

2297Positive: &#8805;6 <em class="gene-name">

2298HER2</em>

2299 copies</li>

2300</ul>

2301</div>

2302</li>

2303</ul>

2304</div>

2305<section id="_1994">

2306<h3 id="_1994_toc">

2307TNM Definitions</h3>

2308<p id="_1995" tabindex="-1">

2309The AJCC has designated staging by TNM (tumor, node, metastasis) classification to define breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_3.3">

23103</a>

2311] The grade of the tumor is determined by its morphologic features, such as tubule formation, nuclear pleomorphism, and mitotic count.</p>

2312<table id="_1941" class="table-default expandable-container">

2313<caption>

2314Table 2. Definition of Primary Tumor (T) &#8211; Clinical and Pathological<span class="sup">

2315a</span>

2316</caption>

2317<colgroup>

2318<col width="15.03%">

2319<col width="84.96%">

2320</colgroup>

2321<THead>

2322<tr>

2323<th align="Center" scope="col">

2324T Category</th>

2325<th align="Center" scope="col">

2326T Criteria</th>

2327</tr>

2328</THead>

2329<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

2330<tr>

2331<td colspan="2">

2332DCIS = ductal carcinoma <em>

2333in situ</em>

2334.</td>

2335</tr>

2336<tr>

2337<td colspan="2">

2338<span class="sup">

2339a</span>

2340Reprinted with permission from AJCC: Breast, revised version. In: Amin MB, Edge SB, Greene FL, et al., eds.: <em>

2341AJCC Cancer Staging Manual</em>

2342. 8th ed. New York, NY: Springer, 2017, pp. 4&#8211;96.</td>

2343</tr>

2344<tr>

2345<td colspan="2">

2346<span class="sup">

2347b</span>

2348Lobular carcinoma <em>

2349in situ</em>

2350 is a benign entity and is removed from TNM staging in the <em>

2351AJCC Cancer Staging Manual</em>

2352, 8th ed.</td>

2353</tr>

2354<tr>

2355<td colspan="2">

2356<span class="sup">

2357c</span>

2358Rules for Classification - The anatomic TNM system is a method for coding extent of disease. This is done by assigning a category of extent of disease for the tumor (T), regional lymph nodes (N), and distant metastases (M). T, N, and M are assigned by clinical means and by adding surgical findings and pathological information to the clinical information. The documented prognostic impact of postneoadjuvant extent of disease and response to therapy warrant clear definitions of the use of the <em>

2359yp</em>

2360 prefix and response to therapy. The use of neoadjuvant therapy does not change the clinical (pretreatment) stage. As per TNM rules, the anatomic component of clinical stage is identified with the prefix <em>

2361c</em>

2362 (e.g., cT). In addition, clinical staging can include the use of fine-needle aspiration (FNA) or core-needle biopsy and sentinel lymph node biopsy before neoadjuvant therapy. These are denoted with the postscripts <em>

2363f </em>

2364and <em>

2365sn</em>

2366, respectively. Nodal metastases confirmed by FNA or core-needle biopsy are classified as macrometastases (cN1), regardless of the size of the tumor focus in the final pathological specimen. For example, if, prior to neoadjuvant systemic therapy, a patient with a 1 cm primary has no palpable nodes but has an ultrasound-guided FNA biopsy of an axillary lymph node that is positive, the patient will be categorized as cN1 (f) for clinical (pretreatment) staging and is assigned to Stage IIA. Likewise, if the patient has a positive axillary sentinel node identified before neoadjuvant systemic therapy, the tumor is categorized as cN1 (sn) (Stage IIA). As per TNM rules, in the absence of pathological T evaluation (removal of the primary tumor), which is identified with prefix <em>

2367p</em>

2368 (e.g., pT), microscopic evaluation of nodes before neoadjuvant therapy, even by complete removal such as sentinel node biopsy, is still classified as clinical (cN).</td>

2369</tr>

2370</TFoot>

2371<tbody>

2372<tr>

2373<td>

2374TX</td>

2375<td>

2376Primary tumor cannot be assessed.</td>

2377</tr>

2378<tr>

2379<td>

2380T0</td>

2381<td>

2382No evidence of primary tumor.</td>

2383</tr>

2384<tr>

2385<td>

2386Tis<span class="sup">

2387b</span>

2388 </td>

2389<td>

2390<em>

2391DCIS</em>

2392.</td>

2393</tr>

2394<tr>

2395<td>

2396Tis (Paget)</td>

2397<td>

2398Paget disease of the nipple NOT associated with invasive carcinoma and/or DCIS in the underlying breast parenchyma. Carcinomas in the breast parenchyma associated with Paget disease are categorized based on the size and characteristics of the parenchymal disease, although the presence of Paget disease should still be noted.</td>

2399</tr>

2400<tr>

2401<td>

2402T1</td>

2403<td>

2404Tumor &#8804;20 mm in greatest dimension.</td>

2405</tr>

2406<tr>

2407<td>

2408&#8211;T1mi</td>

2409<td>

2410Tumor &#8804;1 mm in greatest dimension.</td>

2411</tr>

2412<tr>

2413<td>

2414&#8211;T1a</td>

2415<td>

2416Tumor &gt;1 mm but &#8804;5 mm in greatest dimension (round any measurement &gt;1.0&#8211;1.9 mm to 2 mm).</td>

2417</tr>

2418<tr>

2419<td>

2420&#8211;T1b</td>

2421<td>

2422Tumor &gt;5 mm but &#8804;10 mm in greatest dimension.</td>

2423</tr>

2424<tr>

2425<td>

2426&#8211;T1c</td>

2427<td>

2428Tumor &gt;10 mm but &#8804;20 mm in greatest dimension.</td>

2429</tr>

2430<tr>

2431<td>

2432T2</td>

2433<td>

2434Tumor &gt;20 mm but &#8804;50 mm in greatest dimension.</td>

2435</tr>

2436<tr>

2437<td>

2438T3</td>

2439<td>

2440Tumor &gt;50 mm in greatest dimension.</td>

2441</tr>

2442<tr>

2443<td>

2444T4</td>

2445<td>

2446Tumor of any size with direct extension to the chest wall and/or to the skin (ulceration or macroscopic nodules); invasion of the dermis alone does not qualify as T4.</td>

2447</tr>

2448<tr>

2449<td>

2450&#8211;T4a</td>

2451<td>

2452Extension to the chest wall; invasion or adherence to pectoralis muscle in the absence of invasion of chest wall structures does not qualify as T4.</td>

2453</tr>

2454<tr>

2455<td>

2456&#8211;T4b</td>

2457<td>

2458Ulceration and/or ipsilateral macroscopic satellite nodules and/or edema (including peau d'orange) of the skin that does not meet the criteria for inflammatory carcinoma.</td>

2459</tr>

2460<tr>

2461<td>

2462&#8211;T4c</td>

2463<td>

2464Both T4a and T4b are present.</td>

2465</tr>

2466<tr>

2467<td>

2468&#8211;T4d</td>

2469<td>

2470Inflammatory carcinoma (see Rules for Classification<span class="sup">

2471c</span>

2472).</td>

2473</tr>

2474</tbody>

2475</table>

2476<table id="_1942" class="table-default expandable-container">

2477<caption>

2478Table 3. Definition of Regional Lymph Nodes &#8211; Clinical (cN)<span class="sup">

2479a,b</span>

2480</caption>

2481<colgroup>

2482<col width="16.97%">

2483<col width="83.02%">

2484</colgroup>

2485<THead>

2486<tr>

2487<th align="Center" scope="col">

2488cN Category</th>

2489<th align="Center" scope="col">

2490cN Criteria</th>

2491</tr>

2492</THead>

2493<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

2494<tr>

2495<td colspan="2">

2496<span class="sup">

2497a</span>

2498Reprinted with permission from AJCC: Breast, revised version. In: Amin MB, Edge SB, Greene FL, et al., eds.: <em>

2499AJCC Cancer Staging Manual</em>

2500. 8th ed. New York, NY: Springer, 2017, pp. 4&#8211;96.</td>

2501</tr>

2502<tr>

2503<td colspan="2">

2504<span class="sup">

2505b</span>

2506(sn) and (f) suffixes should be added to the N category to denote confirmation of metastasis by sentinel node biopsy or fine-needle aspiration/core needle biopsy, respectively.</td>

2507</tr>

2508<tr>

2509<td colspan="2">

2510<span class="sup">

2511c</span>

2512The cNX category is used sparingly in cases where regional lymph nodes have previously been surgically removed or where there is no documentation of physical examination of the axilla.</td>

2513</tr>

2514<tr>

2515<td colspan="2">

2516<span class="sup">

2517d</span>

2518cN1mi is rarely used but may be appropriate in cases where sentinel node biopsy is performed before tumor resection, most likely to occur in cases treated with neoadjuvant therapy.</td>

2519</tr>

2520</TFoot>

2521<tbody>

2522<tr>

2523<td>

2524cNX<span class="sup">

2525c</span>

2526</td>

2527<td>

2528Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed (e.g., previously removed).</td>

2529</tr>

2530<tr>

2531<td>

2532cN0</td>

2533<td>

2534No regional lymph node metastases (by imaging or clinical examination).</td>

2535</tr>

2536<tr>

2537<td>

2538cN1</td>

2539<td>

2540Metastases to movable ipsilateral Level I, II axillary lymph nodes(s).</td>

2541</tr>

2542<tr>

2543<td>

2544&#8211;cN1mi<span class="sup">

2545d</span>

2546</td>

2547<td>

2548Micrometastases (approximately 200 cells, &gt;0.2 mm, but &#8804;2.0 mm).</td>

2549</tr>

2550<tr>

2551<td rowspan="2">

2552cN2</td>

2553<td>

2554Metastases in ipsilateral Level I, II axillary lymph nodes that are clinically fixed or matted; </td>

2555</tr>

2556<tr>

2557<td>

2558<em>

2559or</em>

2560 in ipsilateral internal mammary nodes in the absence of axillary lymph node metastases.</td>

2561</tr>

2562<tr>

2563<td>

2564&#8211;cN2a</td>

2565<td>

2566Metastases in ipsilateral Level I, II axillary lymph nodes fixed to one another (matted) or to other structures.</td>

2567</tr>

2568<tr>

2569<td>

2570&#8211;cN2b</td>

2571<td>

2572Metastases only in ipsilateral internal mammary nodes in the absence of axillary lymph node metastases.</td>

2573</tr>

2574<tr>

2575<td>

2576cN3</td>

2577<td>

2578Metastases in ipsilateral infraclavicular (Level Ill axillary) lymph node(s) with or without Level l, II axillary lymph node involvement;

2579<em>

2580or</em>

2581 in ipsilateral internal mammary lymph node(s) with Level l, II axillary lymph

2582

2583node metastases;

2584<em>

2585or</em>

2586 metastases in ipsilateral supraclavicular lymph node(s) with or without

2587axillary or internal mammary lymph node involvement.</td>

2588</tr>

2589<tr>

2590<td>

2591&#8211;cN3a</td>

2592<td>

2593Metastases in ipsilateral infraclavicular lymph node(s).</td>

2594</tr>

2595<tr>

2596<td>

2597&#8211;cN3b</td>

2598<td>

2599Metastases in ipsilateral internal mammary lymph node(s) and axillary lymph node(s).</td>

2600</tr>

2601<tr>

2602<td>

2603&#8211;cN3c</td>

2604<td>

2605Metastases in ipsilateral supraclavicular lymph node(s).</td>

2606</tr>

2607</tbody>

2608</table>

2609<table id="_1943" class="table-default expandable-container">

2610<caption>

2611Table 4. Definition of Regional Lymph Nodes &#8211; Pathological (pN)<span class="sup">

2612a,b</span>

2613</caption>

2614<colgroup>

2615<col width="15.87%">

2616<col width="84.12%">

2617</colgroup>

2618<THead>

2619<tr>

2620<th align="Center" scope="col">

2621pN Category</th>

2622<th align="Center" scope="col">

2623pN Criteria</th>

2624</tr>

2625</THead>

2626<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

2627<tr>

2628<td colspan="2">

2629ITCs = isolated tumor cells; RT-PCR = reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction. </td>

2630</tr>

2631<tr>

2632<td colspan="2">

2633<span class="sup">

2634a</span>

2635Reprinted with permission from AJCC: Breast, revised version. In: Amin MB, Edge SB, Greene FL, et al., eds.: <em>

2636AJCC Cancer Staging Manual</em>

2637. 8th ed. New York, NY: Springer, 2017, pp. 4&#8211;96.</td>

2638</tr>

2639<tr>

2640<td colspan="2">

2641<span class="sup">

2642b</span>

2643(sn) and (f) suffixes should be added to the N category to denote confirmation of metastasis by sentinel node biopsy or fine-needle aspiration/core needle biopsy, respectively, with NO further resection of nodes.</td>

2644</tr>

2645</TFoot>

2646<tbody>

2647<tr>

2648<td>

2649pNX</td>

2650<td>

2651Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed (e.g., not removed for pathological study or previously removed).</td>

2652</tr>

2653<tr>

2654<td>

2655pN0</td>

2656<td>

2657No regional lymph node metastasis identified or ITCs only.</td>

2658</tr>

2659<tr>

2660<td>

2661&#8211;pN0(I+)</td>

2662<td>

2663ITCs only (malignant cell clusters &#8804;0.2 mm) in regional lymph node(s).</td>

2664</tr>

2665<tr>

2666<td>

2667&#8211;pN0(mol+)</td>

2668<td>

2669Positive molecular findings by RT-PCR; no ITCs detected.

2670</td>

2671</tr>

2672<tr>

2673<td>

2674pN1</td>

2675<td>

2676Micrometastases; or metastases in 1&#8211;3 axillary lymph nodes; and/or clinically negative internal mammary nodes with micrometastases or macrometastases by

2677sentinel lymph node biopsy.

2678</td>

2679</tr>

2680<tr>

2681<td>

2682&#8211;pN1mi</td>

2683<td>

2684Micrometastases (~200 cells, &gt;0.2 mm, but &#8804;2.0 mm).

2685</td>

2686</tr>

2687<tr>

2688<td>

2689&#8211;pN1a</td>

2690<td>

2691Metastases in 1&#8211;3 axillary lymph nodes, at least one metastasis &gt;2.0 mm.</td>

2692</tr>

2693<tr>

2694<td>

2695&#8211;pN1b</td>

2696<td>

2697Metastases in ipsilateral internal mammary sentinel nodes, excluding ITCs.</td>

2698</tr>

2699<tr>

2700<td>

2701&#8211;pN1c</td>

2702<td>

2703pN1a and pN1b combined.</td>

2704</tr>

2705<tr>

2706<td>

2707pN2</td>

2708<td>

2709Metastases in 4&#8211;9 axillary lymph nodes; or positive ipsilateral internal mammary lymph nodes by imaging in the absence of axillary lymph node metastases.</td>

2710</tr>

2711<tr>

2712<td>

2713&#8211;pN2a</td>

2714<td>

2715Metastases in 4&#8211;9 axillary lymph nodes (at least 1 tumor deposit &gt;2.0 mm).

2716</td>

2717</tr>

2718<tr>

2719<td>

2720&#8211;pN2b</td>

2721<td>

2722Metastases in clinically detected internal mammary lymph nodes with or without microscopic confirmation; with pathologically negative axillary nodes.</td>

2723</tr>

2724<tr>

2725<td>

2726pN3</td>

2727<td>

2728Metastases in &#8805;10 axillary lymph nodes; <em>

2729or</em>

2730 in infraclavicular (Level Ill axillary) lymph nodes; <em>

2731or</em>

2732 positive ipsilateral internal mammary lymph nodes by imaging in the presence of one or more positive Level l, II axillary lymph nodes;

2733<em>

2734or</em>

2735 in &gt;3 axillary lymph nodes and micrometastases or macrometastases by sentinel lymph node biopsy in clinically negative ipsilateral internal mammary lymph nodes;

2736<em>

2737or</em>

2738 in ipsilateral supraclavicular lymph nodes.

2739</td>

2740</tr>

2741<tr>

2742<td>

2743&#8211;pN3a</td>

2744<td>

2745Metastases in &#8805;10 axillary lymph nodes (at least 1 tumor deposit &gt;2.0 mm);

2746

2747<em>

2748or</em>

2749 metastases to the infraclavicular (Level III axillary lymph) nodes.

2750</td>

2751</tr>

2752<tr>

2753<td rowspan="2">

2754&#8211;pN3b</td>

2755<td>

2756pN1a or pN2a in the presence of cN2b (positive internal mammary nodes by imaging);

2757</td>

2758</tr>

2759<tr>

2760<td>

2761<em>

2762or</em>

2763 pN2a in the presence of pN1b.

2764</td>

2765</tr>

2766<tr>

2767<td>

2768&#8211;pN3c</td>

2769<td>

2770Metastases in ipsilateral supraclavicular lymph nodes.</td>

2771</tr>

2772</tbody>

2773</table>

2774<table id="_1944" class="table-default expandable-container">

2781<col width="83.60%">

2782</colgroup>

2807<tbody>

2808<tr>

2809<td>

2810M0</td>

2811<td>

2812No clinical or radiographic evidence of distant metastases.<span class="sup">

2813b</span>

2814</td>

2815</tr>

2816<tr>

2817<td>

2818cM0(I+)</td>

2819<td>

2820No clinical or radiographic evidence of distant metastases in the presence of tumor cells or deposits &#8804;0.2 mm detected microscopically or by molecular techniques in circulating blood, bone marrow, or other nonregional nodal tissue in a patient without symptoms or signs of metastases.</td>

2821</tr>

2822<tr>

2823<td>

2824cM1</td>

2825<td>

2826Distant metastases detected by clinical and radiographic means.</td>

2827</tr>

2828<tr>

2829<td>

2830pM1</td>

2831<td>

2832Any histologically proven metastases in distant organs; or if in nonregional nodes, metastases &gt;0.2 mm.</td>

2833</tr>

2834</tbody>

2835</table>

2950</section>

2951<section id="_1996">

2952<h3 id="_1996_toc">

2953AJCC Anatomic and Prognostic Stage Groups</h3>

2954<p id="_1991" tabindex="-1">

2955There are three stage group tables for invasive cancer:[<a href="#cit/section_3.3">

29563</a>

2957]</p>

2958<div class="pdq-content-list">

2959<ul id="_1992">

2960<li>

2961<strong>

2962Anatomic Stage Group.</strong>

2963 The Anatomic Stage Group table is used in regions of the world where tumor grading and/or biomarker testing for ER, PR, and HER2 are not routinely available. (See <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_1952">

2964Table 8</a>

2965.)</li>

2966<li>

2967<strong>

2968Clinical Prognostic Stage Group.</strong>

2969 The Clinical Prognostic Stage Group table is used for all patients in the United States. Patients who have neoadjuvant therapy as their initial treatment should have the clinical prognostic stage and the observed degree of response to treatment recorded, but these patients are not assigned a pathological prognostic stage. (See <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_1959">

2970Table 9</a>

2971.)</li>

2972<li>

2973<strong>

2974Pathological Prognostic Stage Group.</strong>

2975 The Pathological Prognostic Stage Group table is used for all patients in the United States who have surgery as initial treatment and have pathological T and N information reported. (See <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_1983">

2976Table 10</a>

2977.)</li>

2978</ul>

2979</div>

2980<p id="_2003" tabindex="-1">

2981In the United States, cancer registries and clinicians must use the Clinical and Pathological Prognostic Stage Group tables for reporting. It is expected that testing is performed for grade, HER2, ER, and PR status and that results are reported for all cases of invasive cancer in the United States.</p>

2982<p id="_1949" tabindex="-1">

2983<strong>

2984AJCC Anatomic Stage Groups</strong>

2985</p>

2986<table id="_1952" class="table-default expandable-container">

2987<caption>

2988Table 8. Definition of Anatomic Stage Groups<span class="sup">

2989a</span>

2990</caption>

2991<colgroup>

2992<col width="17.69%">

2993<col width="82.30%">

2994</colgroup>

2995<THead>

2996<tr>

2997<th align="Center" scope="col">

2998Stage</th>

2999<th align="Center" scope="col">

3000TNM</th>

3001</tr>

3002</THead>

3003<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

3004<tr>

3005<td colspan="2">

3006T = primary tumor; N = regional lymph node; M = distant metastasis. </td>

3007</tr>

3008<tr>

3009<td colspan="2">

3010<span class="sup">

3011a</span>

3012Adapted with permission from AJCC: Breast, revised version. In: Amin MB, Edge SB, Greene FL, et al., eds.: <em>

3013AJCC Cancer Staging Manual</em>

3014. 8th ed. New York, NY: Springer, 2017, pp. 4&#8211;96.</td>

3015</tr>

3016<tr>

3017<td colspan="2">

3018Notes: </td>

3019</tr>

3020<tr>

3021<td colspan="2">

30221. T1 includes T1mi.</td>

3023</tr>

3024<tr>

3025<td colspan="2">

30262. T0 and T1 tumors with nodal micrometastases (N1mi) are staged as Stage IB.</td>

3027</tr>

3028<tr>

3029<td colspan="2">

30303. T2, T3, and T4 tumors with nodal micrometastases (N1mi) are staged using the N1 category.</td>

3031</tr>

3032<tr>

3033<td colspan="2">

30344. M0 includes M0(I+).</td>

3035</tr>

3036<tr>

3037<td colspan="2">

30385. The designation pM0 is not valid; any M0 is clinical.</td>

3039</tr>

3040<tr>

3041<td colspan="2">

30426. If a patient presents with M1 disease before receiving neoadjuvant systemic therapy, the stage is Stage

3043IV and remains Stage IV regardless of response to neoadjuvant therapy.

3044</td>

3045</tr>

3046<tr>

3047<td colspan="2">

30487. Stage designation may be changed if postsurgical imaging studies reveal the presence of distant metastases, provided the studies are performed within 4 months of diagnosis in the absence of

3049disease progression, and provided the patient has not received neoadjuvant therapy.

3050</td>

3051</tr>

3052<tr>

3053<td colspan="2">

30548. Staging following neoadjuvant therapy is denoted with a <em>

3055yc</em>

3056 or <em>

3057ypn</em>

3058 prefix to the T and N classification. There is no anatomic stage group assigned if there is a complete pathological response (pCR) to neoadjuvant therapy, for example, ypT0, ypN0, cM0.</td>

3059</tr>

3060</TFoot>

3061<tbody>

3062<tr>

3063<td>

30640</td>

3065<td>

3066Tis, N0, M0</td>

3067</tr>

3068<tr>

3069<td>

3070IA</td>

3071<td>

3072T1, N0, M0</td>

3073</tr>

3074<tr>

3075<td rowspan="2">

3076IB</td>

3077<td>

3078T0, N1mi, M0</td>

3079</tr>

3080<tr>

3081<td>

3082T1, N1mi, M0</td>

3083</tr>

3084<tr>

3085<td rowspan="3">

3086IIA</td>

3087<td>

3088T0, N1, M0</td>

3089</tr>

3090<tr>

3091<td>

3092T1, N1, M0</td>

3093</tr>

3094<tr>

3095<td>

3096T2, N0, M0</td>

3097</tr>

3098<tr>

3099<td rowspan="2">

3100IIB</td>

3101<td>

3102T2, N1, M0</td>

3103</tr>

3104<tr>

3105<td>

3106T3, N0, M0</td>

3107</tr>

3108<tr>

3109<td rowspan="5">

3110IIIA</td>

3111<td>

3112T0, N2, M0</td>

3113</tr>

3114<tr>

3115<td>

3116T1, N2, M0</td>

3117</tr>

3118<tr>

3119<td>

3120T2, N2, M0</td>

3121</tr>

3122<tr>

3123<td>

3124T3, N1, M0</td>

3125</tr>

3126<tr>

3127<td>

3128T3, N2, M0</td>

3129</tr>

3130<tr>

3131<td rowspan="3">

3132IIIB</td>

3133<td>

3134T4, N0, M0</td>

3135</tr>

3136<tr>

3137<td>

3138T4, N1, M0</td>

3139</tr>

3140<tr>

3141<td>

3142T4, N2, M0</td>

3143</tr>

3144<tr>

3145<td>

3146IIIC</td>

3147<td>

3148Any T (Tis, T1, T0, T2, T3, T4), N3, M0</td>

3149</tr>

3150<tr>

3151<td>

3152IV</td>

3153<td>

3154Any T (Tis, T1, T0, T2, T3, T4), Any N (N0, N1mi, N1, N2, N3), M1</td>

3155</tr>

3156</tbody>

3157</table>

3158<p id="_1953" tabindex="-1">

3159<strong>

3160AJCC Prognostic Stage Groups</strong>

3161</p>

3162<p id="_1993" tabindex="-1">

3163The Clinical Prognostic Stage is used for clinical classification and staging of patients in the United States with invasive breast cancer. It uses TNM information based on the patient&#8217;s history, physical examination, imaging results (not required for clinical staging), and biopsies.</p>

3164<table id="_1959" class="table-default expandable-container">

3165<caption>

3166Table 9. Definition of Clinical Prognostic Stage Groups<span class="sup">

3167a</span>

3168</caption>

3169<colgroup>

3170<col width="16.06%">

3171<col width="25.51%">

3172<col width="10.85%">

3173<col width="12.16%">

3174<col width="16.06%">

3175<col width="19.32%">

3176</colgroup>

3177<THead>

3178<tr>

3179<th align="Center" scope="col">

3180TNM</th>

3181<th align="Center" scope="col">

3182Grade </th>

3183<th align="Center" scope="col">

3184HER2 Status</th>

3185<th align="Center" scope="col">

3186ER Status</th>

3187<th align="Center" scope="col">

3188PR Status</th>

3189<th align="Center" scope="col">

3190Stage Group </th>

3191</tr>

3192</THead>

3193<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

3194<tr>

3195<td colspan="6">

3196T = primary tumor; N = regional lymph node; M = distant metastasis.</td>

3197</tr>

3198<tr>

3199<td colspan="6">

3200<span class="sup">

3201a</span>

3202Adapted with permission from AJCC: Breast, revised version. In: Amin MB, Edge SB, Greene FL, et al., eds.: <em>

3203AJCC Cancer Staging Manual</em>

3204. 8th ed. New York, NY: Springer, 2017, pp. 4&#8211;96.</td>

3205</tr>

3206<tr>

3207<td colspan="6">

3208<span class="sup">

3209b</span>

3210T1 includes T1mi.</td>

3211</tr>

3212<tr>

3213<td colspan="6">

3214<span class="sup">

3215c</span>

3216N1 does not include N1mi. T1, N1mi, M0, and T0, N1mi, M0 cancers are included for prognostic staging with T1, N0, M0 cancers of the same prognostic factor status.</td>

3217</tr>

3218<tr>

3219<td colspan="6">

3220<span class="sup">

3221d</span>

3222N1 includes N1mi. T2, T3, and T4 cancers and N1mi are included for prognostic staging with T2, N1;

3223

3224T3, N1; and T4, N1, respectively.

3225</td>

3226</tr>

3227<tr>

3228<td colspan="6">

3229Notes:</td>

3230</tr>

3231<tr>

3232<td colspan="6">

32331. Because N1mi categorization requires evaluation of the entire node, and cannot be assigned on the basis of a fine-needle aspiration or core biopsy, N1mi can only be used with Clinical Prognostic Staging when clinical staging is based on a resected lymph node in the absence of resection of the primary cancer, such as in the situation where sentinel node biopsy is performed before receiving neoadjuvant chemotherapy or endocrine therapy.</td>

3234</tr>

3235<tr>

3236<td colspan="6">

32372. For cases with lymph node involvement with no evidence of primary tumor (e.g., T0, N1, etc.) or with breast ductal carcinoma <em>

3238in situ</em>

3239 (e.g.,Tis, N1, etc.), the grade, human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2), estrogen receptor, and progesterone receptor information from the tumor in the lymph node should be used for assigning stage group.</td>

3240</tr>

3241<tr>

3242<td colspan="6">

32433. For cases where HER2 is determined to be <em>

3244equivocal</em>

3245 by <em>

3246in situ</em>

3247 hybridization (fluorescence <em>

3248in situ</em>

3249 hybridization or chromogenic <em>

3250in situ</em>

3251 hybridization) testing under the

32522013 American Society of Clinical Oncologists/College of American Pathologists HER2 testing guidelines, the HER2-<em>

3253negative</em>

3254 category should be used for staging in the Pathological Prognostic Stage Group table.[<a href="#cit/section_3.4">

32554</a>

3256,<a href="#cit/section_3.5">

32575</a>

3258]</td>

3259</tr>

3260<tr>

3261<td colspan="6">

32624. The prognostic value of these Prognostic Stage Groups is based on populations of persons with breast cancer that have been offered and mostly treated with appropriate endocrine and/or systemic chemotherapy (including anti&#8211;HER2 therapy).</td>

3263</tr>

3264</TFoot>

3265<tbody>

3266<tr>

3267<td>

3268Tis, N0, M0</td>

3269<td>

3270Any (see <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_1978">

4266</section>

4267<section id="_1981">

4268<h3 id="_1981_toc">

4269AJCC Pathological Prognostic Stage Groups</h3>

4270<p id="_1982" tabindex="-1">

4271The Pathological Prognostic Stage applies to patients with invasive breast cancer initially treated with surgery. It includes all information used for clinical staging, surgical findings, and pathological findings following surgery to remove the tumor. Pathological Prognostic Stage is not used for patients treated with neoadjuvant therapy before surgery to remove the tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_3.3">

42723</a>

4273]</p>

4274<table id="_1983" class="table-default expandable-container">

4275<caption>

4276Table 10. Definition of Pathological Prognostic Stage Groups<span class="sup">

4277a</span>

4278</caption>

4279<colgroup>

4280<col width="16.41%">

4281<col width="24.66%">

4282<col width="8.87%">

4283<col width="16.50%">

4284<col width="16.50%">

4285<col width="17.03%">

4286</colgroup>

4287<THead>

4288<tr>

4289<th align="Center" scope="col">

4290TNM</th>

4291<th align="Center" scope="col">

4292Grade</th>

4293<th align="Center" scope="col">

4294HER2 Status</th>

4295<th align="Center" scope="col">

4296ER Status</th>

4297<th align="Center" scope="col">

4298PR Status</th>

4299<th align="Center" scope="col">

4300Stage Group</th>

4301</tr>

4302</THead>

4303<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

4304<tr>

4305<td colspan="6">

4306T = primary tumor; N = regional lymph node; M = distant metastasis.</td>

4307</tr>

4308<tr>

4309<td colspan="6">

4310<span class="sup">

4311a</span>

4312Adapted with permission from AJCC: Breast, revised version. In: Amin MB, Edge SB, Greene FL, et al., eds.: <em>

4313AJCC Cancer Staging Manual</em>

4314. 8th ed. New York, NY: Springer, 2017, pp. 4&#8211;96.</td>

4315</tr>

4316<tr>

4317<td colspan="6">

4318<span class="sup">

4319b</span>

4320T1 includes T1mi.</td>

4321</tr>

4322<tr>

4323<td colspan="6">

4324<span class="sup">

4325c</span>

4326N1 does not include N1mi. T1, N1mi, M0 and T0, N1mi, M0 cancers are included for prognostic staging with T1, N0, M0 cancers of the same prognostic factor status.</td>

4327</tr>

4328<tr>

4329<td colspan="6">

4330<span class="sup">

4331d</span>

4332N1 includes N1mi. T2, T3, and T4 cancers and N1mi are included for prognostic staging with T2, N1;

4333

4334T3, N1; and T4, N1, respectively.

4335</td>

4336</tr>

4337<tr>

4338<td colspan="6">

4339Notes:</td>

4340</tr>

4341<tr>

4342<td colspan="6">

43431. For cases with lymph node involvement with no evidence of primary tumor (e.g., T0, N1, etc.) or with breast ductal carcinoma <em>

4344in situ</em>

4345 (e.g.,Tis, N1, etc.), the grade, human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2), estrogen receptor, and progesterone receptor information from the tumor in the lymph node should be used for assigning stage group.</td>

4346</tr>

4347<tr>

4348<td colspan="6">

43492. For cases where HER2 is determined to be <em>

4350equivocal</em>

4351 by <em>

4352in situ</em>

4353 hybridization (fluorescence <em>

4354in situ</em>

4355 hybridization or chromogenic<em>

4356 in situ</em>

4357 hybridization) testing under the

43582013 American Society of Clinical Oncologists/College of American Pathologists HER2 testing guidelines, the HER2-<em>

4359negative</em>

4360 category should be used for staging in the Pathological Prognostic Stage Group table.[<a href="#cit/section_3.4">

43614</a>

4362,<a href="#cit/section_3.5">

43635</a>

4364]</td>

4365</tr>

4366<tr>

4367<td colspan="6">

43683. The prognostic value of these Prognostic Stage Groups is based on populations of persons with breast cancer that have been offered and mostly treated with appropriate endocrine and/or systemic chemotherapy (including anti&#8211;HER2 therapy).</td>

4369</tr>

4370</TFoot>

4371<tbody>

4372<tr>

4373<td>

4374Tis, N0, M0</td>

4375<td>

4376Any (see <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_1978">

4377Table 6</a>

4378 and <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_1980">

4379Table 7)</a>

4380</td>

4381<td>

4382Any</td>

5198Positive</td>

5199<td>

5200Positive</td>

5201<td>

5202IIIA</td>

5203</tr>

5204<tr>

5205<td>

5206Negative</td>

5207<td>

5208IIIB</td>

5209</tr>

5210<tr>

5211<td rowspan="2">

5212Negative</td>

5213<td>

5214Positive</td>

5215<td>

5216IIIB</td>

5217</tr>

5218<tr>

5219<td>

5220Negative</td>

5221<td>

5222IIIB</td>

5223</tr>

5224<tr>

5226G2</td>

5265</tr>

5285</tr>

5297</tr>

5347</tr>

5350Any T, Any N, M1</td>

5351<td>

5352Any (see <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_1978">

5353Table 6</a>

5354 and <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_1980">

5355Table 7)</a>

5356</td>

5368</section>

5391</div>

5392

5393 </section>

5394

5395

5396

5397 <section id="_1375">

5399 <h2>

5400Treatment of Early/Localized/Operable Breast Cancer</h2>

5401

5402 <div id="_section_1375" class="pdq-sections">

5403<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

5404<h6>

5405In This Section</h6>

5545</nav>

5546<section id="_183">

5547<h3 id="_183_toc">

5548Treatment Option Overview for Early/Localized/Operable Breast Cancer</h3>

5549<p id="_995" tabindex="-1">

5550Treatment options for early, localized, or operable breast cancer may include the following:</p>

5551<div class="pdq-content-list">

5552<p class="pdq-list-title">

5553Surgery:</p>

5554<ol id="_1343">

5555<li>

5556Breast-conserving surgery (lumpectomy) and sentinel lymph node (SLN) biopsy with or without axillary lymph node dissection for positive SLNs.</li>

5557<li>

5558Modified radical mastectomy (removal of the entire breast with axillary dissection of levels I and II) with or without breast reconstruction and sentinel node biopsy with or without axillary lymph node dissection for positive SLNs.</li>

5559</ol>

5560</div>

5561<div class="pdq-content-list">

5562<p class="pdq-list-title">

5563Postoperative radiation therapy:</p>

5564<ol id="_1344">

5565<li>

5566Axillary node&#8211;negative breast cancer (postmastectomy):<div class="pdq-content-list">

5567<ul id="_1001">

5568<li>

5569No additional therapy.</li>

5570<li>

5571Radiation therapy.</li>

5572</ul>

5573</div>

5574</li>

5575<li>

5576Axillary node&#8211;positive breast cancer (postmastectomy):<div class="pdq-content-list">

5577<ul id="_1000">

5578<li>

5579For one to three nodes, the role of regional radiation therapy to the infra/supraclavicular nodes, internal mammary nodes, axillary nodes, and chest wall is unclear.</li>

5580<li>

5581For four or more nodes or extranodal involvement, regional radiation therapy is advised.</li>

5582</ul>

5583</div>

5584</li>

5585<li>

5586Axillary node&#8211;negative or positive breast cancer (post&#8211;breast-conserving therapy):<div class="pdq-content-list">

5587<ul id="_1002">

5588<li>

5589Whole-breast radiation therapy.</li>

5590</ul>

5591</div>

5592</li>

5593</ol>

5594</div>

5595<div class="pdq-content-list">

5596<p class="pdq-list-title">

5597Postoperative systemic therapy:</p>

5598<ol id="_1345">

5599<li>

5600Therapy depends on many factors including stage, grade, molecular status of the tumor (e.g., estrogen receptor [ER], progesterone receptor [PR], human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 [HER2/neu], or triple-negative [ER-negative, PR-negative, and HER2/neu-negative] status). Adjuvant treatment options may include the following:<div class="pdq-content-list">

5601<ul id="_1004">

5602<li>

5603Tamoxifen.</li>

5604<li>

5605Aromatase inhibitor (AI) therapy.</li>

5606<li>

5607Ovarian function suppression. </li>

5608<li>

5609Chemotherapy.</li>

5610</ul>

5611</div>

5612</li>

5613</ol>

5614</div>

5615<div class="pdq-content-list">

5616<p class="pdq-list-title">

5617Preoperative systemic therapy:</p>

5618<ol id="_1346">

5619<li>

5620Chemotherapy.</li>

5621<li>

5622HER2-targeted therapy.</li>

5623<li>

5624Endocrine therapy.</li>

5625</ol>

5626</div>

5627</section>

5628<section id="_1019">

5629<h3 id="_1019_toc">

5630Surgery</h3>

5631<p id="_97" tabindex="-1">

5632Stages I, II, IIIA, and operable IIIC breast cancer often require a multimodal approach to

5633treatment. The diagnostic

5634biopsy and surgical procedure that will be used as primary treatment should be

5635performed as two separate procedures:</p>

5636<div class="pdq-content-list">

5637<ul id="_1137">

5638<li>

5639<strong>

5640Biopsy.</strong>

5641 In many cases, the diagnosis of breast

5642carcinoma is made by core needle biopsy.</li>

5643<li>

5644<strong>

5645Surgical procedure.</strong>

5646 After the presence of a malignancy is

5647confirmed by biopsy, the following surgical treatment options can be discussed

5648with the patient before a therapeutic procedure is selected:<div class="pdq-content-list">

5649<ul id="_1138" class="list-dash">

5650<li>

5651Breast-conserving surgery.</li>

5652<li>

5653Modified radical mastectomy (removal of the entire breast with axillary dissection of levels I and II) with or without breast reconstruction.</li>

5654</ul>

5655</div>

5656 </li>

5657</ul>

5658</div>

5659<p id="_1139" tabindex="-1">

5660To guide the selection of adjuvant therapy, many factors including stage, grade, and molecular status of the tumor (e.g., ER, PR, HER2/neu, or triple-negative status) are considered.[<a href="#cit/section_4.1">

56611</a>

5662-<a href="#cit/section_4.5">
