56635</a>

5664]</p>

5665<section id="_1020">

5666<h4 id="_1020_toc">

5667Locoregional treatment</h4>

5668<p id="_1140" tabindex="-1">

5669Selection of a local therapeutic approach depends on the

5670following:[<a href="#cit/section_4.6">

56716</a>

5672]</p>

5673<div class="pdq-content-list">

5674<ul id="_1141">

5675<li>

5676Location and size of the lesion.</li>

5677<li>

5678Analysis of the mammogram.</li>

5679<li>

5680Breast size.</li>

5681<li>

5682Patient&#8217;s desire to preserve the breast. </li>

5683</ul>

5684</div>

5685<p id="_98" tabindex="-1">

5686Options for surgical management of the primary tumor include the following: </p>

5687<div class="pdq-content-list">

5688<ul id="_1142">

5689<li>

5690<strong>

5691Breast-conserving

5692surgery plus radiation therapy.</strong>

5693 All histological types of invasive breast cancer may be treated with

5694breast-conserving surgery plus radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.7">

56957</a>

5696] However, the presence of inflammatory breast cancer, regardless of histological subtype, is a contraindication to breast-conserving therapy. The presence of

5697multifocal disease in the breast and a history of collagen vascular disease are

5698relative contraindications to breast-conserving therapy.</li>

5699<li>

5700<strong>

5701Mastectomy with or without breast reconstruction.</strong>

5702</li>

5703</ul>

5704</div>

5705<p id="_1143" tabindex="-1">

5706Surgical staging of the axilla should also be performed. </p>

5707<p id="_1144" tabindex="-1">

5708Survival is

5709equivalent with any of these options, as documented in the trial of the European Organisation for Research and Treatment of Cancer (EORTC) (EORTC-10801) [<a href="#cit/section_4.8">

57108</a>

5711] and other prospective randomized trials.[<a href="#cit/section_4.9">

57129</a>

5713-<a href="#cit/section_4.15">

571415</a>

5715] Also, a retrospective study of 753 patients who were divided into three groups based on hormone receptor status (ER positive or PR positive; ER negative and PR negative but HER2/neu positive; and triple negative) found no differences in disease control within the breast in patients treated with standard breast-conserving surgery; however, there are not yet substantive data to support this finding.[<a href="#cit/section_4.16">

571616</a>

5717]</p>

5718<p id="_99" tabindex="-1">

5719The rate of local

5720recurrence in the breast after conservative treatment is low and varies slightly

5721with the surgical technique used (e.g., lumpectomy, quadrantectomy, segmental

5722mastectomy, and others). Whether completely clear

5723microscopic margins are necessary has been debated.[<a href="#cit/section_4.17">

572417</a>

5725-<a href="#cit/section_4.19">

572619</a>

5727]

5728However, a multidisciplinary consensus panel recently used margin width and ipsilateral breast tumor recurrence from a meta-analysis of 33 studies (N = 28,162 patients) as the primary evidence base for a new consensus regarding margins in stage I and stage II breast cancer patients treated with breast-conserving surgery plus radiation therapy. Results of the meta-analysis include the following:[<a href="#cit/section_4.20">

572920</a>

5730]</p>

5731<div class="pdq-content-list">

5732<ul id="_1316">

5733<li>

5734Positive margins (ink on invasive carcinoma or ductal carcinoma <em>

5735in situ</em>

5736) were associated with a twofold increase in the risk of ipsilateral breast tumor recurrence compared with negative margins.</li>

5737<li>

5738More widely clear margins were not found to significantly decrease the rate of ipsilateral breast tumor recurrence compared with no ink on tumor. Thus, it was recommended that the use of no ink on tumor be the new standard for an adequate margin in invasive cancer.</li>

5739<li>

5740There was no evidence that more widely clear margins reduced ipsilateral breast tumor recurrence for young patients or for those with unfavorable biology, lobular cancers, or cancers with an extensive intraductal component.</li>

5741</ul>

5742</div>

5743<p id="_1651" tabindex="-1">

5744For patients undergoing partial mastectomy, margins may be positive after primary surgery, often leading to re-excision. A clinical trial of 235 patients with stage 0 to III breast cancer who underwent partial mastectomy, with or without resection of selective margins, randomly assigned patients to have additional cavity shave margins resected (shave group) or not (no-shave group).[<a href="#cit/section_4.21">

574521</a>

5746] Patients in the shave group had a significantly lower rate of positive margins than those in the no-shave group (19% vs. 34%, <em>

5747P </em>

5748= .01) and a lower rate of second surgery for clearing margins (10% vs. 21%, <em>

5749P </em>

5750= .02).[<a href="#cit/section_4.21">

575121</a>

5752][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5753Level of evidence B3</a>

5754]</p>

5755</section>

5756<section id="_1021">

5757<h4 id="_1021_toc">

5758Axillary lymph node management</h4>

5759<p id="_1317" tabindex="-1">

5760Axillary node status remains the most important predictor of outcome in patients with breast cancer. Evidence is insufficient to recommend that lymph node staging can be omitted in most patients with invasive breast cancer. Several groups have attempted to define a population of women in whom the probability of nodal metastasis is low enough to preclude axillary node biopsy. In these single-institution case series, the prevalence of positive nodes in patients with T1a tumors ranged from 9% to 16%.[<a href="#cit/section_4.22">

576122</a>

5762,<a href="#cit/section_4.23">

576323</a>

5764] Another series reported the incidence of axillary node relapse in patients with T1a tumors treated without axillary lymph node dissection (ALND) was 2%.[<a href="#cit/section_4.24">

576524</a>

5766][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5767Level of evidence C1</a>

5768]</p>

5769<p id="_779" tabindex="-1">

5770The axillary lymph nodes are staged to aid in determining prognosis and

5771therapy. SLN biopsy is the initial standard axillary staging procedure performed in women with invasive breast cancer. The SLN is defined as any node that receives drainage directly from the primary tumor; therefore, allowing for more than one SLN, which is often the case. Studies have shown that the injection of technetium Tc 99m-labeled sulfur colloid, vital blue dye, or both around the tumor or biopsy cavity, or in the subareolar area, and subsequent drainage of these compounds to the axilla results in the identification of the SLN in 92% to 98% of patients.[<a href="#cit/section_4.25">

577225</a>

5773,<a href="#cit/section_4.26">

577426</a>

5775] These reports demonstrate a 97.5% to 100% concordance between SLN biopsy and complete ALND.[<a href="#cit/section_4.27">

577627</a>

5777-<a href="#cit/section_4.30">

577830</a>

5779]</p>

5780<p id="_1147" tabindex="-1">

5781Because of the following body of evidence, SLN biopsy is the standard initial surgical staging procedure of the axilla for women with invasive breast cancer. SLN biopsy alone is associated with less morbidity than axillary lymphadenectomy. </p>

5782<p id="_1148" tabindex="-1">

5783Evidence (SLN biopsy):</p>

5784<div class="pdq-content-list">

5785<ol id="_1149">

5786<li>

5787A randomized trial of 1,031 women compared SLN biopsy followed by ALND when the SLN was positive with ALND in all patients.[<a href="#cit/section_4.31">

578831</a>

5789][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5790Level of evidence A3</a>

5791]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5792<ul id="_1151">

5793<li>

5794Quality of life (QOL) at 1 year (as assessed by the frequency of patients experiencing a clinically significant deterioration in the Trial Outcome Index of the Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy-Breast scale) was superior in the SLN biopsy group (23% deteriorating in the SLN biopsy group vs. 35% in the ALND group; <em>

5795P</em>

5796 = .001). Arm function was also better in the SLN group.</li>

5797</ul>

5798</div>

5799</li>

5800<li>

5801The National Surgical Adjuvant Breast and Bowel Project&#8217;s (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003830">

5802NSABP-B-32</a>

5803 [NCT00003830]) multicenter, phase III trial randomly assigned women (N = 5,611) to undergo either SLN plus ALND or SLN resection alone, with ALND only if the SLNs were positive.[<a href="#cit/section_4.32">

580432</a>

5805][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5806Level of evidence A1</a>

5807]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5808<ul id="_1150">

5809<li>

5810The study showed no detectable difference in overall survival (OS), disease-free survival (DFS), and regional control. OS was 91.8% for SLN plus ALND versus 90.3% for SLN resection alone (<em>

5811P</em>

5812 = .12).</li>

5813</ul>

5814</div>

5815</li>

5816</ol>

5817</div>

5818<p id="_1152" tabindex="-1">

5819Because of the following trial results, ALND is unnecessary after a positive SLN biopsy in patients with limited SLN-positive breast cancer treated with breast conservation or mastectomy, radiation, and systemic therapy.</p>

5820<p id="_1153" tabindex="-1">

5821Evidence (ALND after a positive SLN biopsy in patients with limited SLN-positive breast cancer):</p>

5822<div class="pdq-content-list">

5823<ol id="_1154">

5824<li>

5825A multicenter, randomized clinical trial sought to determine whether ALND is required after an SLN biopsy reveals an SLN metastasis of breast cancer. This phase III noninferiority trial planned to randomly assign 1,900 women with clinical T1 or T2 invasive breast cancer without palpable adenopathy and with one to two SLNs containing metastases identified by frozen section to undergo ALND or no further axillary treatment. All patients underwent lumpectomy, tangential whole-breast radiation therapy, and appropriate systemic therapy; OS was the primary end point. Because of enrollment challenges, a total of 891 women out of a target enrollment of 1,900 women were randomly assigned to one of the two treatment arms.[<a href="#cit/section_4.33">

582633</a>

5827][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5828Level of evidence A1</a>

5829]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5830<ul id="_1155">

5831<li>

5832 At a median follow-up of 6.3 years, the 5-year OS rate was 91.8% (95% confidence interval [CI], 89.1%&#8211;94.5%) with ALND and 92.5% (95% CI, 90.0&#8211;95.1%) with SLN biopsy alone.</li>

5833<li>

5834The 5-year DFS rate (secondary end point) was 82.2% (95% CI, 78.3%&#8211;86.3%) with ALND and 83.9% (95% CI, 80.2%&#8211;87.9%) with SLN biopsy alone.</li>

5835</ul>

5836</div>

5837</li>

5838<li>

5839In a similarly designed trial, 929 women with breast tumors smaller than 5 cm and SLN involvement smaller than 2 mm were randomly assigned to ALND or no ALND.[<a href="#cit/section_4.34">

584034</a>

5841][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5842Level of evidence A1</a>

5843]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5844<ul id="_1156">

5845<li>

5846Patients without axillary dissection had fewer DFS events (hazard ratio [HR], 0.78; 95% CI, 0.55&#8211;1.11).</li>

5847<li>

5848No difference in OS was observed.</li>

5849</ul>

5850</div>

5851</li>

5852<li>

5853The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00014612">

5854AMAROS</a>

5855 trial (NCT00014612) studied ALND and axillary radiation therapy after identification of a positive sentinel node.[<a href="#cit/section_4.35">

585635</a>

5857][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5858Level of evidence A1</a>

5859]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5860<ul id="_1157">

5861<li>

5862ALND and axillary radiation therapy provided excellent and comparable axillary control for patients with T1 or T2 primary breast cancer and no palpable lymphadenopathy who underwent breast-conserving therapy or mastectomy.</li>

5863<li>

5864The use of axillary radiation therapy was also associated with significantly less morbidity.</li>

5865</ul>

5866</div>

5867</li>

5868</ol>

5869</div>

5870<p id="_1158" tabindex="-1">

5871For patients who require an ALND, the standard evaluation usually involves only a level I and II dissection, thereby removing a satisfactory number of nodes for evaluation (i.e., at least 6&#8211;10), while reducing morbidity from the procedure. </p>

5872</section>

5873<section id="_1022">

5874<h4 id="_1022_toc">

5875Breast reconstruction</h4>

5876<p id="_107" tabindex="-1">

5877For patients who opt for a total mastectomy, reconstructive surgery may be

5878performed at the time of the mastectomy (immediate reconstruction)

5879or at some subsequent time (delayed reconstruction).[<a href="#cit/section_4.36">

588036</a>

5881-<a href="#cit/section_4.39">

588239</a>

5883] Breast contour can

5884be restored by the following:</p>

5885<div class="pdq-content-list">

5886<ul id="_1161">

5887<li>

5888<strong>

5889Submuscular insertion of an artificial implant

5890(silicone or saline filled).</strong>

5891 If an immediate implant cannot technically be performed,

5892a tissue expander can be inserted beneath the pectoral muscle. Saline is

5893injected into the expander to stretch the tissues for a period of weeks or

5894months until the desired volume is obtained. The tissue expander is then

5895replaced by a permanent implant. For more information on breast implants, see the <a href="https://www.fda.gov/medical-devices/implants-and-prosthetics/breast-implants" title="https://www.fda.gov/medical-devices/implants-and-prosthetics/breast-implants">

5896U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA)</a>

5897. </li>

5898<li>

5899<strong>

5900Rectus muscle or other flap.</strong>

5901 Muscle flaps require a

5902considerably more complicated and prolonged operative procedure, and blood

5903transfusions may be required.

5904</li>

5905</ul>

5906</div>

5907<p id="_648" tabindex="-1">

5908After breast reconstruction, radiation

5909therapy can be delivered to the chest wall and regional nodes in either the

5910adjuvant or local recurrent disease setting. Radiation therapy after

5911reconstruction with a breast prosthesis may affect cosmesis, and the incidence

5912of capsular fibrosis, pain, or the need for implant removal may be

5913increased.[<a href="#cit/section_4.40">

591440</a>

5915]</p>

5916</section>

5917</section>

5918<section id="_1023">

5919<h3 id="_1023_toc">

5920Postoperative Radiation Therapy</h3>

5921<p id="_436" tabindex="-1">

5922Radiation therapy is regularly used after breast-conserving surgery. Radiation therapy is also indicated for high-risk postmastectomy patients. The main goal of adjuvant radiation therapy is to eradicate residual disease, reducing local recurrence.[<a href="#cit/section_4.41">

592341</a>

5924]</p>

5925<section id="_1024">

5926<h4 id="_1024_toc">

5927Post&#8211;breast-conserving surgery</h4>

5928<p id="_438" tabindex="-1">

5929For women who are treated with breast-conserving surgery without radiation therapy, the risk of recurrence in the conserved breast is substantial (&gt;20%), even in confirmed axillary lymph node&#8211;negative women.[<a href="#cit/section_4.42">

593042</a>

5931] Although all trials assessing the role of radiation therapy in breast-conserving therapy have shown highly statistically significant reductions in local recurrence rate, no single trial has demonstrated a statistically significant reduction in mortality. However, a large meta-analysis demonstrated a significant reduction in risk of recurrence and breast cancer death.[<a href="#cit/section_4.43">

593243</a>

5933] Thus, evidence supports the use of whole-breast radiation therapy after breast-conserving surgery. </p>

5934<p id="_1168" tabindex="-1">

5935Evidence (breast-conserving surgery followed by radiation therapy):</p>

5936<div class="pdq-content-list">

5937<ol id="_1169">

5938<li>

5939<p id="_1170" tabindex="-1">

5940A 2011 meta-analysis of 17 clinical trials performed by the Early Breast Cancer Trialists&#8217; Collaborative Group (EBCTCG), which included over 10,000 women with early-stage breast cancer, supported whole-breast radiation therapy after breast-conserving surgery.[<a href="#cit/section_4.43">

594143</a>

5942][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5943Level of evidence A1</a>

5944] </p>

5945<div class="pdq-content-list">

5946<ul id="_1171">

5947<li>

5948Whole-breast radiation therapy resulted in a significant reduction in the 10-year risk of recurrence compared with breast-conserving surgery alone (19% for whole-breast radiation therapy vs. 35% for breast-conserving surgery alone; relative risk [RR], 0.52; 95% CI, 0.48&#8211;0.56) and a significant reduction in the 15-year risk of breast cancer death (21% for whole-breast radiation therapy vs. 25% for breast-conserving surgery alone; RR, 0.82; 95% CI, 0.75&#8211;0.90).</li>

5949</ul>

5950</div>

5951</li>

5952</ol>

5953</div>

5954<p id="_938" tabindex="-1">

5955Regarding radiation dosing and schedule, the following has been noted:</p>

5956<div class="pdq-content-list">

5957<ul id="_1172">

5958<li>

5959<strong>

5960Whole-breast radiation dose. </strong>

5961Conventional whole-breast radiation therapy is delivered to the whole breast (with or without regional lymph nodes) in 1.8 Gy to 2 Gy daily fractions over about 5 to 6 weeks to a total dose of 45 Gy to 50 Gy. </li>

5962<li>

5963<strong>

5964Radiation boost. </strong>

5965A further radiation boost is commonly given to the tumor bed. Two randomized trials conducted in Europe have shown that using boosts of 10 Gy to 16 Gy reduces the risk of local recurrence from 4.6% to 3.6% at 3 years (<em>

5966P</em>

5967 = .044),[<a href="#cit/section_4.44">

596844</a>

5969][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5970Level of evidence B1</a>

5971] and from 7.3% to 4.3% at 5 years (<em>

5972P</em>

5973 &lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_4.45">

597445</a>

5975][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5976Level of evidence B1</a>

5977] Results were similar after a median follow-up of 17.2 years.[<a href="#cit/section_4.46">

597846</a>

5979][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5980Level of evidence B1</a>

5981] If a boost is used, it can be delivered either by external-beam radiation therapy, generally with electrons, or by using an interstitial radioactive implant.[<a href="#cit/section_4.47">

598247</a>

5983] Administering a radiation boost may, however, be associated with unfavorable quality-of-life outcomes.[<a href="#cit/section_4.48">

598448</a>

5985]</li>

5986<li>

5987<strong>

5988Radiation schedule. </strong>

5989Some studies show that a shorter fractionation schedule of 42.5 Gy over 3 to 4 weeks is a reasonable alternative for some patients with breast cancer.<div class="pdq-content-list">

5990<ul id="_1173" class="list-dash">

5991<li>

5992A noninferiority trial of 1,234 randomly assigned patients with node-negative invasive breast cancer analyzed locoregional recurrence rates with conventional whole-breast radiation therapy versus a shorter fractionation schedule.[<a href="#cit/section_4.49">

599349</a>

5994] The 10-year locoregional relapse rate among women who received shorter fractionation was not inferior to conventional whole-breast radiation therapy (6.2% for a shorter fractionation schedule vs. 6.7% for whole-breast radiation therapy with absolute difference, 0.5 percentage points; 95% CI, &#8722;2.5 to 3.5).[<a href="#cit/section_4.49">

599549</a>

5996][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5997Level of evidence B1</a>

5998</li>

5999<li>

6000Similarly, a combined analysis of the randomized United Kingdom Standardisation of Breast Radiotherapy trials (START), (START-A [ISRCTN59368779]) and START-B [ISRCTN59368779]), which collectively randomly assigned 4,451 women with completely excised invasive (pT1&#8211;3a, pN0&#8211;1, M0) early-stage breast cancer after breast-conserving surgery to receive conventional whole-breast radiation therapy dosing or shorter fractionation, revealed no difference in a 10-year locoregional relapse rate.[<a href="#cit/section_4.50">

600150</a>

6002][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6003Level of evidence B1</a>

6004]</li>

6005<li>

6006 A meta-analysis that included the three trials mentioned above plus six others confirmed that differences with respect to local recurrence or cosmesis between shorter and conventional fractionation schedules were neither statistically nor clinically significant.[<a href="#cit/section_4.51">

600751</a>

6008]</li>

6009</ul>

6010</div>

6011<p id="_1174" tabindex="-1">

6012 Additional studies are needed to determine whether shorter fractionation is appropriate for women with higher nodal disease burden.[<a href="#cit/section_4.50">

601350</a>

6014]</p>

6015</li>

6016</ul>

6017</div>

6018</section>

6019<section id="_1602">

6020<h4 id="_1602_toc">

6021Regional nodal irradiation</h4>

6022<p id="_1603" tabindex="-1">

6023Regional nodal irradiation is routinely given postmastectomy to patients with involved lymph nodes; however, its role in patients who have breast-conserving surgery and whole-breast irradiation has been less clear. A randomized trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00005957">

6024NCT00005957</a>

6025) of 1,832 women showed that administering regional nodal irradiation after breast-conserving surgery and whole-breast irradiation reduces the risk of recurrence (10-year DFS rate, 82.0% vs. 77.0%; HR, 0.76; 95% CI, 0.61&#8211;0.94; <em>

6026P</em>

6027 = .01) but does not affect survival (10-year OS rate, 82.8% vs. 81.8%; HR, 0.91; 95% CI, 0.72&#8211;1.13; <em>

6028P</em>

6029 = .38).[<a href="#cit/section_4.52">

603052</a>

6031][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6032Level of evidence A1</a>

6033] </p>

6034<p id="_1720" tabindex="-1">

6035Similar findings were reported from the EORTC trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002851">

6036NCT00002851</a>

6037). Women with a centrally or medially located primary tumor with or without axillary node involvement, or an externally located tumor with axillary involvement, were randomly assigned to receive whole-breast or thoracic-wall irradiation in addition to regional nodal irradiation or not. Breast-conserving surgery was performed for 76.1% of the study population, and the remaining study population underwent mastectomy. No improvement in OS was seen at 10 years among patients who underwent regional nodal irradiation when compared with patients who did not undergo regional nodal radiation (82.3% vs. 80.7%, <em>

6038P</em>

6039 = .06). Distant DFS was improved among patients who underwent regional nodal irradiation when compared with patients who did not undergo regional nodal irradiation (78% vs. 75%, <em>

6040P</em>

6041 = .02).[<a href="#cit/section_4.53">

604253</a>

6043][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6044Level of evidence A1</a>

6045]</p>

6046<p id="_1727" tabindex="-1">

6047A meta-analysis that combined the results of the two trials mentioned above found a marginally statistically significant difference in OS (HR, 0.88; 95% CI, 0.78&#8211;0.99; <em>

6048P</em>

6049 = .034; absolute difference, 1.6% at 5 years).[<a href="#cit/section_4.54">

605054</a>

6051] </p>

6052</section>

6053<section id="_1025">

6054<h4 id="_1025_toc">

6055Postmastectomy</h4>

6056<p id="_110" tabindex="-1">

6057Postoperative chest wall and regional lymph node adjuvant radiation therapy has traditionally been given

6058to selected patients considered at high risk of locoregional failure

6059after mastectomy.

6060Patients at highest risk of local recurrence have one or more of the following:[<a href="#cit/section_4.55">

606155</a>

6062-<a href="#cit/section_4.57">

606357</a>

6064] </p>

6065<div class="pdq-content-list">

6066<ul id="_1175">

6067<li>

6068Four or more

6069positive axillary nodes.</li>

6070<li>

6071Grossly evident extracapsular nodal extension.</li>

6072<li>

6073Large

6074primary tumors.</li>

6075<li>

6076Very close or positive deep margins of resection of the

6077primary tumor.</li>

6078</ul>

6079</div>

6080<p id="_1176" tabindex="-1">

6081In this high-risk group, radiation therapy can decrease locoregional recurrence, even among patients who receive adjuvant chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.58">

608258</a>

6083]</p>

6084<p id="_441" tabindex="-1">

6085Patients with one to three involved nodes without any of the high-risk factors are at low risk of local recurrence, and the value of routine use of adjuvant radiation therapy in this setting is unclear.</p>

6086<p id="_1319" tabindex="-1">

6087Evidence (postoperative radiation therapy in patients with one to three involved lymph nodes):</p>

6088<div class="pdq-content-list">

6089<ol id="_1320">

6090<li>

6091The 2005 EBCTCG meta-analysis of 42,000 women in 78 randomized treatment comparisons indicated that radiation therapy is beneficial, regardless of the number of lymph nodes involved.[<a href="#cit/section_4.41">

609241</a>

6093][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6094Level of evidence A1</a>

6095]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6096<ul id="_1321">

6097<li>

6098For women with node-positive disease postmastectomy and axillary clearance (removal of axillary lymph nodes and surrounding fat), radiation therapy reduced the 5-year local recurrence risk from 23% to 6% (absolute gain, 17%; 95% CI, 15.2%&#8211;18.8%). This translated into a significant reduction (<em>

6099P</em>

6100 = .002) in breast cancer mortality, 54.7% versus 60.1%, with an absolute gain of 5.4% (95% CI, 2.9%&#8211;7.9%).</li>

6101<li>

6102In subgroup analyses, the 5-year local recurrence rate was reduced by 12% (95% CI, 8%&#8211;16%) for women with one to three involved lymph nodes and by 14% (95% CI, 10%&#8211;18%) for women with four or more involved lymph nodes. In an updated meta-analysis of 1,314 women with axillary dissection and one to three positive nodes, radiation therapy reduced locoregional recurrence (2-sided <em>

6103P</em>

6104 &lt; .00001), overall recurrence (RR, 0.68; 95% CI, 0.57&#8211;0.82; 2-sided <em>

6105P</em>

6106 = .00006), and breast cancer mortality (RR, 0.80; 95% CI, 0.67&#8211;0.95; 2-sided <em>

6107P</em>

6108 = .01).[<a href="#cit/section_4.59">

610959</a>

6110][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6111Level of evidence A1</a>

6112]</li>

6113<li>

6114In contrast, for women at low risk of local recurrence with node-negative disease, the absolute reduction in 5-year local recurrence was only 4% (<em>

6115P</em>

6116 = .002; 95% CI, 1.8%&#8211;6.2%), and there was not a statistically significant reduction in 15-year breast cancer mortality (absolute gain, 1.0%; <em>

6117P</em>

6118 &gt; .1; 95% CI, -0.8%&#8211;2.8%).</li>

6119</ul>

6120</div>

6121</li>

6122</ol>

6123</div>

6124<p id="_1361" tabindex="-1">

6125Further, an analysis of NSABP trials showed that even in patients with large (&gt;5 cm) primary tumors and negative axillary lymph nodes, the risk of isolated locoregional recurrence was low enough (7.1%) that routine locoregional radiation therapy was not warranted.[<a href="#cit/section_4.60">

612660</a>

6127]</p>

6128</section>

6129<section id="_269">

6130<h4 id="_269_toc">

6131Timing of postoperative radiation therapy</h4>

6132<p id="_171" tabindex="-1">

6133The optimal sequence of adjuvant chemotherapy and radiation therapy after

6134breast-conserving surgery has been studied. Based on the following studies, delaying radiation therapy for several months after

6135breast-conserving surgery, until the completion of adjuvant chemotherapy, does not appear to have a negative impact on overall outcome. Additionally, initiating chemotherapy soon after breast-conserving surgery may be preferable for patients at high risk of distant dissemination.</p>

6136<p id="_1162" tabindex="-1">

6137Evidence (timing of postoperative radiation therapy):</p>

6138<div class="pdq-content-list">

6139<ol id="_1163">

6140<li>

6141 In a randomized trial, patients

6142received one of the following regimens:[<a href="#cit/section_4.61">

614361</a>

6144][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6145Level of evidence A1</a>

6146]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6147<ol id="_1322" class="lower-alpha">

6148<li>

6149Chemotherapy first (n = 122), consisting of cyclophosphamide, methotrexate, fluorouracil (5-FU), and prednisone (CMFP) plus doxorubicin

6150repeated every 21 days for four cycles, followed by breast radiation.</li>

6151<li>

6152Breast

6153radiation first (n = 122), followed by the same chemotherapy.</li>

6154</ol>

6155</div>

6156<p id="_1347" tabindex="-1">

6157The following results were observed:</p>

6158<div class="pdq-content-list">

6159<ul id="_1164">

6160<li>

6161With a median

6162follow-up of 5 years, OS was 73% for the radiation-first group

6163and 81% for the chemotherapy-first group (<em>

6164P</em>

6165 = .11).</li>

6166<li>

6167The 5-year crude rate of first recurrence by site was 5% in the radiation-first group and

616814% in the chemotherapy-first group for local recurrence

6169and 32% in the radiation-first group and 20% in the chemotherapy-first group for distant or regional recurrence or both. This difference in

6170the pattern of recurrence was of borderline statistical significance (<em>

6171P</em>

6172 = .07).</li>

6173<li>

6174Further analyses revealed that differences in recurrence patterns persisted for

6175most subgroups except for those who had either negative tumor

6176margins or one to three positive lymph nodes. For these two subgroups, sequence

6177assignment made little difference in local or distant recurrence rates,

6178although the statistical power of these subgroup analyses was low.</li>

6179<li>

6180Potential

6181explanations for the increase in distant recurrence noted in the radiation-first group are that chemotherapy was delayed for a median of 17 weeks

6182after surgery, and that this group received lower chemotherapy dosages because of

6183increased myelosuppression.

6184</li>

6185</ul>

6186</div>

6187</li>

6188<li>

6189Two additional randomized trials, though not specifically designed to address

6190the timing of radiation therapy and adjuvant chemotherapy, do add useful

6191information.<div class="pdq-content-list">

6192<ol id="_1165" class="lower-alpha">

6193<li>

6194 In the NSABP-B-15 trial, patients who had undergone

6195breast-conserving surgery received either one course of cyclophosphamide, methotrexate, and 5-FU (CMF) (n = 194) followed by

6196radiation therapy followed by five additional cycles of CMF, or they received four

6197cycles of doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide (AC) (n = 199) followed by radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.62">

619862</a>

6199][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6200Level of evidence A1</a>

6201]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6202<ul id="_1166">

6203<li>

6204No differences in

6205DFS, distant DFS, and OS were

6206observed between these two arms.</li>

6207</ul>

6208</div>

6209</li>

6210<li>

6211The International

6212Breast Cancer Study Group trials VI and VII also varied the timing of

6213radiation therapy with CMF adjuvant chemotherapy and reported results similar to NSABP-B-15.[<a href="#cit/section_4.63">

621463</a>

6215] </li>

6216</ol>

6217</div>

6218</li>

6219</ol>

6220</div>

6221<p id="_1167" tabindex="-1">

6222These studies showed

6223that delaying radiation therapy for 2 to 7 months after surgery had no effect

6224on the rate of local recurrence.

6225 These findings have been confirmed in a meta-analysis.[<a href="#cit/section_4.64">

622664</a>

6227][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6228Level of evidence A1</a>

6229]</p>

6230<p id="_683" tabindex="-1">

6231A phase III trial evaluated trastuzumab in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer. In an unplanned analysis, there was no associated increase in acute adverse events or frequency of cardiac events in patients who received concurrent adjuvant radiation therapy and trastuzumab.[<a href="#cit/section_4.65">

623265</a>

6233] Therefore, delivering radiation therapy concomitantly with trastuzumab appears to be safe and avoids additional delay in radiation therapy treatment initiation.</p>

6234</section>

6235<section id="_1026">

6236<h4 id="_1026_toc">

6237Late toxic effects

6238of radiation</h4>

6239<p id="_116" tabindex="-1">

6240Late toxic effects of radiation therapy are uncommon and can be minimized with current

6241radiation delivery techniques and careful delineation of the target

6242volume. Late effects of radiation include

6243the following:

6244</p>

6245<div class="pdq-content-list">

6246<ul id="_1178">

6247<li>

6248<strong>

6249Radiation pneumonitis. </strong>

6250In a retrospective analysis of 1,624 women treated with conservative surgery and

6251adjuvant breast radiation at a single institution, the overall incidence of

6252symptomatic radiation pneumonitis was 1.0% at a median follow-up of 77 months.[<a href="#cit/section_4.66">

625366</a>

6254]

6255The incidence of pneumonitis increased to 3.0% with the use of a supraclavicular

6256radiation field and to 8.8% when concurrent chemotherapy was administered.

6257The incidence was only 1.3% in patients who received sequential

6258chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.66">

625966</a>

6260][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6261Level of evidence C1</a>

6262]</li>

6263<li>

6264<strong>

6265Cardiac events. </strong>

6266Controversy existed as to whether adjuvant radiation therapy to the left chest wall or breast, with or without inclusion of the regional lymphatics, was associated with increased cardiac mortality. In women treated with radiation therapy before 1980, an increased cardiac death rate was noted after 10 to 15 years, compared with women with nonradiated or right-side-only radiated breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_4.58">

626758</a>

6268,<a href="#cit/section_4.67">

626967</a>

6270-<a href="#cit/section_4.69">

627169</a>

6272] This was probably caused by the radiation received by the left myocardium.<p id="_1179" tabindex="-1">

6273Modern radiation therapy techniques introduced in the 1990s minimized deep radiation to the underlying myocardium when left-sided chest wall or left-breast radiation was used. Cardiac mortality decreased accordingly.[<a href="#cit/section_4.70">

627470</a>

6275,<a href="#cit/section_4.71">

627671</a>

6277] </p>

6278<p id="_1180" tabindex="-1">

6279An analysis of the National Cancer Institute&#8217;s Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results Program (SEER) data from 1973 to 1989 reviewed deaths caused by ischemic heart disease in women who received breast or chest wall radiation. The analysis showed no increased death rate resulting from ischemic heart disease in women who received left chest wall or breast radiation since 1980.[<a href="#cit/section_4.72">

628072</a>

6281,<a href="#cit/section_4.73">

628273</a>

6283][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6284Level of evidence C1</a>

6285]</p>

6286</li>

6287<li>

6288<strong>

6289Arm lymphedema. </strong>

6290Lymphedema remains a major quality-of-life

6291concern for patients with breast cancer. Single-modality treatment of the axilla

6292(surgery or radiation) is associated with a low incidence of arm edema.

6293In patients who receive axillary dissection, adjuvant radiation therapy increases the risk of arm edema. Edema occurs in 2% to 10% of patients who receive axillary dissection alone, compared with 13% to 18% of patients who receive axillary dissection and adjuvant radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.74">

629474</a>

6295-<a href="#cit/section_4.76">

629676</a>

6297] For more information, see <a href="/about-cancer/treatment/side-effects/lymphedema/lymphedema-hp-pdq">

6298Lymphedema</a>

6299.

6300</li>

6301<li>

6302<strong>

6303Brachial plexopathy. </strong>

6304Radiation injury to the brachial plexus after adjuvant nodal radiation therapy is

6305a rare clinical entity for patients with breast cancer. In a single-institution

6306study using current radiation techniques, 449 breast cancer patients treated

6307with postoperative radiation therapy to the breast and regional lymphatics were

6308monitored for 5.5 years to assess the rate of brachial plexus injury.[<a href="#cit/section_4.77">

630977</a>

6310] The

6311diagnosis of such injury was made clinically with computerized tomography (CT) to

6312distinguish radiation injury from tumor recurrence. When 54 Gy in 30 fractions

6313was delivered to the regional nodes, the incidence of symptomatic brachial

6314plexus injury was 1.0%, compared with 5.9% when increased fraction sizes (45 Gy

6315in 15 fractions) were used.

6316</li>

6317<li>

6318<strong>

6319Contralateral breast cancer. </strong>

6320One report suggested an increase in contralateral breast

6321cancer for women younger than 45 years who received chest wall

6322radiation therapy after mastectomy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.78">

632378</a>

6324] No increased risk of contralateral

6325breast cancer occurred in women aged 45 years and older who received radiation

6326therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.79">

632779</a>

6328] Techniques to minimize the radiation dose to the contralateral

6329breast are used to keep the absolute risk as low as possible.[<a href="#cit/section_4.80">

633080</a>

6331]</li>

6332<li>

6333<strong>

6334Risk of second malignancy. </strong>

6335The rate of second malignancy after adjuvant radiation therapy is very

6336low. Sarcomas in the treated field are rare, with a long-term risk of 0.2%

6337at 10 years.[<a href="#cit/section_4.81">

633881</a>

6339] In

6340nonsmokers, the risk of lung cancer as a result of radiation exposure during

6341treatment is minimal when current dosimetry techniques are used. Smokers,

6342however, may have a small increased risk of lung cancer in the ipsilateral

6343lung.[<a href="#cit/section_4.82">

634482</a>

6345]</li>

6346</ul>

6347</div>

6348</section>

6349</section>

6350<section id="_2226">

6351<h3 id="_2226_toc">

6352Partial Breast Irradiation </h3>

6353<p id="_2227" tabindex="-1">

6354Evidence (partial breast irradiation):</p>

6355<div class="pdq-content-list">

6356<ol id="_2228">

6357<li>

6358 The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00282035">

6359RAPID</a>

6360 trial (NCT00282035) randomly assigned 2,135 women aged 40 years or older with ductal carcinoma <em>

6361in situ</em>

6362 or node-negative breast cancer treated by breast-conserving surgery to receive either external-beam accelerated partial breast irradiation (APBI) (38.5 Gy in ten fractions delivered twice per day over 5&#8211;8 days) or whole-breast irradiation (42.5 Gy in 16 fractions delivered once per day over 21 days, or 50 Gy in 25 fractions once per day over 35 days).[<a href="#cit/section_4.83">

636383</a>

6364] Sixty-five ipsilateral breast tumor recurrences were observed, 37 in the APBI group, and 28 in the whole-breast irradiation group. <div class="pdq-content-list">

6365<ul id="_2231">

6366<li>

6367In patients treated with APBI, the 5-year cumulative rate of ipsilateral breast tumor recurrence was 2.3% (95% CI, 1.4%&#8211;3.2%) and the 8-year cumulative rate was 3.0% (95% CI, 1.9%&#8211;4.0%). </li>

6368<li>

6369In patients treated with whole-breast irradiation, the 5-year cumulative rate of ipsilateral breast tumor recurrence was 1.7% (range, 0.9%&#8211;2.5%) and the 8-year cumulative rate was 2.8% (range, 1.8%&#8211;3.9%). </li>

6370<li>

6371The HR for APBI versus whole-breast irradiation was 1.27 (90% CI, 0.84&#8211;1.91). </li>

6372<li>

6373Thus, the upper bound of the estimated 90% CI did not exceed the noninferiority margin of 2.02. The APBI arm was associated with less short-term, but more long-term toxicity.[<a href="#cit/section_4.83">

637483</a>

6375][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6376Level of evidence B1</a>

6377]</li>

6378</ul>

6379</div>

6380</li>

6381<li>

6382 The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00103181">

6383NSABP B-39/RTOG 0413</a>

6384 trial (NCT00103181) randomly assigned 4,216 women to whole-breast irradiation or APBI.[<a href="#cit/section_4.84">

638584</a>

6386] Whole-breast irradiation was delivered in 25 daily fractions of 50 Gy over 5 weeks, with or without a supplemental boost to the tumor bed, and APBI was delivered as 34 Gy of brachytherapy or 38.5 Gy of external-bream radiation therapy in 10 fractions, over 5 treatment days within an 8-day period. <div class="pdq-content-list">

6387<ul id="_2232">

6388<li>

6389At a median follow-up of 10.2 years (interquartile range, 7.5&#8211;11.5), 90 (4%) of 2,089 women eligible for the primary outcome in the APBI group and 71 (3%) of 2,036 women in the whole-breast irradiation group had an ipsilateral breast tumor recurrence (HR, 1.22; 90% CI, 0.94&#8211;1.58). The results did not meet the prespecified criterion for equivalence, an HR of 1.50 or less. </li>

6390<li>

6391Toxicity was not substantially different between the arms.[<a href="#cit/section_4.84">

639284</a>

6393][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6394Level of evidence B1</a>

6395]</li>

6396</ul>

6397</div>

6398</li>

6399</ol>

6400</div>

6401</section>

6402<section id="_1027">

6403<h3 id="_1027_toc">

6404Postoperative Systemic Therapy</h3>

6405<p id="_714" tabindex="-1">

6406Stage and molecular features determine the need for adjuvant systemic therapy and the choice of modalities used. The selection of

6407therapy is most appropriately based on knowledge of an individual&#8217;s

6408risk of tumor recurrence balanced against the short-term and long-term risks of

6409adjuvant treatment. This approach allows clinicians to help individuals

6410determine if the gains anticipated from treatment are reasonable for

6411their situation. </p>

6412<p id="_2379" tabindex="-1">

6413Many of the studies that support the use of chemotherapy after surgery were conducted before the widespread practice of testing for HER2. In general, their results are still applicable to the management of patients with all three subtypes of breast cancer. Exceptions are described below.</p>

6414<section id="_2380">

6415<h4 id="_2380_toc">

6416HER2/neu-negative hormone receptor&#8211;positive breast cancer</h4>

6417<p id="_2381" tabindex="-1">

6418The EBCTCG meta-analysis analyzed 11 trials that began from 1976 to 1989 in

6419which women were randomly assigned to receive regimens containing anthracyclines (e.g., doxorubicin or epirubicin) or CMF (cyclophosphamide, methotrexate, and 5-FU). The result of the overview analysis comparing CMF and

6420anthracycline-containing regimens suggested a slight advantage for the

6421anthracycline regimens in both premenopausal and postmenopausal women. The HER2 status of the women in these trials was unknown.[<a href="#cit/section_4.85">

642285</a>

6423]</p>

6424<p id="_2382" tabindex="-1">

6425Several trials have addressed the benefit of adding a taxane (paclitaxel or docetaxel) to an anthracycline-based adjuvant chemotherapy regimen.[<a href="#cit/section_4.86">

642686</a>

6427-<a href="#cit/section_4.90">

642890</a>

6429]</p>

6430<p id="_2383" tabindex="-1">

6431A literature-based meta-analysis of 13 studies demonstrated that the inclusion of a taxane improved both DFS and OS (DFS: HR, 0.83; 95% CI, 0.79&#8211;0.87; <em>

6432P</em>

6433 &lt; .001; OS: HR, 0.85; 95% CI, 0.79&#8211;0.91; <em>

6434P</em>

6435 &lt; .001). Five-year absolute survival differences were 5% for DFS and 3% for OS, in favor of taxane-containing regimens.[<a href="#cit/section_4.86">

643686</a>

6437][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6438Level of evidence A1</a>

6439]</p>

6440<p id="_2384" tabindex="-1">

6441A number of studies have addressed the optimal chemotherapy schedule and taxane selection.</p>

6442<p id="_2385" tabindex="-1">

6443An Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group&#8211;led intergroup trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00004125">

6444E1199</a>

6445 [NCT00004125]) involving 4,950 patients compared, in a factorial design, two schedules (weekly and every 3 weeks) of the two drugs (docetaxel vs. paclitaxel) after standard-dose AC chemotherapy given every 3 weeks.[<a href="#cit/section_4.91">

644691</a>

6447][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6448Level of evidence A1</a>

6449] Study findings include the following:</p>

6450<div class="pdq-content-list">

6451<ul id="_2386">

6452<li>

6453There was no difference observed in the overall comparison of docetaxel to paclitaxel with regard to DFS (odds ratio [OR], 1.03; 95% CI, 0.91&#8211;1.16; <em>

6454P</em>

6455 = .61) or between the 1-week and 3-week schedules (OR, 1.06; 95% CI, 0.94&#8211;1.20; <em>

6456P</em>

6457 = .33).</li>

6458<li>

6459There was a significant association between the drug administered and schedule for both DFS (0.003) and OS (0.01). Thus, compared with paclitaxel given every 3 weeks, paclitaxel given weekly improved both DFS (OR, 1.27; 95% CI, 1.01&#8211;1.57; <em>

6460P</em>

6461 = .006) and OS (OR, 1.32; 95% CI, 1.02&#8211;1.72; <em>

6462P</em>

6463 = .01).</li>

6464<li>

6465Docetaxel given every 3 weeks was also superior in DFS to paclitaxel given every 3 weeks (OR, 1.23; 95% CI, 1.00&#8211;1.52; <em>

6466P</em>

6467 = .02), but the difference was not statistically significant for OS (OR, 1.13; 95% CI, 0.88&#8211;1.46; <em>

6468P</em>

6469 = .25).</li>

6470<li>

6471Docetaxel given weekly was not superior to paclitaxel given every 3 weeks. There was no stated <em>

6472a priori</em>

6473 basis for expecting that varying the schedule of administration would have opposite effects for the two drugs.</li>

6474</ul>

6475</div>

6476<p id="_2387" tabindex="-1">

6477Several studies sought to determine whether decreasing the duration between chemotherapy cycles could improve clinical outcomes. The overall results of these studies support the use of dose-dense chemotherapy for women with HER2-negative breast cancer.</p>

6478<p id="_2388" tabindex="-1">

6479Evidence (administration of dose-dense chemotherapy in women with HER2-negative breast cancer):</p>

6480<div class="pdq-content-list">

6481<ol id="_2389">

6482<li>

6483A U.S. intergroup trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003088">

6484CALGB-9741</a>

6485 [NCT00003088]) of 2,005 node-positive patients compared, in a 2 &#215; 2 factorial design, the use of concurrent AC followed by paclitaxel with sequential doxorubicin, paclitaxel, and cyclophosphamide given every 2 weeks with filgrastim or every 3 weeks.[<a href="#cit/section_4.92">

648692</a>

6487][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6488Level of evidence A1</a>

6489] <div class="pdq-content-list">

6490<ul id="_2390">

6491<li>

6492At a median follow-up of 68 months, dose-dense treatment improved DFS, the primary end point, in all patient populations (HR, 0.80; <em>

6493P</em>

6494 = .018), but not OS (HR, 0.85; <em>

6495P</em>

6496 = .12).[<a href="#cit/section_4.93">

649793</a>

6498][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6499Level of evidence A1</a>

6500]</li>

6501<li>

6502There was no interaction between density and sequence.</li>

6503<li>

6504Severe neutropenia was less frequent in patients who received the dose-dense regimens.[<a href="#cit/section_4.94">

650594</a>

6506][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6507Level of evidence A1</a>

6508]</li>

6509</ul>

6510</div>

6511</li>

6512<li>

6513An Italian trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00433420">

6514NCT00433420</a>

6515) compared two versus three weekly doses of epirubicin plus cyclophosphamide (with or without 5-FU) in a factorial design, with a result similar to a U.S. intergroup trial; however, this trial also demonstrated a difference in OS.[<a href="#cit/section_4.95">

651695</a>

6517]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6518<ul id="_2391">

6519<li>

6520For the dose-density comparison, the rate of DFS at 5 years was 81% (95% CI, 79%&#8211;84%) in patients treated every 2 weeks and 76% (95% CI, 74%&#8211;79%) in patients treated every 3 weeks (HR, 0.77; 95% CI, 0.65&#8211;0.92; <em>

6521P</em>

6522 = .004). </li>

6523<li>

6524OS rates at 5 years were 94% (95% CI, 93%&#8211;96%) and 89% (95% CI, 87%&#8211;91%; HR, 0.65; 0.51&#8211;0.84; <em>

6525P</em>

6526 = .001).[<a href="#cit/section_4.95">

652795</a>

6528][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6529Level of evidence A1</a>

6530]</li>

6531</ul>

6532</div>

6533</li>

6534<li>

6535A meta-analysis of 26 randomized trials that included 37,298 women treated with anthracycline- and taxane-containing chemotherapy compared standard regimens (given every 3&#8211;4 weeks) with more dose-intense regimens. Regimens that increased dose intensity by shortening the interval between cycles (i.e., dose-dense therapy or administration of the same dose over a shorter time period) and regimens that increased dose intensity by administering individual drugs in sequence to allow for higher doses (i.e., sequential scheduling).[<a href="#cit/section_4.96">

653696</a>

6537]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6538<ul id="_2392">

6539<li>

6540Patients who received more dose-intense regimens had superior recurrence-free survival (28.0% vs. 31.4%; RR, 0.86; 95% CI, 0.82&#8211;0.89; <em>

6541P</em>

6542 &lt; .0001) and OS (18.9% vs. 21.3%; RR, 0.87; 95% CI, 0.83&#8211;0.92; <em>

6543P</em>

6544 &lt; .0001) at 10 years. The difference was present and statistically significant in receptor-positive and receptor-negative subgroups.</li>

6545</ul>

6546</div>

6547</li>

6548</ol>

6549</div>

6550<section id="_2393">

6551<h5 id="_2393_toc">

6552Non&#8211;anthracycline-containing regimens</h5>

6553<p id="_2394" tabindex="-1">

6554Because of potential long-term toxicities from anthracyclines, the efficacy and toxicity of non&#8211;anthracycline-containing regimens have been studied. For more information, see the <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_2352">

6555Toxicity of adjuvant chemotherapy</a>

6556 section.</p>

6557<p id="_2395" tabindex="-1">

6558Data are inconsistent regarding whether an anthracycline-containing regimen is more efficacious than a non&#8211;anthracycline-containing regimen. Both types of regimens are acceptable, and the choice must be individualized on the basis of risk and other patient characteristics.</p>

6559<p id="_2396" tabindex="-1">

6560Evidence (non&#8211;anthracycline-containing regimens):</p>

6561<div class="pdq-content-list">

6562<ol id="_2397">

6563<li>

6564The ABC trials were three open-label, randomized, phase III trials comparing TC (taxane/cyclophosphamide) with regimens containing an anthracycline/cyclophosphamide plus a taxane (TaxAC) for the adjuvant treatment of patients with HER2-negative early breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_4.97">

656597</a>

6566] The three trials were analyzed together with a primary end point of invasive disease-free survival (IDFS). The primary aim was to determine if TC (the non-anthracycline arm) was noninferior to the TaxAC arms. Inferiority for TC was predefined as an HR exceeding 1.18 for the TC versus TaxAC arms. A total of 2,125 participants were randomly assigned to receive TC. A total of 2,127 participants were randomly assigned to receive TaxAC.<div class="pdq-content-list">

6567<ul id="_2398">

6568<li>

6569In an interim futility analysis, the HR for IDFS was 1.202 (95% CI, 0.97&#8211;1.49) for TC versus TaxAC, which exceeded the predetermined limit to define TC as inferior. </li>

6570<li>

6571 The 4-year IDFS rate was 88.2% for patients who received TC and 90.7% for patients who received TaxAC (<em>

6572P</em>

6573 = .04).</li>

6574<li>

6575 Although the findings favored treatment with regimens containing an anthracycline/cyclophosphamide plus a taxane, absolute differences between TC and TaxAC were small. Exploratory analyses suggested the greatest benefits from the TaxAC regimens were seen in patients with triple-negative disease and hormone receptor&#8211;positive disease with involved axillary lymph nodes, supporting a role for non&#8211;anthracycline-containing regimens in patients with lower-risk disease.</li>

6576</ul>

6577</div>

6578</li>

6579<li>

6580The West German <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01049425">

6581Plan B</a>

6582 trial (NCT01049425) randomly assigned 2,499 women with node-positive or high-risk node-negative disease to receive either four cycles of epirubicin/cyclophosphamide plus four cycles of docetaxel (EC-T) or six cycles of TC.[<a href="#cit/section_4.98">

658398</a>

6584] After an early amendment, women with hormone receptor&#8211;positive disease and a recurrence score below 12 were excluded.<div class="pdq-content-list">

6585<ul id="_2399">

6586<li>

6587After a median follow-up of 60 months, 5-year outcomes were similar in the EC-T and TC arms for DFS (HR, 1.004; 95% CI, 0.776&#8211;1.299) and OS (HR, 0.937; 95% CI, 0.654&#8211;1.342).[<a href="#cit/section_4.98">

658898</a>

6589][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6590Level of evidence B1</a>

6591]</li>

6592<li>

6593The upper 90% confidence limit for DFS did not exceed the noninferiority boundary of 1.467.</li>

6594<li>

6595There were five treatment-related deaths among patients who received TC and one death among those who received EC-T, but symptomatic adverse events were more frequent in patients who received EC-T.</li>

6596</ul>

6597</div>

6598</li>

6599</ol>

6600</div>

6601</section>

6602</section>

6603<section id="_1376">

6604<h4 id="_1376_toc">

6605Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC)</h4>

6606<p id="_1379" tabindex="-1">

6607TNBC is defined as the absence of staining for ER, PR, and HER2/neu. TNBC is insensitive to some of the most effective therapies for patients with breast cancer, including HER2-directed therapy such as trastuzumab and endocrine therapies such as tamoxifen or AIs. </p>

6608<p id="_2262" tabindex="-1">

6609Patients with TNBC are frequently treated with preoperative systemic therapy. For more information, see the <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_1049">

6610Preoperative Systemic Therapy</a>

6611 section. For patients who undergo surgery first, combination chemotherapy is typically given in the adjuvant setting. While there is no established standard therapy in this setting, the following trial provides evidence that a non&#8211;anthracycline-based regimen may be suitable:</p>

6612<p id="_2473" tabindex="-1">

6613Evidence (adjuvant non&#8211;anthracycline-containing regimens):</p>

6614<div class="pdq-content-list">

6615<ol id="_2423">

6616<li>

6617 The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01216111">

6618PATTERN</a>

6619 trial (NCT01216111) compared an anthracycline-based regimen (cyclophosphamide, 5-FU, epirubicin, and docetaxel [CEF-T]) with paclitaxel and carboplatin (PCb) in 647 Chinese women with TNBC who had completed definitive surgery. The primary end point was DFS.[<a href="#cit/section_4.99">

662099</a>

6621]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6622<ul id="_2424">

6623<li>

6624 At a median follow-up of 62 months, the 5-year DFS rate was 86.5% for patients who received PCb and 80.3% for patients who received CEF-T (HR, 0.65; 95% CI, 0.44&#8211;0.96; <em>

6625P</em>

6626 = .03).[<a href="#cit/section_4.99">

662799</a>

6628][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6629Level of evidence B1</a>

6630]</li>

6631<li>

6632 There was no statistically significant difference in OS between the groups (HR, 0.71; 95% CI, 0.42&#8211;1.22; <em>

6633P</em>

6634 = .22).</li>

6635</ul>

6636</div>

6637</li>

6638</ol>

6639</div>

6640<section id="_2299">

6641<h5 id="_2299_toc">

6642Capecitabine maintenance therapy</h5>

6643<p id="_2300" tabindex="-1">

6644Capecitabine maintenance therapy increased DFS when given after conventional adjuvant therapy.</p>

6645<p id="_2301" tabindex="-1">

6646Evidence (capecitabine maintenance therapy):</p>

6647<div class="pdq-content-list">

6648<ol id="_2302">

6649<li>

6650The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01112826">

6651SYSUCC-001</a>

6652 trial (NCT01112826) included 443 women (434 analyzed) with TNBC from 13 Chinese institutions. The women had received adjuvant chemotherapy and were randomly assigned to receive either no further therapy or capecitabine at a dose of 650 mg/m<span class="sup">

66532</span>

6654 twice daily for 1 year. The primary study end point was DFS.[<a href="#cit/section_4.100">

6655100</a>

6656]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6657<ul id="_2303">

6658<li>

6659After a median follow-up of 61 months, the 5-year DFS rate was 82.5% for patients who received capecitabine maintenance therapy compared with 73.0% for patients who received no further therapy (HR, 0.64; 95% CI, 0.42&#8211;0.95; <em>

6660P</em>

6661 = .03).[<a href="#cit/section_4.100">

6662100</a>

6663][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6664Level of evidence B1</a>

6665]</li>

6666<li>

6667Forty-five percent of patients who received capecitabine developed hand-foot syndrome, which was grade 3 in 7.7% of patients. </li>

6668<li>

6669The rate of patients who completed 1 year of therapy was 82.8%.</li>

6670</ul>

6671</div>

6672</li>

6673</ol>

6674</div>

6675</section>

6676</section>

6677<section id="_1055">

6678<h4 id="_1055_toc">

6679HER2/neu-positive breast cancer</h4>

6680<p id="_580" tabindex="-1">

6681<strong>

6682Treatment options for HER2-positive early breast cancer:</strong>

6683</p>

6684<p id="_1205" tabindex="-1">

6685Standard treatment for HER2-positive early breast cancer is 1 year of adjuvant HER2-targeted therapy. </p>

6686<section id="_1062">

6687<h5 id="_1062_toc">

6688Trastuzumab</h5>

6689<p id="_569" tabindex="-1">

6690Several phase III clinical trials have addressed the role of the anti-HER2/neu antibody, trastuzumab, as adjuvant therapy for patients with HER2-overexpressing cancers. Study results confirm the benefit of 12 months of adjuvant trastuzumab therapy.</p>

6691<p id="_1206" tabindex="-1">

6692Evidence (including duration of trastuzumab therapy):</p>

6693<div class="pdq-content-list">

6694<ol id="_1207">

6695<li>

6696<p id="_1348" tabindex="-1">

6697The Herceptin Adjuvant (HERA) (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00045032">

6698BIG-01-01</a>

6699 [NCT00045032]) trial examined whether trastuzumab was effective as adjuvant treatment for HER2-positive breast cancer if used after completion of the primary treatment. For most patients, primary treatment consisted of an anthracycline-containing chemotherapy regimen given preoperatively or postoperatively, with or without locoregional radiation therapy. Trastuzumab was given every 3 weeks starting within 7 weeks of the completion of primary treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_4.101">

6700101</a>

6701][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6702Level of evidence A1</a>

6703] Patients were randomly assigned to one of three study arms:</p>

6704<div class="pdq-content-list">

6705<ul id="_1367">

6706<li>

6707Observation (n = 1,693).</li>

6708<li>

67091 year of trastuzumab (n = 1,694).</li>

6710<li>

67112 years of trastuzumab (n = 1,694).</li>

6712</ul>

6713</div>

6714<p id="_1350" tabindex="-1">

6715Of the patients in the comparison of 1 year of trastuzumab versus observation group, the median age was 49 years, about 33% had node-negative disease, and nearly 50% had hormone receptor (ER and PR)&#8211;negative disease.[<a href="#cit/section_4.102">

6716102</a>

6717]</p>

6718<div class="pdq-content-list">

6719<ol id="_1370" class="lower-alpha">

6720<li>

6721One year of trastuzumab versus observation:<div class="pdq-content-list">

6722<ul id="_1371">

6723<li>

6724After a median follow-up of 11 years,[<a href="#cit/section_4.102">

6725102</a>

6726] the finding was that 1 year of trastuzumab improved DFS (HR, 0.76; 95% CI, 0.68&#8211;0.86; 10-year DFS rate, 72% vs. 66%; <em>

6727P</em>

6728 &lt; .0001), despite a crossover of 52% of the patients on observation.</li>

6729<li>

6730One year of trastuzumab also improved OS (HR, 0.74; 95% CI, 0.64&#8211;0.86; 12-year OS rate, 79% vs. 73%; <em>

6731P</em>

6732 &lt; .0001).[<a href="#cit/section_4.102">

6733102</a>

6734][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6735Level of evidence A1</a>

6736]</li>

6737</ul>

6738</div>

6739</li>

6740<li>

6741One year versus 2 years of trastuzumab:<div class="pdq-content-list">

6742<ul id="_1372">

6743<li>

6744After a median follow-up of 11 years, there was no benefit to an additional year of trastuzumab for DFS (HR, 1.02; 95% CI, 0.89&#8211;1.17).</li>

6745</ul>

6746</div>

6747</li>

6748<li>

6749Symptomatic cardiac events occurred in 1% of the patients on trastuzumab and in 0.1% of the observation group.</li>

6750</ol>

6751</div>

6752</li>

6753<li>

6754In the combined analysis of the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00004067">

6755NSABP-B-31</a>

6756 (NCT00004067) and intergroup <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00005970">

6757NCCTG-N9831</a>

6758 (NCT00005970) trials, trastuzumab was given weekly, concurrently, or immediately after the paclitaxel component of the AC with paclitaxel regimen.[<a href="#cit/section_4.103">

6759103</a>

6760,<a href="#cit/section_4.104">

6761104</a>

6762][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6763Level of evidence A1</a>

6764] <div class="pdq-content-list">

6765<ul id="_1209">

6766<li>

6767The HERA results were confirmed in a joint analysis of the two studies, with a combined enrollment of 3,676 patients. A highly statistically significant improvement in DFS (HR, 0.48; <em>

6768P</em>

6769 &lt; .001; 3-year DFS rate, 87% vs. 75%) was observed, as was a significant improvement in OS (HR, 0.67; <em>

6770P</em>

6771 = .015; 3-year OS rate, 94.3% in the trastuzumab group vs. 91.7% in the control group; 4-year OS rate, 91.4% in the trastuzumab group vs. 86.6% in the control group).[<a href="#cit/section_4.103">

6772103</a>

6773]</li>

6774<li>

6775Patients treated with trastuzumab experienced a longer DFS, with a 52% lower risk of a DFS event (HR, 0.48; 95% CI, 0.39&#8211;0.59; <em>

6776P</em>

6777 &lt; .001), corresponding to an absolute difference in DFS of 11.8% at 3 years and 18% at 4 years. The risk of distant recurrence in patients treated with trastuzumab was 53% lower (HR, 0.47; 95% CI, 0.37&#8211;0.61; <em>

6778P</em>

6779 &lt; .001), and the risk of death was 33% lower (HR, 0.67; 95% CI, 0.48&#8211;0.93; <em>

6780P</em>

6781 = .015).[<a href="#cit/section_4.103">

6782103</a>

6783]</li>

6784<li>

6785 In an updated analysis with a median follow-up of 8.4 years, the addition of trastuzumab to chemotherapy led to a 37% relative improvement in OS (HR, 0.63; 95% CI, 0.54&#8211;0.73; <em>

6786P</em>

6787 &lt; .001) and an increase in the 10-year OS rate from 75.2% to 84%.[<a href="#cit/section_4.105">

6788105</a>

6789] </li>

6790</ul>

6791</div>

6792</li>

6793<li>

6794In the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00021255">

6795BCIRG-006</a>

6796 trial (NCT00021255), 3,222 women with early-stage HER2-overexpressing breast cancer were randomly assigned to receive AC followed by docetaxel (AC-T), AC followed by docetaxel plus trastuzumab (AC-T plus trastuzumab), or docetaxel, carboplatin, plus trastuzumab (TCH, a non&#8211;anthracycline-containing regimen).[<a href="#cit/section_4.106">

6797106</a>

6798][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6799Level of evidence A1</a>

6800] <div class="pdq-content-list">

6801<ul id="_1210">

6802<li>

6803A significant DFS and OS benefit was seen in both groups treated with

6804trastuzumab compared with the control group that did not receive trastuzumab.

6805</li>

6806<li>

6807For patients receiving AC-T plus trastuzumab, the 5-year DFS rate was 84% (HR for the comparison with AC-T, 0.64; <em>

6808P</em>

6809 &lt; .001), and the OS rate was 92% (HR, 0.63; <em>

6810P</em>

6811 &lt; .001). For patients receiving TCH, the 5-year DFS rate was 81% (HR, 0.75; <em>

6812P</em>

6813 = .04), and the OS rate was 91% (HR, 0.77; <em>

6814P</em>

6815 = .04).

6816The control group had a 5-year DFS rate of 75% and an OS rate of

681787%.</li>

6818<li>

6819The authors stated that there was no significant difference in DFS or OS between the two trastuzumab-containing regimens.

6820However, the study was not powered to detect equivalence between the two trastuzumab-containing regimens.</li>

6821<li>

6822The rates of congestive heart failure (CHF) and cardiac dysfunction were significantly higher in the group receiving AC-T plus trastuzumab than in the TCH group (<em>

6823P</em>

6824 &lt; .001).</li>

6825<li>

6826These trial findings raise the question of whether anthracyclines are needed for the adjuvant treatment of HER2-overexpressing breast cancer. The group receiving AC-trastuzumab showed a small but not statistically significant benefit over TCH.</li>

6827<li>

6828This trial supports the use of TCH as an alternative adjuvant regimen for women with early-stage HER2-overexpressing breast cancer, particularly in those with concerns about cardiac toxic effects.</li>

6829</ul>

6830</div>

6831</li>

6832<li>

6833The Finland Herceptin (FINHER) study assessed the impact of a much shorter course of trastuzumab. In this trial, 232 women younger than 67 years with node-positive or high-risk (&gt;2 cm tumor size) node-negative HER2-overexpressing breast cancer were given nine weekly infusions of trastuzumab concurrently with docetaxel or vinorelbine followed by 5-FU, epirubicin, and cyclophosphamide (FEC).[<a href="#cit/section_4.107">

6834107</a>

6835][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6836Level of evidence A1</a>

6837]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6838<ul id="_1214">

6839<li>

6840At a 3-year median follow-up, the risk of recurrence and/or death was significantly reduced in patients receiving trastuzumab (HR, 0.41; <em>

6841P</em>

6842 = .01; 95% CI, 0.21&#8211;0.83; 3-year DFS, 89% vs. 78%).</li>

6843<li>

6844The difference in OS (HR, 0.41) was not statistically significant (<em>

6845P</em>

6846 = .07; 95% CI, 0.16&#8211;1.08).</li>

6847</ul>

6848</div>

6849</li>

6850<li>

6851Several studies have compared 6 months of trastuzumab administration to 12 months.[<a href="#cit/section_4.108">

6852108</a>

6853-<a href="#cit/section_4.110">

6854110</a>

6855]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6856<ol id="_2053" class="lower-alpha">

6857<li>

6858In an interim analysis of the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00381901">

6859PHARE</a>

6860 trial (NCT00381901), the 2-year DFS rate was 93.8% (95% CI, 92.6%&#8211;94.9%) in the 12-month group and 91.1% (89.7%&#8211;92.4%) in the 6-month group (HR, 1.28; 95% CI, 1.05&#8211;1.56; noninferiority, <em>

6861P</em>

6862 = .29).[<a href="#cit/section_4.108">

6863108</a>

6864][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6865Level of evidence A1</a>

6866]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6867<ul id="_2054">

6868<li>

6869In the final analysis, after 704 events were observed, the adjusted HR was 1.08 (95% CI, 0.93&#8211;1.25), and the prespecified noninferiority HR of 1.15 was not excluded.</li>

6870</ul>

6871</div>

6872</li>

6873<li>

6874Similar results were noted in a much smaller study of 481 patients led by the Hellenic Oncology Research Group.[<a href="#cit/section_4.109">

6875109</a>

6876][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6877Level of evidence A1</a>

6878]

6879</li>

6880<li>

6881In contrast, the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00712140">

6882PERSEPHONE</a>

6883 trial (NCT00712140), which enrolled 4,088 patients who experienced 512 DFS events at the time of analysis, excluded its prespecified noninferiority margin (HR, 1.07; 90% CI, 0.93&#8722;1.24; noninferiority, <em>

6884P</em>

6885 = .011).[<a href="#cit/section_4.110">

6886110</a>

6887][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6888Level of evidence A1</a>

6889]</li>

6890</ol>

6891</div>

6892</li>

6893<li>

6894 The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00593697">

6895SOLD</a>

6896 trial (NCT00593697) compared 9 weeks of trastuzumab with 1 year of trastuzumab in 2,174 women with HER2-positive breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_4.111">

6897111</a>

6898] <div class="pdq-content-list">

6899<ul id="_2229">

6900<li>

6901Noninferiority of the 9-week treatment could not be demonstrated for DFS (HR, 1.39; 2-sided 90% CI, 1.12&#8722;1.72).[<a href="#cit/section_4.111">

6902111</a>

6903][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6904Level of evidence B1</a>

6905]</li>

6906</ul>

6907</div>

6908</li>

6909<li>

6910 A meta-analysis that included these trials concluded that, with respect to OS, 1 year of trastuzumab was superior to a shorter duration of therapy; however, there was no significant benefit of 1 year of therapy in patients with low-risk disease.[<a href="#cit/section_4.112">

6911112</a>

6912][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6913Level of evidence A1</a>

6914]</li>

6915</ol>

6916</div>

6917<p id="_943" tabindex="-1">

6918Several studies have evaluated the use of subcutaneous (SQ) trastuzumab in the neoadjuvant and adjuvant settings.</p>

6919<section id="_1048">

6920<h6 id="_1048_toc">

6921Cardiac toxic effects with adjuvant trastuzumab</h6>

6922<p id="_1217" tabindex="-1">

6923Cardiac events associated with adjuvant trastuzumab have been reported in multiple studies. Key study results include the following:</p>

6924<div class="pdq-content-list">

6925<ul id="_1218">

6926<li>

6927In the HERA (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00045032">

6928BIG-01-01</a>

6929) trial, severe CHF (New York Heart Association class III&#8211;IV) occurred in 0.6% of patients treated with trastuzumab.[<a href="#cit/section_4.101">

6930101</a>

6931] Symptomatic CHF occurred in 1.7% of patients in the trastuzumab arm and 0.06% of patients in the observation arm.</li>

6932<li>

6933In the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00004067">

6934NSABP B-31</a>

6935 trial (NCT00004067), 31 of 850 patients in the trastuzumab arm had confirmed symptomatic cardiac events, compared with 5 of 814 patients in the control arm.[<a href="#cit/section_4.113">

6936113</a>

6937] The 3-year cumulative incidence of cardiac events for trastuzumab-treated patients was 4.1%, compared with 0.8% of patients in the control arm (95% CI, 1.7%&#8211;4.9%).</li>

6938<li>

6939In the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00005970">

6940NCCTG-N9831</a>

6941 trial, 39 cardiac events were reported in the three arms over a 3-year period. The 3-year cumulative incidence of cardiac events was 0.35% in arm A (no trastuzumab), 3.5% in arm B (trastuzumab after paclitaxel), and 2.5% in arm C, (trastuzumab concomitant with paclitaxel).</li>

6942<li>

6943In the<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00768092">

6944 AVENTIS-TAX-GMA-302</a>

6945 (BCIRG 006) trial (NCT00021255), clinically symptomatic cardiac events were detected in 0.38% of patients in the AC/docetaxel (AC-D) arm, 1.87% of patients in the AC/docetaxel/trastuzumab (AC-DH) arm, and 0.37% of patients in the docetaxel/carboplatin/trastuzumab (DCbH) arm.[<a href="#cit/section_4.114">

6946114</a>

6947] There was also a statistically significant higher incidence of asymptomatic and persistent decrease in left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) in the AC-DH arm than with either the AC-D or DCbH arms.</li>

6948<li>
