6949In the FINHER trial, none of the patients who received trastuzumab experienced clinically significant cardiac events. LVEF was preserved in all of the women receiving trastuzumab, but the number of patients receiving adjuvant trastuzumab was very low.[<a href="#cit/section_4.107">

6950107</a>

6951]</li>

6952</ul>

6953</div>

6954</section>

6955</section>

6956<section id="_1759">

6957<h5 id="_1759_toc">

6958Pertuzumab</h5>

6959<p id="_1760" tabindex="-1">

6960 Pertuzumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody that binds to a distinct epitope on the extracellular domain of the HER2 receptor and inhibits dimerization. Its use, in combination with trastuzumab, has been evaluated in a randomized trial in the postoperative setting.</p>

6961<p id="_1761" tabindex="-1">

6962 Evidence (pertuzumab):</p>

6963<div class="pdq-content-list">

6964<ol id="_1762">

6965<li>

6966 The Breast Intergroup (BIG) trial enrolled 4,805 women with HER2-positive cancer cells in a blinded comparison study for 12 months of trastuzumab plus placebo versus 12 months of trastuzumab plus pertuzumab, which were given in conjunction with standard chemotherapy and hormone therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.115">

6967115</a>

6968] <div class="pdq-content-list">

6969<ul id="_1763">

6970<li>

6971At the time of the final analysis of the primary end point (breast cancer, relapse-free survival [RFS]), there was a significant difference in favor of the combination regimen (HR, 0.81; 95% CI, 0.66&#8211;1.00; <em>

6972P</em>

6973 = .045; 3-year invasive DFS, 94.1% vs. 93.2%). </li>

6974<li>

6975There was no statistically significant difference in OS at the first interim analysis for this end point. </li>

6976<li>

6977Patients receiving pertuzumab had more grade 3 diarrhea (9.8% vs. 3.7%) and were more likely to develop heart failure (0.6% vs. 0.2%).</li>

6978</ul>

6979</div>

6980</li>

6981</ol>

6982</div>

6983</section>

6984<section id="_1771">

6985<h5 id="_1771_toc">

6986Neratinib</h5>

6987<p id="_1772" tabindex="-1">

6988Neratinib is an irreversible tyrosine kinase inhibitor of HER1, HER2, and HER4, which has been approved by the FDA for the extended adjuvant treatment of patients with early-stage HER2-positive breast cancer, to follow adjuvant trastuzumab-based therapy.</p>

6989<p id="_1773" tabindex="-1">

6990Evidence (neratinib):</p>

6991<div class="pdq-content-list">

6992<ol id="_1774">

6993<li>

6994 In the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00878709">

6995ExteNET</a>

6996 trial (NCT00878709), the safety and efficacy of 12 months of adjuvant neratinib was investigated in patients with early-stage HER2-positive breast cancer (n = 2,840) who had completed neoadjuvant trastuzumab up to 2 years before randomization. Patients received 240 mg of oral neratinib daily for 1 year or a placebo.[<a href="#cit/section_4.116">

6997116</a>

6998][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6999Level of evidence A1</a>

7000]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7001<ul id="_1775">

7002<li>

7003 The primary end point was invasive DFS. </li>

7004<li>

7005After a median follow-up of 5.2 years (interquartile range, 2.1&#8211;5.3), patients in the neratinib group had significantly fewer invasive DFS events than those in the placebo group (neratinib group, 116 events vs. placebo group, 163 events; stratified HR, 0.73; 95% CI, 0.57&#8211;0.92; <em>

7006P</em>

7007 = .0083). The 5-year invasive DFS rate was 90.2% (95% CI, 88.3%&#8211;91.8%) in the neratinib group and 87.7% (85.7%&#8211;89.4%) in the placebo group.[<a href="#cit/section_4.117">

7008117</a>

7009]</li>

7010<li>

7011 OS data are not mature. </li>

7012<li>

7013 The most common grade 1 to 2 adverse events included diarrhea (neratinib, 55% vs. placebo, 34%), nausea (41% vs. 21%), fatigue (25% vs. 20%), vomiting (23% vs. 8%), and abdominal pain (22% vs. 10%). Prophylactic loperamide is recommended on the FDA label during the first 56 days of therapy, and as needed thereafter to help manage diarrhea. </li>

7014<li>

7015 The most common grade 3 to 4 adverse event was diarrhea (neratinib, 40% vs. placebo, 2%). All other grade 3 to 4 adverse events occurred in 2% or less of patients. </li>

7016</ul>

7017</div>

7018</li>

7019</ol>

7020</div>

7021</section>

7022</section>

7023<section id="_2428">

7024<h4 id="_2428_toc">

7025 Node-negative, small, HER2/neu-positive breast cancer</h4>

7026<p id="_2454" tabindex="-1">

7027There are no studies comparing different regimens in patients with node-negative, small, HER2-positive breast tumors. The following two large single-arm studies demonstrated outcomes that appear to be superior to previous results in similar patients who did not receive adjuvant therapy.

7028</p>

7029<p id="_2474" tabindex="-1">

7030Evidence (combination regimens for node-negative, small, HER2-positive tumors):</p>

7031<div class="pdq-content-list">

7032<ol id="_2429">

7033<li>

7034The single-arm Adjuvant Paclitaxel and Trastuzumab

7035(<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00542451">

7036APT</a>

7037) trial (NCT00542451) evaluated a non&#8211;anthracycline-containing regimen, paclitaxel and trastuzumab. The trial enrolled 410 women with node-negative, small (&#8804;3 cm), HER2-positive tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_4.118">

7038118</a>

7039]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7040<ul id="_2430">

7041<li>

7042After 6.5 years of follow-up, the DFS rate was 93% (95% CI, 90.4%&#8211;96.2%).[<a href="#cit/section_4.118">

7043118</a>

7044][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7045Level of evidence C2</a>

7046]</li>

7047</ul>

7048</div>

7049</li>

7050<li>

7051The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01853748">

7052ATEMPT</a>

7053 trial (NCT01853748) compared paclitaxel and trastuzumab with trastuzumab emtansine (T-DM1) in patients with node-negative HER2-positive tumors measuring 2 cm or smaller (patients with a single micrometastatic node were eligible). The goals of the trial were to determine if T-DM1 produced fewer clinically relevant toxicities (CRTs) and was associated with an acceptable 3-year IDFS rate. The trial randomly assigned 383 patients to the T-DM1 arm and 114 patients to the paclitaxel and trastuzumab arm.[<a href="#cit/section_4.119">

7054119</a>

7055]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7056<ul id="_2431">

7057<li>

7058 Although the types of toxicities differed in the two treatment arms, the total number of CRTs was nearly identical (46% in the T-DM1 arm vs. 47% in the paclitaxel and trastuzumab arm; <em>

7059P</em>

7060 = .83). However, patients who received T-DM1 reported more favorable outcomes during treatment.</li>

7061<li>

7062 The 3-year IDFS rate for patients who received T-DM1 was 97.8% (95% CI, 96.3%&#8211;99.3%) which exceeded the protocol-specified rate of 95% to reject the null hypothesis (<em>

7063P</em>

7064 = .0001).[<a href="#cit/section_4.119">

7065119</a>

7066][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7067Level of evidence C1</a>

7068]</li>

7069</ul>

7070</div>

7071</li>

7072</ol>

7073</div>

7074</section>

7075<section id="_267">

7076<h4 id="_267_toc">

7077Timing of postoperative chemotherapy</h4>

7078<p id="_167" tabindex="-1">

7079The optimal time to initiate adjuvant therapy is uncertain. Studies have reported the following:</p>

7080<div class="pdq-content-list">

7081<ol id="_1327">

7082<li>

7083A retrospective, observational, single-institution study of patients with early-stage breast cancer who were diagnosed between 1997 and 2011 revealed that delays in initiation of adjuvant chemotherapy adversely affected survival outcomes.[<a href="#cit/section_4.120">

7084120</a>

7085][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7086Level of evidence C1</a>

7087] <div class="pdq-content-list">

7088<ul id="_1328">

7089<li>

7090Initiation of chemotherapy 61 days or more after surgery was associated with adverse outcomes among patients with stage II breast cancer (distant RFS: HR, 1.20; 95% CI, 1.02&#8211;1.43) and stage III breast cancer (OS: HR, 1.76; 95% CI, 1.26&#8211;2.46; RFS: HR, 1.34; 95% CI, 1.01&#8211;1.76; and distant RFS: HR, 1.36; 95% CI, 1.02&#8211;1.80).</li>

7091<li>

7092Patients with TNBC and those with HER2-positive tumors treated with trastuzumab who started chemotherapy 61 days or more after surgery had worse survival (TNBC: HR, 1.54; 95% CI, 1.09&#8211;2.18; HER2-positive: HR, 3.09; 95% CI, 1.49&#8211;6.39) than did those who initiated treatment in the first 30 days after surgery.</li>

7093<li>

7094Because of the weaknesses and limitations of this study design, the optimal time to initiate adjuvant chemotherapy remains uncertain.</li>

7095</ul>

7096</div>

7097</li>

7098<li>

7099 A population-based study from California included 24,843 patients and found that delays in initiating adjuvant chemotherapy of 90 days or less had no impact on OS, but found a substantial effect for delays over 90 days (HR, 1.27; 95% CI, 1.05&#8211;1.53), particularly among patients with TNBC.[<a href="#cit/section_4.121">

7100121</a>

7101][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7102Level of evidence C1</a>

7103]</li>

7104<li>

7105 Multiple other studies have examined the effect of treatment delays of 90 days or less and have reported inconsistent results, with the possible exception of patients with TNBC.[<a href="#cit/section_4.121">

7106121</a>

7107]</li>

7108</ol>

7109</div>

7110</section>

7111<section id="_2352">

7112<h4 id="_2352_toc">

7113Toxicity of adjuvant chemotherapy</h4>

7114<p id="_2353" tabindex="-1">

7115The acute toxicities of the drugs used for adjuvant chemotherapy are the same as those observed when these drugs are used in other treatment settings. However, because many patients with early breast cancer have prolonged survival, long-term adverse effects are particularly important in this setting. The following two toxicities are of special concern:</p>

7116<div class="pdq-content-list">

7117<ol id="_2354">

7118<li>

7119 Cardiotoxicity from anthracyclines. See the <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_1055">

7120HER2/neu-positive breast cancer</a>

7121 section for data on the cardiotoxicity observed in patients assigned to the standard chemotherapy control arms of studies that examined the use of trastuzumab.</li>

7122<li>

7123 Marrow neoplasia. A study of 20,063 patients treated in National Comprehensive Cancer Network centers found an incidence of marrow neoplasia of 0.46 per 1,000 person-years in women treated with anthracycline- and/or cyclophosphamide-containing chemotherapy. This rate was significantly higher than the rate observed in women who were treated with surgery alone (HR, 6.8; 95% CI, 1.3&#8211;36.1).[<a href="#cit/section_4.122">

7124122</a>

7125]</li>

7126</ol>

7127</div>

7128</section>

7129<section id="_2408">

7130<h4 id="_2408_toc">

7131Adjuvant PARP inhibitors for patients with germline <em class="gene-name">

7132BRCA1</em>

7133 and <em class="gene-name">

7134BRCA2</em>

7135 mutations</h4>

7136<p id="_2414" tabindex="-1">

7137The role of adjuvant poly (ADP-ribose) polymerase (PARP) inhibition has been evaluated in patients with early breast cancer and germline <em class="gene-name">

7138BRCA1</em>

7139 or <em class="gene-name">

7140BRCA2</em>

7141 mutations. <em class="gene-name">

7142BRCA1</em>

7143 and <em class="gene-name">

7144BRCA2</em>

7145 are tumor suppressor genes that encode proteins involved in DNA repair through the homologous recombination repair pathway. PARP plays a critical role in DNA repair.</p>

7146<p id="_2415" tabindex="-1">

7147Evidence (olaparib):</p>

7148<div class="pdq-content-list">

7149<ol id="_2416">

7150<li>

7151The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02032823">

7152OlympiA</a>

7153 trial (NCT02032823) randomly assigned 1,836 patients with HER2-negative breast cancer and germline <em class="gene-name">

7154BRCA1</em>

7155 or <em class="gene-name">

7156BRCA2</em>

7157 mutations to receive either one year of adjuvant olaparib (300 mg twice daily) or placebo. All women completed surgery and adjuvant or neoadjuvant chemotherapy or radiotherapy. Patients were considered at higher risk of recurrence on the basis of tumor size, node involvement, or the presence of residual cancer after neoadjuvant therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.123">

7158123</a>

7159] <div class="pdq-content-list">

7160<p class="pdq-list-title">

7161Eligibility criteria for patients who underwent initial surgery and received adjuvant chemotherapy </p>

7162<ul id="_2411">

7163<li>

7164Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) patients had axillary node-positive (&#8805;pN1, any tumor size) disease OR axillary node-negative disease with an invasive primary tumor larger than 2 cm (pN0, &#8805;pT2). </li>

7165<li>

7166At least four pathologically-confirmed positive lymph nodes were required for ER- and/or PR-positive/HER2-negative patients. </li>

7167</ul>

7168</div>

7169<div class="pdq-content-list">

7170<p class="pdq-list-title">

7171Eligibility criteria for patients who underwent neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by surgery </p>

7172<ul id="_2412">

7173<li>

7174TNBC patients had residual invasive cancer in the breast and/or resected lymph nodes (i.e., no pathological complete response [pCR]). </li>

7175<li>

7176ER- and/or PR-positive/HER2-negative patients had residual invasive cancer in the breast and/or resected lymph nodes (i.e., no pCR) AND a CPS+EG (<strong>

7177C</strong>

7178linical stage/<strong>

7179P</strong>

7180athological <strong>

7181S</strong>

7182tage + <strong>

7183E</strong>

7184R status/nuclear <strong>

7185G</strong>

7186rade) score of 3 or higher.[<a href="#cit/section_4.124">

7187124</a>

7188]</li>

7189</ul>

7190</div>

7191<p id="_2413" tabindex="-1">

7192The primary end point of the study was invasive disease-free survival (IDFS).[<a href="#cit/section_4.123">

7193123</a>

7194][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7195Level of evidence B1</a>

7196]</p>

7197<div class="pdq-content-list">

7198<ul id="_2410">

7199<li>

7200At the time of the first (and only) planned interim analysis, when 284 events (i.e., invasive disease or death) had occurred, the HR for IDFS strongly favored the olaparib arm, and the prespecified stopping boundary for significance was exceeded (HR, 0.58; 99.5% CI, 0.41&#8211;0.82; 3-year IDFS rate, 85.9% vs 77.1%; <em>

7201P</em>

7202 &lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_4.123">

7203123</a>

7204][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7205Level of evidence B1</a>

7206]</li>

7207<li>

7208Distant DFS was also statistically significantly improved for patients who received olaparib (HR, 0.57; 99.5% CI, 0.39&#8211;0.83; <em>

7209P</em>

7210 &lt; .001). </li>

7211<li>

7212A difference in OS was also observed (HR, 0.68; 99% CI, 0.44&#8211;1.05; <em>

7213P</em>

7214 = .02), but it did not meet the prespecified level of significance when corrected for multiple testing (<em>

7215P</em>

7216 &lt; .01).</li>

7217<li>

7218Grade 3 or higher adverse events that occurred in more than 1% of patients on the olaparib arm included anemia (8.7%), decreased neutrophil count (4.8%), decreased white cell count (3.0%), fatigue (1.8%), and lymphopenia (1.2%). No adverse events of grade 3 or higher occurred in more than 1% of the patients on the placebo arm.</li>

7219</ul>

7220</div>

7221</li>

7222</ol>

7223</div>

7224</section>

7225<section id="_1028">

7226<h4 id="_1028_toc">

7227Endocrine therapy for hormone receptor&#8211;positive breast cancer</h4>

7228<p id="_1363" tabindex="-1">

7229Much of the evidence presented in the following sections on therapy for women with hormone receptor&#8211;positive disease has been considered in an American Society of Clinical Oncology guideline that describes several options for the management of these patients.[<a href="#cit/section_4.125">

7230125</a>

7231] Five years of adjuvant endocrine therapy has been shown to substantially reduce the risks of locoregional and distant recurrence, contralateral breast cancer, and death from breast cancer.</p>

7232<p id="_1803" tabindex="-1">

7233The optimal duration of endocrine therapy is unclear, with the preponderance of evidence supporting at least 5 years of endocrine therapy. A meta-analysis of 88 clinical trials involving 62,923 women with hormone receptor&#8211;positive breast cancer who were disease free after 5 years of endocrine therapy showed a steady risk of late recurrence 5 to 20 years after diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_4.126">

7234126</a>

7235][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7236Level of evidence C2</a>

7237] The risk of distant recurrence correlated with the original tumor (T) and node (N) status, with risks ranging from 10% to 41%.</p>

7238<section id="_1029">

7239<h5 id="_1029_toc">

7240Tamoxifen</h5>

7241<p id="_1227" tabindex="-1">

7242Tamoxifen has been shown to benefit women with hormone receptor&#8211;positive breast cancer.</p>

7243<p id="_1228" tabindex="-1">

7244Evidence (tamoxifen for hormone receptor&#8211;positive early breast cancer):</p>

7245<div class="pdq-content-list">

7246<ol id="_1229">

7247<li>

7248The EBCTCG performed a meta-analysis of systemic treatment of early breast

7249cancer by hormone, cytotoxic, or biological therapy methods in randomized trials

7250involving 144,939 women with stage I or stage II breast cancer. An analysis published in 2005 included information on 80,273 women in 71 trials of adjuvant tamoxifen.[<a href="#cit/section_4.85">

725185</a>

7252][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7253Level of evidence A1</a>

7254]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7255<ul id="_1230">

7256<li>

7257In this analysis, the benefit of

7258tamoxifen was found to be restricted to women with hormone receptor&#8211;positive or hormone receptor&#8211;unknown

7259breast tumors. In these women, the 15-year absolute reduction associated with 5 years of use was 12% for

7260recurrence and 9% for mortality.</li>

7261<li>

7262Allocation to approximately 5 years of adjuvant tamoxifen reduces the annual breast cancer death rate by 31%, largely irrespective of the use of chemotherapy and of age (&lt;50 years, 50&#8211;69 years, &#8805;70 years), PR status, or other tumor characteristics.</li>

7263<li>

7264The meta-analysis also confirmed the benefit of adjuvant

7265tamoxifen in hormone receptor&#8211;positive premenopausal women. Women younger than 50 years obtained a degree of benefit from 5 years of tamoxifen similar to that

7266obtained by older women. In addition, the proportional reductions in both

7267recurrence and mortality associated with tamoxifen use were similar in women

7268with either node-negative or node-positive breast cancer, but the absolute

7269improvement in survival at 10 years was greater in the node-positive breast cancer group (5.3%

7270vs. 12.5% with 5 years of use).</li>

7271</ul>

7272</div>

7273</li>

7274<li>

7275Similar results were found in the IBCSG-13-93 trial.[<a href="#cit/section_4.127">

7276127</a>

7277] Of 1,246 women with stage II disease, only the women with hormone receptor&#8211;positive disease benefited from tamoxifen.

7278</li>

7279</ol>

7280</div>

7281<p id="_1231" tabindex="-1">

7282The optimal duration of tamoxifen use has been addressed by the EBCTCG

7283meta-analysis and by several large randomized trials.[<a href="#cit/section_4.85">

728485</a>

7285,<a href="#cit/section_4.128">

7286128</a>

7287-<a href="#cit/section_4.131">

7288131</a>

7289] Ten years of tamoxifen therapy has been shown to be superior to shorter durations of tamoxifen therapy.</p>

7290<p id="_1232" tabindex="-1">

7291Evidence (duration of tamoxifen therapy):</p>

7292<div class="pdq-content-list">

7293<ol id="_1233">

7294<li>

7295The EBCTCG

7296meta-analysis demonstrated that 5 years of tamoxifen was superior to shorter durations. The following results were reported:[<a href="#cit/section_4.85">

729785</a>

7298]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7299<ul id="_1234">

7300<li>

7301A highly significant advantage of 5 years versus 1 to 2 years of tamoxifen with respect to the risk of recurrence (proportionate reduction, 15.2%; <em>

7302P</em>

7303 &lt; .001) and a less significant advantage with respect to mortality (proportionate reduction, 7.9%; <em>

7304P</em>

7305 = .01) was observed.</li>

7306</ul>

7307</div>

7308</li>

7309<li>

7310Long-term follow-up of the Adjuvant Tamoxifen Longer Against Shorter (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003016">

7311ATLAS</a>

7312 [NCT00003016]) trial demonstrated that 10 years of tamoxifen therapy was superior to 5 years of tamoxifen therapy. Between 1996 and 2005, 12,894 women with early breast cancer were randomly assigned to receive 10 years or 5 years of tamoxifen therapy. The following results were reported:[<a href="#cit/section_4.131">

7313131</a>

7314][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7315Level of evidence A1</a>

7316]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7317<ol id="_1713" class="lower-alpha">

7318<li>

7319Study results revealed that 10 years of tamoxifen reduced the risk of breast cancer recurrence (617 recurrences for 10 years of tamoxifen vs. 711 recurrences for 5 years of tamoxifen; <em>

7320P </em>

7321= .002), reduced breast-cancer mortality (331 deaths for 10 years of tamoxifen vs. 397 deaths for 5 years of tamoxifen; <em>

7322P</em>

7323 = .01), and reduced overall mortality (639 deaths for 10 years of tamoxifen vs. 722 deaths for 5 years of tamoxifen; <em>

7324P</em>

7325 = .01).</li>

7326<li>

7327Of note, from the time of the original breast cancer diagnosis, the benefits of 10 years of therapy were less extreme before than after year 10. At 15 years from the time of diagnosis, breast cancer mortality was 15% at 10 years and 12.2% at 5 years.</li>

7328<li>

7329Compared with 5 years, 10 years of tamoxifen therapy increased the risk of the following:<div class="pdq-content-list">

7330<ul id="_1714">

7331<li>

7332Pulmonary embolus RR, 1.87; (95% CI, 1.13&#8211;3.07; <em>

7333P </em>

7334= .01). </li>

7335<li>

7336Stroke RR, 1.06; (95% CI, 0.83&#8211;1.36).</li>

7337<li>

7338Ischemic heart disease RR, 0.76; (95% CI, 0.6&#8211;0.95; <em>

7339P</em>

7340 = .02).</li>

7341<li>

7342Endometrial cancer RR, 1.74; (95% CI, 1.30&#8211;2.34; <em>

7343P</em>

7344 = .0002). Notably, the cumulative risk of endometrial cancer during years 5 to 14 from breast cancer diagnosis was 3.1% for women who received 10 years of tamoxifen versus 1.6% for women who received 5 years of tamoxifen. The mortality for years 5 to 14 was 12.2 versus 15 for an absolute mortality reduction of 2.8%.</li>

7345</ul>

7346</div>

7347</li>

7348</ol>

7349</div>

7350<p id="_1715" tabindex="-1">

7351The results of the ATLAS trial indicated that for women who remained premenopausal after 5 years of adjuvant tamoxifen, continued tamoxifen for 5 more years was beneficial.[<a href="#cit/section_4.131">

7352131</a>

7353] Women who have become menopausal after 5 years of tamoxifen may also be treated with AIs. For more information, see the <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_1034">

7354Aromatase inhibitors</a>

7355 section.</p>

7356 </li>

7357</ol>

7358</div>

7359<section id="_1030">

7360<h6 id="_1030_toc">

7361Tamoxifen and chemotherapy</h6>

7362<p id="_1091" tabindex="-1">

7363Because of the results of an EBCTCG analysis, the use of tamoxifen in women who received adjuvant chemotherapy does not attenuate the benefit of chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.85">

736485</a>

7365] However, concurrent use of tamoxifen with chemotherapy is less effective than sequential administration.[<a href="#cit/section_4.132">

7366132</a>

7367]</p>

7368</section>

7369</section>

7370<section id="_1032">

7371<h5 id="_1032_toc">

7372Ovarian ablation, tamoxifen, and chemotherapy</h5>

7373<p id="_1354" tabindex="-1">

7374Evidence suggests ovarian ablation alone is not an effective substitute for other systemic therapies.[<a href="#cit/section_4.133">

7375133</a>

7376-<a href="#cit/section_4.137">

7377137</a>

7378] Further, the addition of ovarian ablation to chemotherapy and/or tamoxifen has not been found to significantly improve outcomes.[<a href="#cit/section_4.135">

7379135</a>

7380,<a href="#cit/section_4.137">

7381137</a>

7382-<a href="#cit/section_4.140">

7383140</a>

7384] </p>

7385<p id="_1355" tabindex="-1">

7386Evidence (tamoxifen plus ovarian suppression):</p>

7387<div class="pdq-content-list">

7388<ol id="_1356">

7389<li>

7390The largest study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00066690">

7391SOFT</a>

7392 [NCT00066690]) to examine the addition of ovarian ablation to tamoxifen with or without chemotherapy randomly assigned 2,033 premenopausal women (53% of whom had received previous chemotherapy) to receive tamoxifen or tamoxifen plus ovarian suppression with triptorelin or ablation with surgery or radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.141">

7393141</a>

7394][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7395Level of evidence B1</a>

7396]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7397<ul id="_2315">

7398<li>

7399Upon initial report, with a median follow-up of 5.6 years, there was no significant difference in the primary outcome of DFS (HR, 0.83; 95% CI, 0.66&#8211;1.04; <em>

7400P</em>

7401 = .10); the 5-year DFS rate was 86% in the tamoxifen-plus-ovarian-suppression group versus 84.7% in the tamoxifen-alone group. However, updated results with a median follow-up of 8 years, demonstrated improved DFS with tamoxifen plus ovarian suppression compared with tamoxifen alone (HR, 0.76; 95% CI, 0.62&#8211;0.93, <em>

7402P</em>

7403 = .009); the 8-year DFS rate was 83.2% in the tamoxifen-plus-ovarian-suppression group versus 78.9% in the tamoxifen-alone group. </li>

7404<li>

7405In addition, OS at 8 years was improved with tamoxifen plus ovarian suppression compared with tamoxifen alone (HR, 0.67; 95% CI, 0.48&#8211;0.92; <em>

7406P</em>

7407 = .01); the 8-year OS rate was 93.3% in the tamoxifen-plus-ovarian-suppression group versus 91.5% in the tamoxifen-alone group.<p id="_2340" tabindex="-1">

7408Despite overall negative initial results, subgroup analysis suggested a benefit with ovarian suppression in women who underwent chemotherapy and remained premenopausal afterwards. Follow-up results at 8 years, however, did not demonstrate heterogeneity of treatment effect according to whether chemotherapy was administered, although recurrences were more frequent among patients who received chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.142">

7409142</a>

7410]</p>

7411</li>

7412</ul>

7413</div>

7414</li>

7415<li>

7416A Korean Breast Cancer Study Group trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00912548">

7417NCT00912548</a>

7418) included 1,293 premenopausal women younger than 45 years, all of whom had received adjuvant chemotherapy and either retained ovarian function or regained it after 2 years of tamoxifen. Patients were randomly assigned to receive either ovarian function suppression with goserelin plus tamoxifen or tamoxifen alone.[<a href="#cit/section_4.143">

7419143</a>

7420] <div class="pdq-content-list">

7421<ul id="_2258">

7422<li>

7423In the intent-to-treat analysis of 1,282 patients, the 5-year DFS rate was 89.8% for patients in the goserelin-plus-tamoxifen group and 87.3% for patients in the tamoxifen-alone group (HR, 0.69; 95% CI, 0.49&#8211;0.98; <em>

7424P</em>

7425 = .036). </li>

7426<li>

7427OS was a secondary end point and was also improved for patients in the goserelin-plus-tamoxifen group (HR, 0.31; 95% CI, 0.10&#8211;0.95; <em>

7428P</em>

7429 = .039).[<a href="#cit/section_4.143">

7430143</a>

7431][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7432Level of evidence A1</a>

7433]</li>

7434</ul>

7435</div>

7436</li>

7437</ol>

7438</div>

7439</section>

7440<section id="_1034">

7441<h5 id="_1034_toc">

7442Aromatase inhibitors (AIs)</h5>

7443<section id="_1609">

7444<h6 id="_1609_toc">

7445Premenopausal women</h6>

7446<p id="_1610" tabindex="-1">

7447AIs have been compared with tamoxifen in premenopausal women in whom ovarian function was suppressed or ablated. The results of these studies have been conflicting.</p>

7448<p id="_1611" tabindex="-1">

7449Evidence (comparison of an AI with tamoxifen in premenopausal women):</p>

7450<div class="pdq-content-list">

7451<ol id="_1612">

7452<li>

7453In one study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00295646">

7454NCT00295646</a>

7455), 1,803 women who received goserelin were randomly assigned to a 2 &#215; 2 factorial design trial that compared anastrozole and tamoxifen, with or without zoledronic acid.[<a href="#cit/section_4.144">

7456144</a>

7457]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7458<ul id="_1613">

7459<li>

7460At a median follow-up of 62 months, there was no difference in DFS (HR, 1.08; 95% CI, 0.81&#8211;1.44; <em>

7461P</em>

7462 = .59).</li>

7463<li>

7464OS was superior with tamoxifen (HR, 1.75; 95% CI, 1.08&#8211;2.83; <em>

7465P</em>

7466 = .02).</li>

7467</ul>

7468</div>

7469</li>

7470<li>

7471In two unblinded studies that were analyzed together (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00066703">

7472TEXT</a>

7473 [NCT00066703] and <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00066703">

7474SOFT</a>

7475 [NCT00066690]), exemestane was also compared with tamoxifen in 4,690 premenopausal women who underwent ovarian ablation.[<a href="#cit/section_4.145">

7476145</a>

7477]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7478<ol id="_1718" class="lower-alpha">

7479<li>

7480The use of exemestane resulted in a significant difference in DFS (HR, 0.77; 95% CI, 0.67&#8211;0.90; <em>

7481P</em>

7482 &lt; .001; 8-year DFS, 86.8% in the exemestane-ovarian suppression group vs. 82.8% in the tamoxifen-ovarian-suppression group).[<a href="#cit/section_4.145">

7483145</a>

7484][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7485Level of evidence B1</a>

7486]</li>

7487<li>

7488 The 8-year rate of freedom from distant recurrence was also higher in the exemestane-ovarian-suppression group (HR, 0.80; 95% CI, 0.66&#8211;0.96; <em>

7489P</em>

7490 = .02); 8-year rate of freedom from distant recurrence was 91.8% in the exemestane-ovarian-suppression group versus 89.7% in the tamoxifen-ovarian-suppression group.</li>

7491<li>

7492Despite improvements in DFS and freedom from distant recurrence, no difference in OS was observed with the use of exemestane in combination with ovarian suppression compared with tamoxifen in combination with ovarian suppression (HR, 0.98; 95% CI, 0.79&#8211;1.22; <em>

7493P</em>

7494 = .84; 8-year OS, 93.4% in the exemestane-ovarian suppression group vs. 93.3% in the tamoxifen-ovarian-suppression group).[<a href="#cit/section_4.145">

7495145</a>

7496][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7497Level of evidence A1</a>

7498] </li>

7499<li>

7500A follow-up report on the differences in QOL for the exemestane-ovarian-suppression group versus the tamoxifen-ovarian-suppression group observed the following (the differences cited below were all significant at <em>

7501P</em>

7502 &lt; .001 and occurred in patients who did and did not receive chemotherapy):[<a href="#cit/section_4.146">

7503146</a>

7504]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7505<ul id="_1719">

7506<li>

7507Patients who received tamoxifen plus ovarian function suppression were more affected by hot flushes and sweats over 5 years than were those who received exemestane plus ovarian function suppression, although these symptoms improved. </li>

7508<li>

7509Patients who received exemestane plus ovarian function suppression reported more vaginal dryness, greater loss of sexual interest, and difficulties becoming aroused than did patients who received tamoxifen plus ovarian function suppression; these differences persisted over time. </li>

7510<li>

7511An increase in bone or joint pain was more pronounced, particularly in the short term, in patients who received exemestane plus ovarian function suppression than in patients who received tamoxifen plus ovarian function suppression. </li>

7512<li>

7513Changes in global QOL indicators from baseline were small and similar between treatments over the 5 years.[<a href="#cit/section_4.146">

7514146</a>

7515][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7516Level of evidence A3</a>

7517]</li>

7518</ul>

7519</div>

7520</li>

7521</ol>

7522</div>

7523</li>

7524</ol>

7525</div>

7526</section>

7527<section id="_1615">

7528<h6 id="_1615_toc">

7529Postmenopausal women</h6>

7530<p id="_1616" tabindex="-1">

7531In postmenopausal women, the use of AIs in sequence with or as a substitute for tamoxifen has been the subject of multiple studies, the results of which have been summarized in an individual patient-level meta-analysis.[<a href="#cit/section_4.147">

7532147</a>

7533] </p>

7534<section id="_1617">

7535<h6 id="_1617_toc">

7536Initial therapy</h6>

7537<p id="_1623" tabindex="-1">

7538Evidence (AI vs. tamoxifen as initial therapy in postmenopausal women):</p>

7539<div class="pdq-content-list">

7540<ol id="_1618">

7541<li>

7542A large, randomized trial of 9,366 patients compared the use of the AI anastrozole and the combination of anastrozole and tamoxifen with tamoxifen alone as adjuvant therapy for postmenopausal patients with lymph node-negative or lymph node-positive disease. Most (84%) of the patients in the study were hormone receptor&#8211;positive. Slightly more than 20% had received chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.148">

7543148</a>

7544]; [<a href="#cit/section_4.149">

7545149</a>

7546][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7547Level of evidence B1</a>

7548]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7549<ul id="_1624">

7550<li>

7551With a median follow-up of 33.3 months, no benefit in DFS was observed for the combination arm relative to tamoxifen alone.[<a href="#cit/section_4.148">

7552148</a>

7553]</li>

7554<li>

7555Patients on anastrozole, however, had a significantly longer DFS (HR, 0.83) than those on tamoxifen. In an analysis conducted after a median follow-up of 100 months among hormone receptor&#8211;positive patients, DFS was significantly (<em>

7556P</em>

7557 = .003) longer in patients on anastrozole (HR, 0.85; 95% CI, 0.76&#8211;0.94), but OS was not improved (HR, 0.97; 95% CI, 0.86&#8211;1.11; <em>

7558P</em>

7559 = .7).[<a href="#cit/section_4.149">

7560149</a>

7561]</li>

7562<li>

7563Patients on tamoxifen more frequently developed endometrial cancer and cerebrovascular accidents, whereas patients on anastrozole had more fracture episodes. The frequency of myocardial infarction was similar in both groups. Except for a continued increased frequency of endometrial cancer in the tamoxifen group, these differences did not persist in the posttreatment period.[<a href="#cit/section_4.149">

7564149</a>

7565]</li>

7566</ul>

7567</div>

7568</li>

7569<li>

7570A large, double-blinded, randomized trial of 8,010 postmenopausal women with hormone receptor&#8211;positive breast cancer compared the use of letrozole with tamoxifen given continuously for 5 years or with crossover to the alternate drug at 2 years.[<a href="#cit/section_4.150">

7571150</a>

7572] An updated analysis from the International Breast Cancer Study Group (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00004205">

7573IBCSG-1-98</a>

7574 [NCT00004205]) reported results on the 4,922 women who received tamoxifen or letrozole for 5 years at a median follow-up of 51 months.[<a href="#cit/section_4.151">

7575151</a>

7576][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7577Level of evidence B1</a>

7578]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7579<ul id="_1625">

7580<li>

7581DFS was significantly superior in patients treated with letrozole (HR, 0.82; 95% CI, 0.71&#8211;0.95; <em>

7582P </em>

7583= .007; 5-year DFS, 84.0% vs. 81.1%).</li>

7584<li>

7585OS was not significantly different in patients treated with letrozole (HR, 0.91; 95% CI, 0.75&#8211;1.11; <em>

7586P</em>

7587 = .35). </li>

7588</ul>

7589</div>

7590</li>

7591<li>

7592In the meta-analysis, which included 9,885 women from multiple trials, the 10-year recurrence risk was 19.1% in the AI group versus 22.7% in the tamoxifen group (RR, 0.80; 95% CI, 0.73&#8211;0.88; <em>

7593P</em>

7594 &lt; .001). The overall 10-year mortality rate was also reduced from 24.0% to 21.3%. (RR, 0.89; 95% CI, 0.8&#8211;0.97; <em>

7595P</em>

7596 = .01).[<a href="#cit/section_4.147">

7597147</a>

7598][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810019&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810019&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7599Level of evidence A2</a>

7600]</li>

7601</ol>

7602</div>

7603</section>

7604</section>

7605<section id="_1098">

7606<h6 id="_1098_toc">

7607Sequential tamoxifen and AI versus 5 years of tamoxifen</h6>

7608<p id="_1099" tabindex="-1">

7609Several trials and meta-analyses have examined the effect of switching to anastrozole or exemestane to complete a total of 5 years of therapy after 2 to 3 years of tamoxifen.[<a href="#cit/section_4.152">

7610152</a>

7611-<a href="#cit/section_4.154">

7612154</a>

7613] The evidence, as described below, indicates that sequential tamoxifen and AI is superior to remaining on tamoxifen for 5 years.</p>

7614<p id="_1250" tabindex="-1">

7615Evidence (sequential tamoxifen and AI vs. 5 years of tamoxifen):</p>

7616<div class="pdq-content-list">

7617<ol id="_1251">

7618<li>

7619Two trials carried out in sequence by the same group enrolled a total of 828 patients and were reported together; one trial used aminoglutethimide as the AI, and the other trial used anastrozole. After a median follow-up of 78 months, an improvement in all-cause mortality (HR, 0.61; 95% CI, 0.42&#8211;0.88; <em>

7620P</em>

7621 = .007) was observed in the AI groups.[<a href="#cit/section_4.154">

7622154</a>

7623][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7624Level of evidence A1</a>

7625]</li>

7626<li>

7627Two other trials were reported together.[<a href="#cit/section_4.153">

7628153</a>

7629] A total of 3,224 patients were randomly assigned after 2 years of tamoxifen to continue tamoxifen for a total of 5 years or to take anastrozole for 3 years. There was a significant difference in event-free survival (EFS) (HR, 0.80; 95% CI; <em>

7630P</em>

7631 = .0009), but not in OS (5-year OS, 97% CI for the switched arm vs. 96% CI for the tamoxifen-alone arm; <em>

7632P</em>

7633 = .16).[<a href="#cit/section_4.154">

7634154</a>

7635][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7636Level of evidence B1</a>

7637]</li>

7638<li>

7639A large, double-blinded, randomized trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003418">

7640EORTC-10967</a>

7641 [ICCG-96OEXE031-C1396-BIG9702]) (NCT00003418) of 4,742 patients compared continuing tamoxifen with switching to exemestane for a total of 5 years of therapy in women who had received 2 to 3 years of tamoxifen.[<a href="#cit/section_4.155">

7642155</a>

7643][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7644Level of evidence B1</a>

7645] <div class="pdq-content-list">

7646<ul id="_1253">

7647<li>

7648 After the second planned interim analysis, when median follow-up for patients on the study was 30.6 months, the results were released because of a highly significant (<em>

7649P</em>

7650 &lt; .005) difference in DFS (HR, 0.68) favoring the exemestane arm.[<a href="#cit/section_4.155">

7651155</a>

7652]</li>

7653<li>

7654After a median follow-up of 55.7 months, the HR for DFS was 0.76 (95% CI, 0.66&#8211;0.88; <em>

7655P</em>

7656 = .001) in favor of exemestane.[<a href="#cit/section_4.156">

7657156</a>

7658][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7659Level of evidence A1</a>

7660]</li>

7661<li>

7662At 2.5 years after random assignment, 3.3% fewer patients on exemestane had developed a DFS event (95% CI, 1.6&#8211;4.9). The HR for OS was 0.85 (95% CI, 0.7&#8211;1.02; <em>

7663P</em>

7664 = .08).[<a href="#cit/section_4.156">

7665156</a>

7666]</li>

7667</ul>

7668</div>

7669</li>

7670</ol>

7671</div>

7672<p id="_1626" tabindex="-1">

7673In the meta-analysis, which included 11,798 patients from six trials, the 10-year recurrence rate was reduced from 19% to 17% in the AI-containing groups (RR, 0.82; 95% CI, 0.75&#8211;0.91; <em>

7674P</em>

7675 = .0001). The overall 10-year mortality was 17.5% in the tamoxifen group and 14.6% in the AI-containing group (RR, 0.82; 95% CI, 0.73&#8211;0.91; <em>

7676P</em>

7677 = .0002).[<a href="#cit/section_4.147">

7678147</a>

7679][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810019&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810019&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7680Level of evidence A2</a>

7681] </p>

7682</section>

7683<section id="_1103">

7684<h6 id="_1103_toc">

7685Sequential tamoxifen and AI for 5 years versus 5 years of an AI</h6>

7686<p id="_1359" tabindex="-1">

7687The evidence indicates that there is no benefit to the sequential use of tamoxifen and an AI for 5 years over 5 years of an AI.</p>

7688<p id="_1256" tabindex="-1">

7689Evidence (sequential use of tamoxifen and an AI vs. 5 years of an AI):</p>

7690<div class="pdq-content-list">

7691<ol id="_1257">

7692<li>

7693A large, randomized trial of 9,779 patients compared DFS of postmenopausal women with hormone receptor&#8211;positive breast cancer between initial treatment with sequential tamoxifen for 2.5 to 3 years followed by exemestane for a total of 5 years versus exemestane alone for 5 years. The primary end points were DFS at 2.75 years and 5.0 years.[<a href="#cit/section_4.157">

7694157</a>

7695][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7696Level of evidence B1</a>

7697]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7698<ul id="_1258">

7699<li>

7700Five-year DFS was 85% in the sequential group and 86% in the exemestane-alone group (HR, 0.97; 95% CI, 0.88&#8211;1.08; <em>

7701P</em>

7702 = .60).</li>

7703</ul>

7704</div>

7705</li>

7706<li>

7707Similarly in the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00004205">

7708IBCSG 1-98</a>

7709 trial (NCT00004205), two sequential arms were compared with 5 years of letrozole.[<a href="#cit/section_4.158">

7710158</a>

7711][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7712Level of evidence B1</a>

7713]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7714<ul id="_1259">

7715<li>

7716There was no difference in DFS when the two sequential arms were compared with 5 years of letrozole (letrozole to tamoxifen HR, 1.06; 95% CI, 0.91&#8211;1.23; <em>

7717P</em>

7718 = .45 and tamoxifen to letrozole HR, 1.07; 95% CI, 0.92&#8211;1.25; <em>

7719P</em>

7720 = .36).</li>

7721</ul>

7722</div>

7723</li>

7724<li>

7725The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00541086">

7726FATA-GIM3</a>

7727 trial (NCT00541086), which was not included in the meta-analysis, compared 2 years of tamoxifen followed by 3 years of one of the three AIs with 5 years of an AI. No significant difference in 5-year DFS was found between the two approaches (88.5% for switching; 89.8% for upfront AI; HR, 0.89; 95% CI, 0.73&#8211;1.08; <em>

7728P</em>

7729 = .23).[<a href="#cit/section_4.159">

7730159</a>

7731]

7732</li>

7733</ol>

7734</div>

7735<p id="_1627" tabindex="-1">

7736In the meta-analysis, which included 12,779 patients from the trials, the 7-year recurrence rate was slightly reduced from 14.5% to 13.8% in the groups that received 5 years of an AI (RR, 0.90; 95% CI, 0.81&#8211;0.99; <em>

7737P</em>

7738 = .045). Overall mortality at 7 years was 9.3% in the tamoxifen-followed-by-AI groups and 8.2% in the AI-alone groups (RR, 0.89; 95% CI, 0.78&#8211;1.03; <em>

7739P</em>

7740 = .11).[<a href="#cit/section_4.147">

7741147</a>

7742][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810019&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810019&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7743Level of evidence A2</a>

7744]</p>

7745</section>

7746<section id="_1619">

7747<h6 id="_1619_toc">

7748One AI versus another for 5 years</h6>

7749<div class="pdq-content-list">

7750<ol id="_1620">

7751<li>

7752The mild androgen activity of exemestane prompted a randomized trial that evaluated whether exemestane might be preferable to anastrozole, in terms of its efficacy (i.e., EFS) and toxicity, as upfront therapy for postmenopausal women diagnosed with hormone receptor&#8211;positive breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_4.160">

7753160</a>

7754][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7755Level of evidence A1</a>

7756] The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00066573">

7757MA27</a>

7758 trial (NCT00066573) randomly assigned 7,576 postmenopausal women to receive 5 years of anastrozole or exemestane.<div class="pdq-content-list">

7759<ul id="_1621">

7760<li>

7761At a median follow-up of 4.1 years, no difference in efficacy was seen (HR, 1.02; 95% CI, 0.87&#8211;1.18; <em>

7762P</em>

7763 = .86).[<a href="#cit/section_4.160">

7764160</a>

7765][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7766Level of evidence B1</a>

7767]</li>

7768<li>

7769The two therapies also were not significantly different in terms of impact on bone mineral density or fracture rates.[<a href="#cit/section_4.161">

7770161</a>

7771][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7772Level of evidence B1</a>

7773]</li>

7774</ul>

7775</div>

7776</li>

7777<li>

7778In the Femara Versus Anastrozole Clinical Evaluation (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00248170">

7779FACE</a>

7780 [NCT00248170]) study, 4,136 patients with hormone receptor&#8211;positive disease were randomly assigned to receive either letrozole or anastrozole.[<a href="#cit/section_4.162">

7781162</a>

7782]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7783<ul id="_1784">

7784<li>

7785There was no significant difference in DFS (HR, 0.93; 95% CI, 0.80&#8211;1.07; <em>

7786P</em>

7787 = .3150) at the time of a final analysis that was conducted when there were 709 of the planned 959 events. </li>

7788<li>

7789There were no substantial differences in adverse events between the arms.</li>

7790</ul>

7791</div>

7792</li>

7793<li>

7794In the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00541086">

7795FATA-GIM3</a>

7796 trial, 3,697 patients with hormone receptor&#8211;positive disease were randomly assigned among the three AIs either for 5 years or after 2 years of tamoxifen. No significant difference in 5-year DFS (90.0% for anastrozole, 88.0% for exemestane, and 89.4% for letrozole; <em>

7797P</em>

7798 = .24) was noted among the three AIs.[<a href="#cit/section_4.159">

7799159</a>

7800]

7801</li>

7802</ol>

7803</div>

7804</section>

7805<section id="_1106">

7806<h6 id="_1106_toc">

7807Switching to an AI after 5 years of tamoxifen</h6>

7808<p id="_1260" tabindex="-1">

7809The evidence, as described below, indicates that switching to an AI after 5 years of tamoxifen is superior to stopping tamoxifen at that time.</p>

7810<div class="pdq-content-list">

7811<ol id="_1261">

7812<li>

7813

7814A large, double-blinded, randomized trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003140">

7815CAN-NCIC-MA17</a>

7816 [NCT00003140]) of 5,187 patients compared the use of letrozole versus placebo in receptor-positive postmenopausal women who received tamoxifen for approximately 5 years (range, 4.5&#8211;6.0) years.[<a href="#cit/section_4.163">

7817163</a>

7818][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7819Level of evidence B1</a>

7820]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7821<ul id="_1262">

7822<li>

7823After the first planned interim analysis, when median follow-up for patients in the study was 2.4 years, the results were unblinded because of a highly significant (<em>

7824P</em>

7825 &lt; .008) difference in DFS (HR, 0.57), favoring the letrozole arm.[<a href="#cit/section_4.163">

7826163</a>

7827]</li>

7828<li>

7829After 3 years of follow-up, 4.8% of the women on the letrozole arm had developed recurrent disease or new primaries versus 9.8% on the placebo arm (95% CI for the difference, 2.7%&#8211;7.3%). Because of the early unblinding of the study, longer-term comparative data on the risks and benefits of letrozole in this setting will not be available.[<a href="#cit/section_4.164">

7830164</a>

7831,<a href="#cit/section_4.165">

7832165</a>

7833]</li>

7834<li>

7835An updated analysis including all events before unblinding confirmed the results of the interim analysis.[<a href="#cit/section_4.166">

7836166</a>

7837] In addition, a statistically significant improvement in distant DFS was found for patients who received letrozole (HR, 0.60; 95% CI, 0.43&#8211;0.84; <em>

7838P</em>

7839 = .002). Although no statistically significant difference was found in the total study population, the lymph node-positive patients who received letrozole also experienced a statistically significant improvement in OS (HR, 0.61; 95% CI, 0.38&#8211;0.98; <em>

7840P</em>

7841 = .04), although the <em>

7842P</em>

7843 value was not corrected for multiple comparisons.</li>

7844</ul>

7845</div>

7846</li>

7847<li>

7848The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00016432">

7849NSABP B-33</a>

7850 trial (NCT00016432) that was designed to compare 5 years of exemestane with placebo after 5 years of tamoxifen was stopped prematurely when the results of <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003140">

7851CAN-NCIC-MA17</a>

7852 became available. At the time of analysis, 560 of the 783 patients who were randomly assigned to receive exemestane remained on that drug and 344 of the 779 patients who were randomly assigned to receive placebo had crossed over to exemestane.[<a href="#cit/section_4.167">

7853167</a>

7854][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7855Level of evidence B1</a>

7856]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7857<ul id="_1263">

7858<li>

7859An intent-to-treat analysis of the primary study end point, DFS, demonstrated a nonsignificant benefit of exemestane (HR, 0.68; <em>

7860P</em>

7861 = .07).</li>

7862</ul>

7863</div>

7864</li>

7865</ol>

7866</div>

7867</section>

7868<section id="_1109">

7869<h6 id="_1109_toc">

7870Duration of AI therapy</h6>

7871<p id="_1813" tabindex="-1">

7872The optimal duration of AI therapy is uncertain, and multiple trials have evaluated courses longer than 5 years. </p>

7873<p id="_1658" tabindex="-1">

7874Evidence regarding extension of endocrine therapy beyond 5 years of initial AI-based adjuvant therapy:</p>

7875<div class="pdq-content-list">

7876<ol id="_1659">

7877<li>

7878A double-blind, randomized, phase III trial assessed the effect of an additional 5 years of letrozole versus placebo in 1,918 women who had received 5 years of an AI.[<a href="#cit/section_4.168">

7879168</a>

7880] Patients who received previous tamoxifen therapy were included. Most women on the study (70.6%) had received 4.5 to 6 years of adjuvant tamoxifen, but a significant proportion of them (20.7%) had been treated initially with an AI.<div class="pdq-content-list">

7881<ol id="_1660" class="lower-alpha">

7882<li>

7883At a median follow-up of 6.3 years, DFS, the primary study end point, was significantly improved in patients randomly assigned to receive letrozole (HR, 0.66; 95% CI, 0.48&#8211;0.91; <em>

7884P</em>

7885 = .01), and 5-year DFS was improved from 91% to 95%.[<a href="#cit/section_4.168">

7886168</a>

7887][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7888Level of evidence B1</a>

7889]</li>

7890<li>

7891 OS rates showed no difference (HR, 0.97; 95% CI, 0.73&#8211;1.28; <em>

7892P</em>

7893 = .83). More patients on letrozole had fractures (14%) than did patients on placebo (9%) (<em>

7894P</em>

7895 = .001).</li>

7896<li>

7897QOL was assessed with the Medical Outcomes Study 36-Item Short-Form Health Survey (SF-36) and Menopause-Specific QOL (MENQOL) instruments. More than 85% of participants completed yearly assessments over a 5-year period. <div class="pdq-content-list">

7898<ul id="_1661">

7899<li>

7900No between-group differences were found on the four MENQOL subscales or on the SF-36 summary score. </li>

7901<li>

7902SF-36 role-emotional and bodily pain scores were statistically significantly worse (<em>

7903P</em>

7904 = .03) among patients receiving letrozole, but the differences observed were fewer than the minimum clinically important differences for the SF-36 instrument.</li>

7905</ul>

7906</div>

7907</li>

7908</ol>

7909</div>

7910</li>

7911<li>

7912A randomized phase III study assessed the effect of an additional 2.5 years of letrozole versus 5 years of letrozole in 1,824 women who received 5 years of an AI.[<a href="#cit/section_4.169">

7913169</a>

7914][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7915Level of evidence B1</a>

7916] <div class="pdq-content-list">

7917<ul id="_1804">

7918<li>

7919DFS events were similar in both groups (HR, 0.92; 95% CI, 0.74&#8211;1.16). The distant metastasis-free interval was also similar (HR, 1.06; 95% CI, 0.78&#8211;1.45). </li>

7920<li>

7921A subgroup analysis did not identify patients who benefited from 5-year extended therapy.</li>

7922<li>

7923This study did not show that 10 years of AI therapy was superior to 7.5 years of AI therapy.</li>

7924</ul>

7925</div>

7926</li>

7927<li>

7928A phase III trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00382070">

7929NSABP-B42</a>

7930 [NCT00382070]) randomly assigned, in a double-blind fashion, 3,966 women who received 5 years of initial adjuvant therapy with an AI or received tamoxifen for 2 to 3 years followed by an AI to receive 5 mg of letrozole or placebo for 5 additional years.[<a href="#cit/section_4.170">

7931170</a>

7932][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7933Level of evidence B1</a>

7934] The planned analysis of DFS was carried out after a median follow-up of 6.9 years.<div class="pdq-content-list">

7935<ul id="_2018">

7936<li>

7937The 7-year DFS was 81.3% in the placebo group and 84.7% in the letrozole group (HR, 0.85; 95% CI, 0.73&#8211;0.999; <em>

7938P</em>

7939 = .048). The observed difference was not statistically significant when interim analyses were accounted for.</li>

7940<li>

7941There were no statistically significant differences in adverse events between the arms.</li>

7942</ul>

7943</div>

7944</li>

7945<li>

7946A phase III trial conducted by the IBCSG (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00553410">

7947SOLE</a>

7948 [NCT00553410]) randomly assigned 4,851 eligible receptor-positive postmenopausal women who had completed 5 years of adjuvant therapy with an AI, a selective estrogen receptor modulator, or both, to receive 2.5 mg of letrozole daily for 5 years or to an intermittent schedule in which there was a 3-month break at the end of each of the first 4 years, but not in the final year.[<a href="#cit/section_4.171">

7949171</a>

7950]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7951<ul id="_2026">

7952<li>

7953There was no observed advantage to the intermittent schedule with respect to DFS (HR, 1.08; 95% CI, 0.93&#8211;1.26; <em>

7954P</em>

7955 = .31) or in the frequency of adverse events.[<a href="#cit/section_4.171">

7956171</a>

7957][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7958Level of evidence B1</a>

7959]</li>

7960</ul>

7961</div>

7962</li>

7963<li>

7964A phase III trial conducted by the Dutch Breast Cancer Study Group (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00301457">

7965DATA</a>

7966 [NCT00301457]) randomly assigned 1,860 eligible receptor-positive postmenopausal women who had received 2 to 3 years of tamoxifen to receive either 3 or 6 years of anastrozole (1 mg daily).[<a href="#cit/section_4.172">

7967172</a>

7968]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7969<ul id="_2027">

7970<li>

7971At 3 years, 1,660 of these women were free of disease: among them, DFS was observed to be improved, but not statistically significantly so, on the extended-therapy arm (HR, 0.79; 95% CI, 0.62&#8211;1.02).[<a href="#cit/section_4.172">

7972172</a>

7973][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7974Level of evidence B1</a>

7975] Myalgia and osteoporosis/osteopenia were more frequent on the extended-therapy arm.</li>

7976</ul>

7977</div>

7978 </li>

7979<li>

7980 A phase III, open-label, Italian trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01064635">

7981NCT01064635</a>

7982) included 2,056 hormone receptor&#8211;positive postmenopausal women who had received 2 to 3 years of tamoxifen treatment. Patients were randomly assigned to receive letrozole for either 2 to 3 years (control) or 5 years (extended therapy). The primary end point was IDFS.[<a href="#cit/section_4.173">

7983173</a>

7984]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7985<ul id="_2427">

7986<li>

7987After 11.7 years of follow up, the 12-year DFS rate was 62% in the control group and 67% in the extended-therapy group (HR, 0.78; 95% CI, 0.65&#8211;0.93; <em>

7988P</em>

7989 = .0064). These results were confirmed in a landmark analysis that excluded patients who experienced a DFS event or who were lost to follow-up before treatment divergence (2&#8211;3 years after randomization).</li>

7990<li>

7991 The 12-year OS rate was 84% in the control group and 88% in the extended-therapy group (HR, 0.77; 95% CI, 0.60&#8211;0.98; <em>

7992P</em>

7993 = .036).[<a href="#cit/section_4.173">

7994173</a>

7995][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7996Level of evidence A1</a>

7997]</li>

7998<li>

7999 Grade 3 or greater arthralgia and myalgia were slightly more frequent in the extended-therapy group than in the control group (3.0% vs. 2.2% and 0.9% vs. 0.7%, respectively).</li>

8000</ul>

8001</div>

8002 </li>

8003<li>

8004The phase III ABCSG-16 study enrolled 3,484 postmenopausal women with hormone receptor&#8211;positive breast cancer who had completed 5 years of endocrine therapy with tamoxifen and/or an AI to either 2 or 5 years of extended therapy with anastrozole. The primary end point was DFS in the 3,208 patients who remained in the study after 2 years. Secondary end points included OS, time to contralateral breast cancer, time to second primary cancer, fractures, and toxicity.[<a href="#cit/section_4.174">

8005174</a>

8006]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8007<ul id="_2029">

8008<li>

8009After 10 years of follow-up, there was no difference in DFS between the two arms (73.6% for the 2-year course vs. 73.9% for the 5-year course [HR, 0.99; 95% CI, 0.85&#8211;1.15; <em>

8010P</em>

8011 = .90]). In addition, there was no difference in OS, time to second primary cancer, and time to contralateral breast cancer between the arms.[<a href="#cit/section_4.174">

8012174</a>

8013][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8014Level of evidence B1</a>

8015]</li>

8016<li>

8017 There was a trend towards more fractures in the 5-year arm (4.7% vs. 6.3%; HR, 1.35; 95% CI, 1.00&#8211;1.84).

8018

8019</li>

8020</ul>

8021</div>

8022</li>

8023</ol>

8024</div>

8025</section>

8026</section>

8027<section id="_2263">

8028<h5 id="_2263_toc">

8029Endocrine therapy and cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK) inhibitor therapy</h5>

8030<p id="_2264" tabindex="-1">

8031CDK4 and CDK6 have been implicated in the continued proliferation of hormone receptor&#8211;positive breast cancer that is resistant to endocrine therapy. CDK inhibitors, in combination with endocrine therapy, have been approved by the FDA in both first-line and later-line treatment of patients with advanced hormone receptor&#8211;positive HER2-negative breast cancer and are now being studied in the adjuvant setting. </p>

8032<p id="_2265" tabindex="-1">

8033Evidence (CDK inhibitors in the adjuvant setting):</p>

8034<div class="pdq-content-list">

8035<ol id="_2266">

8036<li>

8037The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03155997">

8038monarchE</a>

8039 trial (NCT03155997) examined the effect of adding abemaciclib to standard endocrine therapy in women with hormone receptor&#8211;positive HER2-negative breast cancer who were at high risk of recurrence.[<a href="#cit/section_4.175">

8040175</a>

8041] The trial enrolled 5,637 women who met one of the following criteria: four or more positive nodes; or one to three positive nodes and either tumor size 5 cm or larger, histological grade 3, or central Ki67 20% or greater. The women were randomly assigned in a 1:1 ratio to standard-of-care adjuvant endocrine therapy with or without open-label abemaciclib (150 mg twice daily for 2 years). The primary end point was IDFS and secondary end points included distant RFS, OS, and safety.<div class="pdq-content-list">

8042<ul id="_2267">

8043<li>

8044At a preplanned efficacy interim analysis, 323 IDFS events were observed in the intent-to-treat population. Abemaciclib plus endocrine therapy demonstrated superior IDFS versus endocrine therapy alone (HR, 0.75; 95% CI, 0.60&#8211;0.93; 2-year IDFS rates, 92.2% vs. 88.7%; <em>

8045P</em>

8046 = .01).[<a href="#cit/section_4.175">

8047175</a>

8048][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8049Level of evidence B1</a>

8050]</li>

8051<li>

8052Because of adverse events, abemaciclib dose adjustments occurred in 1,901 patients (68.1%); 56.9% of these patients had dose omissions and 41.2% had dose reductions. In the abemaciclib arm, 463 patients (16.6%) discontinued abemaciclib because of adverse events, 306 of whom remained on endocrine therapy when abemaciclib was discontinued. </li>

8053</ul>

8054</div>

8055</li>

8056<li>

8057 The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02513394">

8058PALLAS</a>

8059 trial (NCT02513394) studied the effect of adding palbociclib to standard adjuvant therapy in women with stage II to stage III hormone receptor&#8211;positive HER2-negative breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_4.176">

8060176</a>

8061] In the trial, 5,760 women were randomly assigned in a 1:1 ratio without blinding to receive one of the two regimens within 6 months of starting endocrine therapy. The primary end point was IDFS.<div class="pdq-content-list">

8062<ul id="_2317">

8063<li>

8064At the time of the second interim analysis, no significant difference between the treatment arms was found (HR, 0.93; 95% CI, 0.76&#8211;1.15; 3-year IDFS rates, 88.2% vs. 88.5%; <em>

8065P</em>

8066 = .51).[<a href="#cit/section_4.176">

8067176</a>

8068][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8069Level of evidence B1</a>

8070]

8071</li>

8072<li>

8073 As the test statistic for futility crossed the prespecified boundary, the data safety monitoring committee recommended that patients discontinue palbociclib therapy.</li>

8074<li>

8075 Neutropenia and leukopenia were much more common in patients on the palbociclib arm, and fatigue was slightly more common, but there were no treatment-related deaths.</li>

8076</ul>

8077</div>

8078</li>

8079</ol>

8080</div>

8081</section>

8082<section id="_2078">

8083<h5 id="_2078_toc">

8084Bone-modifying therapy</h5>

8085<p id="_2079" tabindex="-1">

8086Both bisphosphonates and denosumab have been evaluated as adjuvant therapies for early-stage breast cancer; however, their role is unclear. Compared with denosumab, the amount of evidence supporting bisphosphonates is greater, and there is evidence supporting a reduction in breast cancer mortality&#8212;an end point that is more clinically relevant. The optimal duration of bisphosphonate therapy is uncertain.</p>

8087<p id="_2080" tabindex="-1">

8088Evidence (bisphosphonates in the treatment of early breast cancer):</p>

8089<div class="pdq-content-list">

8090<ol id="_2081">

8091<li>

8092A meta-analysis included data from 18,766 patients from 26 adjuvant trials of bisphosphonates of any type.[<a href="#cit/section_4.177">

8093177</a>

8094] Overall, reductions associated with bisphosphonate use in recurrence (RR, 0.94; 95% CI, 0.87&#8211;1.01; 2-sided <em>

8095P</em>

8096 = .08), distant recurrence (RR, 0.92; 95% CI, 0.85&#8211;0.99; 2-sided <em>

8097P</em>

8098 = .03), and breast cancer mortality (RR, 0.91; 95% CI, 0.83&#8211;0.99; 2-sided <em>

8099P</em>

8100 = .04) were of only borderline significance, but the reduction in bone recurrence was more definite (RR, 0.83; 95% CI, 0.73&#8211;0.94; 2-sided <em>

8101P</em>

8102 = .004).<div class="pdq-content-list">

8103<ul id="_2082">

8104<li>

8105In a prespecified subgroup analysis among premenopausal women, treatment had no apparent effect on any outcome, but among 11,767 postmenopausal women, it produced highly significant reductions in recurrence (RR, 0.86; 95% CI, 0.78&#8211;0.94; 2-sided <em>

8106P</em>

8107 = .002), distant recurrence (RR, 0.82; 95% CI, 0.74&#8211;0.92; 2-sided <em>

8108P</em>

8109 = .0003), bone recurrence (RR, 0.72; 95% CI, 0.60&#8211;0.86; 2-sided <em>

8110P</em>

8111 = .0002), and breast cancer mortality (RR, 0.82; 95% CI, 0.73&#8211;0.93; 2-sided <em>

8112P</em>

8113 = .002).[<a href="#cit/section_4.177">

8114177</a>

8115]</li>

8116</ul>

8117</div>

8118</li>

8119<li>

8120The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00556374">

8121ABCSG-18</a>

8122 trial (NCT00556374) included 3,435 postmenopausal women with receptor-positive breast cancer who were receiving an AI. Patients were randomly assigned to receive denosumab or a placebo every 6 months during AI therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.178">

8123178</a>

8124] The patients were unblinded when results related to bone events were reported, and patients on placebo were allowed to cross over to the active drug. <div class="pdq-content-list">

8125<ul id="_2083">

8126<li>

8127In an intent-to-treat analysis according to the original assignment, DFS, a secondary end point, was improved in patients who received denosumab (HR, 0.82; 95% CI, 0.69&#8211;0.98; <em>

8128P</em>

8129 = .0260; 5-year DFS rate, 89.2% vs. 87.3%).[<a href="#cit/section_4.178">

8130178</a>

8131][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8132Level of evidence B1</a>

8133] </li>

8134<li>

8135The frequency of adverse events was similar in the two groups.</li>

8136</ul>

8137</div>

8138</li>

8139<li>

8140The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01077154">

8141D-CARE</a>

8142 trial (NCT01077154) randomly assigned 4,509 women with stage II or stage III breast cancer to receive denosumab or placebo.[<a href="#cit/section_4.179">

8143179</a>

8144] <div class="pdq-content-list">

8145<ul id="_2230">

8146<li>

8147The primary end point of bone metastasis-free survival was not significantly different between the groups (median, not reached in either group; HR, 0.97; 95% CI, 0.82&#8722;1.14; <em>

8148P</em>

8149 = .70).[<a href="#cit/section_4.179">

8150179</a>

8151][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8152Level of evidence B1</a>

8153]</li>

8154</ul>

8155</div>

8156

8157</li>

8158<li>

8159The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02181101">

8160SUCCESS</a>

8161 trial (NCT02181101) included 3,421 patients with node-positive or high-risk (&#8805;pT2, grade 3, hormone receptor&#8211;negative, or aged 35 years or younger) node-negative breast cancer who completed adjuvant chemotherapy. Patients were randomly assigned to receive zoledronate 4 mg intravenously for either 2 years (every 3 months) or 5 years (every 3 months for 2 years and then every 6 months for 3 years). Only those patients who completed 2 years of zoledronate treatment (1,447 on the 2-year arm; 1,729 on the 5-year arm) were included in the final analysis.[<a href="#cit/section_4.180">

8162180</a>

8163] <div class="pdq-content-list">

8164<ul id="_2475">

8165<li>

8166Outcomes were similar between the two arms for the main study end points of DFS (HR, 0.97; 95% CI, 0.76&#8211;1.25; <em>

8167P</em>

8168 = .83) and OS (HR, 0.93; 95% CI, 0.65&#8211;1.34; <em>

8169P</em>

8170 = .71).[<a href="#cit/section_4.180">

8171180</a>

8172][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8173Level of evidence A1</a>

8174]</li>

8175<li>

8176An accompanying editorial explained why the results of this study do not definitively establish how long bisphosphonates should be administered.[<a href="#cit/section_4.181">

8177181</a>

8178]

8179</li>

8180</ul>

8181</div>

8182

8183</li>

8184</ol>

8185</div>

8186</section>

8187</section>

8188</section>

8189<section id="_1049">

8190<h3 id="_1049_toc">

8191Preoperative Systemic Therapy</h3>

8192<p id="_2276" tabindex="-1">

8193Preoperative chemotherapy, also known as primary or neoadjuvant chemotherapy, has traditionally been administered in patients with locally advanced breast cancer to reduce tumor volume and allow for definitive surgery. Treatment with preoperative chemotherapy can also allow for breast conservation therapy in patients who are not candidates for breast conservation at initial presentation. Preoperative chemotherapy may also reduce the need for an ALND in patients presenting with node-positive disease. </p>

8194<p id="_2355" tabindex="-1">

8195Much of the evidence presented in the following sections on preoperative chemotherapy is discussed in an American Society of Clinical Oncology guideline that describes the selection of options for the management of these patients.[<a href="#cit/section_4.182">

8196182</a>

8197] </p>

8198<p id="_2277" tabindex="-1">

8199A meta-analysis of multiple, randomized clinical trials performed in 2005 demonstrated that preoperative chemotherapy is associated with identical DFS and OS compared with the administration of the same therapy in the adjuvant setting.[<a href="#cit/section_4.183">

8200183</a>

8201][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8202Level of evidence A1</a>

8203] </p>

8204<p id="_2076" tabindex="-1">

8205In 2019, the Early Breast Cancer Trialists&#8217; Collaborative Group performed a meta-analysis using individual patient data from 4,756 women who participated in 10 trials that compared neoadjuvant chemotherapy with the same regimen given in the adjuvant setting.[<a href="#cit/section_4.184">

8206184</a>

8207] Compared with adjuvant therapy, neoadjuvant therapy was associated with an increased frequency of breast conservation (65% vs. 49%). There were no differences between neoadjuvant chemotherapy and adjuvant therapy in distant recurrence, breast cancer mortality, or death from any cause; however, neoadjuvant therapy was associated with higher 15-year local recurrence (21.4% vs. 15.9%; rate ratio, 1.37; 95% CI, 1.17&#8722;1.61; <em>

8208P</em>

8209 = .001).[<a href="#cit/section_4.184">

8210184</a>

8211][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8212Level of evidence A1</a>

8213] </p>

8214<p id="_1662" tabindex="-1">

8215pCR has been used as a surrogate end point for long-term outcomes, such as DFS, EFS, and OS, in preoperative clinical trials in breast cancer. A pooled analysis (CTNeoBC) of 11 preoperative randomized trials (n = 11,955) determined that pCR, defined as no residual invasive cancer in the breast and axillary nodes with presence or absence of <em>

8216in situ</em>

8217 cancer (ypT0/is ypN0 or ypT0 ypN0), provided a better association with improved outcomes compared with eradication of invasive tumor from the breast alone (ypT0/is).[<a href="#cit/section_4.185">

8218185</a>

8219] pCR could not be validated in this study as a surrogate end point for improved EFS and OS.[<a href="#cit/section_4.185">

8220185</a>

8221][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8222Level of evidence C2</a>

8223] Because of a strong association of pCR with substantially improved outcomes in individual patients with more aggressive subtypes of breast cancer, the FDA has supported use of pCR as an end point in preoperative clinical trials for patients with high-risk, early-stage breast cancer.</p>

8224<p id="_2511" tabindex="-1">
