8225Categorizing patients as having pCR or residual disease unfortunately offers no distinction among patients with varied amounts of residual disease. The residual cancer burden (RCB) method was designed to address this and other prognostic deficits. The RCB method provides a standard to evaluate and quantify the extent of residual disease in breast and axillary lymph nodes following neoadjuvant chemotherapy. It is reported as a continuous score, with pCR being scored as RCB-0. There are four RCB classes ranging from RCB-0 to RCB-3. Determining RCB after neoadjuvant treatment has been validated as a prognostic predictor in early breast cancer. </p>

8226<p id="_2512" tabindex="-1">

8227 A pooled, multinational, multi-institutional analysis was performed, using participant-level RCB results and clinicopathological data. Participant data from 5,161 patients were analyzed to assess the association between the continuous RCB score and the primary study outcome, EFS. With a median follow-up of 56 months, the RCB score was prognostic within each breast cancer subtype, with a higher RCB score significantly associated with worse EFS. RCB score was prognostic for EFS in multivariable models adjusted for age, grade, T category, and nodal status at baseline. The adjusted HR associated with a one-unit increase in RCB ranged from 1.52 in the hormone receptor&#8211;positive HER2-negative group to 2.09 in the hormone receptor&#8211;negative HER2-positive group (<em>

8228P</em>

8229 &lt; .0001 for all subtypes).[<a href="#cit/section_4.186">

8230186</a>

8231]</p>

8232<p id="_2278" tabindex="-1">

8233 Neoadjuvant therapy is particularly favored in patients with triple-negative or HER2-positive disease, when pathological response is used as a guide in choosing the optimal adjuvant therapy after surgery. For more information, see the sections on <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_2310">

8234Triple-negative breast cancer</a>

8235 and <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_268">

8236HER2/neu-positive breast cancer</a>

8237.</p>

8238<p id="_2279" tabindex="-1">

8239Omission of postoperative radiation therapy to the regional nodes in patients who initially present as node positive and become node negative after neoadjuvant therapy is currently being evaluated. </p>

8240<section id="_1381">

8241<h4 id="_1381_toc">

8242Patient selection, staging, treatment, and follow-up</h4>

8243<p id="_1382" tabindex="-1">

8244Multidisciplinary management of patients undergoing preoperative therapy by an experienced team is essential to optimize the following:</p>

8245<div class="pdq-content-list">

8246<ul id="_1269">

8247<li>

8248Patient selection.</li>

8249<li>

8250Choice of systemic therapy.</li>

8251<li>

8252Management of the axilla and surgical approach.</li>

8253<li>

8254Decision to administer adjuvant radiation therapy. </li>

8255</ul>

8256</div>

8257<p id="_1270" tabindex="-1">

8258The tumor histology, grade, and receptor status are carefully evaluated before preoperative therapy is initiated. Patients whose tumors have a pure lobular histology, low grade, or high hormone-receptor expression and HER2-negative status are less likely to respond to chemotherapy and should be considered for primary surgery, especially when the nodes are clinically negative. Even if adjuvant chemotherapy is administered after surgery in these cases, a third-generation regimen (anthracycline/taxane based) may be avoided.</p>

8259<p id="_1116" tabindex="-1">

8260Before beginning preoperative therapy, the extent of the disease within the breast and regional lymph nodes should be assessed. Staging of systemic disease may include the following:[<a href="#cit/section_4.187">

8261187</a>

8262] </p>

8263<div class="pdq-content-list">

8264<ul id="_1271">

8265<li>

8266CT scan of the chest and abdomen and a bone scan.</li>

8267<li>

8268Positron-emission tomography.</li>

8269</ul>

8270</div>

8271<p id="_1272" tabindex="-1">

8272Baseline breast imaging is performed when breast-conserving therapy is desired to identify the tumor location and exclude multicentric disease. Suspicious abnormalities are usually biopsied before beginning treatment and a marker placed at the center of the breast tumor(s). When possible, suspicious axillary nodes should be biopsied before initiation of systemic treatment.</p>

8273<p id="_2280" tabindex="-1">

8274In patients with clinically negative nodes who receive neoadjuvant chemotherapy, an SLN biopsy is typically performed at the time of surgery. In patients presenting with positive lymph nodes, detected by either clinical examination or imaging, SLN biopsy may be performed in a patient who becomes clinically node negative after preoperative therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.188">

8275188</a>

8276] The use of dual mapping with both radiocolloid and blue dye and retrieval of at least three negative lymph nodes was associated with a lower false-negative rate and ALND may be omitted in these patients.[<a href="#cit/section_4.189">

8277189</a>

8278][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8279Level of evidence B4</a>

8280]; [<a href="#cit/section_4.190">

8281190</a>

8282][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8283Level of evidence C2</a>

8284]; [<a href="#cit/section_4.191">

8285191</a>

8286][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8287Level of evidence C3</a>

8288] </p>

8289<p id="_1274" tabindex="-1">

8290When considering preoperative therapy, treatment options include the following:</p>

8291<div class="pdq-content-list">

8292<ul id="_1275">

8293<li>

8294For HER2-negative breast tumors, an anthracycline/taxane-based chemotherapy regimen. </li>

8295<li>

8296For HER2-positive disease, chemotherapy and HER2-targeted therapy.</li>

8297<li>

8298Ideally, the entire treatment regimen is administered before surgery. </li>

8299<li>

8300For postmenopausal women with hormone receptor&#8211;positive breast cancer, chemotherapy is an option. For those who cannot be given chemotherapy, preoperative endocrine therapy may be an option.</li>

8301<li>

8302For premenopausal women with hormone-responsive cancer, the use of preoperative endocrine therapy is under investigation.</li>

8303</ul>

8304</div>

8305<p id="_1118" tabindex="-1">

8306Regular clinical assessment of response to therapy is necessary after beginning preoperative therapy. Repeat radiographic

8307assessment is also required if breast conservation is the surgical goal. Patients with progressive disease during preoperative therapy may either transition to a non&#8211;cross-resistant regimen or proceed to surgery, if feasible.[<a href="#cit/section_4.192">

8308192</a>

8309,<a href="#cit/section_4.193">

8310193</a>

8311] Although switching to a non&#8211;cross-resistant regimen results in a higher pCR rate than continuing the same therapy, there is no clear evidence that other breast cancer outcomes are improved with this approach.</p>

8312</section>

8313<section id="_1058">

8314<h4 id="_1058_toc">

8315HER2/neu-negative breast cancer</h4>

8316<p id="_1059" tabindex="-1">

8317Early trials examined whether anthracycline-based regimens used in the adjuvant setting would prolong DFS and OS when used in the preoperative setting. The evidence supports higher rates of breast-conserving therapy with the use of a preoperative anthracycline chemotherapy regimen than with postoperative use, but no improvement in survival was noted with the preoperative strategy.</p>

8318<p id="_2346" tabindex="-1">

8319Typically, an anthracycline-and-taxane&#8211;based regimen is used if chemotherapy is administered in the neoadjuvant setting for patients with HER2/neu-negative breast cancer.</p>

8320<p id="_1279" tabindex="-1">

8321Evidence (anthracycline/taxane&#8211;based chemotherapy regimen):</p>

8322<div class="pdq-content-list">

8323<ol id="_1280">

8324<li>

8325In an effort to improve on the results observed with AC alone, the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002707">

8326NSABP B-27</a>

8327 trial (NCT00002707) was conducted.[<a href="#cit/section_4.194">

8328194</a>

8329][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8330Level of evidence B1</a>

8331] <div class="pdq-content-list">

8332<ul id="_1281">

8333<li>

8334The administration of preoperative AC followed by docetaxel was associated with a higher clinical complete response rate compared with the administration of AC alone (63.6% for AC followed by docetaxel and 40.1% for AC alone; <em>

8335P</em>

8336 &lt; .001); a higher pCR rate was also observed (26.1% for AC followed by docetaxel and 13.7% for AC alone; <em>

8337P</em>

8338 &lt; .001). </li>

8339</ul>

8340</div>

8341</li>

8342<li>

8343Data from NSABP B-27 and the Aberdeen Breast Group Trial support the use of anthracycline/taxane&#8211;based regimens in women with initial response or with relative resistance to anthracyclines.[<a href="#cit/section_4.192">

8344192</a>

8345]</li>

8346<li>

8347 Alternative anthracycline/taxane schedules have also been evaluated (concurrent TAC) and appear similar in efficacy to the sequential approach described above.[<a href="#cit/section_4.195">

8348195</a>

8349][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8350Level of evidence B3</a>

8351] </li>

8352<li>

8353 The phase III <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01583426">

8354GeparSepto</a>

8355 trial (NCT01583426) investigated an alternative taxane (nab-paclitaxel) in patients with untreated primary breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_4.196">

8356196</a>

8357] Patients (n = 1,229) were randomly assigned to receive 12 weeks of nab-paclitaxel or paclitaxel followed by epirubicin and cyclophosphamide (EC) for four cycles. <div class="pdq-content-list">

8358<ul id="_2374">

8359<li>

8360The pCR rate was higher in the nab-paclitaxel arm (233 patients, 38%; 95% CI, 35%&#8211;42%) when compared with the paclitaxel arm (174 patients, 29%; 95% CI, 25%&#8211;33%).[<a href="#cit/section_4.196">

8361196</a>

8362][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8363Level of evidence B3</a>

8364] </li>

8365<li>

8366However, in the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01822314">

8367ETNA</a>

8368 trial (NCT01822314) that compared neoadjuvant nab-paclitaxel with paclitaxel followed by anthracycline-based therapy, no significant difference in pCR was observed, and neutropenia and peripheral neuropathy were more frequent in the nab-paclitaxel arm.[<a href="#cit/section_4.197">

8369197</a>

8370]</li>

8371<li>

8372Differences in taxane dose and schedule may explain the different findings in the GeparSepto and ETNA trials.</li>

8373</ul>

8374</div>

8375 </li>

8376<li>

8377The incorporation of many additional cytotoxic agents to anthracycline/taxane&#8211;based regimens has not offered a significant additional benefit to breast conservation or pCR rate in unselected breast cancer populations.[<a href="#cit/section_4.198">

8378198</a>

8379][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8380Level of evidence B3</a>

8381]</li>

8382</ol>

8383</div>

8384</section>

8385<section id="_2310">

8386<h4 id="_2310_toc">

8387Triple-negative breast cancer</h4>

8388<p id="_2269" tabindex="-1">

8389Promising results have been observed with the addition of carboplatin to anthracycline/taxane combination chemotherapy regimens in patients with triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC). </p>

8390<p id="_2270" tabindex="-1">

8391Evidence (adding carboplatin to an anthracycline/taxane&#8211;based chemotherapy regimen in patients with TNBC):</p>

8392<div class="pdq-content-list">

8393<ol id="_2271">

8394<li>

8395In the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01426880">

8396GeparSixto</a>

8397 trial (NCT01426880), carboplatin was added to an anthracycline/taxane&#8211;based backbone.[<a href="#cit/section_4.199">

8398199</a>

8399][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8400Level of evidence B3</a>

8401] <div class="pdq-content-list">

8402<ul id="_2272">

8403<li>

8404Higher pCR rates were observed with the addition of carboplatin to an anthracycline/taxane&#8211;based backbone compared with anthracycline/taxane alone (36.9% vs. 53.2%; <em>

8405P</em>

8406 = .005) in patients with TNBC.</li>

8407<li>

8408 Patients with <em class="gene-name">

8409BRCA</em>

8410 mutations had a higher rate of pCR, which was not increased by the addition of carboplatin (66.7% in the nonplatinum arm vs. 65.7% in the platinum-containing arm).</li>

8411<li>

8412 The 3-year DFS rate was higher for patients with TNBC randomly assigned to the carboplatin arm (86.1% vs. 75.8%; HR, 0.56; 95% CI, 0.34&#8722;0.93), but OS did not differ.[<a href="#cit/section_4.200">

8413200</a>

8414]</li>

8415<li>

8416The more intensive regimen was also associated with increased toxicity and treatment discontinuations (39% vs. 48%).</li>

8417</ul>

8418</div>

8419</li>

8420<li>

8421The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00861705">

8422CALGB 40603</a>

8423 trial (NCT00861705) compared an anthracycline/taxane backbone alone with an anthracycline/taxane backbone plus carboplatin in patients with stage II and stage III TNBC.[<a href="#cit/section_4.201">

8424201</a>

8425][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8426Level of evidence B3</a>

8427] <div class="pdq-content-list">

8428<ul id="_2273">

8429<li>

8430The pCR rate for the breast and axilla was 54% for the anthracycline/taxane backbone-plus-carboplatin group versus 41% for the anthracycline/taxane backbone-alone group (<em>

8431P</em>

8432 = .0029).</li>

8433</ul>

8434</div>

8435</li>

8436</ol>

8437</div>

8438<p id="_2417" tabindex="-1">

8439Evidence (adding pembrolizumab to a chemotherapy regimen in patients with stage II or stage III TNBC):</p>

8440<div class="pdq-content-list">

8441<ol id="_2418">

8442<li>

8443The randomized, double blind, phase III <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03036488">

8444KEYNOTE-522</a>

8445 trial (NCT03036488) evaluated the addition of immunotherapy to neoadjuvant chemotherapy for patients with stage II and stage III TNBC.[<a href="#cit/section_4.202">

8446202</a>

8447][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8448Level of evidence B1</a>

8449] Participants were randomly assigned in a 2:1 ratio to receive neoadjuvant chemotherapy (paclitaxel plus carboplatin, followed by doxorubicin plus cyclophosphamide) with either neoadjuvant and adjuvant pembrolizumab or neoadjuvant and adjuvant placebo. Co-primary end points were pCR rate and EFS. The pCR rate, as reported at the time of the first interim analysis for the first 602 participants (pembrolizumab arm, n = 401; placebo arm, n = 201), favored the pembrolizumab arm. <div class="pdq-content-list">

8450<ul id="_2419">

8451<li>

8452A pCR was observed in 64.8% of patients in the pembrolizumab arm and 51.2% of patients in the placebo arm (estimated treatment difference, 13.6%; 95% CI, 5.4%&#8722;21.8%; <em>

8453P</em>

8454 &lt; .001). Approximately 80% of tumors were positive for programmed death-ligand 1 (PD-L1), but the benefits of pembrolizumab regarding pCR were observed regardless of PD-L1 status. </li>

8455<li>

8456 At the time of the fourth interim analysis, when the median follow-up was 39 months, an improved EFS was observed in patients who received pembrolizumab. The 36-month EFS rate was 84.5% for patients who received pembrolizumab and 76.8% for patients who received placebo. (HR, 0.63; 95% CI, 0.48&#8211;0.82; <em>

8457P</em>

8458 &lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_4.203">

8459203</a>

8460][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8461Level of evidence B1</a>

8462]</li>

8463<li>

8464EFS data are immature. </li>

8465<li>

8466Grade 3 or higher adverse events occurred in 76.8% of participants in the pembrolizumab arm and 72.2% of participants in the placebo arm. Serious treatment-related adverse events occurred in 32.5% of participants in the pembrolizumab arm and 19.5% of participants in the placebo arm. Grade 3 or higher skin rashes, infusion reactions, and adrenal insufficiency were more frequent in the pembrolizumab arm. </li>

8467</ul>

8468</div>

8469</li>

8470<li>

8471The randomized, double-blind, phase III <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03197935">

8472IMPassion031</a>

8473 trial (NCT03197935) also evaluated the addition of immunotherapy to neoadjuvant chemotherapy for patients with stage II and stage III TNBC.[<a href="#cit/section_4.204">

8474204</a>

8475][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8476Level of evidence B3</a>

8477] Participants were randomly assigned in a 1:1 ratio to receive neoadjuvant chemotherapy (nab-paclitaxel followed by doxorubicin plus cyclophosphamide) with either neoadjuvant and adjuvant atezolizumab or neoadjuvant placebo. Participants were eligible regardless of PD-L1 status. Co-primary end points were pCR rates in all randomized participants and in the PD-L1&#8211;positive subpopulation (defined as &#8805;1%). Secondary end points included EFS, DFS, and OS, each evaluated in all randomized participants and in the PD-L1&#8211;positive subpopulation. A total of 165 participants (78 PD-L1 positive) were randomly assigned to the atezolizumab-plus-chemotherapy arm and 168 participants (76 PD-L1 positive) were randomly assigned to the placebo-plus-chemotherapy arm.<div class="pdq-content-list">

8478<ul id="_2420">

8479<li>

8480 Among the entire study population, pCR was observed in 58% of participants in the atezolizumab arm and 41% in the placebo arm (rate difference, 17%; 95% CI, 6%&#8211;27%; one-sided <em>

8481P</em>

8482 = .0044, which crossed the significance boundary of <em>

8483P</em>

8484 &lt; .0184).</li>

8485<li>

8486 Among the PD-L1&#8211;positive subpopulation, pCR was observed in 69% of participants in the atezolizumab arm and 49% in the placebo arm (rate difference, 20%; 95% CI, 4%&#8211;35%; <em>

8487P</em>

8488 = .021, which did not cross the significance boundary of <em>

8489P</em>

8490 &lt; .0184.</li>

8491<li>

8492This trial was not powered for EFS, DFS, or OS. Survival outcome data are immature.</li>

8493<li>

8494 The addition of neoadjuvant atezolizumab was well tolerated. Grade 3 to grade 4 adverse events occurred in 63% of participants in the atezolizumab arm and 60% of participants in the placebo arm.</li>

8495</ul>

8496</div>

8497</li>

8498</ol>

8499</div>

8500</section>

8501<section id="_268">

8502<h4 id="_268_toc">

8503HER2/neu-positive breast cancer</h4>

8504<p id="_1124" tabindex="-1">

8505After the success in the adjuvant setting, initial reports from phase II studies indicated improved pCR rates when trastuzumab, a monoclonal antibody that binds the extracellular domain of HER2, was added to preoperative anthracycline/taxane&#8211;based regimens.[<a href="#cit/section_4.205">

8506205</a>

8507][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8508Level of evidence B3</a>

8509] This has been confirmed in phase III studies.[<a href="#cit/section_4.206">

8510206</a>

8511,<a href="#cit/section_4.207">

8512207</a>

8513]</p>

8514<section id="_902">

8515<h5 id="_902_toc">

8516Trastuzumab</h5>

8517<p id="_1288" tabindex="-1">

8518Evidence (trastuzumab):</p>

8519<div class="pdq-content-list">

8520<ol id="_1342">

8521<li>

8522The phase III NeOAdjuvant Herceptin (NOAH) study randomly assigned patients with HER2-positive locally advanced or inflammatory breast cancers to undergo preoperative chemotherapy with or without 1 year of trastuzumab therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.207">

8523207</a>

8524][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8525Level of evidence A1</a>

8526]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8527<ul id="_1290">

8528<li>

8529Study results confirmed that the addition of trastuzumab to preoperative chemotherapy resulted not only in improved clinical responses (87% vs. 74%) and pathological responses (breast and axilla, 38% vs. 19%) but also in EFS, the primary outcome.[<a href="#cit/section_4.207">

8530207</a>

8531][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8532Level of evidence A1</a>

8533]</li>

8534<li>

8535After a median follow-up of 5.4 years, the EFS benefit was 58% with the addition of trastuzumab to chemotherapy (95% CI, 48%&#8211;66%) and 43% (95% CI, 34%&#8211;52%) in patients in the chemotherapy group. The unadjusted HR for EFS between the two randomized HER2-positive treatment groups was 0.64 (95% CI, 0.44&#8211;0.93; two-sided log-rank <em>

8536P</em>

8537 = .016). EFS was strongly associated with pCR in patients who received trastuzumab.[<a href="#cit/section_4.208">

8538208</a>

8539] </li>

8540<li>

8541Symptomatic cardiac failure occurred in two patients who received concurrent doxorubicin and trastuzumab for two cycles. Close cardiac monitoring of LVEF and the total dose of doxorubicin not exceeding 180 mg/m<span class="sup">

85422</span>

8543 accounted for the relatively low number of declines in LVEF and only two cardiac events. For more information, see the <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_1048">

8544Cardiac toxic effects with adjuvant trastuzumab</a>

8545 section.[<a href="#cit/section_4.207">

8546207</a>

8547][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8548Level of evidence B1</a>

8549]</li>

8550</ul>

8551</div>

8552</li>

8553<li>

8554Due to concern about coadministration of trastuzumab and anthracyclines, a phase III trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00513292">

8555Z1041</a>

8556 [NCT00513292]) randomly assigned patients with operable HER2-positive breast cancer to receive trastuzumab sequential to or concurrent with the anthracycline component (FEC) of the preoperative chemotherapy regimen.[<a href="#cit/section_4.209">

8557209</a>

8558][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8559Level of evidence B3</a>

8560]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8561<ul id="_1291">

8562<li>

8563pCR was the primary outcome. There was no significant difference in pCR rate in the breast between the arms (56.5% sequential, 54.2% concurrent; difference, 2.3% with 95% CI, -9.3&#8211;13.9).</li>

8564<li>

8565Asymptomatic declines in LVEF during preoperative chemotherapy were identified in similar proportions of patients in each arm.</li>

8566<li>

8567DFS and OS were secondary outcomes. After median follow-up of 5.1 years, there was no difference in DFS (HR, 1.02; 95% CI, 0.56&#8722;1.83, <em>

8568P</em>

8569 = .96) or OS (HR, 1.17; 95% CI, 0.48&#8722;2.88; <em>

8570P</em>

8571 = .73) between the sequential and concurrent arms.[<a href="#cit/section_4.210">

8572210</a>

8573]</li>

8574<li>

8575The conclusion was that concurrent administration of trastuzumab with anthracyclines is not warranted based on these findings.</li>

8576</ul>

8577</div>

8578</li>

8579</ol>

8580</div>

8581<p id="_2043" tabindex="-1">

8582A subcutaneous formulation of trastuzumab has also been approved.</p>

8583<p id="_2044" tabindex="-1">

8584The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01566721">

8585SafeHer</a>

8586 trial (NCT01566721) evaluated the safety and tolerability of self-administered versus clinician-administered SQ trastuzumab in stage I to stage III HER2-positive breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_4.211">

8587211</a>

8588] Chemotherapy was administered concurrently or sequentially.</p>

8589<p id="_1336" tabindex="-1">

8590A phase III (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00950300">

8591HannaH</a>

8592 [NCT00950300]) trial also demonstrated that the pharmacokinetics and efficacy of preoperative SQ trastuzumab is noninferior to the IV formulation. This international, open-label trial (n = 596) randomly assigned women with operable, locally advanced, or inflammatory HER2-positive breast cancer to undergo preoperative chemotherapy (anthracycline/taxane&#8211;based), with either SQ-administered or IV-administered trastuzumab every 3 weeks before surgery. Patients received adjuvant trastuzumab to complete 1 year of therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.212">

8593212</a>

8594][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8595Level of evidence B1</a>

8596] The pCR rates between the arms differed by 4.7% (95% CI, 4.0%&#8211;13.4%); 40.7% in the IV-administered group versus 45.4% in the SQ-administered group, demonstrating noninferiority for the SQ formulation. EFS and OS were secondary end points. Six-year EFS was 65% in both arms (HR, 0.98; 95% CI, 0.74&#8722;1.29). The 6-year OS rate was 84% in both arms (HR, 0.94; 95% CI, 0.61&#8722;1.45).[<a href="#cit/section_4.213">

8597213</a>

8598] </p>

8599<p id="_1337" tabindex="-1">

8600Newer HER2-targeted therapies (lapatinib, pertuzumab) have also been investigated. It appears that dual targeting of the HER2 receptor results in an increase in pCR rate; however, no survival advantage has been demonstrated to date with this approach.[<a href="#cit/section_4.214">

8601214</a>

8602,<a href="#cit/section_4.215">

8603215</a>

8604]</p>

8605</section>

8606<section id="_905">

8607<h5 id="_905_toc">

8608Pertuzumab</h5>

8609<p id="_906" tabindex="-1">

8610 Pertuzumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody that binds to a distinct epitope on the extracellular domain of the HER2 receptor and inhibits dimerization. Pertuzumab, in combination with trastuzumab with or without chemotherapy, has been evaluated in two preoperative clinical trials to improve on the pCR rates observed with trastuzumab and chemotherapy. </p>

8611<p id="_1294" tabindex="-1">

8612Evidence (pertuzumab):</p>

8613<div class="pdq-content-list">

8614<ol id="_1295">

8615<li>

8616In the open-label, randomized, phase II <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00545688">

8617NeoSPHERE</a>

8618 trial (NCT00545688),[<a href="#cit/section_4.214">

8619214</a>

8620] 417 women with tumors that were larger than 2 cm or node-positive, and who had HER2-positive breast cancer, were randomly assigned to one of four preoperative regimens:[<a href="#cit/section_4.214">

8621214</a>

8622][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8623Level of evidence B3</a>

8624]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8625<ol id="_1296" class="lower-alpha">

8626<li>

8627Docetaxel plus trastuzumab.</li>

8628<li>

8629Docetaxel plus trastuzumab and pertuzumab.</li>

8630<li>

8631Pertuzumab plus trastuzumab.</li>

8632<li>

8633Docetaxel plus pertuzumab. </li>

8634</ol>

8635</div>

8636<p id="_1297" tabindex="-1">

8637The following results were observed:</p>

8638<div class="pdq-content-list">

8639<ul id="_1298">

8640<li>

8641The pCR rates were 29% for docetaxel plus trastuzumab, 46% for docetaxel plus trastuzumab and pertuzumab, 17% for pertuzumab plus trastuzumab, and 24% for docetaxel plus pertuzumab. Therefore, the highest pCR rate was seen in the preoperative treatment arm with dual HER2 blockade plus chemotherapy. </li>

8642<li>

8643The addition of pertuzumab to the docetaxel-plus-trastuzumab combination did not appear to increase toxic effects, including the risk of cardiac adverse events. </li>

8644<li>

8645Despite the high pCR rate observed with dual HER2 blockade plus chemotherapy, PFS and DFS rates were not improved, although the NeoSPHERE trial was not powered to detect differences in long-term efficacy outcomes.[<a href="#cit/section_4.216">

8646216</a>

8647] </li>

8648</ul>

8649</div>

8650</li>

8651<li>

8652The open-label, randomized, phase II <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00976989">

8653TRYPHAENA</a>

8654 trial (NCT00976989) sought to evaluate the tolerability and activity associated with trastuzumab and pertuzumab.[<a href="#cit/section_4.217">

8655217</a>

8656][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8657Level of evidence B3</a>

8658] All 225 women with tumors that were larger than 2 cm or node positive, and who had operable, locally advanced, or inflammatory HER2-positive breast cancer, were randomly assigned to one of three preoperative regimens: <div class="pdq-content-list">

8659<ol id="_1338" class="lower-alpha">

8660<li>

8661Concurrent FEC plus trastuzumab plus pertuzumab (&#215;3) followed by concurrent docetaxel plus trastuzumab plus pertuzumab.</li>

8662<li>

8663FEC alone (&#215;3) followed by concurrent docetaxel plus trastuzumab plus pertuzumab (&#215;3). </li>

8664<li>

8665Concurrent docetaxel and carboplatin plus trastuzumab plus pertuzumab (&#215;6). </li>

8666</ol>

8667</div>

8668<p id="_1300" tabindex="-1">

8669The following results were observed:</p>

8670<div class="pdq-content-list">

8671<ul id="_1301">

8672<li>

8673The pCR rate was equivalent across all three treatment arms: (62% for concurrent FEC plus trastuzumab plus pertuzumab followed by concurrent docetaxel plus trastuzumab plus pertuzumab; 57% for FEC alone followed by concurrent docetaxel plus trastuzumab plus pertuzumab; and 66% for concurrent docetaxel and carboplatin plus trastuzumab plus pertuzumab).</li>

8674<li>

8675All three arms were associated with a low incidence of cardiac adverse events of 5% or less.</li>

8676</ul>

8677</div>

8678</li>

8679</ol>

8680</div>

8681<p id="_912" tabindex="-1">

8682Because of these studies, the FDA granted <a href="https://www.accessdata.fda.gov/drugsatfda_docs/label/2013/125409s051lbl.pdf" title="https://www.accessdata.fda.gov/drugsatfda_docs/label/2013/125409s051lbl.pdf">

8683accelerated approval </a>

8684 for the use of pertuzumab as part of a preoperative treatment for women with early-stage, HER2-positive breast cancer whose tumors are larger than 2 cm or node-positive. </p>

8685<p id="_1302" tabindex="-1">

8686The FDA approval of pertuzumab was subsequently converted to regular approval following the results of the confirmatory <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01358877">

8687APHINITY</a>

8688 trial (NCT01358877), a randomized, phase III, adjuvant study for women with HER2-positive breast cancer, which demonstrated improved invasive DFS with the combination of chemotherapy and dual HER2-targeted therapy with pertuzumab plus trastuzumab compared with chemotherapy and trastuzumab alone.[<a href="#cit/section_4.115">

8689115</a>

8690] Pertuzumab is now approved both in combination with trastuzumab and chemotherapy for the neoadjuvant therapy of locally advanced, inflammatory, or early-stage HER2-positive breast cancer, which is larger than 2 cm or node-positive, as part of a complete treatment regimen and in combination with chemotherapy and trastuzumab as adjuvant treatment for HER2-positive early breast cancer at a high risk of recurrence. </p>

8691<p id="_2375" tabindex="-1">

8692The randomized, open-label, multicenter <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01996267">

8693TRAIN-2</a>

8694 trial (NCT01996267) evaluated the optimal chemotherapy backbone to use with neoadjuvant pertuzumab and trastuzumab in patients with stage II to stage III HER2-positive breast cancer (i.e., an anthracycline-containing or non&#8211;anthracycline-containing regimen).[<a href="#cit/section_4.218">

8695218</a>

8696,<a href="#cit/section_4.219">

8697219</a>

8698][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8699Level of evidence B3</a>

8700] A total of 438 patients were randomly assigned to receive one of the following regimens:</p>

8701<div class="pdq-content-list">

8702<ol id="_2403" class="lower-alpha">

8703<li>

8704FEC every 3 weeks for three cycles followed by paclitaxel and carboplatin every 3 weeks for six cycles. Paclitaxel was administered on days 1 and 8 and carboplatin was administered either on day 1 alone or on days 1 and 8. Trastuzumab and pertuzumab were given every 3 weeks throughout chemotherapy. Primary prophylaxis with filgrastim was not administered during the FEC portion of therapy.</li>

8705<li>

8706Paclitaxel and carboplatin according to the same schedule for nine cycles. Trastuzumab and pertuzumab were given every 3 weeks throughout chemotherapy.</li>

8707</ol>

8708</div>

8709<p id="_2377" tabindex="-1">

8710The primary end point was pCR (ypT0/is, ypN0). Secondary end point data on EFS, OS, toxicity, and breast conservation are available. The following results were observed:</p>

8711<div class="pdq-content-list">

8712<ul id="_2404">

8713<li>

8714There was no statistically significant difference in the proportion of patients with pCR between the anthracycline (67%) and non-anthracycline (68%) arm. </li>

8715<li>

8716 There was no difference in the proportion of patients in each arm who underwent breast-conserving surgery.</li>

8717<li>

8718Irrespective of hormone receptor and nodal status, 3-year EFS estimates were 92.7% in the anthracycline group and 93.6% in the non-anthracycline group. The 3-year OS estimates were 97.7% in the anthracycline group and 98.2% in the non-anthracycline group. </li>

8719<li>

8720 A decline in LVEF of 10% or more from baseline to less than 50% was more common in patients who received anthracyclines than those who did not (7.7% vs. 3.2%; <em>

8721P</em>

8722 = .04). </li>

8723<li>

8724 Two patients treated with anthracyclines developed acute leukemia.</li>

8725<li>

8726 There was no difference in the proportion of patients in each arm with at least grade 2 peripheral neuropathy: 66 patients (30%) in the anthracycline arm versus 68 patients (31%) in the non-anthracycline arm.</li>

8727<li>

8728 Grade 4 neutropenia and febrile neutropenia were more common in the anthracycline arm (23 patients [10%]) than in the non-anthracycline arm (3 patients [1%], <em>

8729P</em>

8730 &lt; .0001).</li>

8731</ul>

8732</div>

8733</section>

8734<section id="_913">

8735<h5 id="_913_toc">

8736Lapatinib</h5>

8737<p id="_1303" tabindex="-1">

8738 Lapatinib is a small-molecule kinase inhibitor that is capable of dual receptor inhibition of both epidermal growth factor receptor and HER2. Study results do not support the use of lapatinib in the preoperative setting.</p>

8739<p id="_1304" tabindex="-1">

8740Evidence (against the use of lapatinib for HER2-positive early breast cancer):</p>

8741<div class="pdq-content-list">

8742<ol id="_1305">

8743<li>

8744 The role of lapatinib in the preoperative setting was examined in the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00567554">

8745GeparQuinto</a>

8746 trial (NCT00567554).[<a href="#cit/section_4.220">

8747220</a>

8748] This phase III trial randomly assigned women with HER2-positive early-stage breast cancer to receive chemotherapy with trastuzumab or chemotherapy with lapatinib, with pCR as the primary end point.[<a href="#cit/section_4.220">

8749220</a>

8750][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8751Level of evidence B3</a>

8752] <div class="pdq-content-list">

8753<ul id="_1306">

8754<li>

8755pCR in the chemotherapy and lapatinib arm was significantly lower than it was with chemotherapy and trastuzumab (22.7% vs. 30.3%; <em>

8756P </em>

8757 = .04).</li>

8758<li>

8759Other end points of DFS, RFS, and OS have not been reported. </li>

8760</ul>

8761</div>

8762</li>

8763<li>

8764<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00770809">

8765CALGB 40601</a>

8766 (NCT00770809) was a phase III trial that randomly assigned patients with stage II and III HER2-positive breast cancer to receive either paclitaxel plus trastuzumab or paclitaxel plus trastuzumab plus lapatinib. The primary end point of the study was pCR in the breast.[<a href="#cit/section_4.221">

8767221</a>

8768][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8769Level of evidence B3</a>

8770]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8771<ul id="_1657">

8772<li>

8773 pCR was 46% (95% CI, 37%&#8211;55%) in the patients who received paclitaxel plus trastuzumab and 56% (95% CI, 47%&#8211;65%; <em>

8774P</em>

8775 = .13) in the patients who received paclitaxel plus trastuzumab plus lapatinib, indicating no benefit with the addition of lapatinib.</li>

8776<li>

8777However, after more than 7 years of follow-up, patients who received paclitaxel/trastuzumab/lapatinib had significantly better RFS and OS than did patients who received paclitaxel/trastuzumab alone.[<a href="#cit/section_4.222">

8778222</a>

8779]</li>

8780</ul>

8781</div>

8782</li>

8783<li>

8784The phase III <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00553358">

8785NeoALTTO</a>

8786 trial (NCT00553358) randomly assigned 455 women with HER2-positive early-stage breast cancer (tumor size &gt;2 cm) to receive preoperative lapatinib, or preoperative trastuzumab, or preoperative lapatinib plus trastuzumab. This anti-HER2 therapy was given alone for 6 weeks, and then weekly paclitaxel was added to the regimen for an additional 12 weeks. The primary end point of this study was pCR. <div class="pdq-content-list">

8787<ul id="_1307">

8788<li>

8789pCR was significantly higher in the lapatinib-plus-trastuzumab combination arm (51.3%; 95% CI, 43.1%&#8211;59.5%) than in the trastuzumab-alone arm (29.5%; 95% CI, 22.4%&#8211;37.5%).</li>

8790<li>

8791No significant difference in pCR was seen between the lapatinib (24.7%, 95% CI, 18.1%&#8211;32.3%) and trastuzumab groups (difference, -4.8%, -17.6 to 8.2; <em>

8792P </em>

8793 = .34).</li>

8794<li>

8795 An updated analysis for the prespecified secondary end points of EFS and OS indicate no difference between the groups.[<a href="#cit/section_4.223">

8796223</a>

8797] </li>

8798</ul>

8799</div>

8800</li>

8801</ol>

8802</div>

8803<p id="_1362" tabindex="-1">

8804More definitive efficacy data were provided by the phase III ALTTO (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00490139">

8805NCT00490139</a>

8806) trial that randomly assigned women to receive trastuzumab or trastuzumab plus lapatinib in the adjuvant setting.[<a href="#cit/section_4.224">

8807224</a>

8808] The trial did not meet its primary end point of DFS. The doubling in pCR rate observed with the addition of lapatinib to trastuzumab in the NeoALTTO trial did not translate into improved survival outcomes in the ALTTO trial at 4.5 years of median follow-up. This indicates that there is currently no role for the use of lapatinib in the preoperative or adjuvant settings.</p>

8809</section>

8810<section id="_2513">

8811<h5 id="_2513_toc">

8812Atezolizumab</h5>

8813<p id="_2514" tabindex="-1">

8814Atezolizumab is a monoclonal antibody that selectively targets PD-L1. </p>

8815<p id="_2515" tabindex="-1">

8816Evidence (<strong>

8817against</strong>

8818 the use of atezolizumab for HER2-positive early breast cancer):</p>

8819<div class="pdq-content-list">

8820<ol id="_2516">

8821<li>

8822 <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03726879">

8823IMpassion050</a>

8824 (NCT03726879) was a double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled study. The trial evaluated the efficacy and safety of neoadjuvant atezolizumab versus placebo in combination with pertuzumab and trastuzumab (PH) and chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.225">

8825225</a>

8826]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8827<ul id="_2517">

8828<li>

8829 Patients with T2 or larger tumors and histologically confirmed node-positive disease were randomly assigned 1:1 to receive either atezolizumab or placebo with dose-dense doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide, followed by paclitaxel and PH. After surgery, patients continued atezolizumab or placebo with PH to total 1 year of HER2-targeted therapy. Patients with residual disease could switch to atezolizumab or placebo with ado-trastuzumab emtansine. </li>

8830<li>

8831 Co-primary end points were pCR rates in the intention-to-treat (ITT) and PD-L1&#8211;positive populations. The pCR rates in the placebo and atezolizumab groups in the ITT populations were 62.7% and 62.4%, respectively (<em>

8832P</em>

8833 = .9551). The pCR rates in the placebo and atezolizumab groups in patients with PD-L1&#8211;positive tumors were 72.5% and 64.2%, respectively (<em>

8834P</em>

8835 = .1846). </li>

8836<li>

8837Grade 3 to 4 adverse events were more frequent in the atezolizumab group than the placebo group. Five grade 5 adverse events occurred in the atezolizumab group (two among those assigned to study treatment).</li>

8838</ul>

8839</div>

8840</li>

8841</ol>

8842</div>

8843</section>

8844</section>

8845<section id="_1652">

8846<h4 id="_1652_toc">

8847Cardiac toxic effects with pertuzumab and lapatinib</h4>

8848<p id="_1653" tabindex="-1">

8849A pooled analysis of cardiac safety in 598 cancer patients treated with pertuzumab was performed using data supplied by Roche and Genentech.[<a href="#cit/section_4.226">

8850226</a>

8851][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8852Level of evidence C2</a>

8853]</p>

8854<div class="pdq-content-list">

8855<ul id="_1654">

8856<li>

8857 Asymptomatic left ventricular systolic dysfunction was observed in 6.9% of patients receiving pertuzumab alone (n = 331; 95% CI, 4.5%&#8211;10.2%), 3.4% of patients receiving pertuzumab in combination with a non&#8211;anthracycline-containing chemotherapy (n = 175; 95% CI, 1.3%&#8211;7.3%), and 6.5% of patients receiving pertuzumab in combination with trastuzumab (n = 93; 95% CI, 2.4%&#8211;13.5%).</li>

8858<li>

8859Symptomatic heart failure was observed in one patient (0.3%) who received pertuzumab alone, two patients (1.1%) who received pertuzumab in combination with a non&#8211;anthracycline-containing chemotherapy, and one patient (1.1%) who received pertuzumab in combination with trastuzumab.</li>

8860</ul>

8861</div>

8862<p id="_1655" tabindex="-1">

8863A meta-analysis of randomized trials (n = 6) that evaluated the administration of anti-HER2 monotherapy (trastuzumab or lapatinib or pertuzumab) versus dual anti-HER2 therapy (trastuzumab plus lapatinib or trastuzumab plus pertuzumab) was performed.[<a href="#cit/section_4.227">

8864227</a>

8865][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8866Level of evidence C2</a>

8867]</p>

8868<div class="pdq-content-list">

8869<ul id="_1656">

8870<li>

8871LVEF decline was observed in 3.1% of the patients who received monotherapy (95% CI, 2.2%&#8211;4.4%) and 2.9% of the patients who received dual therapy (95% CI, 2.1%&#8211;4.1%).</li>

8872<li>

8873 Symptomatic heart failure was observed in 0.88% of the patients who received monotherapy (95% CI, 0.47%&#8211;1.64%) and 1.49% of the patients who received dual therapy (95% CI, 0.98%&#8211;2.23%).</li>

8874</ul>

8875</div>

8876</section>

8877<section id="_1125">

8878<h4 id="_1125_toc">

8879Preoperative endocrine therapy</h4>

8880<p id="_1126" tabindex="-1">

8881Preoperative endocrine therapy may be an option for postmenopausal women with hormone receptor&#8211;positive breast cancer when chemotherapy is not a suitable option because of comorbidities or performance status. Although the toxicity profile of preoperative hormonal therapy over the course of 3 to 6 months is favorable, the pCR rates obtained (1%&#8211;8%) are far lower than have been reported with chemotherapy in unselected populations.[<a href="#cit/section_4.228">

8882228</a>

8883][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8884Level of evidence B3</a>

8885] </p>

8886<p id="_1309" tabindex="-1">

8887Longer duration of preoperative therapy may be required in this patient population. Preoperative tamoxifen was associated with an overall response rate of 33%, with maximum response occurring up to 12 months after therapy in some patients.[<a href="#cit/section_4.229">

8888229</a>

8889] A randomized study of 4, 8, or 12 months of preoperative letrozole in older patients who were not fit for chemotherapy indicated that the longer duration of therapy resulted in the highest pCR rate (17.5% vs. 5% vs. 2.5%, <em>

8890P</em>

8891-value for trend &lt; .04).[<a href="#cit/section_4.230">

8892230</a>

8893][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8894Level of evidence B3</a>

8895] </p>

8896<p id="_1310" tabindex="-1">

8897AIs have also been compared with tamoxifen in the preoperative setting. Overall objective response and breast-conserving therapy rates with 3 to 4 months of preoperative therapy were either statistically significantly improved in the AI-treated women [<a href="#cit/section_4.228">

8898228</a>

8899] or comparable to tamoxifen-associated outcomes.[<a href="#cit/section_4.230">

8900230</a>

8901] An American College of Surgeons Oncology Group trial is currently comparing the efficacy of anastrozole, letrozole, or exemestane in the preoperative setting.</p>

8902<p id="_1311" tabindex="-1">

8903The use of preoperative endocrine therapy in premenopausal women with hormone-responsive breast cancer remains investigational.</p>

8904</section>

8905<section id="_1128">

8906<h4 id="_1128_toc">

8907Postoperative therapy</h4>

8908<section id="_1766">

8909<h5 id="_1766_toc">

8910Capecitabine</h5>

8911<p id="_1767" tabindex="-1">

8912One clinical trial suggested that there is a benefit to using capecitabine as adjuvant therapy in patients who did not obtain a pCR after preoperative chemotherapy.</p>

8913<p id="_1768" tabindex="-1">

8914Evidence (capecitabine):</p>

8915<div class="pdq-content-list">

8916<ol id="_1769">

8917<li>

8918 In a study conducted in Japan and Korea, 910 women with HER2/neu-negative breast cancers, who had residual disease after preoperative chemotherapy with anthracyclines, taxanes, or both, were randomly assigned in a nonblinded fashion to receive 6 to 8 four-weekly cycles of capecitabine or no further chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.231">

8919231</a>

8920] The study was terminated because of the results of a planned interim analysis, and a final analysis was done. <div class="pdq-content-list">

8921<ul id="_1770">

8922<li>

8923In the final analysis, which included 887 eligible patients, DFS, the primary end point, was statistically significantly prolonged (HR, 0.70; 95% CI, 0.53&#8211;0.92; <em>

8924P</em>

8925 = .01; 5-year DFS rate, 74.1% vs. 67.6%). </li>

8926<li>

8927OS, a secondary end point, was also longer in the capecitabine group (HR, 0.59; 95% CI, 0.39&#8211;0.90; <em>

8928P</em>

8929 = .01; 5-year OS rate, 89.2% vs. 83.6%). </li>

8930<li>

8931In the capecitabine group, 73.4% of the patients experienced hand-foot syndrome of varying degrees of severity.</li>

8932</ul>

8933</div>

8934</li>

8935</ol>

8936</div>

8937</section>

8938<section id="_2019">

8939<h5 id="_2019_toc">

8940Trastuzumab emtansine (T-DM1)</h5>

8941<p id="_2020" tabindex="-1">

8942Evidence (T-DM1):</p>

8943<div class="pdq-content-list">

8944<ol id="_2021">

8945<li>

8946In a phase III trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01772472">

8947KATHERINE</a>

8948 [NCT01772472]), 1,486 women with HER2-positive disease who received a preoperative taxane-containing chemotherapy (with or without an anthracycline) along with trastuzumab with or without a second HER2 targeted agent, but who had residual disease after surgery, were randomly assigned to receive 14 cycles of adjuvant trastuzumab or T-DM1.[<a href="#cit/section_4.232">

8949232</a>

8950][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8951Level of evidence B1</a>

8952]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8953<ul id="_2022">

8954<li>

8955 At the time of a planned interim analysis, invasive DFS (the primary study end point) was significantly higher in the T-DM1 group than in the trastuzumab group (HR<sub>

8956invasive disease or death</sub>

8957, 0.50; 95% CI, 0.39&#8211;0.64; <em>

8958P</em>

8959 &lt; .001; invasive DFS at 3 years, 88.3% vs. 77%).</li>

8960<li>

8961 Data on OS are immature and not significant (HR, 0.70; 95% CI, 0.47&#8211;1.05).</li>

8962<li>

8963 Patients receiving T-DM1 were more likely to discontinue treatment because of an adverse event (18% vs. 2.1%) and had a higher frequency of sensory neuropathy (18.6% vs. 6.9%), most cases of which had resolved at the time of the analysis.</li>

8964<li>

8965On subgroup analysis, the benefit of T-DM1 was observed in all subgroups, including participants who received dual HER2-targeted therapy in the preoperative setting.</li>

8966</ul>

8967</div>

8968</li>

8969</ol>

8970</div>

8971</section>

8972<p id="_1776" tabindex="-1">

8973These approaches and participation in clinical trials of novel therapies should be considered for patients with residual disease after preoperative therapy. <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02445391">

8974EA1131</a>

8975 (NCT02445391) is a randomized phase III clinical trial that randomly assigned patients with residual basal-like TNBC after preoperative therapy to receive platinum-based chemotherapy or capecitabine. <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02954874">

8976S1418/BR006</a>

8977 (NCT02954874) is a phase III trial evaluating the efficacy of pembrolizumab as adjuvant therapy for patients with residual TNBC (&#8805;1 cm invasive cancer or residual nodes) after preoperative therapy. </p>

8978<p id="_1312" tabindex="-1">

8979Radiation therapy is administered after breast conservation in most women who have received preoperative therapy to reduce the risk of locoregional recurrence. Baseline clinical and subsequent pathological staging should be considered in deciding whether to administer postmastectomy radiation. </p>

8980<p id="_1313" tabindex="-1">

8981Other adjuvant systemic treatments may be administered either postoperatively, during, or after completion of adjuvant radiation, including adjuvant hormonal therapy for patients with hormone receptor&#8211;positive disease and adjuvant trastuzumab for those with HER2-positive disease. For more information, see the <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_1028">

8982Endocrine therapy for hormone receptor&#8211;positive breast cancer</a>

8983 section.</p>

8984</section>

8985</section>

8986<section id="_1065">

8987<h3 id="_1065_toc">

8988Posttherapy Surveillance</h3>

8989<p id="_1130" tabindex="-1">

8990The frequency of follow-up and the

8991appropriateness of screening tests after the completion of primary treatment

8992for stage I, stage II, or stage III breast cancer remain controversial.</p>

8993<p id="_1131" tabindex="-1">

8994Evidence from randomized trials indicates that periodic follow-up with bone

8995scans, liver sonography, chest x-rays, and blood tests of liver function does <strong>

8996not</strong>

8997

8998improve survival or quality of life when compared with routine physical

8999examinations.[<a href="#cit/section_4.233">

9000233</a>

9001-<a href="#cit/section_4.235">

9002235</a>

9003]

9004Even when these tests permit earlier detection of

9005recurrent disease, patient survival is unaffected.[<a href="#cit/section_4.234">

9006234</a>

9007] On the basis of these data,

9008acceptable follow-up can be limited to the following for asymptomatic patients who complete treatment for stages I to III breast cancer: </p>

9009<div class="pdq-content-list">

9010<ul id="_1314">

9011<li>

9012Physical

9013examination.</li>

9014<li>

9015Annual mammography.</li>

9016</ul>

9017</div>

9018</section>

9019<section id="_TrialSearch_1375_sid_4">

9020<h3 id="_TrialSearch_1375_sid_4_toc">

9021Current Clinical Trials</h3>

9022<p id="_TrialSearch_1375_22" tabindex="-1">

9023Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

9024advanced clinical trial search</a>

9025 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

9026General information</a>

9027 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

9028</section>

9110[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9111</li>

9112<li id="section_4.21">

9113Chagpar AB, Killelea BK, Tsangaris TN, et al.: A Randomized, Controlled Trial of Cavity Shave Margins in Breast Cancer. N Engl J Med 373 (6): 503-10, 2015.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26028131&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26028131&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9114[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9115</li>

9116<li id="section_4.22">

9117Barth RJ, Danforth DN, Venzon DJ, et al.: Level of axillary involvement by lymph node metastases from breast cancer is not an independent predictor of survival. Arch Surg 126 (5): 574-7, 1991.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=2021339&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=2021339&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9118[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9119</li>

Lancet Oncol 19 (12): 1630-1640, 2018.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=30413379&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=30413379&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9892[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9893</li>

9894<li id="section_4.219">

9895van der Voort A, van Ramshorst MS, van Werkhoven ED, et al.: Three-Year Follow-up of Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy With or Without Anthracyclines in the Presence of Dual ERBB2 Blockade in Patients With ERBB2-Positive Breast Cancer: A Secondary Analysis of the TRAIN-2 Randomized, Phase 3 Trial. JAMA Oncol 7 (7): 978-984, 2021.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=34014249&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=34014249&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9896[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9897</li>

9898<li id="section_4.220">

9899Untch M, Loibl S, Bischoff J, et al.: Lapatinib versus trastuzumab in combination with neoadjuvant anthracycline-taxane-based chemotherapy (GeparQuinto, GBG 44): a randomised phase 3 trial. Lancet Oncol 13 (2): 135-44, 2012.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22257523&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22257523&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9900[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9901</li>

9902<li id="section_4.221">

9903Carey LA, Berry DA, Cirrincione CT, et al.: Molecular Heterogeneity and Response to Neoadjuvant Human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 2 Targeting in CALGB 40601, a Randomized Phase III Trial of Paclitaxel Plus Trastuzumab With or Without Lapatinib. J Clin Oncol 34 (6): 542-9, 2016.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26527775&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26527775&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9904[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9905</li>

9906<li id="section_4.222">

9907Fernandez-Martinez A, Krop IE, Hillman DW, et al.: Survival, Pathologic Response, and Genomics in CALGB 40601 (Alliance), a Neoadjuvant Phase III Trial of Paclitaxel-Trastuzumab With or Without Lapatinib in HER2-Positive Breast Cancer. J Clin Oncol 38 (35): 4184-4193, 2020.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=33095682&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=33095682&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9908[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9909</li>

9910<li id="section_4.223">

9911de Azambuja E, Holmes AP, Piccart-Gebhart M, et al.: Lapatinib with trastuzumab for HER2-positive early breast cancer (NeoALTTO): survival outcomes of a randomised, open-label, multicentre, phase 3 trial and their association with pathological complete response. Lancet Oncol 15 (10): 1137-46, 2014.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=25130998&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=25130998&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9912[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9913</li>

9914<li id="section_4.224">

9915Piccart-Gebhart M, Holmes E, Baselga J, et al.: Adjuvant Lapatinib and Trastuzumab for Early Human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 2-Positive Breast Cancer: Results From the Randomized Phase III Adjuvant Lapatinib and/or Trastuzumab Treatment Optimization Trial. J Clin Oncol 34 (10): 1034-42, 2016.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26598744&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26598744&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9916[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9917</li>

9918<li id="section_4.225">

9919Huober J, Barrios CH, Niikura N, et al.: Atezolizumab With Neoadjuvant Anti-Human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 2 Therapy and Chemotherapy in Human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 2-Positive Early Breast Cancer: Primary Results of the Randomized Phase III IMpassion050 Trial. 9920[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9921</li>

9922<li id="section_4.226">

9923Lenihan D, Suter T, Brammer M, et al.: Pooled analysis of cardiac safety in patients with cancer treated with pertuzumab. Ann Oncol 23 (3): 791-800, 2012.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21665955&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21665955&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9925</li>

9928[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9929</li>

9930<li id="section_4.228">

9931Eiermann W, Paepke S, Appfelstaedt J, et al.: Preoperative treatment of postmenopausal breast cancer patients with letrozole: A randomized double-blind multicenter study.
