9932[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9933</li>

9934<li id="section_4.229">

9935Preece PE, Wood RA, Mackie CR, et al.: Tamoxifen as initial sole treatment of localised breast cancer in elderly women: a pilot study. Br Med J (Clin Res Ed) 284 (6319): 869-70, 1982.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=6802332&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=6802332&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9936[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9937</li>

9938<li id="section_4.230">

9939Smith IE, Dowsett M, Ebbs SR, et al.: Neoadjuvant treatment of postmenopausal breast cancer with anastrozole, tamoxifen, or both in combination: the Immediate Preoperative Anastrozole, Tamoxifen, or Combined with Tamoxifen (IMPACT) multicenter double-blind randomized trial. J Clin Oncol 23 (22): 5108-16, 2005.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15998903&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15998903&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9940[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9941</li>

9942<li id="section_4.231">

9943Masuda N, Lee SJ, Ohtani S, et al.: Adjuvant Capecitabine for Breast Cancer after Preoperative Chemotherapy. N Engl J Med 376 (22): 2147-2159, 2017.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28564564&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28564564&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9944[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9945</li>

9946<li id="section_4.232">

9947von Minckwitz G, Huang CS, Mano MS, et al.: Trastuzumab Emtansine for Residual Invasive HER2-Positive Breast Cancer. N Engl J Med 380 (7): 617-628, 2019.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=30516102&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=30516102&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9948[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9949</li>

9950<li id="section_4.233">

9951Impact of follow-up testing on survival and health-related quality of life in breast cancer patients. A multicenter randomized controlled trial. The GIVIO Investigators. JAMA 271 (20): 1587-92, 1994.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=8182811&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=8182811&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9952[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9953</li>

9954<li id="section_4.234">

9955Rosselli Del Turco M, Palli D, Cariddi A, et al.: Intensive diagnostic follow-up after treatment of primary breast cancer. A randomized trial. National Research Council Project on Breast Cancer follow-up. JAMA 271 (20): 1593-7, 1994.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7848404&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7848404&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9956[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9957</li>

9958<li id="section_4.235">

9959Khatcheressian JL, Wolff AC, Smith TJ, et al.: American Society of Clinical Oncology 2006 update of the breast cancer follow-up and management guidelines in the adjuvant setting. J Clin Oncol 24 (31): 5091-7, 2006.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17033037&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17033037&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9960[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9961</li>

9962</ol>

9963</div>

9964

9965 </section>

9966

9967

9968

9969 <section id="_1699">

9970

9971 <h2>

9972Treatment of Locally Advanced or Inflammatory Breast Cancer</h2>

9973

9974 <div id="_section_1699" class="pdq-sections">

9975<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

9976<h6>

9977In This Section</h6>

9978<ul>

9979<li>

9980<a href="#_1700_toc">

9981Treatment Option Overview for Locally Advanced or Inflammatory Breast Cancer</a>

9982</li>

9983<li>

9984<a href="#_TrialSearch_1699_sid_5_toc">

9985Current Clinical Trials</a>

9986</li>

9987</ul>

9988</nav>

9989<section id="_1700">

9990<h3 id="_1700_toc">

9991Treatment Option Overview for Locally Advanced or Inflammatory Breast Cancer</h3>

9992<p id="_1701" tabindex="-1">

9993On the basis of the available evidence, multimodality therapy delivered with curative intent is the standard of care

9994for patients with locally advanced or inflammatory breast cancer. </p>

9995<p id="_1702" tabindex="-1">

9996Treatment options for locally advanced or inflammatory breast cancer may include the following:</p>

9997<div class="pdq-content-list">

9998<ol id="_1703">

9999<li>

10000Breast-conserving surgery or total mastectomy with axillary lymph node dissection.</li>

10001<li>

10002Chemotherapy.</li>

10003<li>

10004Radiation therapy.</li>

10005<li>

10006Hormone therapy.</li>

10007</ol>

10008</div>

10009<p id="_1704" tabindex="-1">

10010Initial surgery is generally

10011limited to biopsy to permit the determination of histology, estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor levels,

10012and human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2/neu) overexpression.</p>

10013<p id="_1705" tabindex="-1">

10014The standard chemotherapy regimen for initial treatment is the same as that used in the adjuvant setting, although trials done solely in patients with locally advanced disease have not shown a statistically significant advantage to dose-dense chemotherapy. For more information, see the <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_1027">

10015Postoperative Systemic Therapy</a>

10016 section.[<a href="#cit/section_5.1">

100171</a>

10018]</p>

10019<p id="_1706" tabindex="-1">

10020For

10021patients whose tumors respond to preoperative chemotherapy, local therapy may consist of

10022total mastectomy with axillary lymph node dissection followed by postoperative

10023radiation therapy to the chest wall and regional lymphatics. Breast-conserving

10024therapy can be considered for patients with a good partial or complete response

10025to preoperative chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.2">

100262</a>

10027] Subsequent systemic therapy may consist of

10028further chemotherapy. Hormone therapy is administered to patients with ER-positive or ER-unknown tumors.</p>

10029<p id="_1707" tabindex="-1">

10030Although the evidence described below has not been replicated, it suggests patients with locally advanced or inflammatory breast cancer should be treated with curative intent. </p>

10031<p id="_1708" tabindex="-1">

10032Evidence (multimodality therapy):</p>

10033<div class="pdq-content-list">

10034<ol id="_1709">

10035<li>

10036In a retrospective series, 70 patients with locally advanced breast cancer and supraclavicular metastases received preoperative chemotherapy. Patients then received local therapy that consisted of either total mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection or breast-conserving surgery and axillary lymph node dissection before or after radiation therapy. Patients whose tumors did not respond to preoperative chemotherapy were treated with surgery and/or radiation therapy. After completion of local therapy, chemotherapy was continued for 4 to 15 cycles, followed by radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.3">

100373</a>

10038]<div class="pdq-content-list">

10039<ul id="_1710">

10040<li>

10041Approximately 32% of patients with ipsilateral supraclavicular node involvement and no evidence of distant metastases (pN3c) had prolonged disease-free survival (DFS) at 10 years with combined-modality therapy.</li>

10042<li>

10043These results have been confirmed in a separate series of patients treated in British Columbia.[<a href="#cit/section_5.4">

100444</a>

10045]</li>

10046</ul>

10047</div>

10048</li>

10049<li>

10050A series of

10051178 patients with inflammatory breast cancer were treated with a combined-modality approach. Patients were treated with induction chemotherapy, then local therapy (radiation therapy or mastectomy), followed by chemotherapy, and, if mastectomy was performed, radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.5">

100525</a>

10053][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10054Level of evidence C2</a>

10055] </li>

10056</ol>

10057</div>

10058<p id="_1711" tabindex="-1">

10059Subsequent trials have confirmed that patients with locally advanced and inflammatory breast cancer can experience long-term DFS when treated with initial chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.1">

100601</a>

10061]</p>

10062<p id="_1712" tabindex="-1">

10063All patients are considered

10064candidates for clinical trials to evaluate the most appropriate way to administer the various components of new multimodality regimens.</p>

10065</section>

10066<section id="_TrialSearch_1699_sid_5">

10067<h3 id="_TrialSearch_1699_sid_5_toc">

10068Current Clinical Trials</h3>

10069<p id="_TrialSearch_1699_22" tabindex="-1">

10070Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

10071advanced clinical trial search</a>

10072 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

10073General information</a>

10074 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

10075</section>

10076<h6 do-not-show="toc">

10077References</h6>

10078<ol>

10079<li id="section_5.1">

10080Petrelli F, Coinu A, Lonati V, et al.: Neoadjuvant dose-dense chemotherapy for locally advanced breast cancer: a meta-analysis of published studies. Anticancer Drugs 27 (7): 702-8, 2016.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=27058707&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=27058707&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10081[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10082</li>

10083<li id="section_5.2">

10084Berg CD, Swain SM: Results of Concomitantly Administered Chemoradiation for Locally Advanced Noninflammatory Breast Cancer. Semin Radiat Oncol 4 (4): 226-235, 1994.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10717111&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10717111&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10085[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10086</li>

10087<li id="section_5.3">

10088Brito RA, Valero V, Buzdar AU, et al.: Long-term results of combined-modality therapy for locally advanced breast cancer with ipsilateral supraclavicular metastases: The University of Texas M.D. Anderson Cancer Center experience. J Clin Oncol 19 (3): 628-33, 2001.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11157012&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11157012&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10089[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10090</li>

10091<li id="section_5.4">

10092Olivotto IA, Chua B, Allan SJ, et al.: Long-term survival of patients with supraclavicular metastases at diagnosis of breast cancer. J Clin Oncol 21 (5): 851-4, 2003.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12610184&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12610184&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10093[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10094</li>

10095<li id="section_5.5">

10096Ueno NT, Buzdar AU, Singletary SE, et al.: Combined-modality treatment of inflammatory breast carcinoma: twenty years of experience at M. D. Anderson Cancer Center. Cancer Chemother Pharmacol 40 (4): 321-9, 1997.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9225950&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9225950&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10097[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10098</li>

10099</ol>

10100</div>

10101

10102 </section>

10103

10104

10105

10106 <section id="_1440">

10107

10108 <h2>

10109Treatment of Locoregional Recurrent Breast Cancer</h2>

10110

10111 <div id="_section_1440" class="pdq-sections">

10112<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

10113<h6>

10114In This Section</h6>

10115<ul>

10116<li>

10117<a href="#_TrialSearch_1440_sid_6_toc">

10118Current Clinical Trials</a>

10119</li>

10120</ul>

10121</nav>

10122<p id="_1441" tabindex="-1">

10123Recurrent breast cancer often responds to therapy, although treatment is

10124rarely curative at this stage of disease. Patients with locoregional breast cancer recurrence may become long-term survivors

10125with appropriate therapy.</p>

10126<p id="_1442" tabindex="-1">

10127 The rates of locoregional recurrence have declined over time, and a meta-analysis suggests a recurrence rate of less than 3% in patients treated with breast-conserving surgery and radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.1">

101281</a>

10129] The rates are somewhat higher (up to 10%) for those treated with mastectomy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.2">

101302</a>

10131] Nine

10132percent to 25% of patients with locoregional recurrence will have distant metastases or locally

10133extensive disease at the time of recurrence.[<a href="#cit/section_6.3">

101343</a>

10135-<a href="#cit/section_6.5">

101365</a>

10137]</p>

10138<p id="_1443" tabindex="-1">

10139Before treatment for recurrent breast cancer,

10140restaging to evaluate the extent of disease is indicated. Cytological or histological

10141documentation of recurrent disease is obtained whenever

10142possible. When therapy is selected, the estrogen-receptor (ER) status, progesterone-receptor (PR) status, and human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2/neu) status at the time of recurrence and previous treatment are

10143considered, if known. </p>

10144<p id="_1444" tabindex="-1">

10145ER status may change at the time

10146of recurrence. In a single small study by the Cancer and Leukemia Group B (MDA-MBDT-8081), 36% of hormone receptor&#8211;positive

10147tumors were found to be receptor negative in biopsy specimens isolated at the

10148time of recurrence.[<a href="#cit/section_6.6">

101496</a>

10150] Patients in this study had no interval treatment. If

10151ER and PR statuses are unknown, then the site(s) of recurrence, disease-free

10152interval, response to previous treatment, and menopausal status are useful in

10153the selection of chemotherapy or hormone therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.7">

101547</a>

10155]</p>

10156<p id="_1445" tabindex="-1">

10157Treatment options for locoregional recurrent breast cancer include the following:</p>

10158<div class="pdq-content-list">

10159<ol id="_1446">

10160<li>

10161Chemotherapy.</li>

10162<li>

10163Hormone therapy.</li>

10164<li>

10165Radiation therapy.</li>

10166<li>

10167Surgery.</li>

10168<li>

10169Targeted therapy (e.g., trastuzumab).</li>

10170</ol>

10171</div>

10172<p id="_1447" tabindex="-1">

10173Patients with locoregional

10174recurrence should be considered for further local treatment (e.g., mastectomy).

10175In one series, the 5-year actuarial rate of relapse for patients treated for

10176invasive recurrence after initial breast conservation and radiation therapy was

1017752%.[<a href="#cit/section_6.4">

101784</a>

10179] </p>

10180<p id="_1448" tabindex="-1">

10181Treatment options also depend on the site of recurrence, as follows:</p>

10182<div class="pdq-content-list">

10183<ul id="_1449">

10184<li>

10185Cutaneous: A phase III randomized study showed that local control of cutaneous metastases could be achieved with the application of topical miltefosine; however, the drug is not currently available in the United States.[<a href="#cit/section_6.8">

101868</a>

10187][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10188Level of evidence B1</a>

10189]

10190</li>

10191<li>

10192Chest wall: Local chest wall recurrence after mastectomy is usually the harbinger of

10193widespread disease, but, in a subset of patients, it may be the only site of

10194recurrence. For patients in this subset, surgery and/or radiation therapy may

10195be curative.[<a href="#cit/section_6.9">

101969</a>

10197,<a href="#cit/section_6.10">

1019810</a>

10199] Patients with chest wall recurrences of less than 3

10200cm, axillary and internal mammary node recurrence (not

10201supraclavicular, which has a poorer survival), and a greater-than-2-year

10202disease-free interval before recurrence have the best chance for prolonged

10203survival.[<a href="#cit/section_6.10">

1020410</a>

10205] The 5-year disease-free survival (DFS) rate in one series of such

10206patients was 25%, with a 10-year rate of 15%.[<a href="#cit/section_6.11">

1020711</a>

10208] The locoregional control

10209rate was 57% at 10 years. Systemic therapy should be considered in patients

10210with locoregional recurrence.</li>

10211<li>

10212Breast: In the Chemotherapy as Adjuvant for Locally Recurrent Breast Cancer (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00074152">

10213CALOR</a>

10214 [NCT00074152]) trial, patients with a history of breast-conserving surgery or mastectomy with clear margins and complete excision of an isolated local recurrence of their breast cancer were randomly assigned to receive either chemotherapy of the physician's choice or no chemotherapy. The study was closed early because of poor accrual. The original sample size for a hazard ratio (HR) of 0.74 was 977 patients (347 DFS events) and was revised subsequently to 265 patients (HR, 0.6; 124 DFS events), with only 162 enrolled at the time of study closure.[<a href="#cit/section_6.12">

1021512</a>

10216][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10217Level of evidence B1</a>

10218]<div class="pdq-content-list">

10219<ul id="_1450">

10220<li>

10221In ER-negative patients, the HR for DFS for chemotherapy versus no chemotherapy was 0.29 (95% CI, 0.13&#8211;0.67; 10 years DFS, 70% vs. 34%), whereas in ER-positive patients, the HR was 1.07 (95% CI, 0.57&#8211;2.00; 10 years DFS, 50% vs. 59%). The interaction between chemotherapy and ER status with respect to DFS was significant (<em>

10222P</em>

10223 = .013).[<a href="#cit/section_6.13">

1022413</a>

10225] </li>

10226<li>

10227This trial supports consideration of adjuvant chemotherapy after complete resection of isolated locoregional recurrence of breast cancer in patients with ER-negative tumors.</li>

10228</ul>

10229</div>

10230</li>

10231</ul>

10232</div>

10233<p id="_1451" tabindex="-1">

10234All patients with recurrent breast cancer are

10235considered candidates for ongoing clinical trials.

10236For more information, see the <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_1452">

10237Treatment of Metastatic Breast Cancer</a>

10238 section.</p>

10239<section id="_TrialSearch_1440_sid_6">

10240<h3 id="_TrialSearch_1440_sid_6_toc">

10241Current Clinical Trials</h3>

10242<p id="_TrialSearch_1440_22" tabindex="-1">

10243Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

10244advanced clinical trial search</a>

10245 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

10246General information</a>

10247 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

10248</section>

10306

10307 </section>

10308

10309

10310

10311 <section id="_1452">

10312

10313 <h2>

10314Treatment of Metastatic Breast Cancer</h2>

10315

10316 <div id="_section_1452" class="pdq-sections">

10317<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

10318<h6>

10319In This Section</h6>

10320<ul>

10321<li>

10322<a href="#_1458_toc">

10323Hormone Receptor&#8211;Positive HER2-Negative Breast Cancer <ul>

10324<li>

10325<a href="#_2087_toc">

10326Endocrine therapy and cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK) inhibitor therapy</a>

10327</li>

10328<li>

10329<a href="#_1477_toc">

10330Mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) inhibitor therapy plus endocrine therapy</a>

10331</li>

10332<li>

10333<a href="#_2161_toc">

10334Alpelisib plus endocrine therapy</a>

10335</li>

10336<li>

10337<a href="#_2575_toc">

10338Elacestrant</a>

10339</li>

10340<li>

10341<a href="#_2518_toc">

10342AKT inhibitor therapy</a>

10343</li>

10344<li>

10345<a href="#_2524_toc">

10346HDAC inhibitor therapy</a>

10347</li>

10351</li>

10354Sequencing therapy for hormone receptor&#8211;positive metastatic breast cancer</a>

10364</ul>

10365</a>

10366</li>

10369HER2/neu-Low Breast Cancer</a>

10370</li>

10371<li>

10372<a href="#_1489_toc">

10373Triple-Negative Breast Cancer<ul>

10374<li>

10375<a href="#_2476_toc">

10376Chemotherapy plus immunotherapy</a>

10377</li>

10378<li>

10379<a href="#_2490_toc">

10380Sacituzumab govitecan</a>

10381</li>

10382<li>

10383<a href="#_2586_toc">

10384PARP inhibitor therapy</a>

10385</li>

10386<li>

10387<a href="#_2588_toc">

10388Chemotherapy</a>

10389</li>

10390<li>

10391<a href="#_2496_toc">

10392Immunotherapy monotherapy</a>

10393</li>

10394</ul>

10395</a>

10396</li>

10397<li>

10398<a href="#_1491_toc">

10399HER2/neu-Positive Breast Cancer<ul>

10400<li>

10401<a href="#_1493_toc">

10402Monoclonal antibody therapy</a>

10403</li>

10404<li>

10405<a href="#_2214_toc">

10406Trastuzumab deruxtecan</a>

10407</li>

10408<li>

10409<a href="#_2535_toc">

10410Margetuximab</a>

10411</li>

10412<li>

10413<a href="#_1515_toc">

10414Tyrosine kinase inhibitor therapy</a>

10415</li>

10416<li>

10417<a href="#_2540_toc">

10418mTOR inhibition</a>

10419</li>

10420</ul>

10421</a>

10422</li>

10423<li>

10424<a href="#_1780_toc">

10425Germline <em class="gene-name">

10426BRCA</em>

10427-Mutated Breast Cancer<ul>

10428<li>

10429<a href="#_1849_toc">

10430Olaparib</a>

10431</li>

10432<li>

10433<a href="#_1853_toc">

10434 Talazoparib</a>

10435</li>

10436</ul>

10437</a>

10438</li>

10439<li>

10440<a href="#_2544_toc">

10441High Tumor Mutational Burden<ul>

10442<li>

10443<a href="#_2546_toc">

10444Pembrolizumab </a>

10445</li>

10446</ul>

10447</a>

10448</li>

10449<li>

10450<a href="#_1520_toc">

10451Chemotherapy for Metastatic Breast Cancer<ul>

10452<li>

10453<a href="#_1541_toc">

10454Cardiac toxic effects with anthracyclines</a>

10455</li>

10456</ul>

10457</a>

10458</li>

10459<li>

10460<a href="#_1547_toc">

10461Surgery

10462</a>

10463</li>

10464<li>

10465<a href="#_1551_toc">

10466Radiation Therapy

10467</a>

10468</li>

10469<li>

10470<a href="#_1555_toc">

10471Bone-Modifying Therapy</a>

10472</li>

10473<li>

10474<a href="#_TrialSearch_1452_sid_7_toc">

10475Current Clinical Trials</a>

10476</li>

10477</ul>

10478</nav>

10479<p id="_1453" tabindex="-1">

10480Treatment of metastatic disease is palliative in intent. Goals of treatment

10481include prolonging life and improving quality of life. Although median

10482survival has been reported to be 18 to 24 months overall,[<a href="#cit/section_7.1">

104831</a>

10484] survival varies according to subtype. The longest median survival outcomes have been observed in patients with human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2)-positive and hormone receptor&#8211;positive metastatic breast cancer, and less favorable outcomes have been observed in patients with metastatic triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC).[<a href="#cit/section_7.2">

104852</a>

10486]

10487</p>

10488<p id="_1454" tabindex="-1">

10489Treatment options for metastatic breast cancer include the following:</p>

10490<div class="pdq-content-list">

10491<ol id="_1455">

10492<li>

10493Hormone therapy (tamoxifen, aromatase inhibitors, selective estrogen receptor [ER] degraders).</li>

10494<li>

10495 HER2-targeted therapy.</li>

10496<li>

10497 CDK4/6 inhibitors.</li>

10498<li>

10499 mTOR inhibitors.</li>

10500<li>

10501 PIK3CA inhibitors.</li>

10502<li>

10503Chemotherapy.</li>

10504<li>

10505Immunotherapy.</li>

10506<li>

10507Surgery, for patients with limited symptomatic metastases.</li>

10508<li>

10509Radiation therapy, for patients with limited symptomatic metastases.</li>

10510<li>

10511Bone-modifying therapy, for patients with bone metastases.</li>

10512</ol>

10513</div>

10514<p id="_2086" tabindex="-1">

10515In many cases, these therapies are given in sequence and used in various combinations.</p>

10516<p id="_1456" tabindex="-1">

10517Cytological or histological

10518documentation of metastatic disease, with testing of ER, progesterone receptor, and HER2 status, should be obtained at the time of metastatic presentation, if possible. If not possible, it is appropriate to consider liquid biopsy (via circulating tumor cell and/or circulating tumor DNA testing).</p>

10519<p id="_1457" tabindex="-1">

10520All patients with metastatic breast cancer are

10521considered candidates for ongoing clinical trials.

10522</p>

10523<section id="_1458">

10524<h3 id="_1458_toc">

10525Hormone Receptor&#8211;Positive HER2-Negative Breast Cancer </h3>

10526<section id="_2087">

10527<h4 id="_2087_toc">

10528Endocrine therapy and cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK) inhibitor therapy</h4>

10529<p id="_2088" tabindex="-1">

10530CDK4 and CDK6 have been implicated in the continued proliferation of hormone receptor&#8211;positive breast cancer resistant to endocrine therapy. CDK inhibitors have been approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in combination with endocrine therapy in both first-line and later-line treatment of advanced hormone receptor&#8211;positive HER2-negative breast cancer. Three oral CDK4/6 inhibitors are currently available: palbociclib, ribociclib, and abemaciclib. </p>

10531<p id="_2089" tabindex="-1">

10532Overall, the addition of CDK4/6 inhibitors to endocrine therapy is associated with improved breast cancer outcomes and, in general, either maintained or improved quality of life.[<a href="#cit/section_7.3">

105333</a>

10534-<a href="#cit/section_7.8">

105358</a>

10536] This benefit was observed across multiple clinicopathological subgroups of breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_7.9">

105379</a>

10538]</p>

10539<section id="_2090">

10540<h5 id="_2090_toc">

10541First-line palbociclib and endocrine therapy</h5>

10542<p id="_2091" tabindex="-1">

10543Evidence (first-line palbociclib and endocrine therapy):</p>

10544<div class="pdq-content-list">

10545<ol id="_2092">

10546<li>

10547<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01740427">

10548PALOMA-2</a>

10549 (NCT01740427) confirmed the results of the phase II PALOMA-1 trial.[<a href="#cit/section_7.10">

1055010</a>

10551] This phase III, double-blind trial compared placebo plus letrozole with palbociclib plus letrozole as initial therapy for ER-positive postmenopausal patients with advanced disease (n = 666).[<a href="#cit/section_7.11">

1055211</a>

10553] <div class="pdq-content-list">

10554<ul id="_2093">

10555<li>

10556 The primary end point (investigator-assessed progression-free survival [PFS]) was met with a median PFS of 24.8 months in the palbociclib-plus-letrozole group compared with 14.5 months in the placebo-plus-letrozole group (hazard ratio [HR], 0.58; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.46&#8211;0.72; <em>

10557P</em>

10558 &lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_7.11">

1055911</a>

10560][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10561Level of evidence B1</a>

10562] </li>

10563<li>

10564Overall survival (OS) data are not yet mature.</li>

10565<li>

10566 Patients who received palbociclib experienced more frequent cytopenias (66.4% grade 3 to 4 in palbociclib-treated patients vs. 1.4% in placebo-treated patients). Other common adverse events included nausea, arthralgia, fatigue, and alopecia. The most common grade 3 to 4 adverse events other than neutropenia included leukopenia (24.8% vs. 0%), anemia (5.4% vs. 1.8%), and fatigue (1.8% vs. 0.5%). </li>

10567</ul>

10568</div>

10569</li>

10570</ol>

10571</div>

10572</section>

10573<section id="_2094">

10574<h5 id="_2094_toc">

10575First-line ribociclib and endocrine therapy</h5>

10576<p id="_2158" tabindex="-1">

10577Ribociclib, another CDK4/6 inhibitor, has also been tested in the first-line setting for postmenopausal patients and premenopausal patients with hormone receptor&#8211;positive and HER2-negative recurrent or metastatic breast cancer. </p>

10578<p id="_2095" tabindex="-1">

10579Evidence (first-line ribociclib and endocrine therapy):</p>

10580<div class="pdq-content-list">

10581<ol id="_2096">

10582<li>

10583The phase III placebo-controlled <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01958021">

10584MONALEESA-2</a>

10585 trial (NCT01958021) randomly assigned 668 patients to receive first-line ribociclib plus letrozole or placebo plus letrozole.[<a href="#cit/section_7.12">

1058612</a>

10587,<a href="#cit/section_7.13">

1058813</a>

10589] <div class="pdq-content-list">

10590<ul id="_2564">

10591<li>

10592The primary end point (investigator-assessed PFS) was met. A preplanned interim analysis was performed after 243 patients had disease progression or died, and median duration of follow-up was 15.3 months. After 18 months, the PFS rate was 63.0% (95% CI, 54.6%&#8211;70.3%) in the ribociclib group and 42.2% (95% CI, 34.8%&#8211;49.5%) in the placebo group.[<a href="#cit/section_7.12">

1059312</a>

10594]</li>

10595<li>

10596OS was a secondary end point. A protocol-specified final analysis of OS was published after 400 deaths and a median follow-up of 6.6 years. Patients who received ribociclib plus letrozole had a significant OS benefit compared with patients who received placebo plus letrozole. Median OS was 63.9 months in the ribociclib group and 51.4 months in the placebo group (HR<sub>

10597death</sub>

10598, 0.76; 95% CI, 0.63&#8211;0.93; two-sided <em>

10599P</em>

10600 = .008).[<a href="#cit/section_7.14">

1060114</a>

10602][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10603Level of evidence A1</a>

10604] </li>

10605<li>

10606Grade 3 to 4 neutropenia occurred in 63.8% of patients in the ribociclib group and 1.2% of patients in the placebo group. Grade 1 to 2 nausea, infection, fatigue, and diarrhea were also noted. Grade 3 to 4 hepatobiliary toxic effects occurred in 14.4% of patients who received ribociclib and 4.8% of patients who received placebo. Prolonged QTcF interval occurred in 4.5% of patients in the ribociclib group and 2.1% of patients in the placebo group.</li>

10607</ul>

10608</div>

10609</li>

10610<li>

10611Ribociclib has also been tested in combination with fulvestrant in postmenopausal patients with hormone receptor&#8211;positive and HER2-negative recurrent or metastatic breast cancer. The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02422615">

10612MONALEESA-3</a>

10613 trial (NCT02422615) included patients receiving first-line or second-line therapy. This phase III, placebo-controlled trial randomly assigned 726 patients in a 2:1 ratio to receive ribociclib plus fulvestrant or placebo plus fulvestrant.[<a href="#cit/section_7.15">

1061415</a>

10615] <div class="pdq-content-list">

10616<ol id="_2099" class="lower-alpha">

10617<li>

10618 The primary end point (investigator-assessed PFS) was met. At the time of final analysis for PFS, the median PFS for the ribociclib group was 20.5 months versus 12.8 months in the placebo group (HR, 0.593; 95% CI, 0.480&#8211;0.732; <em>

10619P</em>

10620 &lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_7.15">

1062115</a>

10622][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10623Level of evidence B1</a>

10624] </li>

10625<li>

10626OS was superior in the ribociclib group (HR, 0.724; 95% CI, 0.568&#8211;0.924; <em>

10627P</em>

10628&#8201;=&#8201;.004). The result crossed the prespecified stopping boundary (<em>

10629P</em>

10630&#8201;=&#8201;.011) for superior efficacy. Results were similar in all subgroups.[<a href="#cit/section_7.16">

1063116</a>

10632][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10633Level of evidence A1</a>

10634]</li>

10635<li>

10636Adverse events were similar to those in other studies of CDK4/6 inhibitors.<div class="pdq-content-list">

10637<ul id="_2100">

10638<li>

10639 Grade 3 to 4 neutropenia occurred in 53.4% of patients in the ribociclib group and 0.0% of patients in the placebo group.</li>

10640<li>

10641 The rate of febrile neutropenia was 1.0% in the ribociclib group and 0% in the placebo group.</li>

10642<li>

10643 An increase in QTcF interval of more than 60 milliseconds from baseline was observed in 6.5% of patients in the ribociclib arm and 0.4% in the placebo arm.</li>

10644</ul>

10645</div>

10646</li>

10647</ol>

10648</div>

10649</li>

10650<li>

10651Ribociclib was also assessed in the first-line setting in a study conducted solely in premenopausal or perimenopausal women receiving either tamoxifen or a nonsteroidal aromatase inhibitor (AI) plus goserelin.[<a href="#cit/section_7.17">

1065217</a>

10653] In the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02278120">

10654MONALEESA-7</a>

10655 trial (NCT02278120), 672 premenopausal patients with hormone receptor&#8211;positive and HER2-negative recurrent or metastatic breast cancer, who had not received endocrine therapy for advanced disease, were randomly assigned in a 1:1 ratio to ribociclib or placebo. <div class="pdq-content-list">

10656<ol id="_2101" class="lower-alpha">

10657<li>

10658 The primary end point (investigator-assessed PFS) was met. At the time of final analysis for PFS, the median PFS for the ribociclib group was 23.8 months versus 13.0 months in the placebo group (HR, 0.55; 95% CI, 0.44&#8211;0.69; <em>

10659P</em>

10660 &lt; .0001).[<a href="#cit/section_7.17">

1066117</a>

10662][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10663Level of evidence A3</a>

10664] </li>

10665<li>

10666OS was a secondary end point. The combination of ribociclib plus endocrine therapy was associated with longer OS than was endocrine therapy alone (42-month OS, 70.2% vs. 46%; HR<sub>

10667death</sub>

10668, 0.71; 95% CI, 0.54&#8722;0.95, <em>

10669P</em>

10670 = .01).[<a href="#cit/section_7.18">

1067118</a>

10672][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10673Level of evidence A1</a>

10674] The survival benefit was observed both in patients who received an AI plus goserelin and in those who received tamoxifen, but it was not statistically significant in the much-smaller tamoxifen group. </li>

10675<li>

10676Adverse events were similar to those in other studies of CDK4/6 inhibitors.<div class="pdq-content-list">

10677<ul id="_2102">

10678<li>

10679 Grade 3 to 4 neutropenia occurred in 61% of patients in the ribociclib group and 4% of patients in the placebo group.</li>

10680<li>

10681 The rate of febrile neutropenia was 2.0% in the ribociclib group and 1.0% in the placebo group.</li>

10682<li>

10683 An increase in QTcF interval of more than 60 milliseconds from baseline was observed in 10.0 % of patients in the ribociclib arm and 2.0% in the placebo arm. Sixty-millisecond increases were more common in patients receiving tamoxifen (16% on ribociclib and 7% on placebo).</li>

10684</ul>

10685</div>

10686</li>

10687</ol>

10688</div>

10689</li>

10690</ol>

10691</div>

10692</section>

10693<section id="_2103">

10694<h5 id="_2103_toc">

10695First-line abemaciclib and endocrine therapy</h5>

10696<p id="_2104" tabindex="-1">

10697Abemaciclib, another CDK4/6 inhibitor, has also been tested in the first-line setting for postmenopausal patients with hormone receptor&#8211;positive and HER2-negative recurrent or metastatic breast cancer.</p>

10698<p id="_2105" tabindex="-1">

10699Evidence (first-line abemaciclib and endocrine therapy):</p>

10700<div class="pdq-content-list">

10701<ol id="_2106">

10702<li>

10703<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02246621">

10704MONARCH 3</a>

10705 (NCT02246621) was a randomized, double-blind, phase III trial that evaluated first-line abemaciclib or placebo plus a nonsteroidal AI in 493 postmenopausal women with hormone receptor&#8211;positive and HER2-negative advanced breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_7.19">

1070619</a>

10707]<div class="pdq-content-list">

10708<ul id="_2107">

10709<li>

10710 The primary end point, investigator-assessed PFS, was met. After a median follow-up of 17.8 months, the PFS was not reached in the abemaciclib arm and was reached at 14.7 months in the placebo arm (HR, 0.54; 95% CI, 0.41&#8211;0.72; <em>

10711P</em>

10712 = .000021).</li>

10713<li>

10714 OS data are not yet mature.</li>

10715<li>

10716 The side effect profile of abemaciclib differs from the other CDK4/6 inhibitors. Diarrhea was the most frequent adverse event in the abemaciclib arm, although most of the diarrhea cases were grade 1. </li>

10717<li>

10718Neutropenia was more common in the abemaciclib arm; however, only 21.1% of participants experienced grade 3 to 4 neutropenia. </li>

10719</ul>

10720</div>

10721</li>

10722</ol>

10723</div>

10724</section>

10725<section id="_2108">

10726<h5 id="_2108_toc">

10727Second-line palbociclib and endocrine therapy</h5>

10728<p id="_2109" tabindex="-1">

10729Evidence (second-line palbociclib and endocrine therapy):</p>

10730<div class="pdq-content-list">

10731<ol id="_2110">

10732<li>

10733<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01942135">

10734PALOMA-3</a>

10735 (NCT01942135) was a double-blind, phase III trial of 521 patients with hormone receptor&#8211;positive, HER2/neu-negative, advanced breast cancer who had relapsed after or progressed on previous endocrine therapy and were randomly assigned to receive either fulvestrant plus placebo or fulvestrant plus palbociclib. Premenopausal and postmenopausal patients were eligible. Premenopausal patients received goserelin.[<a href="#cit/section_7.5">

107365</a>

10737][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10738Level of evidence A3</a>

10739] <div class="pdq-content-list">

10740<ul id="_2111">

10741<li>

10742The final PFS analysis showed a median PFS of 9.5 months on the palbociclib-fulvestrant arm versus 4.6 months on the placebo-fulvestrant arm (HR, 0.46; 95% CI, 0.36&#8211;0.59; <em>

10743P</em>

10744 &lt; .0001).[<a href="#cit/section_7.20">

1074520</a>

10746][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10747Level of evidence A3</a>

10748]</li>

10749<li>

10750Cytopenias, particularly neutropenia, were much more frequent on the palbociclib-containing arm, but febrile neutropenia was very uncommon (1%) in both groups. Patients receiving palbociclib had more-frequent fatigue, nausea, and headache.</li>

10751<li>

10752A prespecified analysis of OS was made after 310 patients had died. A 6.9 month difference in median OS favoring the palbociclib-fulvestrant arm (34.9 months vs. 28.0 months) was found, which did not reach statistical significance (HR, 0.81; 95% CI, 0.64&#8211;1.03, <em>

10753P</em>

10754 = .09).[<a href="#cit/section_7.21">

1075521</a>

10756] </li>

10757<li>

10758In a preplanned subgroup analysis, improved OS was observed in patients who had demonstrated sensitivity to hormone therapy (HR, 0.72; 95% CI, 0.55&#8722;0.94), whereas in patients without sensitivity, OS was not improved in the palbociclib group (HR, 1.14; 95% CI, 0.71&#8722;1.84; <em>

10759P</em>

10760 = .12 for interaction).</li>

10761</ul>

10762</div>

10763</li>

10764</ol>

10765</div>

10766</section>

10767<section id="_2112">

10768<h5 id="_2112_toc">

10769Second-line ribociclib and endocrine therapy</h5>

10770<p id="_2113" tabindex="-1">

10771The MONALEESA-3 trial included patients receiving second-line therapy. For more information, see the evidence on first-line ribociclib and endocrine therapy <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_2096">

10772above</a>

10773.</p>

10774</section>

10775<section id="_2114">

10776<h5 id="_2114_toc">

10777Second-line abemaciclib and endocrine therapy</h5>

10778<p id="_2115" tabindex="-1">

10779Evidence:</p>

10780<div class="pdq-content-list">

10781<ol id="_2116">

10782<li>

10783The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02107703">

10784MONARCH 2</a>

10785 study (NCT02107703) tested abemaciclib (CDK4/6 inhibitor) in a phase III, placebo-controlled trial that randomly assigned 669 patients with hormone receptor&#8211;positive and HER2-negative advanced breast cancer (with previous progression on endocrine therapy) to receive abemaciclib plus fulvestrant or placebo plus fulvestrant.[<a href="#cit/section_7.22">

1078622</a>

10787]<div class="pdq-content-list">

10788<ol id="_2117" class="lower-alpha">

10789<li>

10790 The primary end point (investigator-assessed PFS) was met, with median duration of follow-up of 19.5 months. The median PFS was 16.4 months for the abemaciclib-fulvestrant arm versus 9.3 months for the placebo-fulvestrant arm (HR, 0.55; 95% CI, 0.45&#8211;0.68; <em>

10791P</em>

10792 &lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_7.22">

1079322</a>

10794][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10795Level of evidence B1</a>

10796] </li>

10797<li>

10798OS data are mature and demonstrate an improvement in OS for patients receiving abemaciclib, and showed a median OS of 46.7 months for abemaciclib plus fulvestrant versus 37.3 months for placebo (HR, 0.757; 95% CI, 0.606&#8211;0.945; <em>

10799P</em>

10800 = .01).[<a href="#cit/section_7.23">

1080123</a>

10802][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10803Level of evidence A1</a>

10804]</li>

10805<li>

10806Adverse events included diarrhea in the abemaciclib group (86.4%) and in the placebo group (24.7%), neutropenia (46% and 4%), nausea (45.1% and 22.9%), fatigue (39.9% and 26.9%), and abdominal pain (35.4% and 15.7%).<div class="pdq-content-list">

10807<ul id="_2118">

10808<li>

10809 These events were mostly grade 1 to 2. Grade 1 to 2 diarrhea occurred in 73% of the patients in the abemaciclib group and in 24.2% of the placebo group. Anti-diarrheal medicine effectively managed this symptom in most cases, according to the study report. </li>

10810<li>

10811 Grade 3 diarrhea occurred in 13.4% of patients in the abemaciclib group and 0.4% of patients in the placebo group. No grade 4 diarrhea was reported. </li>

10812<li>

10813 Grade 3 to 4 neutropenia occurred in 25.5% of patients in the abemaciclib group and 1.7% of patients in the placebo group. Febrile neutropenia was reported in six patients in the abemaciclib arm. </li>

10814</ul>

10815</div>

10816</li>

10817</ol>

10818</div>

10819</li>

10820</ol>

10821</div>

10822</section>

10823<section id="_2119">

10824<h5 id="_2119_toc">

10825Single-agent CDK inhibitor therapy</h5>

10826<p id="_2120" tabindex="-1">

10827Evidence (single-agent CDK inhibitor therapy):</p>

10828<div class="pdq-content-list">

10829<ol id="_2121">

10830<li>

10831Single-agent abemaciclib was approved by the FDA for use in hormone receptor&#8211;positive HER2-negative breast cancer with disease progression on or after endocrine therapy and chemotherapy on the basis of results of the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02102490">

10832MONARCH 1</a>

10833 trial (NCT02102490).[<a href="#cit/section_7.24">

1083424</a>

10835] Abemaciclib is the only CDK4/6 inhibitor approved as a single agent. MONARCH 1 was a single-arm phase II study of single-agent abemaciclib in 132 women with hormone receptor&#8211;positive and HER2-negative advanced breast cancer that had progressed on at least one line of previous endocrine therapy and at least two lines of previous chemotherapy. The study population was heavily pretreated, and most participants had visceral disease. Patients who had previous CDK inhibitors were excluded.<div class="pdq-content-list">

10836<ul id="_2122">

10837<li>

10838 The primary end point, investigator-assessed objective response rate, was 19.7% at 12 months (95% CI, 13.3%&#8211;27.5%). </li>

10839<li>

10840 The clinical benefit rate was 42.4%. </li>

10841<li>

10842 Median PFS was 6.0 months (95% CI, 4.2&#8211;7.5). </li>

10843<li>

10844 The most common adverse event was diarrhea, which occurred in 90.2% of the participants. However, the majority was grade 1 to 2, and only 19.7% of participants experienced grade 3 diarrhea. There was no grade 4 diarrhea. </li>

10845<li>

10846Neutropenia occurred in 97.7% of participants; however, the majority was grade 1 to 2, and only 26.9% of participants experienced grade 3 to 4 neutropenia.</li>

10847</ul>

10848</div>

10849</li>

10850</ol>

10851</div>

10852</section>

10853</section>

10854<section id="_1477">

10855<h4 id="_1477_toc">

10856Mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) inhibitor therapy plus endocrine therapy</h4>

10857<p id="_1478" tabindex="-1">

10858Preclinical models and clinical studies suggest that mTOR inhibitors might overcome endocrine resistance. </p>

10859<p id="_1479" tabindex="-1">

10860Evidence (mTOR inhibitor therapy):</p>

10861<div class="pdq-content-list">

10862<ol id="_1480">

10863<li>

10864The Breast Cancer Trial of Oral Everolimus (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00863655">

10865BOLERO-2</a>

10866 [NCT00863655]) was a randomized, phase III, placebo-controlled trial in which patients with hormone receptor&#8211;positive metastatic breast cancer that is resistant to nonsteroidal aromatase inhibition were randomly assigned to receive either the mTOR inhibitor everolimus plus exemestane, or placebo plus exemestane.[<a href="#cit/section_7.25">

1086725</a>

10868][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10869Level of evidence B1</a>

10870]<div class="pdq-content-list">

10871<ul id="_1481">

10872<li>

10873At the interim analysis, median PFS was 6.9 months for everolimus plus exemestane and 2.8 months for placebo plus exemestane (HR, 0.43; 95% CI, 0.35&#8211;0.54; <em>

10874P</em>

10875 &lt; .001).</li>

10876<li>

10877The addition of everolimus to exemestane was more toxic than was placebo plus exemestane, with the most-common grade 3 or 4 adverse events being stomatitis (8% vs. 1%), anemia (6% vs. &lt;1%), dyspnea (4% vs. 1%), hyperglycemia (4% vs. &lt;1%), fatigue (4% vs. 1%), and pneumonitis (3% vs. 0%).</li>

10878<li>

10879OS differences were not significant after further follow-up.[<a href="#cit/section_7.26">

1088026</a>

10881]</li>

10882</ul>

10883</div>

10884</li>

10885<li>

10886<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01298713">

10887TAMRAD</a>

10888 (NCT01298713) was an open-label, randomized, phase II trial comparing tamoxifen with tamoxifen plus everolimus in postmenopausal women whose disease had progressed after receiving an AI in the adjuvant or metastatic setting. The trial randomly assigned 57 women to receive tamoxifen and 54 women to receive the combination therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_7.27">

1088927</a>

10890]<div class="pdq-content-list">

10891<ul id="_2123">

10892<li>

10893Median time to progression was 8.6 months in the combination group and 4.5 months in the tamoxifen group (HR, 0.54; 95% CI, 0.56&#8722;0.81; <em>

10894P</em>

10895 = .002).</li>

10896<li>

10897 Toxicities were greater on the everolimus arm and similar to those in the BOLERO2 trial.</li>

10898<li>

10899 In an exploratory analysis, OS was 32.9 months in the tamoxifen group and not reached in the combination group (HR, 0.45; 95% CI, 0.24&#8722;0.81; <em>

10900P</em>

10901 = .007).[<a href="#cit/section_7.27">

1090227</a>

10903][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10904Level of evidence A1</a>

10905]</li>

10906</ul>

10907</div>

10908</li>

10909<li>

10910<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01797120">

10911PrE0102</a>

10912 (NCT01797120) was a double-blind, randomized, phase II trial comparing fulvestrant with fulvestrant plus everolimus in postmenopausal women whose disease had progressed after receiving an AI in the adjuvant or metastatic setting. Sixty-six women were randomly assigned to the combination arm and 65 to fulvestrant alone.[<a href="#cit/section_7.28">

1091328</a>

10914]<div class="pdq-content-list">

10915<ul id="_2124">

10916<li>

10917 Median PFS was 10.3 months on the combination arm and 5.1 months on the fulvestrant-alone arm (HR, 0.61; 95% CI, 0.40&#8722;0.92; <em>

10918P</em>

10919 = .02).[<a href="#cit/section_7.28">

1092028</a>

10921][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10922Level of evidence B1</a>

10923]</li>

10924<li>

10925 Toxicities were similar to those in previous studies.</li>

10926<li>

10927 The was no observed difference in OS between the arms.</li>

10928</ul>

10929</div>

10930</li>

10931<li>

10932The single-arm <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02069093">

10933SWISH</a>

10934 trial (NCT02069093) assessed the efficacy of a dexamethasone oral solution (0.5 mg per 5 mL) in the prevention of stomatitis in women receiving exemestane plus everolimus.[<a href="#cit/section_7.29">

1093529</a>

10936] The incidence of grade 2 or worse stomatitis was 2% in the 85 evaluable patients in this study compared with 33% in the BOLERO-2 trial. </li>

10937</ol>

10938</div>

10939</section>

10940<section id="_2161">

10941<h4 id="_2161_toc">

10942Alpelisib plus endocrine therapy</h4>

10943<p id="_2162" tabindex="-1">

10944Activating mutations in <em class="gene-name">

10945PIK3CA</em>

10946 are identified in approximately 40% of hormone receptor&#8211;positive and HER2-negative breast cancers. Alpelisib is an alpha-specific PI3K inhibitor.</p>

10947<p id="_2163" tabindex="-1">

10948Evidence (alpelisib plus endocrine therapy):</p>

10949<div class="pdq-content-list">

10950<ol id="_2164">

10951<li>

10952<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02437318">

10953SOLAR-1</a>

10954 (NCT02437318) was a randomized phase III trial comparing alpelisib plus fulvestrant with placebo plus fulvestrant. The trial included 572 postmenopausal women with hormone receptor&#8211;positive and HER2-negative advanced breast cancer who had received previous endocrine therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_7.30">

1095530</a>

10956][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10957Level of evidence B1</a>

10958] <p id="_2165" tabindex="-1">

10959<em class="gene-name">

10960PIK3CA</em>

10961 mutations were confirmed in 341 participants. The primary end point was PFS in the cohort of patients with <em class="gene-name">

10962PIK3CA</em>

10963 mutations. </p>

10964<div class="pdq-content-list">

10965<ul id="_2166">

10966<li>

10967In this cohort, median PFS was 11 months in the alpelisib-plus-fulvestrant arm compared with 5.7 months in the placebo-plus-fulvestrant arm (HR<sub>

10968progression</sub>

10969 or HR<sub>

10970death</sub>

10971, 0.65; 95% CI, 0.50&#8722;0.85; <em>

10972P</em>

10973 &lt; .001).</li>

10974<li>

10975 PFS did not differ between arms in the cohort of participants without <em class="gene-name">

10976PIK3CA</em>

10977 mutations (median PFS, 7.4 months in the alpelisib-plus-fulvestrant arm vs. 5.6 months in the placebo-plus-fulvestrant arm).</li>

10978<li>

10979 OS in the cohort with <em class="gene-name">

10980PIK3CA</em>

10981 mutations was a secondary end point. OS data are not yet mature. </li>

10982<li>

10983 Very few study participants had received previous CDK4/6 inhibitor therapy.</li>

10984<li>

10985 Common toxicities associated with alpelisib included hyperglycemia, diarrhea, nausea, anorexia, and rash. Careful monitoring and management of hyperglycemia are required during alpelisib use.</li>

10986</ul>

10987</div>

10988<p id="_2551" tabindex="-1">

10989The FDA approved alpelisib for use in combination with fulvestrant in advanced <em class="gene-name">

10990PIK3CA</em>

10991-mutated, hormone receptor&#8211;positive, HER2-negative breast cancer after previous endocrine therapy.</p>

10992</li>

10993</ol>

10994</div>

10995</section>

10996<section id="_2575">

10997<h4 id="_2575_toc">

10998Elacestrant</h4>

10999<p id="_2576" tabindex="-1">

11000Elacestrant is an oral selective ER degrader (SERD). It degrades ER alpha in a dose-dependent manner and inhibits estradiol-dependent ER-directed gene transcription and tumor growth, including in cells harboring <em class="gene-name">

11001ESR1</em>

11002 mutations. Mutations in <em class="gene-name">

11003ESR1</em>

11004 result in estrogen-independent ER activation and, consequently, resistance to AIs, but not necessarily to SERDs and selective ER modulators. </p>

11005<p id="_2577" tabindex="-1">

11006Evidence (elacestrant):

11007

11008</p>

11009<div class="pdq-content-list">

11010<ol id="_2578">

11011<li>

11012A randomized, open-label, phase III trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03778931">

11013EMERALD</a>

11014 [NCT03778931]) enrolled patients with ER-positive HER2-negative metastatic breast cancer. Eligible patients had previously received one or two lines of endocrine therapy, a CDK4/6 inhibitor, and no more than one line of chemotherapy. A total of 477 patients were randomly assigned in a 1:1 ratio to receive either elacestrant 400 mg orally once daily or standard-of-care endocrine monotherapy. Primary end points were PFS by blinded independent central review in all patients and in patients with detectable <em class="gene-name">

11015ESR1</em>

11016 mutations. An <em class="gene-name">

11017ESR1</em>

11018 mutation was detected in 47.8% of patients, and 43.4% of patients had received two prior endocrine therapies. Twenty-nine percent of patients in the elacestrant arm and 31% of patients in the standard-of-care arm had received prior fulvestrant therapy. Less than 5% of patients in either arm had received prior mTOR inhibitor therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_7.31">

1101931</a>

11020]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11021<ul id="_2579">

11022<li>

11023 PFS was prolonged in the elacestrant arm in all patients (HR, 0.70; 95% CI, 0.55&#8211;0.88; <em>

11024P</em>

11025 = .002) and in elacestrant-treated patients with <em class="gene-name">

11026ESR1</em>

11027 mutations (HR, 0.55; 95% CI, 0.39&#8211;0.77; <em>

11028P</em>

11029 = .0005). Among all patients, 6-month PFS rates were 34.3% for patients in the elacestrant arm and 20.4% for patients in the standard-of-care arm. Among patients with <em class="gene-name">

11030ESR1</em>

11031 mutations, 6-month PFS rates were 40.8% for patients in the elacestrant arm and 19.1% for patients in the standard-of-care arm. Similarly, for all patients, 12-month PFS rates were 22.3% for patients in the elacestrant arm and 9.4% for patients in the standard-of-care arm. For patients with <em class="gene-name">

11032ESR1</em>

11033 mutations, 12-month PFS rates were 26.8% for patients in the elacestrant arm and 8.2% for patients in the standard-of-care arm.[<a href="#cit/section_7.31">

1103431</a>

11035][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11036Level of evidence B1</a>

11037]</li>

11038<li>

11039 The most common adverse events observed with elacestrant versus standard-of-care therapy included nausea (35.0% vs. 18.8%), fatigue (19.0% vs. 18.8%), vomiting (19.0% vs. 8.3%), decreased appetite (14.8% vs. 9.2%), and arthralgia (14.3% vs. 16.2%). Grade 3 or 4 adverse events occurred in 64 patients (27.0%) who received elacestrant and 47 patients (20.5%) who received standard-of-care therapy. The most common grade 3 or 4 adverse events in the elacestrant arm were nausea (six patients, 2.5%), back pain (six patients, 2.5%), and increased alanine aminotransferase (five patients, 2.1%). The most common grade 3 or 4 adverse events in the standard-of-care arm were nausea, fatigue, diarrhea, and increased aspartate aminotransferase (each occurring in two patients, 0.9%). Adverse events led to treatment discontinuation in 15 patients (6.3%) in the elacestrant arm and 10 patients (4.4%) in the standard-of-care arm. </li>

11040</ul>

11041</div>

11042</li>

11043</ol>

11044</div>

11045</section>

11046<section id="_2518">

11047<h4 id="_2518_toc">

11048AKT inhibitor therapy</h4>

11049<p id="_2519" tabindex="-1">

11050<em class="gene-name">

11051AKT1</em>

11052-activating mutations are found in 5% to 10% of advanced breast cancers. AKT is downstream from both PI3K and PTEN in the PI3K/AKT/PTEN pathway. Capivasertib is a selective inhibitor of all three AKT isoforms (AKT1, AKT2, and AKT3).</p>

11053<section id="_2552">

11054<h5 id="_2552_toc">

11055Capivasertib</h5>

11056<p id="_2553" tabindex="-1">

11057Evidence (capivasertib):</p>

11058<div class="pdq-content-list">

11059<ol id="_2554">

11060<li>

11061The multicenter, double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase II <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01992952">

11062FAKTION</a>

11063 trial (NCT01992952) randomly assigned 140 postmenopausal women with metastatic breast cancer to receive fulvestrant with either capivasertib or placebo. No enrollees had received prior therapy with a CDK inhibitor.[<a href="#cit/section_7.32">

1106432</a>

11065][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11066Level of evidence A1</a>

11067]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11068<ul id="_2555">

11069<li>

11070 The primary end point was PFS in the intention-to-treat (ITT) population. The median follow-up was 58.5 months for patients who received fulvestrant plus capivasertib and 62.3 months for patients who received fulvestrant plus placebo. The updated median PFS was 10.3 months in the fulvestrant-plus-capivasertib group and 4.8 months in the fulvestrant-plus-placebo group (two-sided <em>

11071P</em>

11072 = .0023).</li>

11073<li>

11074 Secondary end points were OS and safety in the ITT population, as well as the effect of tumor PI3K/AKT/PTEN pathway status. The median OS was 29.3 months in the capivasertib group and 23.4 months in the placebo group (adjusted HR, 0.66; 95% CI, 0.45&#8211;0.97; two-sided <em>

11075P</em>

11076 = .035). </li>

11077<li>

11078 An expanded biomarker panel identified an expanded pathway&#8211;altered subgroup of 76 participants (54% of the ITT population). The median PFS in the expanded pathway&#8211;altered subgroup was 12.8 months for patients who received capivasertib (n = 39) and 4.6 months for patients who received placebo (n = 37) (adjusted HR, 0.44; 95% CI, 0.26&#8211;0.72; two-sided <em>

11079P</em>

11080 = .0014). The median OS for the expanded pathway&#8211;altered subgroup who received capivasertib was 38.9 months compared with 20.0 months for patients who received placebo (adjusted HR, 0.46; 95% CI, 0.27&#8211;0.79; two-sided <em>

11081P</em>

11082 = .0047). There were no statistically significant differences in the PFS or OS of patients in the expanded pathway&#8211;nonaltered subgroups who received capivasertib (n = 30) or placebo (n = 34).</li>

11083</ul>

11084</div>

11085</li>

11086</ol>

11087</div>

11088<p id="_2556" tabindex="-1">

11089The FDA has not approved capivasertib.</p>

11090</section>

11091</section>

11092<section id="_2524">

11093<h4 id="_2524_toc">

11094HDAC inhibitor therapy</h4>

11095<p id="_2525" tabindex="-1">

11096Epigenetic modification alters gene expression. This can lead to endocrine therapy resistance and may be reversed by epigenetic modifiers such as histone deacetylase (HDAC) inhibitors. Entinostat, an oral HDAC inhibitor, induces downregulation of estrogen-independent growth factor signaling pathways and normalization of estrogen receptor levels. Entinostat was evaluated in a phase III trial and showed no benefit.[<a href="#cit/section_7.33">

1109733</a>

11098,<a href="#cit/section_7.34">

1109934</a>

11100]</p>

11101</section>

11102<section id="_2189">

11103<h4 id="_2189_toc">

11104Endocrine therapy alone</h4>

11105<p id="_2190" tabindex="-1">

11106With the PFS and OS advantages associated with combination therapy with targeted agents and endocrine therapy as discussed above, single-agent endocrine therapy is less frequently used, especially in the first-line setting. However, its use remains appropriate in select cases as first-line therapy and in later-line therapy after progression on targeted therapies and before the use of chemotherapy in cases in which endocrine-sensitive disease is still thought to be present. </p>

11107<p id="_2191" tabindex="-1">

11108Commonly used single-agent endocrine therapies include tamoxifen, nonsteroidal AI (letrozole, anastrozole), the steroidal AI exemestane, and fulvestrant. In general, premenopausal women with metastatic breast cancer undergo ovarian suppression or ablation and are treated in the same manner as postmenopausal women.</p>

11109<section id="_2192">

11110<h5 id="_2192_toc">

11111Tamoxifen and AI therapy</h5>

11112<p id="_2193" tabindex="-1">

11113While tamoxifen has been used

11114for many years in treating postmenopausal women with newly metastatic disease that is ER positive, PR positive, or ER/PR unknown, several randomized trials suggest equivalent or superior response rates and PFS for the AI compared with tamoxifen.[<a href="#cit/section_7.35">

1111535</a>

11116-<a href="#cit/section_7.37">

1111737</a>

11118][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11119Level of evidence B1</a>

11120]</p>

11121<p id="_2194" tabindex="-1">

11122Evidence (tamoxifen and AI therapy):</p>

11123<div class="pdq-content-list">

11124<ol id="_2195">

11125<li>

11126A meta-analysis evaluated patients with metastatic disease who were randomly assigned to receive either an AI as their first or second hormone therapy, or standard therapy (tamoxifen or a progestational agent).[<a href="#cit/section_7.38">

1112738</a>

11128][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11129Level of evidence A1</a>

11130]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11131<ul id="_2196">

11132<li>

11133Patients who received an AI as either their first or second hormone therapy for metastatic disease and were randomly assigned to receive a third-generation drug (anastrozole, letrozole, exemestane, or vorozole) lived longer (HR<sub>

11134death</sub>

11135, 0.87; 95% CI, 0.82&#8211;0.93) than those who received standard therapy (tamoxifen or a progestational agent).</li>

11136</ul>

11137</div>

11138</li>

11139</ol>

11140</div>

11141</section>

11142<section id="_2197">

11143<h5 id="_2197_toc">

11144Fulvestrant</h5>

11145<p id="_2198" tabindex="-1">

11146Fulvestrant is a selective estrogen receptor degrader that has been studied in the first-line and second-line setting in women with advanced or metastatic breast cancer.</p>

11147<section id="_2199">

11148<h6 id="_2199_toc">

11149First-line fulvestrant</h6>

11150<p id="_2200" tabindex="-1">

11151Evidence (first-line fulvestrant):</p>

11152<div class="pdq-content-list">

11153<ol id="_2201">

11154<li>

11155<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01602380">

11156FALCON</a>

11157 (NCT01602380) was a phase III, double-blind, randomized trial that compared fulvestrant (500 mg) with anastrozole (1 mg) in patients with advanced or metastatic receptor-positive breast cancer who had not received previous endocrine therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_7.39">

1115839</a>

11159] The trial randomly assigned 230 patients to receive fulvestrant and 232 patients to receive anastrozole.<div class="pdq-content-list">

11160<ul id="_2202">

11161<li>

11162Median PFS was 16.6 months in the fulvestrant group and 13.8 months in the anastrozole group (HR, 0.797; 95% CI, 0.637&#8722;0.999; <em>

11163P</em>

11164 = .049).[<a href="#cit/section_7.39">

1116539</a>

11166][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11167Level of evidence B1</a>

11168]</li>

11169<li>

11170 The frequency of adverse events was similar in the two groups, and there was no difference in quality of life.</li>

11171<li>

11172 OS results were not reported.</li>

11173</ul>

11174</div>

11175</li>

11176</ol>

11177</div>

11178</section>

11179<section id="_2203">

11180<h6 id="_2203_toc">

11181Second-line fulvestrant</h6>

11182<p id="_2204" tabindex="-1">

11183Evidence (second-line fulvestrant):</p>

11184<div class="pdq-content-list">

11185<ol id="_2205">

11186<li>

11187Two randomized trials that enrolled 400 and 451

11188patients whose disease had progressed after they received tamoxifen demonstrated that

11189fulvestrant yielded results similar to those of anastrozole in terms of its impact on PFS.[<a href="#cit/section_7.40">

1119040</a>

11191,<a href="#cit/section_7.41">

1119241</a>

11193] The proper sequence of these therapies is not known.[<a href="#cit/section_7.42">

1119442</a>

11195,<a href="#cit/section_7.43">

1119643</a>

11197]</li>

11198<li>

11199<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00065325">

11200EFECT</a>

11201 (NCT00065325) was a phase III, double-blind, randomized trial that compared fulvestrant given in a loading-dose regimen (500 mg day 0, 250 mg days 14 and 28, and 250 mg every 28 days thereafter) with exemestane (25 mg) in women who had developed progressive disease after previous nonsteroidal AI (anastrozole or letrozole) therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_7.44">

1120244</a>

11203] The trial randomly assigned 351 women to receive fulvestrant and 342 women to receive exemestane.<div class="pdq-content-list">

11204<ul id="_2206">

11205<li>

11206 Median time to progression was 3.7 months in both groups (HR, 0.93; 95% CI, 0.819&#8722;1.133; <em>

11207P</em>

11208 = .65).[<a href="#cit/section_7.44">

1120944</a>

11210][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11211Level of evidence B1</a>

11212]</li>

11213<li>

11214 The frequency of adverse events was similar in both groups, and there was no difference in quality of life.</li>

11215<li>

11216 OS results were not reported.</li>

11217</ul>

11218</div>

11219</li>

11220<li>

11221<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00099437">

11222CONFIRM</a>

11223 (NCT00099437) was a double-blind phase III trial that compared two doses of fulvestrant (500 mg vs. 250 mg, each given in a loading-dose schedule) in 736 women whose disease had progressed on previous endocrine therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_7.45">

1122445</a>

11225]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11226<ul id="_2207">

11227<li>

11228 PFS was significantly better on the higher-dose arm (HR, 0.80; 95% CI, 0.68&#8211;0.94; <em>

11229P</em>

11230 = .006).[<a href="#cit/section_7.45">

1123145</a>

11232][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11233Level of evidence B1</a>

11234]</li>

11235<li>

11236 Adverse events and quality of life were similar on the two arms.</li>

11237</ul>

11238</div>

11239</li>

11240</ol>

11241</div>

11242</section>

11243</section>

11244<section id="_2208">

11245<h5 id="_2208_toc">

11246Combination endocrine therapy with an AI and fulvestrant</h5>

11247<p id="_2209" tabindex="-1">

11248Conflicting results were found in two trials that compared the combination of the antiestrogen fulvestrant and anastrozole with anastrozole alone in the first-line treatment of hormone receptor&#8211;positive postmenopausal patients with recurrent or metastatic disease. For more information, see the <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_2197">

11249Fulvestrant</a>

11250 section.[<a href="#cit/section_7.46">

1125146</a>

11252,<a href="#cit/section_7.47">

1125347</a>

11254] In both studies, fulvestrant was administered as a 500-mg loading dose on day 1; 250 mg was administered on days 15 and 29, and monthly thereafter; plus, 1 mg of anastrozole was administered daily. The Southwest Oncology Group (SWOG) trial included more patients who presented with metastatic disease; the Fulvestrant and Anastrozole Combination Therapy (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00256698">

11255FACT</a>

11256 [NCT00256698]) study enrolled more patients who had previously received tamoxifen.[<a href="#cit/section_7.46">

1125746</a>

11258,<a href="#cit/section_7.47">

1125947</a>

11260]</p>

11261<p id="_2210" tabindex="-1">

11262Evidence (combination endocrine therapy with an AI and fulvestrant):</p>

11263<div class="pdq-content-list">

11264<ol id="_2211">

11265<li>

11266The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00075764">

11267SWOG-0226</a>

11268 trial (NCT00075764), which enrolled 707 patients, demonstrated a statistically significant difference in PFS (HR, 0.80; 95% CI, 0.68&#8211;0.94; <em>

11269P</em>

11270 = .007) and OS (HR, 0.81; 95% CI, 0.65&#8211;1.00; <em>

11271P</em>

11272 = .05).[<a href="#cit/section_7.46">

1127346</a>

11274][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11275Level of evidence A1</a>

11276]</li>

11277<li>

11278In an analysis done after 5 more years of follow-up, the observed benefits of combined therapy were still present, and the level of significance with respect to OS was greater (HR, 0.82; 95% CI, 0.69&#8211;0.98; <em>

11279P</em>

11280 = .03).[<a href="#cit/section_7.48">

1128148</a>

11282][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11283Level of evidence A1</a>

11284]</li>

11285<li>

11286In contrast, the FACT trial , which enrolled 514 patients, found no difference in either disease-free survival (DFS) (HR, 0.99; 95% CI, 0.81&#8211;1.20; <em>

11287P</em>

11288 = .91) or OS (HR, 1.0; 95% CI, 0.76&#8211;1.32; <em>

11289P</em>

11290 = 1.00).[<a href="#cit/section_7.47">

1129147</a>

11292][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11293Level of evidence A1</a>

11294]</li>

11295</ol>

11296</div>

11297</section>

11298</section>

11299<section id="_2580">

11300<h4 id="_2580_toc">

11301Sequencing therapy for hormone receptor&#8211;positive metastatic breast cancer</h4>

11302<p id="_2581" tabindex="-1">

11303The optimal sequence of therapies for hormone receptor&#8211;positive metastatic breast cancer is not known. In general, in the absence of a visceral crisis, most patients receive sequential endocrine-based regimens before transitioning to chemotherapy. On the basis of the PFS and OS improvements mentioned above, a combination of a CDK4/6 inhibitor therapy and endocrine therapy in the first line is an appropriate choice.</p>

11304<section id="_2582">

11305<h5 id="_2582_toc">

11306Poly (ADP-ribose) polymerase (PARP) inhibitor therapy</h5>

11307<p id="_2583" tabindex="-1">

11308Patients with hormone receptor-positive metastatic breast cancer and a germline <em class="gene-name">

11309BRCA</em>

11310 mutation are eligible for PARP inhibitor therapy. For more information, see the <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_1780">

11311Germline <em class="gene-name">

11312BRCA</em>

11313-Mutated Breast Cancer</a>

11314 section.</p>

11315</section>

11316</section>

11317<section id="_2526">

11318<h4 id="_2526_toc">

11319Sacituzumab govitecan</h4>

11320<p id="_2527" tabindex="-1">

11321Sacituzumab govitecan is an antibody-drug conjugate that combines an anti&#8211;trophoblast cell-surface antigen 2 (TROP2) antibody with an active metabolite of irinotecan (SN-38). TROP2 is a transmembrane calcium signal transducer highly expressed in ER-positive HER2-negative breast cancer. Internalization of TROP2&#8211;bound sacituzumab govitecan delivers SN-38 into the tumor cell through hydrolysis of the linker.[<a href="#cit/section_7.49">

1132249</a>

11323]</p>

11324<p id="_2528" tabindex="-1">

11325Evidence (sacituzumab govitecan):</p>

11326<div class="pdq-content-list">

11327<ol id="_2529">

11328<li>

11329 The global phase III <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03901339">

11330TROPiCS-02</a>

11331 trial (NCT03901339) randomly assigned 543 patients to receive either sacituzumab govitecan or physician&#8217;s choice chemotherapy (eribulin, vinorelbine, capecitabine, or gemcitabine). Patients had locally recurrent inoperable or metastatic breast cancer that was endocrine-resistant, chemotherapy-treated, hormone receptor&#8211;positive, and HER2-negative. Patients had received three median lines of chemotherapy for advanced disease, and 99% of patients had previously received a CDK4/6 inhibitor.[<a href="#cit/section_7.50">

1133250</a>

11333][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11334Level of evidence B1</a>

11335] <div class="pdq-content-list">

11336<ul id="_2530">

11337<li>

11338 The primary end point was PFS by blinded independent central review. An analysis noted a 34% reduction in the risk of progression or death (HR, 0.66; 95% CI, 0.53&#8211;0.83; <em>

11339P</em>

11340 = .0003). The median PFS was 5.5 months in the sacituzumab govitecan group and 4.0 months in the chemotherapy group. The PFS at 6 and 12 months was 46% and 21% for patients who received sacituzumab govitecan and 30% and 7% for patients who received chemotherapy. </li>

11341<li>

11342 Median OS data are not yet mature.</li>

11343<li>

11344 Key grade 3 or greater treatment-related adverse events were neutropenia (occurring in 51% of patients who received sacituzumab govitecan and 38% of patients who received chemotherapy) and diarrhea (occurring in 9% of patients who received sacituzumab govitecan and 1% of patients who received chemotherapy). One patient in the sacituzumab govitecan group died of a treatment-related adverse event (septic shock related to neutropenic colitis).</li>

11345<li>

11346 The objective response rate by blinded independent central review was 21% in the sacituzumab govitecan group and 14% in the chemotherapy group. The clinical benefit rate was higher with sacituzumab govitecan than with chemotherapy (34% vs. 22%).</li>

11347</ul>

11348</div>

11349</li>

11350</ol>

11351</div>

11352<p id="_2531" tabindex="-1">

11353The FDA has approved sacituzumab govitecan for patients with metastatic unresectable breast cancer, including patients with TNBC who have received at least two systemic therapies, including at least one for metastatic cancer. It is also approved in patients with hormone receptor&#8211;positive and HER2-negative breast cancer who have received hormone therapy and at least two systemic therapies for metastatic cancer. </p>

11354</section>

11355<section id="_2584">

11356<h4 id="_2584_toc">

11357Chemotherapy</h4>

11358<p id="_2585" tabindex="-1">
