11359Chemotherapy may be appropriate for patients with hormone receptor&#8211;positive HER2-negative breast cancer. For more information, see the <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_1520">

11360Chemotherapy for Metastatic Breast Cancer</a>

11361 section.</p>

11362</section>

11363</section>

11364<section id="_2432">

11365<h3 id="_2432_toc">

11366HER2/neu-Low Breast Cancer</h3>

11367<p id="_2433" tabindex="-1">

11368Sixty percent of HER2&#8211;negative metastatic breast cancers express low levels of HER2, defined as a score of 1+ on immunohistochemical (IHC) analysis or as an IHC score of 2+ and negative results on <em>

11369in situ</em>

11370 hybridization. These are referred to as HER2-low tumors. Historically, HER2-directed therapies have not improved outcomes in these patients. Early-phase trials of trastuzumab deruxtecan showed potential efficacy in this subgroup.[<a href="#cit/section_7.51">

1137151</a>

11372] A subsequent randomized phase III trial showed OS benefit in this subgroup.[<a href="#cit/section_7.52">

1137352</a>

11374] Trastuzumab deruxtecan is an antibody-drug conjugate consisting of a humanized anti-HER2 monoclonal antibody linked to a topoisomerase-I inhibitor payload through a cleavable linker. This agent offers bystander effect to surrounding HER2-low cells via uptake into HER2-amplified cells, intracellular cleavage of payload, and release of payload into the surrounding tumor.</p>

11375<p id="_2434" tabindex="-1">

11376Evidence (trastuzumab deruxtecan for hormone receptor&#8211;positive and negative HER2-low tumors): </p>

11377<div class="pdq-content-list">

11378<ol id="_2435">

11379<li>

11380 The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03734029">

11381DESTINY-Breast04</a>

11382 trial (NCT03734029) randomly assigned 557 women in a 2:1 ratio to receive either trastuzumab deruxtecan or the physician&#8217;s choice of chemotherapy (capecitabine, eribulin, gemcitabine, paclitaxel, or nab-paclitaxel). Patients had received one or two prior lines of chemotherapy. The primary end point was PFS in the hormone receptor&#8211;positive group (88.7% of patients). The secondary end points were PFS in the total population, OS in the total population, and OS in the hormone receptor&#8211;positive group.[<a href="#cit/section_7.52">

1138352</a>

11384]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11385<ul id="_2436">

11386<li>

11387 In the hormone receptor&#8211;positive cohort, the median PFS was 10.1 months for patients who received trastuzumab deruxtecan and 5.4 months for patients who received the physician&#8217;s choice of chemotherapy (HR<sub>

11388disease progression or death</sub>

11389, 0.51; <em>

11390P</em>

11391 &lt; .001). The OS was 23.9 months for patients who received trastuzumab deruxtecan and 17.5 months for patients who received the physician's choice of chemotherapy (HR<sub>

11392death</sub>

11393, 0.64; <em>

11394P</em>

11395 = .003). </li>

11396<li>

11397 Among all patients, the median PFS was 9.9 months in the trastuzumab deruxtecan group and 5.1 months in the physician&#8217;s choice group (HR<sub>

11398disease progression or death</sub>

11399, 0.50; <em>

11400P</em>

11401 &lt; .001). The OS was 23.4 months in the trastuzumab deruxtecan group and 16.8 months in the physician's choice group (HR<sub>

11402death</sub>

11403, 0.64; <em>

11404P</em>

11405 = .001).</li>

11406<li>

11407 Drug-related interstitial lung disease or pneumonitis occurred in 12.1% of the patients who received trastuzumab deruxtecan; 0.8% had grade 5 events.</li>

11408</ul>

11409</div>

11410</li>

11411</ol>

11412</div>

11413</section>

11414<section id="_1489">

11415<h3 id="_1489_toc">

11416Triple-Negative Breast Cancer</h3>

11417<section id="_2476">

11418<h4 id="_2476_toc">

11419Chemotherapy plus immunotherapy</h4>

11420<p id="_2477" tabindex="-1">

11421The standard-of-care treatment for first-line metastatic TNBC with a programmed death-ligand 1 (PD-L1) combined positive score (CPS) of 10 or more is chemotherapy plus pembrolizumab. This was evaluated in the KEYNOTE-355 trial.[<a href="#cit/section_7.53">

1142253</a>

11423,<a href="#cit/section_7.54">

1142454</a>

11425]</p>

11426<section id="_2478">

11427<h5 id="_2478_toc">

11428Pembrolizumab</h5>

11429<p id="_2479" tabindex="-1">

11430The phase III, randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind, multinational <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02819518">

11431KEYNOTE-355</a>

11432 trial (NCT02819518) evaluated the addition of pembrolizumab to first-line chemotherapy in patients with metastatic TNBC. This combination was approved for use in this patient population as a result of the trial.[<a href="#cit/section_7.53">

1143353</a>

11434,<a href="#cit/section_7.54">

1143554</a>

11436]</p>

11437<p id="_2480" tabindex="-1">

11438Evidence (pembrolizumab):</p>

11439<div class="pdq-content-list">

11440<ol id="_2481">

11441<li>

11442Patients were randomly assigned in a 2:1 ratio to receive either pembrolizumab (200 mg every 3 weeks) and chemotherapy (nab-paclitaxel, paclitaxel, or gemcitabine plus carboplatin) or placebo and chemotherapy. Randomization was stratified by the type of on-study chemotherapy (taxane or gemcitabine/carboplatin), PD-L1 expression at baseline (CPS &#8805;1 or &lt;1), and previous treatment with the same class of chemotherapy in the neoadjuvant or adjuvant setting (yes or no). Dual primary efficacy end points were PFS and OS assessed in the PD-L1 CPS of 10 or more, PD-L1 CPS of 1 or more, and ITT populations. Of the 847 patients assigned to treatment, 566 patients received pembrolizumab and chemotherapy and 281 patients received placebo and chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_7.53">

1144353</a>

11444,<a href="#cit/section_7.54">

1144554</a>

11446]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11447<ul id="_2482">

11448<li>

11449At the second interim analysis, the median follow-up was 25.9 months in the pembrolizumab-and-chemotherapy group and 26.3 months in the placebo-and-chemotherapy group. Among patients with CPS of 10 or more, the median PFS was 9.7 months with pembrolizumab and chemotherapy and 5.6 months with placebo and chemotherapy (HR<sub>

11450progression or death</sub>

11451, 0.65; 95% CI, 0.49&#8211;0.86; one-sided <em>

11452P</em>

11453 = .0012 [primary objective met]). Among patients with CPS of 1 or more, the median PFS was 7.6 months with pembrolizumab and chemotherapy and 5.6 months with placebo and chemotherapy (HR, 0.74; 0.61&#8211;0.90; one-sided <em>

11454P</em>

11455 = .0014 [not significant]). Among the ITT population, the median PFS was 7.5 months and 5.6 months (HR, 0.82; 0.69&#8211;0.97 [not tested]). The pembrolizumab treatment effect increased with PD-L1 enrichment.</li>

11456<li>

11457Based on the PFS data, the FDA approved pembrolizumab and chemotherapy for the treatment of patients with locally recurrent unresectable or metastatic TNBC whose tumors express PD-L1 (CPS &#8805;10). </li>

11458<li>

11459At time of final analysis, the median follow-up was 44.1 months. In the group with a CPS of at least 10, the median OS was 23 months in the pembrolizumab-and-chemotherapy group and 16.1 months in the placebo-and-chemotherapy group (HR, 0.73; 95% CI, 0.55&#8211;0.95; two-sided <em>

11460P</em>

11461 = .0185 [significant]). In the group with a CPS of at least 1, the median survival was not significantly altered (17.6 vs. 16 months; <em>

11462P</em>

11463 = .1125).</li>

11464<li>

11465Grade 3 to 5 treatment-related adverse events occurred in 68.1% of patients in the pembrolizumab group and 66.9% of patients in the placebo group. Two deaths occurred in the pembrolizumab group (acute kidney injury and pneumonia). There were no deaths in the placebo group. Grade 3 to 4 immune-mediated adverse events occurred in 5.3% of patients in the pembrolizumab group, none of which led to death.</li>

11466</ul>

11467</div>

11468</li>

11469</ol>

11470</div>

11471</section>

11472<section id="_2483">

11473<h5 id="_2483_toc">

11474Atezolizumab</h5>

11475<p id="_2484" tabindex="-1">

11476The addition of atezolizumab, a PD-L1&#8211;positive antibody, to first-line chemotherapy for patients with hormone receptor&#8211;negative and HER2-negative advanced breast cancer was evaluated in the phase III, randomized, placebo-controlled <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02425891">

11477IMpassion130</a>

11478 trial (NCT02425891).[<a href="#cit/section_7.55">

1147955</a>

11480,<a href="#cit/section_7.56">

1148156</a>

11482] Participants (N = 902) were randomly assigned 1:1 to atezolizumab plus nanoparticle albumin-bound (nab)-paclitaxel or to placebo plus nab-paclitaxel. Participants were stratified according to the presence of liver metastases (yes/no), receipt of previous taxane therapy (yes/no), and PD-L1 status (positive or negative). PD-L1 expression of 1% or greater was defined as positive. Co-primary end points included PFS and OS, both of which were evaluated in the ITT population and in the PD-L1&#8211;positive population (n = 369).</p>

11483<p id="_2485" tabindex="-1">

11484Based on the initial publication of PFS data from IMPassion130, the FDA granted accelerated approval for the use of atezolizumab in combination with protein-bound paclitaxel for patients with unresectable locally advanced or metastatic TNBC whose tumors express PD-L1. However, a 2021 final analysis revealed no OS benefit in the ITT population.[<a href="#cit/section_7.55">

1148555</a>

11486,<a href="#cit/section_7.56">

1148756</a>

11488]</p>

11489<p id="_2486" tabindex="-1">

11490<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03125902">

11491IMpassion131</a>

11492 (NCT03125902) was a phase III, randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind trial of first-line paclitaxel with or without atezolizumab for patients with unresectable locally advanced or metastatic TNBC. The study included 651 patients, 45% of whom had PD-L1&#8211;positive TNBC. This trial also did not demonstrate a benefit from the addition of atezolizumab to paclitaxel in this population.[<a href="#cit/section_7.57">

1149357</a>

11494] Accordingly, the sponsor voluntarily withdrew this approval.</p>

11495<div class="pdq-content-list">

11496<ol id="_2487">

11497<li>

11498IMpassion130 reported PFS data with a median follow-up of 12.9 months.[<a href="#cit/section_7.55">

1149955</a>

11500]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11501<ul id="_2488">

11502<li>

11503In the ITT population, PFS was improved with the addition of atezolizumab (median PFS, 7.2 months vs. 5.5 months; HR, 0.80; 95% CI, 0.69&#8211;0.92; <em>

11504P</em>

11505 = .0025).</li>

11506<li>

11507In the PD-L1&#8211;positive population, PFS was improved with the addition of atezolizumab (median PFS, 7.5 months vs. 5 months; HR, 0.62; 95% CI, 0.49&#8211;0.78; <em>

11508P</em>

11509 &lt; .001).</li>

11510<li>

11511Adverse events occurred as expected. Adverse events that were potentially immune-related were more frequent in the atezolizumab arm.</li>

11512</ul>

11513</div>

11514</li>

11515<li>

11516 The primary PFS analysis from IMpassion131 revealed that adding atezolizumab to paclitaxel did not improve investigator-assessed PFS in the PD-L1&#8211;positive population. The median PFS was 6.0 months for patients who received atezolizumab and paclitaxel compared with 5.7 months for patients who received placebo and paclitaxel (HR, 0.82; 95% CI, 0.60&#8211;1.12; <em>

11517P</em>

11518 = .20).[<a href="#cit/section_7.57">

1151957</a>

11520]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11521<ul id="_2489">

11522<li>

11523 The final OS results showed no difference between the treatment arms. The median OS was 22.1 months for patients who received atezolizumab and paclitaxel compared with 28.3 months for patients who received placebo and paclitaxel in the PD-L1&#8211;positive population (HR, 1.11; 95% CI, 0.76&#8211;1.64). </li>

11524<li>

11525 Results in the ITT population were consistent with the PD-L1&#8211;positive population. The safety profile was consistent with known effects of each study drug.</li>

11526</ul>

11527</div>

11528</li>

11529</ol>

11530</div>

11531</section>

11532</section>

11533<section id="_2490">

11534<h4 id="_2490_toc">

11535Sacituzumab govitecan</h4>

11536<p id="_2491" tabindex="-1">

11537Sacituzumab govitecan is an antibody-drug conjugate that combines an anti&#8211;trophoblast cell-surface antigen 2 (TROP2) antibody with an active metabolite of irinotecan (SN-38). TROP2 is a transmembrane calcium signal transducer highly expressed in TNBC. Internalization of TROP2&#8211;bound sacituzumab govitecan delivers SN-38 into the tumor cell through hydrolysis of the linker.[<a href="#cit/section_7.49">

1153849</a>

11539].</p>

11540<p id="_2492" tabindex="-1">

11541Evidence (sacituzumab govitecan):</p>

11542<div class="pdq-content-list">

11543<ol id="_2493">

11544<li>

11545In a phase I/II trial, 108 women with TNBC who received at least two previous chemotherapy regimens (median, three) were treated with sacituzumab govitecan at a dose of 10 mg/kg intravenously on days 1 and 8 of a 21-day cycle.[<a href="#cit/section_7.58">

1154658</a>

11547][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11548Level of evidence C3</a>

11549] <div class="pdq-content-list">

11550<ul id="_2494">

11551<li>

11552A response rate of 33.3% (95% CI, 24.6%&#8211;43.1%) was observed. </li>

11553<li>

11554The median duration of response was 7.7 months (95% CI, 4.9&#8211;10.8).</li>

11555<li>

11556The main toxicity was neutropenia, and four deaths occurred during treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_7.58">

1155758</a>

11558][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11559Level of evidence C3</a>

11560]</li>

11561<li>

11562The FDA granted accelerated approval to sacituzumab govitecan for patients with metastatic TNBC after at least two previous lines of therapy. </li>

11563</ul>

11564</div>

11565</li>

11566<li>

11567A phase III randomized trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02574455">

11568ASCENT</a>

11569 [NCT02574455]) confirmed the efficacy of sacituzumab govitecan in patients with metastatic TNBC that was relapsed or refractory to two or more previous chemotherapy regimens. The trial randomly assigned 468 women without brain metastases to receive either sacituzumab govitecan or the physician's choice of single-agent chemotherapy (eribulin, vinorelbine, capecitabine, or gemcitabine). The primary end point was PFS. All patients had previous taxane exposure. Patients received sacituzumab govitecan at a dose of 10 mg/kg intravenously on days 1 and 8 of each 21-day cycle.[<a href="#cit/section_7.59">

1157059</a>

11571]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11572<ul id="_2495">

11573<li>

11574 In the chemotherapy arm, 54% of patients received eribulin, 20% received vinorelbine, 13% received capecitabine, and 12% received gemcitabine.</li>

11575<li>

11576 The median PFS was 5.6 months (95% CI, 4.3&#8211;6.3; 166 events) in the sacituzumab govitecan arm and 1.7 months (95% CI, 1.5&#8211;2.6; 150 events) in the chemotherapy arm (HR<sub>

11577disease progression or death</sub>

11578, 0.41; 95% CI, 0.32&#8211;0.52; <em>

11579P</em>

11580 &lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_7.59">

1158159</a>

11582][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11583Level of evidence A1</a>

11584] </li>

11585<li>

11586 The median OS was 12.1 months (95% CI, 10.7&#8211;14.0) in the sacituzumab govitecan arm and 6.7 months (95% CI, 5.8&#8211;7.7) in the chemotherapy arm (HR<sub>

11587death</sub>

11588, 0.48; 95% CI, 0.38&#8211;0.59; <em>

11589P</em>

11590 &lt; .001).</li>

11591<li>

11592 The overall response rate was 35% in the sacituzumab govitecan arm and 5% in the chemotherapy arm.</li>

11593<li>

11594Key treatment-related adverse events of grade 3 or higher occurred more often in patients who received sacituzumab govitecan than patients who received chemotherapy: neutropenia (51% vs. 33%), leukopenia (10% vs. 5%), diarrhea (10% vs. &lt;1%), anemia (8% vs. 5%), and febrile neutropenia (6% vs. 2%).</li>

11595</ul>

11596</div>

11597</li>

11598</ol>

11599</div>

11600</section>

11601<section id="_2586">

11602<h4 id="_2586_toc">

11603PARP inhibitor therapy</h4>

11604<p id="_2587" tabindex="-1">

11605Patients with TNBC and a germline <em class="gene-name">

11606BRCA</em>

11607 mutation are eligible for PARP inhibitor therapy. For more information, see the <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_1780">

11608Germline <em class="gene-name">

11609BRCA</em>

11610-Mutated Breast Cancer</a>

11611 section.</p>

11612</section>

11613<section id="_2588">

11614<h4 id="_2588_toc">

11615Chemotherapy</h4>

11616<p id="_2589" tabindex="-1">

11617Chemotherapy may be appropriate for patients with TNBC. For more information, see the <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_1520">

11618Chemotherapy for Metastatic Breast Cancer</a>

11619 section.</p>

11620</section>

11621<section id="_2496">

11622<h4 id="_2496_toc">

11623Immunotherapy monotherapy</h4>

11624<p id="_2497" tabindex="-1">

11625To date, immunotherapy monotherapy has not demonstrated an OS benefit for patients with metastatic TNBC.</p>

11626<p id="_2498" tabindex="-1">

11627Evidence (pembrolizumab):

11628

11629</p>

11630<div class="pdq-content-list">

11631<ol id="_2499">

11632<li>

11633KEYNOTE-119 (NCT02555657) was a phase III, randomized, open-label, multicenter, international trial that enrolled patients with metastatic TNBC. Patients had received one or two previous systemic treatments for metastatic disease and had previous treatment with an anthracycline or taxane. The trial randomly assigned 622 patients to receive intravenous pembrolizumab 200 mg once every 3 weeks for 35 cycles (pembrolizumab group), or to the investigator's choice of single-drug chemotherapy (capecitabine, eribulin, gemcitabine, or vinorelbine). The primary end point was OS as assessed in each of the following groups: patients with a PD-L1 CPS of 10 or more, patients with a CPS of 1 or more, and all patients.[<a href="#cit/section_7.60">

1163460</a>

11635]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11636<ul id="_2500">

11637<li>

11638In patients with a PD-L1 CPS of 10 or more, the median OS was 12.7 months (95% CI, 9.9&#8211;16.3) in the pembrolizumab group and 11.6 months (95% CI, 8.3&#8211;13.7) in the chemotherapy group (HR, 0.78; 95% CI, 0.57&#8211;1.06; log-rank <em>

11639P</em>

11640 = .057).[<a href="#cit/section_7.60">

1164160</a>

11642][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11643Level of evidence A1</a>

11644] </li>

11645<li>

11646In patients with a CPS of 1 or more, the median OS was 10.7 months (95% CI, 9.3&#8211;12.5) in the pembrolizumab group and 10.2 months (95% CI, 7.9&#8211;12.6) in the chemotherapy group (HR, 0.86; 95% CI, 0.69&#8211;1.06; log-rank <em>

11647P</em>

11648 = .073). </li>

11649<li>

11650Among all patients, the median OS was 9.9 months (95% CI, 8.3&#8211;11.4) in the pembrolizumab group and 10.8 months (95% CI, 9.1&#8211;12.6) in the chemotherapy group (HR, 0.97; 95% CI, 0.82&#8211;1.15).</li>

11651</ul>

11652</div>

11653</li>

11654</ol>

11655</div>

11656</section>

11657</section>

11658<section id="_1491">

11659<h3 id="_1491_toc">

11660HER2/neu-Positive Breast Cancer</h3>

11661<p id="_1492" tabindex="-1">

11662Antibody therapy targeting the HER2 pathway has been used since the 1990s and has revolutionized the treatment of HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer. Several HER2-targeted agents (e.g., trastuzumab, pertuzumab, trastuzumab emtansine, lapatinib) have been approved for treatment of this disease.</p>

11663<section id="_1493">

11664<h4 id="_1493_toc">

11665Monoclonal antibody therapy</h4>

11666<section id="_1494">

11667<h5 id="_1494_toc">

11668Trastuzumab

11669</h5>

11670<p id="_1495" tabindex="-1">

11671Approximately 20% to 25% of patients with breast cancer have tumors that overexpress

11672HER2/neu.[<a href="#cit/section_7.61">

1167361</a>

11674] Trastuzumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody that

11675binds to the HER2/neu receptor.[<a href="#cit/section_7.61">

1167661</a>

11677] In patients previously treated with

11678cytotoxic chemotherapy whose tumors overexpress HER2/neu, administration of

11679trastuzumab as a single agent resulted in a response rate of 21%.[<a href="#cit/section_7.62">

1168062</a>

11681][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11682Level of evidence C3</a>

11683]

11684 </p>

11685<p id="_1496" tabindex="-1">

11686Evidence (trastuzumab):</p>

11687<div class="pdq-content-list">

11688<ol id="_1497">

11689<li>

11690In a phase III trial, patients with metastatic disease

11691were randomly assigned to receive either chemotherapy alone (doxorubicin and

11692cyclophosphamide or paclitaxel) or the same chemotherapy plus trastuzumab.[<a href="#cit/section_7.63">

1169363</a>

11694][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11695Level of evidence A1</a>

11696]

11697<div class="pdq-content-list">

11698<ul id="_1498">

11699<li>

11700Patients treated with chemotherapy plus trastuzumab had an OS advantage over those who received chemotherapy alone (25.1 months vs.

1170120.3 months, <em>

11702P</em>

11703 = .05).[<a href="#cit/section_7.63">

1170463</a>

11705][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11706Level of evidence A1</a>

11707] </li>

11708</ul>

11709</div>

11710</li>

11711</ol>

11712</div>

11713<p id="_1499" tabindex="-1">

11714Notably, when combined with

11715doxorubicin, trastuzumab is associated with significant cardiac toxicity.[<a href="#cit/section_7.64">

1171664</a>

11717]</p>

11718<p id="_1500" tabindex="-1">

11719Clinical trials comparing multiagent chemotherapy plus trastuzumab with single-agent chemotherapy have yielded conflicting results. </p>

11720<div class="pdq-content-list">

11721<ul id="_1501">

11722<li>

11723In one randomized study of patients with metastatic breast cancer treated with trastuzumab, paclitaxel, and carboplatin, patients tolerated the combination well and had a longer time to disease progression, compared with those treated with trastuzumab and paclitaxel alone.[<a href="#cit/section_7.65">

1172465</a>

11725][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11726Level of evidence B1</a>

11727]</li>

11728<li>

11729However, no difference in OS, time to disease progression, or response rate was shown in the Breast Cancer International Research Group&#8217;s phase III trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00047255">

11730BCIRG-007</a>

11731 [NCT00047255]) that compared carboplatin and docetaxel plus trastuzumab versus docetaxel plus trastuzumab as first-line chemotherapy for metastatic HER2-overexpressing breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_7.66">

1173266</a>

11733][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11734Level of evidence A1</a>

11735] </li>

11736</ul>

11737</div>

11738<p id="_1502" tabindex="-1">

11739Outside of a clinical trial, standard first-line treatment for metastatic HER2-overexpressing breast cancer is single-agent chemotherapy plus trastuzumab.</p>

11740</section>

11741<section id="_1503">

11742<h5 id="_1503_toc">

11743Pertuzumab</h5>

11744<p id="_1504" tabindex="-1">

11745Pertuzumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody that binds to a different epitope at the HER2 extracellular domain than does trastuzumab. The binding of pertuzumab to HER2 prevents dimerization with other ligand-activated HER receptors, most notably HER3. </p>

11746<p id="_1505" tabindex="-1">

11747Evidence (pertuzumab):</p>

11748<div class="pdq-content-list">

11749<ol id="_1506">

11750<li>

11751The phase III <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00567190">

11752CLEOPATRA</a>

11753 trial (NCT00567190) assessed the efficacy and safety of pertuzumab plus trastuzumab plus docetaxel versus placebo plus trastuzumab plus docetaxel, in the first-line HER2-positive metastatic setting.[<a href="#cit/section_7.67">

1175467</a>

11755,<a href="#cit/section_7.68">

1175668</a>

11757][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11758Level of evidence A1</a>

11759]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11760<ul id="_1507">

11761<li>

11762With a median follow-up of 50 months, the median OS was 40.8 months in the control group versus 56.5 months in the pertuzumab group (HR favoring pertuzumab group, 0.68; 95% CI, 0.56&#8211;0.84; <em>

11763P</em>

11764 &lt; .001). Median PFS per investigator assessment was improved by 6.3 months by the addition of pertuzumab (HR, 0.68; 95% CI, 0.58&#8211;0.80).</li>

11765<li>

11766Median OS was 56.5 months in the pertuzumab group compared with 40.8 months in the placebo group (HR, 0.68; 95% CI, 0.57&#8211;0.84; <em>

11767P</em>

11768 &lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_7.68">

1176968</a>

11770] Eight-year landmark OS rates were 37% with the addition of pertuzumab, compared with 23% in the placebo group.[<a href="#cit/section_7.69">

1177169</a>

11772] </li>

11773<li>

11774The toxicity profile was similar in both treatment groups, with no increase in cardiac toxic effects seen in the pertuzumab combination arm.</li>

11775</ul>

11776</div>

11777</li>

11778</ol>

11779</div>

11780</section>

11781<section id="_1508">

11782<h5 id="_1508_toc">

11783Trastuzumab emtansine</h5>

11784<p id="_1509" tabindex="-1">

11785Trastuzumab emtansine (T-DM1) is an antibody-drug conjugate that incorporates the HER2-targeted antitumor properties of trastuzumab with the cytotoxic activity of the microtubule-inhibitory agent DM1. T-DM1 allows specific intracellular drug delivery to HER2-overexpressing cells, potentially improving the therapeutic index and minimizing exposure of normal tissue. </p>

11786<p id="_1510" tabindex="-1">

11787Evidence (T-DM1):</p>

11788<div class="pdq-content-list">

11789<ol id="_1511">

11790<li>

11791The phase III <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00829166">

11792EMILIA</a>

11793 or TDM4370g study (NCT00829166) was a randomized open-label trial that enrolled 991 patients with HER2-overexpressing, unresectable, locally advanced or metastatic breast cancer who were previously treated with trastuzumab and a taxane.[<a href="#cit/section_7.70">

1179470</a>

11795][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11796Level of evidence A1</a>

11797] Patients were randomly assigned to receive either T-DM1 or lapatinib plus capecitabine. <div class="pdq-content-list">

11798<ul id="_1512">

11799<li>

11800Median PFS was 9.6 months with T-DM1 versus 6.4 months with lapatinib plus capecitabine (HR, 0.65; 95% CI, 0.55&#8211;0.77; <em>

11801P</em>

11802 &lt; .001).</li>

11803<li>

11804 Median OS was longer with trastuzumab emtansine versus lapatinib plus capecitabine (29.9 months vs. 25.9 months; HR, 0.75 [95% CI, 0.64&#8211;0.88]).[<a href="#cit/section_7.71">

1180571</a>

11806] </li>

11807<li>

11808The incidences of thrombocytopenia and increased serum aminotransferase levels were higher in patients who received T-DM1, whereas the incidences of diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, and palmar-plantar syndrome were higher in patients who received lapatinib plus capecitabine.</li>

11809</ul>

11810</div>

11811</li>

11812<li>

11813Further evidence of T-DM1&#8217;s activity in metastatic HER2-overexpressed breast cancer was shown in a randomized phase II study of T-DM1 versus trastuzumab plus docetaxel.[<a href="#cit/section_7.72">

1181472</a>

11815][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11816Level of evidence B1</a>

11817] This trial randomly assigned 137 women with HER2-overexpressed breast cancer in the first-line metastatic setting.<div class="pdq-content-list">

11818<ul id="_1513">

11819<li>

11820At median follow-up of 14 months, median PFS was 9.2 months with trastuzumab plus docetaxel and 14.2 months with T-DM1 (HR, 0.59; 95% CI, 0.36&#8211;0.97).</li>

11821<li>

11822Preliminary OS results were similar between treatment arms. </li>

11823<li>

11824T-DM1 had a favorable safety profile compared with trastuzumab plus docetaxel, with fewer grade 3 adverse events (46.4% vs. 90.9%), adverse events leading to treatment discontinuations (7.2% vs. 40.9%), and serious adverse events (20.3% vs. 25.8%).</li>

11825</ul>

11826</div>

11827</li>

11828<li>

11829Evidence of activity of T-DM1 in heavily pretreated patients with metastatic, HER2-overexpressed breast cancer who had received previous trastuzumab and lapatinib was shown in the randomized phase III <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01419197">

11830TH3RESA</a>

11831 study (NCT01419197) of T-DM1 versus physician&#8217;s choice of treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_7.73">

1183273</a>

11833][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11834Level of evidence A1</a>

11835] This trial randomly assigned 602 patients in a 2:1 ratio (404 patients assigned to T-DM1 and 198 patients assigned to physician&#8217;s choice) and allowed crossover to T-DM1. <div class="pdq-content-list">

11836<ul id="_1514">

11837<li>

11838At a median follow-up of 7.2 months in the T-DM1 group and 6.5 months in the physician&#8217;s-choice group, median PFS was 6.2 months in the T-DM1 group and 3.3 months in the physician&#8217;s-choice group (HR, 0.528; 95% CI, 0.422&#8211;0.661; <em>

11839P</em>

11840 &lt; .0001).</li>

11841<li>

11842 OS was significantly longer with trastuzumab emtansine versus the treatment of physician&#8217;s choice (median OS, 22.7 months vs. 15.8 months; HR, 0.68; 95% CI, 0.54&#8211;0.85; <em>

11843P</em>

11844 = .0007).[<a href="#cit/section_7.74">

1184574</a>

11846] </li>

11847</ul>

11848</div>

11849</li>

11850<li>

11851 The role of T-DM1 as first-line treatment of metastatic HER2-overexpressed breast cancer was evaluated in the phase III <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01120184">

11852MARIANNE</a>

11853 trial (NCT01120184).[<a href="#cit/section_7.75">

1185475</a>

11855][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11856Level of evidence B1</a>

11857] This study randomly assigned 1,095 patients to receive either trastuzumab plus taxane, T-DM1 plus placebo, or T-DM1 plus pertuzumab. <div class="pdq-content-list">

11858<ul id="_1779">

11859<li>

11860The median PFS for these treatment groups was 13.7 months for the trastuzumab-plus-taxane group, 14.1 months for the T-DM1-plus-placebo group, and 15.2 months for the T-DM1-plus-pertuzumab group. </li>

11861<li>

11862There was no significant difference in PFS with T-DM1 plus placebo compared with trastuzumab plus taxane (HR, 0.91; 97.5% CI, 0.73&#8211;1.13), or with T-DM1 plus pertuzumab compared with trastuzumab plus taxane (HR, 0.87; 97.5% CI, 0.69&#8211;1.08). </li>

11863<li>

11864Therefore, neither T-DM1 plus placebo nor T-DM1 plus pertuzumab showed PFS superiority over trastuzumab plus taxane. </li>

11865</ul>

11866</div>

11867</li>

11868</ol>

11869</div>

11870</section>

11871</section>

11872<section id="_2214">

11873<h4 id="_2214_toc">

11874Trastuzumab deruxtecan</h4>

11875<p id="_2215" tabindex="-1">

11876Trastuzumab deruxtecan is an antibody-drug conjugate that combines trastuzumab with a topoisomerase inhibitor. This drug has demonstrated antitumor activity in patients with advanced HER2-positive breast cancer. </p>

11877<p id="_2216" tabindex="-1">

11878Evidence (trastuzumab deruxtecan):</p>

11879<div class="pdq-content-list">

11880<ol id="_2217">

11881<li>

11882 A phase III, multicenter, open-label, randomized trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03529110">

11883DESTINY-Breast03</a>

11884 [NCT03529110]) compared the efficacy and safety of trastuzumab deruxtecan with trastuzumab emtansine. The study included 524 patients with HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer previously treated with a taxane and trastuzumab. PFS was the primary end point.[<a href="#cit/section_7.76">

1188576</a>

11886] <div class="pdq-content-list">

11887<ul id="_2534">

11888<li>

11889 At 12 months, 75.8% of patients who received trastuzumab deruxtecan were alive without disease progression, compared with 34.1% of patients who received trastuzumab emtansine (HR, 0.28; 95% CI, 0.22&#8211;0.37; <em>

11890P</em>

11891 &lt; .001). </li>

11892<li>

11893 Secondary end points were OS, overall response rate, and safety. A total of 94.1% of patients who received trastuzumab deruxtecan were alive at 12 months, compared with 85.9% of patients who received trastuzumab emtansine (HR<sub>

11894death</sub>

11895, 0.55; 95% CI, 0.36&#8211;0.86). The overall response rate was 79.7% versus 34.2%, favoring trastuzumab deruxtecan. Grade 3 to 4 drug-related adverse events occurred in 45.1% of patients who received trastuzumab deruxtecan and 38.9% of patients who received trastuzumab emtansine. Interstitial lung disease and pneumonitis occurred in 10.5% of patients who received trastuzumab deruxtecan and 1.9% of patients who received trastuzumab emtansine; none of these events were grade 4 to 5.</li>

11896<li>

11897 This trial led to a change in the standard of care for patients with HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer, such that patients with prior taxane/trastuzumab therapy proceed to trastuzumab deruxtecan, rather than trastuzumab emtansine, for second-line therapy.</li>

11898</ul>

11899</div>

11900</li>

11901</ol>

11902</div>

11903</section>

11904<section id="_2535">

11905<h4 id="_2535_toc">

11906Margetuximab</h4>

11907<p id="_2536" tabindex="-1">

11908Margetuximab is an Fc-engineered anti-HER2 immunoglobulin G monoclonal antibody that targets the same epitope as trastuzumab, with similar antiproliferative effects. Compared with trastuzumab, margetuximab was designed to increase binding affinity (<em>

11909in vitro</em>

11910) for the activating Fc-gamma receptor and decrease binding affinity for the inhibitory Fc-gamma receptor.</p>

11911<p id="_2537" tabindex="-1">

11912Evidence (margetuximab):</p>

11913<div class="pdq-content-list">

11914<ol id="_2538">

11915<li>

11916The primary PFS analysis from the phase III <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02492711">

11917SOPHIA</a>

11918 study (NCT02492711) led to the FDA approval of margetuximab with chemotherapy in patients with HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer who have received as least two previous anti-HER2 regimens, at least one of which was for metastatic disease.

11919The open-label SOPHIA trial randomly assigned 536 patients in the ITT population to receive either margetuximab or trastuzumab. Both groups received investigator's choice of chemotherapy (capecitabine, eribulin, gemcitabine, or vinorelbine). Eligible patients had disease progression after two or more previous anti-HER2 therapies and one to three lines of therapy for metastatic disease. All patients had received previous trastuzumab, all but one had received previous pertuzumab, and 91.2% had received prior ado-trastuzumab emtansine.[<a href="#cit/section_7.77">

1192077</a>

11921,<a href="#cit/section_7.78">

1192278</a>

11923][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11924Level of evidence B1</a>

11925]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11926<ul id="_2539">

11927<li>

11928 The sequential primary end points were PFS by central review followed by OS. Margetuximab improved primary PFS over trastuzumab with a 24% relative risk reduction (HR, 0.76; 95% CI, 0.59&#8211;0.98; <em>

11929P</em>

11930&#8201;=&#8201;.03) (median PFS, 5.8 months vs. 4.9 months, favoring margetuximab).</li>

11931<li>

11932 The median follow-up was 20.2 months. The median OS in the ITT population was not statistically different between the two treatment groups: 21.6 months in the margetuximab group and 21.9 months in the trastuzumab group (HR, 0.95; 95% CI, 0.77&#8211;1.17; <em>

11933P</em>

11934 = .620).</li>

11935<li>

11936 Grade 3 or greater adverse events that occurred in at least 5% of patients included decreased neutrophil count and anemia in both groups, fatigue in the margetuximab group, and febrile neutropenia in the trastuzumab group.</li>

11937</ul>

11938</div>

11939</li>

11940</ol>

11941</div>

11942</section>

11943<section id="_1515">

11944<h4 id="_1515_toc">

11945Tyrosine kinase inhibitor therapy</h4>

11946<p id="_2281" tabindex="-1">

11947 The FDA has approved several tyrosine kinase inhibitors for metastatic HER2-positive breast cancer. </p>

11948<section id="_2282">

11949<h5 id="_2282_toc">

11950Tucatinib</h5>

11951<p id="_2283" tabindex="-1">

11952Tucatinib is an oral tyrosine kinase inhibitor highly selective for the kinase domain of HER2 that minimally inhibits the epidermal growth factor receptor. A phase Ib trial in pretreated patients demonstrated activity when tucatinib was combined with trastuzumab and capecitabine.</p>

11953<p id="_2284" tabindex="-1">

11954Evidence (tucatinib):</p>

11955<div class="pdq-content-list">

11956<ol id="_2285">

11957<li>

11958The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02614794">

11959HER2CLIMB</a>

11960 trial (NCT02614794) compared trastuzumab, capecitabine, and tucatinib with trastuzumab, capecitabine, and placebo in 632 patients who had previously been treated with trastuzumab, pertuzumab, and trastuzumab emtansine. Patients had an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance status of 0 or 1. Patients with and without brain metastases were included.[<a href="#cit/section_7.79">

1196179</a>

11962][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11963Level of evidence A1</a>

11964]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11965<ul id="_2286">

11966<li>

11967 The analysis of the primary study end point, PFS, demonstrated a median PFS in the tucatinib combination group of 7.8 months and 5.6 months in the placebo combination group (HR, 0.54; 95% CI, 0.42&#8211;0.71; <em>

11968P</em>

11969 &lt; .001)</li>

11970<li>

11971 In an interim analysis conducted at the time of the PFS analysis, median OS was 21.9 months in the tucatinib combination group and 17.4 months in the placebo combination group (HR, 0.66; 95% CI, 0.50&#8211;0.88; <em>

11972P</em>

11973 = .005)</li>

11974<li>

11975 Patients with and without brain metastases benefited from the tucatinib combination.</li>

11976<li>

11977 Grade 3 adverse events including diarrhea, palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia syndrome, and elevated aminotransferase levels were more common in the tucatinib combination group but occurred in fewer than 15% of patients.</li>

11978</ul>

11979</div>

11980</li>

11981</ol>

11982</div>

11983</section>

11984<section id="_2287">

11985<h5 id="_2287_toc">

11986Neratinib</h5>

11987<p id="_2288" tabindex="-1">

11988Neratinib is an irreversible pan-HER tyrosine kinase inhibitor (HER1, HER2, and HER4), which is approved in combination with capecitabine for the treatment of patients with advanced or metastatic HER2-positive breast cancer after two or more prior anti&#8211;HER2-based regimens in the metastatic setting.</p>

11989<p id="_2289" tabindex="-1">

11990Evidence (neratinib):</p>

11991<div class="pdq-content-list">

11992<ol id="_2290">

11993<li>

11994In the phase III <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01808573">

11995NALA</a>

11996 trial (NCT01808573), neratinib and capecitabine were compared with lapatinib and capecitabine in 621 patients with HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer who received two or more HER2-directed regimens in the metastatic setting. PFS and OS were co-primary end points. Secondary end points were time to intervention for metastatic central nervous system (CNS) disease and duration of response. Patients with stable or asymptomatic CNS disease were included.[<a href="#cit/section_7.80">

1199780</a>

11998][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11999Level of evidence B1</a>

12000]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12001<ul id="_2291">

12002<li>

12003 Patients who received neratinib and capecitabine had significantly improved PFS (HR, 0.76; 95% CI, 0.63&#8211;0.93). OS between the two arms was not different. </li>

12004<li>

12005 The cumulative incidence of intervention for CNS disease was 22.8% (95% CI, 15.5%&#8211;30.9%) for patients who received neratinib versus 29.2% (95% CI, 22.5%&#8211;36.1%) for patients who received lapatinib.</li>

12006<li>

12007Duration of response was 8.5 months for patients who received neratinib versus 5.6 months for patients who received lapatinib.</li>

12008<li>

12009 Diarrhea, nausea, palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia, and vomiting were the most common adverse events, with grade 3 diarrhea occurring in 24.4% of patients who received neratinib. Antidiarrheal medications were required in the neratinib arm and used by 98.3% of those patients. </li>

12010<li>

12011 Quality-of-life scores were similar between the two groups.</li>

12012</ul>

12013</div>

12014</li>

12015</ol>

12016</div>

12017</section>

12018<section id="_2292">

12019<h5 id="_2292_toc">

12020Lapatinib</h5>

12021<p id="_2293" tabindex="-1">

12022Lapatinib is an orally administered tyrosine kinase inhibitor of both HER2/neu and the epidermal growth factor receptor. Lapatinib plus capecitabine has shown activity in patients who have HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer that progressed after treatment with trastuzumab.</p>

12023<p id="_2294" tabindex="-1">

12024Evidence (lapatinib):</p>

12025<div class="pdq-content-list">

12026<ol id="_2295">

12027<li>

12028A nonblinded randomized trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00078572">

12029GSK-EGF100151</a>

12030 [NCT00078572]) compared the combination of capecitabine and lapatinib with capecitabine alone in 324 patients with locally advanced or metastatic disease that progressed after therapies that included anthracyclines, taxanes, and trastuzumab.[<a href="#cit/section_7.81">

1203181</a>

12032][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

12033Level of evidence A1</a>

12034]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12035<ul id="_2296">

12036<li>

12037Median time-to-disease progression in the lapatinib-plus-capecitabine arm was 8.4 months compared with 4.4 months in the capecitabine-alone arm (HR, 0.49; 95% CI, 0.34&#8211;0.71; <em>

12038P</em>

12039 &lt; .001).</li>

12040<li>

12041There was no difference in OS (HR, 0.92; 95% CI, 0.58&#8211;1.46; <em>

12042P</em>

12043 = .72).[<a href="#cit/section_7.81">

1204481</a>

12045][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

12046Level of evidence A1</a>

12047]</li>

12048<li>

12049Patients on combination therapy were more likely to develop diarrhea, rash, and dyspepsia. For more information, see the <a href="/about-cancer/treatment/side-effects/constipation/GI-complications-hp-pdq#_119">

12050Diarrhea</a>

12051 section in Gastrointestinal Complications. </li>

12052<li>

12053No data are available on quality of life or treatment after disease progression. </li>

12054</ul>

12055</div>

12056</li>

12057</ol>

12058</div>

12059</section>

12060</section>

12061<section id="_2540">

12062<h4 id="_2540_toc">

12063mTOR inhibition</h4>

12064<p id="_2541" tabindex="-1">

12065Evidence of mTOR inhibitor activity in HER2-positive breast cancer was shown in the double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase III <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01007942">

12066BOLERO-3</a>

12067 trial (NCT01007942).[<a href="#cit/section_7.82">

1206882</a>

12069]</p>

12070<div class="pdq-content-list">

12071<ol id="_2542">

12072<li>

12073In the BOLERO-3 trial, 569 patients with HER2-positive trastuzumab-resistant breast cancer, who had received previous taxane therapy, were randomly assigned to receive either everolimus plus trastuzumab plus vinorelbine, or placebo plus trastuzumab plus vinorelbine.[<a href="#cit/section_7.82">

1207482</a>

12075][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

12076Level of evidence B1</a>

12077] <div class="pdq-content-list">

12078<ul id="_2543">

12079<li>

12080At median follow-up of 20.2 months, median PFS was 7.0 months in the everolimus group versus 5.78 months in the placebo group (HR, 0.78; 95% CI, 0.65&#8211;0.95; <em>

12081P</em>

12082 = .0067).</li>

12083<li>

12084Serious adverse events were reported in 117 patients (42%) in the everolimus group and 55 patients (20%) in the placebo group.</li>

12085<li>

12086Final OS outcomes for this trial have not yet been reported.</li>

12087</ul>

12088</div>

12089</li>

12090</ol>

12091</div>

12092</section>

12093</section>

12094<section id="_1780">

12095<h3 id="_1780_toc">

12096Germline <em class="gene-name">

12097BRCA</em>

12098-Mutated Breast Cancer</h3>

12099<p id="_1781" tabindex="-1">

12100For patients with metastatic breast cancer who carry a germline <em class="gene-name">

12101BRCA</em>

12102 mutation, oral PARP inhibitors have shown activity. <em class="gene-name">

12103BRCA1</em>

12104 and <em class="gene-name">

12105BRCA2</em>

12106 are tumor suppressor genes that encode proteins involved in DNA repair through the homologous recombination repair pathway. PARP plays a critical role in DNA repair and has been studied as therapy for patients with breast cancer who harbor a germline <em class="gene-name">

12107BRCA</em>

12108 mutation.</p>

12109<section id="_1849">

12110<h4 id="_1849_toc">

12111Olaparib</h4>

12112<p id="_1850" tabindex="-1">

12113Evidence (olaparib):</p>

12114<div class="pdq-content-list">

12115<ol id="_1851">

12116<li>

12117The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02000622">

12118OlympiAD</a>

12119 trial (NCT02000622) was a randomized, open-label, phase III trial that randomly assigned 302 patients, in a 2:1 ratio, to receive olaparib (300 mg bid) or standard therapy (either single-agent capecitabine, eribulin, or vinorelbine).[<a href="#cit/section_7.83">

1212083</a>

12121] All patients had received anthracycline and taxane previously in either the adjuvant or metastatic setting, and those with hormone receptor&#8211;positive disease had also received endocrine therapy previously.<div class="pdq-content-list">

12122<ul id="_1852">

12123<li>

12124Median PFS was significantly longer in the olaparib group than in the standard therapy group (7.0 months vs. 4.2. months; HR<sub>

12125disease progression or death</sub>

12126, 0.58; 95% CI, 0.43&#8211;0.80; <em>

12127P</em>

12128 &lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_7.83">

1212983</a>

12130][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

12131Level of evidence A1</a>

12132] </li>

12133<li>

12134OS did not differ between the two treatment groups with median time to death (HR<sub>

12135death</sub>

12136, 0.90; 95% CI, 0.63&#8211;1.29; <em>

12137P</em>

12138 = .57). </li>

12139<li>

12140Olaparib was less toxic than standard therapy, with a rate of grade 3 or higher adverse events of 36.6% in the olaparib group and 50.5% in the standard therapy group, with anemia, nausea, vomiting, fatigue, headache, and cough occurring more frequently with olaparib; neutropenia, palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia, and liver-function test abnormalities occurred more commonly with chemotherapy. </li>

12141<li>

12142Of note, subset analysis suggested that PFS improvement with olaparib appeared greater in the TNBC subgroup (HR, 0.43; 95% CI, 0.29&#8211;0.63) than in the hormone receptor&#8211;positive subgroup (HR, 0.82; 95% CI, 0.55&#8211;1.26).</li>

12143</ul>

12144</div>

12145</li>

12146</ol>

12147</div>

12148</section>

12149<section id="_1853">

12150<h4 id="_1853_toc">

12151 Talazoparib</h4>

12152<p id="_1854" tabindex="-1">

12153Evidence (talazoparib):</p>

12154<div class="pdq-content-list">

12155<ol id="_1855">

12156<li>

12157 The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01945775">

12158EMBRACA</a>

12159 trial (NCT01945775) was a randomized, open label, phase III trial that assigned 431 patients with a deleterious germline <em class="gene-name">

12160BRCA</em>

12161 or <em class="gene-name">

12162BRCA2</em>

12163 mutation and locally advanced or metastatic breast cancer in a 2:1 ratio to talazoparib (1 mg PO qd) or standard single-agent chemotherapy of the physician&#8217;s choice (eribulin, capecitabine, gemcitabine, or vinorelbine).[<a href="#cit/section_7.84">

1216484</a>

12165] All patients had received previous treatment with an anthracycline, taxane, or both. Patients had received three or fewer lines of cytotoxic chemotherapy for advanced breast cancer. Previous platinum therapy in the setting of early breast cancer was permitted if it was completed at least 6 months before progressive disease or if there was no objective progression while on platinum therapy in the advanced-disease setting. Hormone receptor&#8211;positive and hormone receptor&#8211;negative patients were enrolled.<div class="pdq-content-list">

12166<ul id="_1856">

12167<li>

12168 Median PFS was significantly longer in the talazoparib group than in the standard therapy group (8.6 months vs. 5.6 months; HR<sub>

12169disease progression or death</sub>

12170, 0.54; 95% CI, 0.41&#8211;0.71; <em>

12171P</em>

12172 &lt; .001). </li>

12173<li>

12174Benefits were observed in all subgroups, although CIs were wide in the subgroup of patients who had received previous platinum therapy. </li>

12175<li>

12176Median OS did not differ between the two groups (22.3 months vs. 19.5 months; HR<sub>

12177death</sub>

12178, 0.76; 95% CI, 0.55&#8211;1.06; <em>

12179P</em>

12180 = .11), although survival data are not yet mature. </li>

12181<li>

12182The primary toxicity observed with talazoparib was myelosuppression, especially anemia. </li>

12183<li>

12184Patient-reported outcome data demonstrated more favorable effects of talazoparib than standard chemotherapy on quality-of-life measures.[<a href="#cit/section_7.85">

1218585</a>

12186]</li>

12187</ul>

12188</div>

12189</li>

12190</ol>

12191</div>

12192</section>

12193</section>

12194<p id="_1785" tabindex="-1">

12195For more information, see <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq">

12196Genetics of Breast and Gynecologic Cancers</a>

12197.</p>

12198<section id="_2544">

12199<h3 id="_2544_toc">

12200High Tumor Mutational Burden</h3>

12201<p id="_2545" tabindex="-1">

12202An established biomarker for checkpoint inhibitor immunotherapy is high somatic tumor mutational burden (TMB). TMB is the number of mutations within the coding region of a tumor genome and is reported as mutations per megabase (Mut/Mb). TMB is high (&#8805;10) in approximately 5% of breast cancers.[<a href="#cit/section_7.86">

1220386</a>

12204] Highest median TMB is noted in triple-negative tumors and lowest median TMB is noted in ER-positive/HER2-negative patients. </p>

12205<section id="_2546">

12206<h4 id="_2546_toc">

12207Pembrolizumab </h4>

12208<p id="_2547" tabindex="-1">

12209Evidence (pembrolizumab):</p>

12210<div class="pdq-content-list">

12211<ol id="_2548">

12212<li>

12213 The FDA approved pembrolizumab for the treatment of metastatic solid tumors with a TMB of at least 10 Mut/Mb, based on the KEYNOTE-158 trial.[<a href="#cit/section_7.87">

1221487</a>

12215]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12216<ul id="_2549">

12217<li>

12218 <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02628067">

12219KEYNOTE-158</a>

12220 (NCT02628067) was a multicohort, open-label, nonrandomized, phase II multinational study. Patients had metastatic solid malignancies, treated with at least one previous line of therapy. Participants received pembrolizumab 200 mg intravenously every 3 weeks for up to 35 cycles. TMB was assessed in formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded tumor samples using the FoundationOne CDx assay. A total of 105 of 805 evaluable patients had high TMB (&#8805;10 Mut/Mb).</li>

12221<li>

12222 The primary outcome was objective response rate. Objective responses were observed in 30 of 102 patients (29%) in the TMB-high group and 43 of 688 patients (6%) in the non-TMB-high group. Grade 3 to 5 treatment-related adverse events occurred in 16 patients. One patient died of pneumonia that was assessed by the investigator to be treatment related.</li>

12223</ul>

12224</div>

12225</li>

12226<li>

12227 The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02693535">

12228TAPUR</a>

12229 study (NCT02693535) was a phase II basket trial done to identify the efficacy of commercially available targeted agents in patients with advanced cancers and genomic alterations known to be drug targets. TAPUR results from patients with metastatic breast cancer and high TMB have been reported.[<a href="#cit/section_7.88">

1223088</a>

12231][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

12232Level of evidence C3</a>

12233]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12234<ul id="_2550">

12235<li>

12236 The study enrolled 28 patients with metastatic breast cancer and high TMB. TMB ranged from 9 to 37 Mut/Mb. </li>

12237<li>

12238 The primary end point was disease control (objective response or stable disease for &#8805;16 weeks). Disease control was noted in 37% of patients, with objective response noted in 21% of patients.</li>

12239<li>

12240 The median PFS was 10.6 weeks and the median OS was 30.6 weeks. </li>

12241</ul>

12242</div>

12243</li>

12244</ol>

12245</div>

12246</section>

12247</section>

12248<section id="_1520">

12249<h3 id="_1520_toc">

12250Chemotherapy for Metastatic Breast Cancer</h3>

12251<p id="_1521" tabindex="-1">

12252Patients receiving hormone therapy whose tumors have progressed are candidates for

12253cytotoxic chemotherapy. There are no data suggesting that combination therapy results in an OS benefit over single-agent therapy. Patients with hormone receptor&#8211;negative tumors and

12254those with visceral metastases or symptomatic disease are also candidates for cytotoxic agents.[<a href="#cit/section_7.89">

1225589</a>

12256]

12257</p>

12258<p id="_1522" tabindex="-1">

12259Single agents that have shown activity in metastatic breast cancer include the following:</p>

12260<div class="pdq-content-list">

12261<ul id="_1523">

12262<li>

12263Anthracyclines.

12264<div class="pdq-content-list">

12265<ul id="_1524" class="list-dash">

12266<li>

12267Doxorubicin.

12268</li>

12269<li>

12270Epirubicin.

12271</li>

12272<li>

12273Liposomal doxorubicin.[<a href="#cit/section_7.90">

1227490</a>

12275-<a href="#cit/section_7.93">

1227693</a>

12277]</li>

12278<li>

12279Mitoxantrone.

12280</li>

12281</ul>

12282</div>

12283</li>

12284<li>

12285Taxanes.

12286<div class="pdq-content-list">

12287<ul id="_1525" class="list-dash">

12288<li>

12289Paclitaxel.[<a href="#cit/section_7.94">

1229094</a>

12291,<a href="#cit/section_7.95">

1229295</a>

12293]

12294</li>

12295<li>

12296Docetaxel.</li>

12297<li>

12298Albumin-bound nanoparticle paclitaxel (ABI-007 or Abraxane).[<a href="#cit/section_7.96">

1229996</a>

12300,<a href="#cit/section_7.97">

1230197</a>

12302]</li>

12303</ul>

12304</div>

12305</li>

12306<li>

12307Alkylating agents.

12308<div class="pdq-content-list">

12309<ul id="_1526" class="list-dash">

12310<li>

12311Cyclophosphamide.

12312</li>

12313</ul>

12314</div>

12315</li>

12316<li>

12317Fluoropyrimidines.

12318<div class="pdq-content-list">

12319<ul id="_1527" class="list-dash">

12320<li>

12321Capecitabine.[<a href="#cit/section_7.98">

1232298</a>

12323-<a href="#cit/section_7.100">

12324100</a>

12325]

12326</li>

12327<li>

12328Fluorouracil (5-FU).

12329</li>

12330</ul>

12331</div>

12332</li>

12333<li>

12334Antimetabolites.

12335<div class="pdq-content-list">

12336<ul id="_1528" class="list-dash">

12337<li>

12338Methotrexate.

12339</li>

12340</ul>

12341</div>

12342</li>

12343<li>

12344Vinca alkaloids.

12345<div class="pdq-content-list">

12346<ul id="_1529" class="list-dash">

12347<li>

12348Vinorelbine.[<a href="#cit/section_7.101">

12349101</a>

12350]

12351</li>

12352<li>

12353Vinblastine.

12354</li>

12355<li>

12356Vincristine.

12357</li>

12358</ul>

12359</div>

12360</li>

12361<li>

12362Platinum.

12363<div class="pdq-content-list">

12364<ul id="_1530" class="list-dash">

12365<li>

12366Carboplatin.</li>

12367<li>

12368Cisplatin.

12369</li>

12370</ul>

12371</div>

12372</li>

12373<li>

12374Other.<div class="pdq-content-list">

12375<ul id="_1531" class="list-dash">

12376<li>

12377Gemcitabine.[<a href="#cit/section_7.102">

12378102</a>

12379]</li>

12380<li>

12381Mitomycin.</li>

12382<li>

12383Eribulin mesylate.[<a href="#cit/section_7.103">

12384103</a>

12385,<a href="#cit/section_7.104">

12386104</a>

12387]</li>

12388<li>

12389Ixabepilone.[<a href="#cit/section_7.105">

12390105</a>

12391]</li>

12392</ul>

12393</div>

12394</li>

12395</ul>

12396</div>

12397<p id="_1532" tabindex="-1">

12398Combination regimens that have shown activity in metastatic breast cancer include the following:

12399</p>

12400<div class="pdq-content-list">

12401<ul id="_1533">

12402<li>

12403AC: Doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide.[<a href="#cit/section_7.106">

12404106</a>

12405]

12406</li>

12407<li>

12408EC: Epirubicin and cyclophosphamide.[<a href="#cit/section_7.107">

12409107</a>

12410]</li>

12411<li>

12412Docetaxel and doxorubicin.[<a href="#cit/section_7.108">

12413108</a>

12414]

12415</li>

12416<li>

12417CAF: Cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, and 5-FU.[<a href="#cit/section_7.109">

12418109</a>

12419]

12420</li>

12421<li>

12422CMF: Cyclophosphamide, methotrexate, and 5-FU.[<a href="#cit/section_7.110">

12423110</a>

12424]</li>

12425<li>

12426Doxorubicin and paclitaxel.[<a href="#cit/section_7.111">

12427111</a>

12428,<a href="#cit/section_7.112">

12429112</a>

12430]

12431</li>

12432<li>

12433Docetaxel and capecitabine.[<a href="#cit/section_7.113">

12434113</a>

12435]</li>

12436<li>

12437Vinorelbine and epirubicin.[<a href="#cit/section_7.114">

12438114</a>

12439]</li>

12440<li>

12441Capecitabine and ixabepilone.[<a href="#cit/section_7.115">

12442115</a>

12443]</li>

12444<li>

12445Carboplatin and gemcitabine.[<a href="#cit/section_7.116">

12446116</a>

12447]</li>

12448<li>

12449Gemcitabine and paclitaxel.[<a href="#cit/section_7.117">

12450117</a>

12451]</li>

12452</ul>

12453</div>

12454<p id="_1534" tabindex="-1">

12455There are no data suggesting that combination therapy results in an OS benefit over single-agent therapy. An ECOG intergroup study (E-1193) randomly assigned patients to receive paclitaxel and doxorubicin, given both as a combination and sequentially.[<a href="#cit/section_7.118">

12456118</a>

12457] Although response rate and time to disease progression were both better for the combination, survival was the same in both groups.[<a href="#cit/section_7.118">

12458118</a>

12459][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

12460Level of evidence A1</a>

12461]; [<a href="#cit/section_7.119">

12462119</a>

12463,<a href="#cit/section_7.120">

12464120</a>

12465] </p>

12466<p id="_1535" tabindex="-1">

12467The selection of therapy in individual patients is influenced by the following:</p>

12468<div class="pdq-content-list">

12469<ul id="_1536">

12470<li>

12471Rate of disease progression.</li>

12472<li>

12473Presence or absence of comorbid medical conditions.</li>

12474<li>

12475Physician/patient

12476preference. </li>

12477</ul>

12478</div>

12479<p id="_1537" tabindex="-1">

12480Sequential use of single agents or combinations can be used for

12481patients who relapse with metastatic disease. Combination chemotherapy is often given if there is evidence of rapidly progressive disease or visceral crisis. Combinations of chemotherapy and hormone therapy have

12482not shown an OS advantage over the sequential use of these

12483agents.[<a href="#cit/section_7.1">

124841</a>

12485,<a href="#cit/section_7.121">

12486121</a>

12487]

12488A systematic review of 17 randomized trials found that the addition of one or more chemotherapy drugs to a chemotherapy regimen in the attempt to intensify the treatment improved tumor response but had no effect on OS.[<a href="#cit/section_7.122">

12489122</a>

12490][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

12491Level of evidence A1</a>

12492]</p>

12493<p id="_1538" tabindex="-1">

12494Decisions regarding the duration of chemotherapy may consider the following: </p>

12495<div class="pdq-content-list">

12496<ul id="_1539">

12497<li>

12498Patient preference and goals of treatment.</li>

12499<li>

12500Presence of toxicities from previous therapies.</li>

12501<li>

12502Availability of alternative treatment options.</li>

12503</ul>

12504</div>

12505<p id="_1540" tabindex="-1">

12506The optimal time for patients with responsive or stable disease

12507has been studied by several groups. For patients who attain a complete

12508response to initial therapy, two randomized trials have shown a prolonged

12509DFS after immediate treatment with a different chemotherapy

12510regimen compared with observation and treatment upon relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_7.123">

12511123</a>

12512,<a href="#cit/section_7.124">

12513124</a>

12514][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

12515Level of evidence A1</a>

12516] Neither of these

12517studies, however, showed an improvement in OS for patients who received

12518immediate treatment; in one of these studies,[<a href="#cit/section_7.124">

12519124</a>

12520] survival was actually

12521worse in the group that was treated immediately. Similarly, no difference in survival

12522was noted when patients with partial response or stable disease after initial

12523therapy were randomly assigned to receive either a different chemotherapy versus

12524observation [<a href="#cit/section_7.125">

12525125</a>

12526] or a different chemotherapy regimen given at higher versus

12527lower doses.[<a href="#cit/section_7.126">

12528126</a>

12529][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

12530Level of evidence A1</a>

12531] However, 324 patients who achieved disease control were randomly assigned to maintenance chemotherapy or observation. Patients who received maintenance chemotherapy (paclitaxel and gemcitabine) had improved PFS at 6 months and improved OS. This was associated with an increased rate of adverse events.[<a href="#cit/section_7.127">

12532127</a>

12533][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

12534Level of evidence A1</a>

12535] Because there is no standard approach for treating metastatic disease, patients

12536requiring second-line regimens are good candidates for clinical trials.</p>

12537<section id="_1541">

12538<h4 id="_1541_toc">

12539Cardiac toxic effects with anthracyclines</h4>

12540<p id="_1542" tabindex="-1">

12541The potential for anthracycline-induced cardiac toxic effects should be considered in

12542the selection of chemotherapeutic regimens for selected patients.

12543Recognized risk factors for cardiac toxicity include the following:</p>

12544<div class="pdq-content-list">

12545<ul id="_1543">

12546<li>

12547Advanced age.</li>

12548<li>

12549Previous

12550chest-wall radiation therapy.</li>

12551<li>

12552Previous anthracycline exposure.</li>

12553<li>

12554Hypertension and known underlying heart disease.</li>

12555<li>

12556Diabetes.</li>

12557</ul>

12558</div>

12559<p id="_1544" tabindex="-1">

12560The cardioprotective drug dexrazoxane has

12561been shown to decrease the risk of doxorubicin-induced cardiac toxicity in

12562patients in controlled studies. The use of this agent has permitted patients

12563to receive higher cumulative doses of doxorubicin and has allowed patients with

12564cardiac risk factors to receive doxorubicin.[<a href="#cit/section_7.128">

12565128</a>

12566-<a href="#cit/section_7.131">

12567131</a>

12568] The risk of cardiac

12569toxicity may also be reduced by giving doxorubicin as a continuous

12570intravenous infusion.[<a href="#cit/section_7.132">

12571132</a>

12572]

12573The American Society of Clinical Oncology guidelines suggest the use of dexrazoxane in patients with metastatic cancer who have received a cumulative dose of doxorubicin of 300 mg/m<span class="sup">

125742</span>

12575 or more when further treatment with an anthracycline is likely to be of benefit.[<a href="#cit/section_7.133">

12576133</a>

12577] Dexrazoxane has a similar

12578protective effect in patients receiving epirubicin.[<a href="#cit/section_7.134">

12579134</a>

12580]</p>

12581</section>

12582</section>

12583<section id="_1547">

12584<h3 id="_1547_toc">

12585Surgery

12586</h3>

12587<p id="_1548" tabindex="-1">

12588Surgery may be indicated for select patients. For example, patients may need surgery if the following issues occur:</p>

12589<div class="pdq-content-list">

12590<ul id="_1549">

12591<li>

12592Fungating/painful breast lesions (mastectomy).</li>

12593<li>

12594Parenchymal brain or

12595vertebral metastases with spinal cord compression.</li>

12596<li>

12597Isolated lung metastases.</li>

12598<li>

12599Pathological (or impending) fractures.</li>

12600<li>

12601Pleural or pericardial effusions.

12602</li>

12603</ul>

12604</div>

12605<p id="_1550" tabindex="-1">

12606For more information about pleural and pericardial effusions, see <a href="/about-cancer/treatment/side-effects/cardiopulmonary-hp-pdq">

12607Cardiopulmonary Syndromes</a>

12608.</p>

12609</section>

12610<section id="_1551">

12611<h3 id="_1551_toc">

12612Radiation Therapy

12613</h3>

12614<p id="_1552" tabindex="-1">

12615Radiation therapy has a major role in the palliation of localized symptomatic

12616metastases.[<a href="#cit/section_7.135">

12617135</a>

12618] Indications for external-beam radiation therapy include the following:</p>

12619<div class="pdq-content-list">

12620<ul id="_1553">

12621<li>

12622Painful bony metastases.</li>

12623<li>

12624Unresectable central

12625nervous system metastases (i.e., brain, meninges, and spinal cord).</li>

12626<li>

12627Bronchial

12628obstruction.</li>

12629<li>

12630Fungating/painful breast or chest wall lesions.</li>

12631<li>

12632After surgery for decompression of

12633intracranial or spinal cord metastases.</li>

12634<li>

12635After fixation of pathological

12636fractures.</li>

12637</ul>

12638</div>

12639<p id="_1554" tabindex="-1">

12640Strontium chloride Sr 89, a systemically administered radionuclide, can be

12641given for palliation of diffuse bony metastases.[<a href="#cit/section_7.136">

12642136</a>

12643,<a href="#cit/section_7.137">

12644137</a>

12645]</p>

12646</section>

12647<section id="_1555">

12648<h3 id="_1555_toc">

12649Bone-Modifying Therapy</h3>

12650<p id="_1556" tabindex="-1">

12651The use of bone-modifying therapy to reduce skeletal morbidity in patients with bone

12652metastases should be considered.[<a href="#cit/section_7.138">

12653138</a>

12654] Results of randomized trials of

12655pamidronate and clodronate in patients with bony metastatic disease show

12656decreased skeletal morbidity.[<a href="#cit/section_7.139">

12657139</a>

12658-<a href="#cit/section_7.141">

12659141</a>

12660][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

12661Level of evidence A3</a>

12662] Zoledronate has been at least as effective as pamidronate.[<a href="#cit/section_7.142">

12663142</a>

12664]</p>

12665<p id="_1732" tabindex="-1">

12666The optimal dosing schedule for zoledronate was studied in <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00869206">

12667CALGB-70604</a>

12668 (Alliance; NCT00869206), which randomly assigned 1,822 patients, 855 of whom had metastatic breast cancer, to receive zoledronic acid every 4 weeks or every 12 weeks.[<a href="#cit/section_7.143">

12669143</a>

12670] Skeletal-related events were similar in both groups, with 260 patients (29.5%) in the zoledronate every-4-week dosing group and 253 patients (28.6%) in the zoledronate every-12-week dosing group experiencing at least one skeletal-related event (risk difference of -0.3% [1-sided 95% CI, -4% to infinity]; <em>

12671P</em>

12672 &lt; .001 for noninferiority).[<a href="#cit/section_7.143">

12673143</a>

12674][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

12675Level of evidence B1</a>

12676] This study suggests that the longer dosing interval of zoledronate every 12 weeks is a reasonable treatment option.</p>

12677<p id="_1557" tabindex="-1">

12678The monoclonal antibody denosumab inhibits the receptor activator of nuclear factor kappa beta ligand (RANKL). A meta-analysis of three phase III trials (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00321464">

12679NCT00321464</a>

12680, <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00321620">

12681NCT00321620</a>

12682, and <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00330759">

12683NCT00330759</a>

12684) comparing zoledronate versus denosumab for management of bone metastases suggests that denosumab is similar to zoledronate in reducing the risk of a first skeletal-related event.[<a href="#cit/section_7.144">

12685144</a>

12686]</p>

12687<p id="_1558" tabindex="-1">

12688For more information about bisphosphonates, see <a href="/about-cancer/treatment/side-effects/pain/pain-hp-pdq">

12689Cancer Pain</a>

12690.</p>

12691</section>

12692<section id="_TrialSearch_1452_sid_7">

12693<h3 id="_TrialSearch_1452_sid_7_toc">

12694Current Clinical Trials</h3>

12695<p id="_TrialSearch_1452_22" tabindex="-1">

12696Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

12697advanced clinical trial search</a>

12698 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

12699General information</a>

12700 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

12701</section>

13147[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

13148</li>

13149<li id="section_7.113">
