13277

13278 </section>

13279

13280

13281

13282 <section id="_1569">

13283

13284 <h2>

13285Treatment of Ductal Carcinoma In Situ</h2>

13286

13287 <div id="_section_1569" class="pdq-sections">

13288<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

13289<h6>

13290In This Section</h6>

13291<ul>

13292<li>

13293<a href="#_1570_toc">

13294Introduction</a>

13295</li>

13296<li>

13297<a href="#_1576_toc">

13298Treatment Options for Patients With DCIS</a>

13299</li>

13300<li>

13301<a href="#_TrialSearch_1569_sid_8_toc">

13302Current Clinical Trials</a>

13303</li>

13304</ul>

13305</nav>

13306<section id="_1570">

13307<h3 id="_1570_toc">

13308Introduction</h3>

13309<p id="_1571" tabindex="-1">

13310Ductal carcinoma <em>

13311in situ</em>

13312 (DCIS) is a noninvasive condition. DCIS can progress to invasive cancer, but estimates of the probability of this vary widely. Some reports include DCIS in breast cancer statistics. In 2023, DCIS is expected to account for about 16% of all newly diagnosed invasive plus noninvasive breast tumors in the United States.[<a href="#cit/section_8.1">

133131</a>

13314] For invasive and noninvasive tumors detected by screening, DCIS accounts for approximately 25% of all cases.</p>

13315<p id="_1572" tabindex="-1">

13316The frequency of a DCIS diagnosis has increased markedly in the United States since the use of screening mammography became widespread. Very few cases of DCIS present as a palpable mass,

13317with more than 90% being diagnosed by mammography alone.[<a href="#cit/section_8.2">

133182</a>

13319]</p>

13320<p id="_1573" tabindex="-1">

13321DCIS comprises a heterogeneous

13322group of histopathological lesions that have been classified into the following

13323subtypes, primarily because of architectural pattern:</p>

13324<div class="pdq-content-list">

13325<ul id="_1574">

13326<li>

13327Micropapillary.</li>

13328<li>

13329Papillary.</li>

13330<li>

13331Solid.</li>

13332<li>

13333Cribriform.</li>

13334<li>

13335Comedo.</li>

13336</ul>

13337</div>

13338<p id="_1575" tabindex="-1">

13339Comedo-type DCIS consists of cells that appear

13340cytologically malignant, with the presence of high-grade nuclei,

13341pleomorphism, and abundant central luminal necrosis. Comedo-type DCIS appears

13342to be more aggressive, with a higher probability of associated invasive ductal

13343carcinoma.[<a href="#cit/section_8.3">

133443</a>

13345]</p>

13346</section>

13347<section id="_1576">

13348<h3 id="_1576_toc">

13349Treatment Options for Patients With DCIS</h3>

13350<p id="_1578" tabindex="-1">

13351Treatment options for DCIS include the following:</p>

13352<div class="pdq-content-list">

13353<ol id="_1579">

13354<li>

13355 Breast-conserving surgery or mastectomy plus radiation therapy with or without tamoxifen.</li>

13356<li>

13357Total mastectomy with or without tamoxifen.

13358</li>

13359</ol>

13360</div>

13361<p id="_1580" tabindex="-1">

13362In the past, the customary treatment for DCIS was mastectomy.[<a href="#cit/section_8.4">

133634</a>

13364] The

13365rationale for mastectomy included a 30% incidence of multicentric disease, a

1336640% prevalence of residual tumor at mastectomy after wide excision alone,

13367and a 25% to 50% incidence of in-breast recurrence after limited surgery for

13368palpable tumor, with 50% of those recurrences being invasive carcinoma.[<a href="#cit/section_8.4">

133694</a>

13370,<a href="#cit/section_8.5">

133715</a>

13372]

13373The combined local and distant recurrence rate after mastectomy is 1% to

133742%.

13375No randomized comparisons of mastectomy versus breast-conserving surgery plus breast radiation therapy are available.</p>

13376<p id="_1581" tabindex="-1">

13377Because breast-conserving surgery combined with breast radiation therapy is successful for invasive carcinoma, this conservative approach was extended to DCIS. To determine whether breast-conserving surgery plus radiation therapy was a reasonable approach to the management of DCIS, the National Surgical Adjuvant Breast and Bowel Project (NSABP) and the European Organisation for Research and Treatment of Cancer (EORTC) have each completed prospective randomized trials in which women with localized DCIS and negative surgical margins after excisional biopsy were randomly assigned to receive either breast radiation therapy (50 Gy) or no further therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_8.6">

133786</a>

13379-<a href="#cit/section_8.9">

133809</a>

13381]

13382</p>

13383<p id="_1582" tabindex="-1">

13384Evidence (breast-conserving surgery plus radiation therapy to the breast):</p>

13385<div class="pdq-content-list">

13386<ol id="_1583">

13387<li>

13388Of the 818 women enrolled in the NSABP-B-17 trial, 80% were diagnosed by mammography, and 70% of the patients' lesions were 1 cm or smaller. Results were reported at the 12-year actuarial follow-up interval.[<a href="#cit/section_8.7">

133897</a>

13390]; [<a href="#cit/section_8.9">

133919</a>

13392][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

13393Level of evidence B1</a>

13394]<div class="pdq-content-list">

13395<ul id="_1584">

13396<li>

13397The overall rate of in-breast tumor recurrence was reduced from 31.7% to 15.7% when radiation therapy was delivered (<em>

13398P</em>

13399 &lt; .005). </li>

13400<li>

13401 Radiation therapy reduced the occurrence of invasive cancer from 16.8% to 7.7% (<em>

13402P</em>

13403 = .001) and recurrent DCIS from 14.6% to 8.0% (<em>

13404P</em>

13405 = .001).</li>

13406<li>

13407Nine pathological features were evaluated for their ability to predict for in-breast recurrence, but only comedo necrosis was a significant predictor for recurrence.</li>

13408</ul>

13409</div>

13410</li>

13411<li>

13412Similarly, of the 1,010 patients enrolled in the EORTC-10853 trial, mammography detected lesions in 71% of the women. Results were reported at a median follow-up of 10.5 years.[<a href="#cit/section_8.9">

134139</a>

13414][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

13415Level of evidence B1</a>

13416]<div class="pdq-content-list">

13417<ul id="_1585">

13418<li>

13419The overall rate of in-breast tumor recurrence was reduced from 26% to 15% (<em>

13420P</em>

13421 &lt; .001), with a similarly effective reduction of invasive recurrence rates (13% to 8%, <em>

13422P</em>

13423 = .065) and noninvasive recurrence rates (14% to 7%, <em>

13424P</em>

13425 = .001).</li>

13426<li>

13427In this analysis, parameters associated with an increased risk of in-breast recurrence included age 40 years or younger, palpable disease, intermediate or poorly differentiated DCIS, cribriform or solid growth pattern, and indeterminate margins. Elsewhere, margins of less than 1 mm have been associated with an unacceptable local recurrence rate, even with radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_8.10">

1342810</a>

13429]</li>

13430</ul>

13431</div>

13432<p id="_1586" tabindex="-1">

13433In both studies, the effect of radiation therapy was consistent across all assessed risk factors.</p>

13434</li>

13435<li>

13436The benefit of administering radiation therapy has been confirmed in a systematic review of four randomized trials (hazard ratio [HR], 0.49; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.41&#8211;0.58; <em>

13437P</em>

13438 &lt; .00001). In this study, the number needed to treat with radiation therapy was nine women to prevent one ipsilateral breast recurrence.[<a href="#cit/section_8.11">

1343911</a>

13440]</li>

13441<li>

13442A large national

13443clinical trial by the Radiation Therapy Oncology Group (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003857">

13444RTOG-9804</a>

13445 [NCT00003857]) comparing breast-conserving surgery and tamoxifen with or

13446without radiation therapy was closed because of poor accrual (636 of planned 1,790 patients accrued). Patients with good-risk DCIS (defined as mammographically detected low- or intermediate-grade DCIS, measuring less than 2.5 cm with margins of 3 mm or more) were enrolled.[<a href="#cit/section_8.12">

1344712</a>

13448]<div class="pdq-content-list">

13449<ul id="_1587">

13450<li>

13451With a median follow-up of 7 years, the ipsilateral local failure rate was low with observation (6.7%; 95% CI, 3.2%&#8211;9.6%) but was decreased significantly with the addition of radiation therapy (0.9%; 95% CI, 0.0%&#8211;2.2%).[<a href="#cit/section_8.12">

1345212</a>

13453]</li>

13454</ul>

13455</div>

13456</li>

13457</ol>

13458</div>

13459<p id="_1588" tabindex="-1">

13460The results of the NSABP-B-17 and EORTC-10853 trials plus two others were included in a meta-analysis that demonstrated reductions in all ipsilateral breast events (HR, 0.49; 95% CI, 0.41&#8211;0.58; <em>

13461P</em>

13462 &lt; .00001), ipsilateral invasive recurrence (HR, 0.50; 95% CI, 0.32&#8211;0.76; <em>

13463P</em>

13464 = .001), and ipsilateral DCIS recurrence (HR, 0.61; 95% CI, 0.39&#8211;0.95; <em>

13465P</em>

13466 = .03).[<a href="#cit/section_8.13">

1346713</a>

13468][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

13469Level of evidence B1</a>

13470] After 10 years of follow-up, there was, however, no significant effect on breast cancer mortality, mortality from causes other than breast cancer, or all-cause mortality.[<a href="#cit/section_8.11">

1347111</a>

13472] </p>

13473<p id="_1589" tabindex="-1">

13474To identify a favorable group of patients for whom postoperative radiation therapy could be omitted, several pathological

13475staging systems have been developed and tested retrospectively, but consensus

13476recommendations have not been achieved.[<a href="#cit/section_8.14">

1347714</a>

13478-<a href="#cit/section_8.17">

1347917</a>

13480]</p>

13481<p id="_1590" tabindex="-1">

13482The Van Nuys Prognostic Index is one pathological staging system that combines three predictors of local recurrence (i.e., tumor size, margin

13483width, and pathological classification). It was used to retrospectively analyze 333

13484patients treated with either excision alone or excision and radiation

13485therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_8.17">

1348617</a>

13487] Using this prognostic index, patients with favorable lesions who

13488received surgical excision alone had a low recurrence rate (i.e., 2%, with a median

13489follow-up of 79 months). A subsequent analysis of these data was performed to

13490determine the influence of margin width on local control.[<a href="#cit/section_8.18">

1349118</a>

13492] Patients whose

13493excised lesions had margin widths of 10 mm or more in every direction

13494had an extremely low probability of local recurrence with surgery alone (4%,

13495with a mean follow-up of 8 years). </p>

13496<p id="_1591" tabindex="-1">

13497Both reviews

13498are retrospective, noncontrolled, and subject to substantial selection

13499bias. In contrast, the prospective NSABP trial did not identify any subset of patients who did not benefit from the addition of radiation

13500therapy to breast-conserving surgery in the management of DCIS.[<a href="#cit/section_8.3">

135013</a>

13502,<a href="#cit/section_8.6">

135036</a>

13504,<a href="#cit/section_8.13">

1350513</a>

13506,<a href="#cit/section_8.19">

1350719</a>

13508]

13509</p>

13510<p id="_1592" tabindex="-1">

13511To determine whether tamoxifen adds to the efficacy of local

13512therapy in the management of DCIS, the NSABP performed a double-blind

13513prospective trial (NSABP-B-24).</p>

13514<p id="_1593" tabindex="-1">

13515Evidence (adjuvant endocrine therapy):</p>

13516<div class="pdq-content-list">

13517<ol id="_1594">

13518<li>

13519In NSABP-B-24, 1,804 women were randomly assigned to receive

13520breast-conserving surgery, radiation therapy (50 Gy), and placebo or breast-conserving surgery, radiation

13521therapy, and tamoxifen (20 mg qd for 5 years).[<a href="#cit/section_8.20">

1352220</a>

13523] Positive or unknown

13524surgical margins were present in 23% of patients. Approximately 80% of the

13525lesions measured 1 cm or smaller, and more than 80% were detected

13526mammographically. Breast cancer events were defined as the presence of new

13527ipsilateral disease, contralateral disease, or metastases. <div class="pdq-content-list">

13528<ul id="_1595">

13529<li>

13530Women in the

13531tamoxifen group had fewer breast cancer events at 5 years than did those treated with a

13532placebo (8.2% vs. 13.4%; <em>

13533P</em>

13534 = .009).[<a href="#cit/section_8.20">

1353520</a>

13536][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

13537Level of evidence B1</a>

13538]</li>

13539<li>

13540With

13541tamoxifen, ipsilateral invasive breast cancer decreased from 4.2% to 2.1% at 5

13542years (<em>

13543P</em>

13544 = .03).</li>

13545<li>

13546Tamoxifen also decreased the incidence of contralateral breast

13547neoplasms (invasive and noninvasive) from 0.8% per year to 0.4% per year

13548(<em>

13549P</em>

13550 = .01).</li>

13551<li>

13552The benefit of tamoxifen extended to patients with positive or

13553uncertain margins.[<a href="#cit/section_8.21">

1355421</a>

13555] For more information, see <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-prevention-pdq">

13556Breast Cancer Prevention</a>

13557.

13558</li>

13559<li>

13560No survival advantage was demonstrated for the use of tamoxifen.</li>

13561</ul>

13562</div>

13563</li>

13564<li>

13565In NSABP-B-24, 1,804 women were randomly assigned to receive

13566breast-conserving surgery, radiation therapy (50 Gy), and placebo or breast-conserving surgery, radiation

13567therapy, and tamoxifen (20 mg qd for 5 y).[<a href="#cit/section_8.20">

1356820</a>

13569] Positive or unknown

13570surgical margins were present in 23% of patients. Approximately 80% of the

13571lesions measured 1 cm or smaller, and more than 80% were detected

13572mammographically. Breast cancer events were defined as the presence of new

13573ipsilateral disease, contralateral disease, or metastases. <div class="pdq-content-list">

13574<ul id="_1596">

13575<li>

13576No survival advantage was demonstrated for the use of tamoxifen.</li>

13577</ul>

13578</div>

13579</li>

13580<li>

13581In the NSABP-B35 double-blind study, 3,104 postmenopausal women with DCIS who were treated with breast-conserving surgery were randomly assigned to receive either adjuvant tamoxifen or anastrozole, in addition to adjuvant radiation therapy.<div class="pdq-content-list">

13582<ul id="_1597">

13583<li>

13584The use of anastrozole was associated with significantly fewer breast cancer events (HR, 0.73; <em>

13585P</em>

13586 = .023) but no improvement in survival.[<a href="#cit/section_8.22">

1358722</a>

13588][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

13589Level of evidence B1</a>

13590]</li>

13591</ul>

13592</div>

13593</li>

13594<li>

13595 The Second International Breast Cancer Intervention Study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00078832">

13596IBIS II DCIS</a>

13597 [NCT00078832]) enrolled 2,980 postmenopausal women in a double-blind comparison of tamoxifen with anastrozole as adjuvant therapy. All of the women had breast-conserving surgery, and 71% of them had radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_8.23">

1359823</a>

13599]<div class="pdq-content-list">

13600<ul id="_1729">

13601<li>

13602No difference in the rate of breast cancer recurrence in favor of anastrozole was found (HR, 0.89; 95% CI, 0.64&#8211;1.23; <em>

13603P</em>

13604 = .49), and there was no difference in survival.</li>

13605</ul>

13606</div>

13607</li>

13608</ol>

13609</div>

13610<p id="_1598" tabindex="-1">

13611The decision to prescribe endocrine therapy after a diagnosis of DCIS often involves a discussion with the patient about the potential benefits and side effects of each agent. </p>

13612</section>

13613<section id="_TrialSearch_1569_sid_8">

13614<h3 id="_TrialSearch_1569_sid_8_toc">

13615Current Clinical Trials</h3>

13616<p id="_TrialSearch_1569_22" tabindex="-1">

13617Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

13618advanced clinical trial search</a>

13619 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

13620General information</a>

13621 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

13622</section>

13680[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

13681</li>

13682<li id="section_8.15">

13683Fisher ER, Costantino J, Fisher B, et al.: Response - blunting the counterpoint. Cancer 75 (6): 1223-1227, 1995.</li>

13684<li id="section_8.16">

13685Holland R, Peterse JL, Millis RR, et al.: Ductal carcinoma in situ: a proposal for a new classification. Semin Diagn Pathol 11 (3): 167-80, 1994.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7831528&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7831528&amp;dopt=Abstract">

13686[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

13687</li>

13688<li id="section_8.17">

13689Silverstein MJ, Lagios MD, Craig PH, et al.: A prognostic index for ductal carcinoma in situ of the breast. Cancer 77 (11): 2267-74, 1996.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=8635094&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=8635094&amp;dopt=Abstract">

13690[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

13691</li>

13692<li id="section_8.18">

13693Silverstein MJ, Lagios MD, Groshen S, et al.: The influence of margin width on local control of ductal carcinoma in situ of the breast. N Engl J Med 340 (19): 1455-61, 1999.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10320383&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10320383&amp;dopt=Abstract">

13694[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

13695</li>

13696<li id="section_8.19">

13697Goodwin A, Parker S, Ghersi D, et al.: Post-operative radiotherapy for ductal carcinoma in situ of the breast--a systematic review of the randomised trials. Breast 18 (3): 143-9, 2009.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19447038&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19447038&amp;dopt=Abstract">

13698[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

13699</li>

13700<li id="section_8.20">

13701Fisher B, Dignam J, Wolmark N, et al.: Tamoxifen in treatment of intraductal breast cancer: National Surgical Adjuvant Breast and Bowel Project B-24 randomised controlled trial. Lancet 353 (9169): 1993-2000, 1999.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10376613&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10376613&amp;dopt=Abstract">

13702[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

13703</li>

13704<li id="section_8.21">

13705Houghton J, George WD, Cuzick J, et al.: Radiotherapy and tamoxifen in women with completely excised ductal carcinoma in situ of the breast in the UK, Australia, and New Zealand: randomised controlled trial. Lancet 362 (9378): 95-102, 2003.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12867108&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12867108&amp;dopt=Abstract">

13706[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

13707</li>

13708<li id="section_8.22">

13709Margolese RG, Cecchini RS, Julian TB, et al.: Anastrozole versus tamoxifen in postmenopausal women with ductal carcinoma in situ undergoing lumpectomy plus radiotherapy (NSABP B-35): a randomised, double-blind, phase 3 clinical trial. Lancet 387 (10021): 849-56, 2016.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26686957&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26686957&amp;dopt=Abstract">

13710[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

13711</li>

13712<li id="section_8.23">

13713Forbes JF, Sestak I, Howell A, et al.: Anastrozole versus tamoxifen for the prevention of locoregional and contralateral breast cancer in postmenopausal women with locally excised ductal carcinoma in situ (IBIS-II DCIS): a double-blind, randomised controlled trial. Lancet 387 (10021): 866-73, 2016.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26686313&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26686313&amp;dopt=Abstract">

13714[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

13715</li>

13716</ol>

13717</div>

13718

13719 </section>

13720

13721

13722

13723 <section id="_298">

13724

13725 <h2>

13726Changes to This Summary (07/28/2023)</h2>

13727

13728 <div id="_section_298" class="pdq-sections">

13729<p id="_1105" tabindex="-1">

13730The PDQ cancer information summaries are reviewed regularly and updated as

13731new information becomes available. This section describes the latest

13732changes made to this summary as of the date above.</p>

13733<p id="_2591" tabindex="-1">

13734<strong>

13735<a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_1">

13736General Information About Breast Cancer</a>

13737</strong>

13738</p>

13739<p id="_2592" tabindex="-1">

13740Revised <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_629">

13741text</a>

13742 to state that age-specific risk estimates are available to help design screening strategies for women with and without a family history of breast cancer. The most commonly used tools include the Gail model and the IBIS/Tyrer-Cuzick model, version 8 (cited Tyrer et al. as reference 22). </p>

13743<p id="_2593" tabindex="-1">

13744Revised <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_931">

13745text</a>

13746 to state that male <em class="gene-name">

13747BRCA1</em>

13748 and <em class="gene-name">

13749BRCA2</em>

13750 mutation carriers have an increased risk of breast cancer.</p>

13751<p id="_2594" tabindex="-1">

13752Revised <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_940">

13753text</a>

13754 to state that at 10 years after diagnosis, the risk of a primary breast cancer in the contralateral breast ranges from 3% to 5%, although endocrine therapy decreases that risk (cited Giannakeas et al. as reference 53).</p>

13755<p id="_2595" tabindex="-1">

13756Added Wolff et al. and Allison et al. as <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_1685">

13757references 65 and 66</a>

13758, respectively.</p>

13759<p id="_2596" tabindex="-1">

13760Added <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_1687">

13761text</a>

13762 about Oncotype DX recurrence score risk groups and related chemotherapy indications.</p>

13763<p id="_2597" tabindex="-1">

13764Added Sparano et al. as <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_1825">

13765reference 80</a>

13766.</p>

13767<p id="_2598" tabindex="-1">

13768<strong>

13769<a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_27">

13770Stage Information for Breast Cancer</a>

13771</strong>

13772</p>

13773<p id="_2599" tabindex="-1">

13774Added Wolff et al. as <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_1985">

13775reference 2</a>

13776.</p>

13777<p id="_2600" tabindex="-1">

13778<strong>

13779<a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_1452">

13780Treatment of Metastatic Breast Cancer</a>

13781</strong>

13782</p>

13783<p id="_2601" tabindex="-1">

13784Revised <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_1456">

13785text</a>

13786 to state that cytological or histological documentation of metastatic disease, with testing of estrogen receptor, progesterone receptor, and HER2 status, should be obtained at the time of metastatic presentation, if possible. If not possible, it is appropriate to consider liquid biopsy.</p>

13787<p id="_2602" tabindex="-1">

13788The <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_1458">

13789Hormone Receptor&#8211;Positive HER2-Negative Breast Cancer</a>

13790 subsection was renamed from Hormone Receptor&#8211;Positive Breast Cancer.</p>

13791<p id="_2603" tabindex="-1">

13792Added <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_2575">

13793Elacestrant</a>

13794 as a new subsection.</p>

13795<p id="_2604" tabindex="-1">

13796Added <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_2583">

13797Poly (ADP-ribose) polymerase (PARP) inhibitor therapy</a>

13798 as a new subsection.</p>

13799<p id="_2605" tabindex="-1">

13800Added <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_2584">

13801Chemotherapy</a>

13802 as a new subsection.</p>

13803<p id="_2606" tabindex="-1">

13804Added <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_2586">

13805PARP inhibitor therapy</a>

13806 as a new subsection.</p>

13807<p id="_2607" tabindex="-1">

13808Added <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_2588">

13809Chemotherapy</a>

13810 as a new subsection.</p>

13811<p id="_disclaimerHP_3" tabindex="-1">

13812This summary is written and maintained by the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/adult-treatment" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/adult-treatment">

13813PDQ Adult Treatment Editorial Board</a>

13814, which is

13815editorially independent of NCI. The summary reflects an independent review of

13816the literature and does not represent a policy statement of NCI or NIH. More

13817information about summary policies and the role of the PDQ Editorial Boards in

13818maintaining the PDQ summaries can be found on the <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq#_AboutThis_1">

13819About This PDQ Summary</a>

13820 and <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq">

13821PDQ&#174; Cancer Information for Health Professionals</a>

13822 pages.

13823</p>

13824</div>

13825

13826 </section>

13827

13828

13829

13830 <section id="_AboutThis_1">

13831

13832 <h2>

13833About This PDQ Summary</h2>

13834

13835 <div id="_section_AboutThis_1" class="pdq-sections">

13836<section id="_AboutThis_2">

13837<h3 id="_AboutThis_2_toc">

13838Purpose of This Summary</h3>

13839<p id="_AboutThis_3" tabindex="-1">

13840This PDQ cancer information summary for health professionals provides comprehensive, peer-reviewed, evidence-based information about the treatment of adult breast cancer. It is intended as a resource to inform and assist clinicians in the care of their patients. It does not provide formal guidelines or recommendations for making health care decisions.</p>

13841</section>

13842<section id="_AboutThis_4">

13843<h3 id="_AboutThis_4_toc">

13844Reviewers and Updates</h3>

13845<p id="_AboutThis_5" tabindex="-1">

13846This summary is reviewed regularly and updated as necessary by the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/adult-treatment" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/adult-treatment">

13847PDQ Adult Treatment Editorial Board</a>

13848, which is editorially independent of the National Cancer Institute (NCI). The summary reflects an independent review of the literature and does not represent a policy statement of NCI or the National Institutes of Health (NIH).</p>

13849<p id="_AboutThis_22" tabindex="-1">

13850 Board members review recently published articles each month to determine whether an article should:</p>

13851<div class="pdq-content-list">

13852<ul id="_AboutThis_6">

13853<li>

13854be discussed at a meeting,</li>

13855<li>

13856be cited with text, or</li>

13857<li>

13858replace or update an existing article that is already cited.</li>

13859</ul>

13860</div>

13861<p id="_AboutThis_7" tabindex="-1">

13862Changes to the summaries are made through a consensus process in which Board members evaluate the strength of the evidence in the published articles and determine how the article should be included in the summary.</p>

13863<p id="" tabindex="-1">

13864The lead reviewers for Breast Cancer Treatment are:</p>

13865<div class="pdq-content-list">

13866<ul id="">

13867<li>

13868Fumiko Chino, MD</li>

13869<li>

13870Tarek Hijal, MD (McGill University Health Centre)</li>

13871<li>

13872Joseph L. Pater, MD (NCIC-Clinical Trials Group)</li>

13873<li>

13874Carol Tweed, MD (Maryland Oncology Hematology)</li>

13875</ul>

13876</div>

13877<p id="_AboutThis_9" tabindex="-1">

13878Any comments or questions about the summary content should be submitted to Cancer.gov through the NCI website's <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us" title="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us">

13879Email Us</a>

13880. Do not contact the individual Board Members with questions or comments about the summaries. Board members will not respond to individual inquiries.</p>

13881</section>

13882<section id="_AboutThis_10">

13883<h3 id="_AboutThis_10_toc">

13884Levels of Evidence</h3>

13885<p id="_AboutThis_11" tabindex="-1">

13886Some of the reference citations in this summary are accompanied by a level-of-evidence designation. These designations are intended to help readers assess the strength of the evidence supporting the use of specific interventions or approaches. The PDQ Adult Treatment Editorial Board uses a <a href="/publications/pdq/levels-evidence/treatment">

13887formal evidence ranking system</a>

13888 in developing its level-of-evidence designations.</p>

13889</section>

13890<section id="_AboutThis_12">

13891<h3 id="_AboutThis_12_toc">

13892Permission to Use This Summary</h3>

13893<p id="_AboutThis_13" tabindex="-1">

13894PDQ is a registered trademark. Although the content of PDQ documents can be used freely as text, it cannot be identified as an NCI PDQ cancer information summary unless it is presented in its entirety and is regularly updated. However, an author would be permitted to write a sentence such as &#8220;NCI&#8217;s PDQ cancer information summary about breast cancer prevention states the risks succinctly: [include excerpt from the summary].&#8221;</p>

13895<p id="_AboutThis_14" tabindex="-1">

13896The preferred citation for this PDQ summary is:</p>

13897<p id="_AboutThis_15" tabindex="-1">

13898PDQ&#174; Adult Treatment Editorial Board. PDQ Breast Cancer Treatment. Bethesda, MD: National Cancer Institute. Updated &lt;MM/DD/YYYY&gt;. Available at: <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq" title="https://www.cancer.gov/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq">

13899https://www.cancer.gov/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq</a>

13900. Accessed &lt;MM/DD/YYYY&gt;. [PMID: 26389406]</p>

13901<p id="_AboutThis_16" tabindex="-1">

13902Images in this summary are used with permission of the author(s), artist, and/or publisher for use within the PDQ summaries only. Permission to use images outside the context of PDQ information must be obtained from the owner(s) and cannot be granted by the National Cancer Institute. Information about using the illustrations in this summary, along with many other cancer-related images, is available in <a href="https://visualsonline.cancer.gov/" title="https://visualsonline.cancer.gov/">

13903Visuals Online</a>

13904, a collection of over 2,000 scientific images.

13905

13906</p>

13907</section>

13908<section id="_AboutThis_17">

13909<h3 id="_AboutThis_17_toc">

13910Disclaimer</h3>

13911<p id="_AboutThis_18" tabindex="-1">

13912Based on the strength of the available evidence, treatment options may be described as either &#8220;standard&#8221; or &#8220;under clinical evaluation.&#8221; These classifications should not be used as a basis for insurance reimbursement determinations. More information on insurance coverage is available on Cancer.gov on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/managing-care" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/managing-care">

13913Managing Cancer Care</a>

13914 page.</p>

13915</section>

13916<section id="_AboutThis_20">

13917<h3 id="_AboutThis_20_toc">

13918Contact Us</h3>

13919<p id="_AboutThis_21" tabindex="-1">

13920More information about contacting us or receiving help with the Cancer.gov website can be found on our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/contact" title="https://www.cancer.gov/contact">

13921Contact Us for Help</a>

13922 page. Questions can also be submitted to Cancer.gov through the website&#8217;s <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us" title="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us">

13923Email Us</a>

13924.</p>

13925</section>

13926</div>
